site_title: Hundreds evacuated from Paris metro after power cut
summary: Hundreds of commuters were evacuated from Paris' metro after a power failure halted driverless trains on Line 1 in the Marais district. The incident occurred at 8.10pm on Tuesday, with passengers forced to walk in the dark to the nearest station. Five people were treated for heat exhaustion due to being stuck underground during a weeks-long heatwave. The power outage disrupted traffic until 11.30pm, with at least eight trains needing to be evacuated. This incident follows a similar electrical fire at a train station in Paris over the weekend.

site_title: Kuala Lumpur International Airport air traffic controllers may face action over MH370
summary: Malaysia's transport minister, Anthony Loke, has announced the formation of an internal committee to decide on action against air traffic controllers at Kuala Lumpur International Airport who were on duty when MH370 went missing in 2014. The committee will review the report's finding of a breach of standard operating procedures. The move comes after the resignation of CAAM chairman Datuk Seri Azharuddin Abdul Rahman, who took responsibility for the incident. The committee's recommendations will be considered before any action is taken against the air traffic controllers.

site_title: Anna Wintour to stay 'indefinitely' at Vogue, quashing exit rumours
summary: Anna Wintour, editor-in-chief of Vogue magazine, has agreed to stay in her role "indefinitely", according to Conde Nast CEO Bob Sauerberg. The decision refutes rumors that she was on her way out after 30 years, with Sauerberg praising her talent and influence. Wintour, 68, has held the position since 1988 and was also promoted to artistic director of Conde Nast in 2013. The move puts an end to speculation about her exit, which had reached a fever pitch in the fashion industry.

site_title: New wineries in Napa Valley
summary: New wineries in Napa Valley are shaking up the traditional tourist experience with unique spaces and innovative offerings. The Prisoner Wine Co, Ashes and Diamonds, Tank Garage Winery, and Promontory are among the newcomers, each with its own distinct design and features. These wineries, such as The Prisoner's industrial aesthetic and Tank Garage's Art Deco design, are encouraging guests to linger and make memories. With tastings ranging from $25 to $200 per person, these wineries are invigorating the Napa Valley tourist destination with a new energy, offering a fresh experience for wine enthusiasts.

site_title: Sterling stalls before expected BoE hike this week
summary: The British pound slid below $1.31 on Tuesday as investors prepare for a Bank of England policy meeting, where a near-90% chance of a 25 basis point rate hike is expected. Sterling has recovered from a 10-month low in July amid Brexit worries. Investors are watching for comments from the central bank's Monetary Policy Committee on whether this rate hike is the start of a series of tightening moves or a one-off hike before the UK leaves the EU next March.

site_title: Australia: Shares inch down as financials drop, but miners support; New Zealand slips
summary: Australian shares slipped 6.5 points to 6,273.7 at the start of August, with financial stocks following US banks lower. However, mining and materials stocks supported the market, driven by a rally in commodity prices after a Bloomberg report suggested a potential resolution of US-China trade differences.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Great Eastern, Mary Chia, TEE International, SBI Offshore
summary: Great Eastern Holdings reported a net profit of S$237.6 million for its second quarter, a 3% increase from last year. Mary Chia Holdings narrowed its net loss to S$5.8 million for the financial year ended March 31. TEE International secured S$65 million worth of engineering contracts, boosting its order book to S$280 million. SBI Offshore expects to report a loss for the first half-year due to challenging economic conditions.

site_title: Singapore's financial sector to undergo IMF's comprehensive assessment for 3rd time
summary: Singapore's financial sector will undergo its third International Monetary Fund (IMF) Financial Sector Assessment Programme (FSAP) assessment, evaluating the sector's resilience, regulatory framework, and crisis management capabilities. The assessment, scheduled for November 2018 and February 2019, will assess Singapore's financial system under hypothetical macroeconomic scenarios and its ability to manage and resolve financial crises. The MAS has deemed Singapore a systemically important financial centre, requiring a FSAP assessment every five years, following previous assessments in 2013 and no previous years. The report is expected to be published in the second half of 2019.

site_title: Great Eastern posts Q2 profit of S$237.6m, up 3%
summary: Great Eastern Holdings (GE), the insurance arm of OCBC Bank, reported a Q2 net profit of S$237.6m, a 3% increase from the same period last year. Earnings per share rose 4.1% to 51 Singapore cents. Higher profit from shareholders' fund investments and growth in Singapore and Malaysia drove the increase, despite lower operating and non-operating profit from the insurance business.

images.alt_text: Great Eastern Holdings (GE), the insurance arm of OCBC Bank, on Wednesday posted a net profit of S$237.6 million for its second quarter ended June 30, up 3 per cent from S$231.6 million a year ago.

site_title: Employees taking up work-related training rose to 48% in 2017: Chee Hong Tat
summary: Singapore's training participation rate has increased for a second consecutive year, reaching 48% in 2017, according to Senior Minister of State Chee Hong Tat. The SkillsFuture Series modular courses have seen over 11,000 participants, while the SkillsFuture for Digital Workplace programme has benefited over 12,000 Singaporeans since its launch in October 2017. The SkillsFuture Fellowships and SkillsFuture Employer Awards recognize individuals and employers for their commitment to skills mastery, with 27 companies and 29 individuals receiving awards this year.

site_title: OCBC to upskill over 330 retail bank wealth advisers
summary: OCBC Bank has partnered with the Wealth Management Institute (WMI) of Nanyang Technological University to upskill over 330 retail bank wealth advisers with private-banking skills. The OCBC-WMI Wealth Advisory programme aims to develop skills in investment advisory principles, portfolio construction, and ethics, offering two certifications: OCBC-WMI Premier Wealth Certification and OCBC-WMI Premier Private Client Wealth Certification. The programme, launched in August 2017, is designed to provide graduates with regulatory certifications, enabling them to start work immediately.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start Wednesday with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose on Wednesday, with the Hang Seng Index increasing 0.35% to 28,684.41, following a positive lead from Wall Street. The US and China were reported to be in talks to resolve their trade row, boosting traders' sentiments. Meanwhile, the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also gained, with the latter adding 0.19% to 1,579.41. The rally came ahead of the US GDP data and amid uncertainty over the US-China trade talks.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Wednesday; STI up 0.1% to 3,324.6
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.1% to 3,324.6 on Wednesday, driven by gains in ComfortDelGro and Hongkong Land Holdings. A total of 68.6 million shares worth S$103.4 million changed hands, with 57 gainers outnumbering 42 losers. The Straits Times Index is on track for a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: 'Rare strata office portfolio' in Tanjong Pagar's GB Building up for sale
summary: A rare strata office portfolio in Tanjong Pagar's GB Building has been launched for sale via an expression of interest exercise. The portfolio includes a podium block and four office floors with guide prices of S$3,200 psf and S$2,000 psf, respectively. The combined strata floor area is approximately 39,590 sq ft and is zoned "commercial," exempting buyers from additional stamp duties. The sale is expected to draw interest from investors, with recent transactions in the area reaching up to S$3,053 psf.

site_title: Update: 97 injured as Mexican plane crashes at airport in hail storm
summary: A Aeromexico flight crashed on takeoff during a hail storm in northern Mexico, injuring 97 people. The Embraer 190 aircraft was carrying 99 passengers and crew when it broke apart, engulfing the plane in flames. No deaths were reported, but two people suffered serious injuries. The cause of the accident is under investigation by Brazilian aircraft manufacturer Embraer, which dispatched a team to the scene.

site_title: TT International proposes new scheme of arrangement
summary: TT International is proposing a new scheme of arrangement to include both existing creditors and other creditors, funded by up to S$45 million from the disposal of shares in its subsidiaries. The company has been under its existing scheme for nearly eight years, with total indebtedness of approximately S$437 million. The new scheme will be sent to creditors, with the existing scheme creditors owed S$268.2 million and other creditors owed S$193.8 million.

site_title: Former Trump campaign chief goes on trial for bank and tax fraud
summary: Former Trump campaign chief Paul Manafort is on trial for bank and tax fraud charges related to his lobbying activities on behalf of the former Russian-backed government of Ukraine. Manafort, 69, is not on trial for his time as Trump's campaign chairman, but rather for alleged crimes including hiding millions of dollars and failing to report foreign bank accounts. Prosecutors accuse Manafort of lying and plan to produce nearly three dozen witnesses during the three-week trial, which may be a "pardon strategy" as Manafort has refused to strike a deal and faces separate charges brought by Mueller.

site_title: Australian hotelier Meriton fined A$3m for manipulating TripAdvisor reviews
summary: Australian hotel operator Meriton was fined A$3 million for manipulating TripAdvisor reviews by withholding contact details of unhappy guests and falsifying reviews. The practice occurred at 13 properties between 2014 and 2015, creating an "unduly favourable impression" on the website. The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission initially sought a A$20 million penalty, citing the case as a strong message to businesses that manipulating reviews will not be tolerated. Meriton stopped the practice after billionaire Harry Triguboff found out.

site_title: US dollar pressures yuan, Australian dollar on tariff reports
summary: The US dollar rose against the yuan and other currencies due to reports that the White House would propose higher tariffs on $200 billion in Chinese imports, potentially sparking new trade tensions. The dollar also strengthened against the yen, with analysts expecting Japanese bond yields to remain low and the yen to test its 2018 low. Solid US economic growth is expected to keep the Federal Reserve on track for further interest rate hikes, while the Bank of England is set to hold a policy meeting with a near-90% chance of a rate hike.

site_title: STI closes higher despite tech retreat
summary: The Straits Times Index rose 0.38% to 3,319.85 on Tuesday, driven by gains from Jardine Matheson, Jardine Strategic, DBS Group Holdings, and OCBC Bank. Tech stocks, including AEM, Hi-P, UMS, and Creative, declined, with AEM falling 16.39% due to a weak US tech earnings season. Analysts attribute the tech sector's decline to investors adjusting growth expectations due to trade tensions, central bank reductions, and company result misses.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks climb on Wall Street gains; won holds steady
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose 0.36% to 2,303.61 points on Wednesday, driven by overnight gains on Wall Street. However, uncertainty over US-China trade tensions, with the US planning 25% tariffs on $200 billion in Chinese imports, weighed on the won, which remained flat. The US dollar rose 4.89% against the won this year, and the KOSPI index is down 7.0% so far this year.

site_title: China's Huawei passes Apple in smartphone share for first time
summary: China's Huawei surpassed Apple to claim the No 2 position in smartphone shipments in the second quarter, according to market research firm IDC. Huawei shipped 54.2 million phones, a 41% increase from the previous year, and accounted for 16% of the market. This marks the first time Huawei has passed Apple in smartphone share. Chinese smartphone makers, including Xiaomi and Oppo, also secured top spots in the market.

site_title: US considering higher 25% tariffs on US$200b in Chinese imports
summary: The US is considering raising its planned 10% tariffs to 25% on $200 billion in Chinese imports, targeting $34 billion of goods already subject to 25% tariffs and another $16 billion of imports. The move aims to pressure Beijing into making concessions ahead of public hearings on the tariffs, scheduled to end on August 30. President Donald Trump directed the US Trade Representative to increase the tariff rate to 25%, sending a signal of increased pressure on China.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks rally on brisk earnings
summary: Tokyo stocks rallied 0.86% on Wednesday, driven by positive earnings from major firms and the Bank of Japan's tweaks to its monetary policy, which confirmed no interest rate hike. The Nikkei 225 index rose 192.98 points to 22,746.70, while the Topix index gained 16.47 points to 1,769.76. Several Japanese firms reported strong profits, including Sony, Nintendo, and Honda, while the yen's weakness against the dollar also boosted Japanese exporters.

site_title: Malaysia shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 5.10 points to 1,779.15 on Wednesday, with 55.76 million lots traded at RM21.91 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 116 to 55. No other relevant information is available in the provided article.

site_title: Y Ventures launches ICO to raise US$50m
summary: Y Ventures Group, a Singapore-listed e-commerce player, has launched an initial coin offering (ICO) to raise US$50 million through its subsidiary Luminore 8. The ICO involves the new AORA Coin cryptocurrency, which will be used in e-commerce transactions. The AORA Coin will be sold at 20 US cents apiece and the funds will be used for the development of its AORA e-commerce platform. The offering began on July 31 and ends on November 30, with the platform expected to be launched in the first half of 2019.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Ascendas Reit's Q1 FY2019 revenue grew 1.5% year-on-year due to acquisitions and positive rental reversion. The trust announced a new asset enhancement initiative worth S$3.9 million and acquired Ferntree Gully Drive in Melbourne and 1-7 Goss Drive in Brisbane. Its balance sheet remains robust with gearing of 35.7% and a weighted all-in cost of debt of 2.9%. CapitaLand Retail China Trust acquired Rock Square in Guangzhou, indicating a growth path, with a revised target price of S$1.70.

site_title: Richard Li's FWD said to be mulling Singapore dual-class IPO
summary: Richard Li's FWD Group is considering a Singapore dual-class IPO, with discussions underway about listing on the Singapore Exchange, amid preparations for an initial public offering. The Hong Kong-based insurer, which manages over $26.6 billion in assets, is weighing its options as it moves forward with an IPO that could take place in the next couple of years. A Singapore listing would be a significant coup for the exchange, which has been seeking to attract big-ticket listings from overseas.

site_title: PSA International makes first foray into Canada with acquisition of port facility stake
summary: PSA International has acquired 60% of Ashcroft Terminal, a port facility in Western Canada, marking its first foray into the country. The terminal, located 300km east of Vancouver, is a major privately owned industrial property with Class 1 railroad lines, allowing for efficient transportation of goods across Canada and to North American markets. The acquisition will enable PSA to partner with shipping lines, rail operators, and trucking companies to implement a more efficient supply chain solution for major exporters in Western Canada.

site_title: Apple quarterly profit leaps, nears US$1t value
summary: Apple has reported a 30% jump in quarterly profit to $11.5 billion, beating market expectations. The tech giant's revenue rose 17% to $53.3 billion, driven by sales of pricier iPhones, online services, and wearable devices. Despite selling fewer iPhones than analysts projected, Apple's shares rose 2.85% to $195.79 in after-hours trade, bringing the company closer to a trillion-dollar market value. The company is expected to unveil new iPhone models in the fall, and its recent share buyback program may help propel it past the one-trillion-dollar mark.

site_title: China to join naval war games in Australia's north despite strained ties
summary: China will join 26 other nations in naval war games off Australia's north coast in August, participating in passage exercises, inter-ship communications, and sea-training manoeuvres, but not live-fire drills. This marks a thawing in relations between the two nations, with analysts suggesting China's involvement could indicate a new willingness to engage. The drills come amid strained ties, following Australia's laws to thwart Chinese influence and China's assertiveness in the South China Sea. The event will run to mid-September and involve 27 nations, including the US, which expelled China from military training around Hawaii.

images.alt_text: China's navy will join 26 other nations in military exercises off Australia's north coast this month, but not live-fire drills, Australia's defence minister said on Wednesday at a time of strained ties between the two nations.

site_title: HSR meeting between Malaysia and Singapore likely in August
summary: Malaysia and Singapore are likely to meet in August to discuss the Singapore-Kuala Lumpur High Speed Rail (HSR) project. Malaysia's Economic Affairs Minister Mohamed Azmin Ali clarified that the July deadline given by Singapore was a suggestion, and the meeting will be rescheduled. The project, originally set to be completed in 2026, is being delayed due to Malaysia's national debt and estimated costs of RM110 billion. Discussions on a deferment of the project are ongoing, with Singapore having spent S$250 million on the project.

site_title: Facebook uncovers political influence campaign ahead of US midterm elections
summary: Facebook has shut down over 30 fake pages and accounts involved in a coordinated campaign ahead of the US midterm elections, with hints of Russian involvement. Despite finding connections to the Saint Petersburg-based Internet Research Agency, Facebook cannot identify the source. The investigation is ongoing, and the company is sharing information with intelligence officials and notifying affected users. This marks another effort by Facebook to combat disinformation and influence campaigns, following similar actions taken in 2016.

images.alt_text: Facebook said Tuesday it shut down more than 30 fake pages and accounts involved in what appeared to be a "coordinated" effort to stoke hot-button social issues ahead of November midterm US elections, but cannot identify the source despite hints Russia was involved.

site_title: Boustead inks contract to develop new production and warehouse facility
summary: Boustead Development Partnership (BDP) has secured a long-term contract to develop an integrated production and warehouse facility in Singapore for Amcor Flexibles Singapore. The 6,922 sqm facility is expected to be completed by 3Q 2019 and will be leased on a long-term basis. The deal raises Boustead Projects' order book backlog to S$242 million, increasing its leasehold portfolio to 20 properties with 275,000 sqm expected GFA.

site_title: Google building third data centre in Singapore with added investment of US$350m
summary: Google is building its third data centre in Singapore, adding US$350 million to its US$850 million investment in the country. The new facility, expected to come online in 2020, will be built on a plot of land the size of the first two centres and will leverage machine learning to reduce energy usage. The company is actively hiring for various roles, with over 1,000 employees currently in Singapore. The expansion aims to meet growing demand for Google's Google Cloud Platform offerings in the region, where over 330 million people have gone online in the past three years.

images.alt_text: Artist's impression of Google's third data centre in Singapore at its Jurong West site.

site_title: Sony jumps to decade high as PlayStation drives higher forecast
summary: Sony Corp. jumped to its highest in over a decade after raising its outlook for the current fiscal year due to robust sales of the PlayStation 4 console and profits from its stake in Spotify Technology SA. The company raised its full-year net income and revenue forecasts, beating operating profit estimates for the June quarter. PlayStation revenue climbed 36% during the quarter, and operating profit nearly quintupled, driven by strong sales of new games like God of War and Detroit: Become Human.

site_title: HNA chief's death delaying Hong Kong Airlines share sale: source
summary: HNA Group Co's co-chairman Wang Jian's sudden death in France has halted discussions between Hong Kong Airlines and potential investors to sell up to 30% of its stock for $250-300 million. The sale, which could help the airline expand and compete with giants like Cathay Pacific, was delayed due to Mr. Wang's involvement in negotiations. Representatives from Hong Kong Airlines and HNA declined to comment, and talks are expected to resume. The airline is also planning an initial public offering in Hong Kong next year. HNA still owns a 27% stake in the airline.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Wednesday afternoon at 3,324.01, up 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading at 3,324.01, up 0.1% on Wednesday afternoon, with 751.3 million shares changing hands. Losers edged out gainers 180-147, as Ezion, AEM, and Genting Singapore were among the most actively traded counters. The Straits Times Index advanced 4.16 points, marking its fifth consecutive day of gains ahead of GDP data.

site_title: As China's troubles pile up, Xi hears a rare rebuke
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping faced a rare rebuke from a prominent academic, Professor Xu Zhangrun, who urged lawmakers to reverse the abolition of term limits on his power. The criticism comes amid economic headwinds, a vaccine scandal, and trade battles with the US, emboldening critics who question Xi's sweeping control. Xu's essay, which criticized Xi's hardline policies and revival of communist orthodoxies, has spread through Chinese social media, sparking a nascent pushback against Xi's absolute power.

site_title: Police find shark stolen from Texas aquarium in stroller
summary: US police have recovered a small shark stolen from a Texas aquarium in a baby carriage. The shark was taken from the San Antonio Aquarium two days ago in a daring heist by three thieves. Surveillance footage shows the thieves removing the shark from its display, placing it in a bucket, and then smuggling it out in a stroller. One of the alleged culprits was arrested and the shark was recovered early Monday.

site_title: Australian shares dip as profits taken before earnings reports; NZ down too
summary: Australian shares fell 0.1% on Wednesday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index closing at 6,275.7, as financial stocks took profits ahead of earnings reports. Mining stocks, including BHP and Rio Tinto, rose 0.6% on higher commodity prices. New Zealand's benchmark index also fell 0.7% on Wednesday, with telecommunications firm Spark New Zealand and Fisher & Paykel Healthcare Corporation Ltd weighing heavily. The earnings season for Australian banks is expected to be a key event, with investors taking profits before results are announced.

site_title: US Federal Reserve meets as key inflation measure holds steady
summary: The US Federal Reserve is expected to hold off on the next interest rate increase for another six weeks, following a steady inflation rate of 2.2% in June. The Fed's preferred price index, the Personal Consumption Expenditures (PCE) index, held steady at 1.9% for the third month in a row, above the Fed's 2% target. Despite President Donald Trump's criticism of higher interest rates, the Fed is expected to continue gradually raising benchmark lending rates to keep the economy on an even keel.

site_title: China's Baidu tops profit estimates on ad sales growth
summary: Baidu, China's largest internet search giant, has topped profit estimates for the second quarter with a 25% rise in online ad sales. Revenue from its newsfeed product grew 25% to 21.1 billion yuan, while net income rose to 6.4 billion yuan. The company's US-listed shares rose 3% to $254 in after-hours trading, exceeding expectations of 16.46 yuan per ADS. Despite competitors facing regulatory issues, Baidu has managed to escape censorship concerns.

site_title: HDT becomes Singapore's 7th taxi operator
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) announced that HDT Singapore Taxi has been granted a full-fledged taxi service operator licence in Singapore, becoming the country's 7th taxi operator. HDT's proposal and past performance records demonstrated its business viability, and the company will need to convert its existing electric taxis and increase its fleet size to at least 800 electric taxis within four years. With this addition, HDT will join ComfortDelGro, CityCab, SMRT Taxis, Trans-Cab, Premier Taxis, and Prime Taxi as the new taxi operator in Singapore.

site_title: Hot stock: AEM Holdings dives 25% as CGS-CIMB downgrades stock, slashes target
summary: AEM Holdings' shares plummeted 24.5% to 75 Singapore cents on Wednesday, down from 100 cents, after CGS-CIMB downgraded the stock to "reduce" due to poor earnings visibility for 2019. The downgrade followed a 19.5 Singapore cent drop on Tuesday, wiping out nearly 40% of the stock's market value in two days. Analyst Willian Tng cited concerns over Intel's order outlook and potential replacement of AEM's equipment. The stock's target price was slashed to S$0.69 from S$1.78 previously.

site_title: Broker's take: OCBC upgrades Cache Logistics Trust to 'buy'; DBS maintains 'hold'
summary: OCBC Investment Research has upgraded Cache Logistics Trust from "hold" to "buy", citing a sector upturn in 2019. The brokerage expects the industrial sector to bottom out at the end of 2018 or early-2019, and believes Cache is reasonably positioned for the recovery. OCBC's fair value estimate is S$0.81, while DBS Group Research maintains a "hold" rating with a 12-month target price of S$0.88. Cache's Q2 results showed a 7.7% increase in gross revenue, but a 6.3% decline in distributable income due to a larger unit base.

site_title: Former 1MDB executive, lawyer targeted in Swiss probe
summary: A Swiss criminal probe targets two former 1MDB executives, L and T, suspected of authorizing a $700 million illicit transfer and facing charges of bribery, misconduct, and money laundering. The probe follows years of stalled investigations into the multibillion-dollar scandal, which has implicated Goldman Sachs and other financial institutions. Swiss prosecutors are also investigating four other individuals, including executives at PetroSaudi and former officials from the United Arab Emirates, in connection with the scandal.

site_title: Yen set for biggest drop in nearly 3 weeks
summary: The Japanese yen is expected to record its biggest daily loss in nearly three weeks due to the Bank of Japan's decision to keep interest rates at record low levels. The central bank also adopted a forward guidance model to strengthen its commitment to its massive policy stimulus, reassuring market participants and encouraging investors to buy higher-yielding currencies like the Australian dollar. This move is seen as a signal that the Bank of Japan will continue to support the economy with low interest rates.

site_title: US to urge pressure against North Korea at Asia talks
summary: The US will press for continued sanctions pressure against North Korea at a security forum in Singapore, amid concerns that Pyongyang has made little progress towards denuclearization. US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo will meet with North Korean counterpart Ri Yong Ho, but analysts expect little new progress. The US will also focus on regional issues, including rival claims in the South China Sea and China's growing presence there. Despite concerns, ministers at the forum are expected to strike an upbeat note about the Trump-Kim agreement, encouraging further talks towards lasting peace and stability.

site_title: Eurozone growth slows as trade tensions persist
summary: Eurozone economic growth slowed to 0.3% in the second quarter, below the 0.4% in the previous quarter, due to rising trade tensions fueled by US President Donald Trump's "America First" policies. Major institutions, including the European Central Bank and International Monetary Fund, warn that protectionism may hurt Europe's economy. Analysts expect growth to regain some pace in the second half of the year, but caution remains due to ongoing uncertainty and the threat of escalating trade tensions.

site_title: Ryanair boss cancels bonus after flights grounded
summary: Ryanair boss Michael O'Leary waived his annual bonus of up to a million euros due to the 2017 flight cancellations crisis, which resulted in 20,000 cancellations and a labour dispute. The crisis led to negotiations with trade unions and agreements were later reached in some countries. O'Leary was also given 1.25 million euros worth of shares. The move comes after the company faced an unprecedented strike by cabin crew in four European countries and warned that strikes could force it to suppress flights and jobs.

site_title: Samsung Electronics profit dips as sales of smartphones fall
summary: Samsung Electronics reported a slight dip in second-quarter net profit due to declining smartphone sales, despite robust demand for premium TVs and memory chips. The company attributed the decline to a sluggish market for premium mobile phones and stiff competition. However, the operating profit increased by almost 6% due to the strong demand for memory chips.

images.alt_text: A sluggish market for premium mobile phones and stiff competition contributed to a decline in Samsung's smartphone shipments and revenue, denting demand for its flagship Galaxy device.

site_title: Hedge funds' big short could be fool's gold
summary: Hedge funds have taken an extreme bearish stance on gold, with a net short of 27,156 contracts, equivalent to 2.7 million troy ounces. This is the largest bearish position since 2006, but gold prices remain stable due to a rising dollar and strong US economy. Despite some market indicators suggesting a potential turn, the extreme positioning may indicate a potential correction. The Federal Reserve's decision to keep rates on hold may also support gold prices.

images.alt_text: An asset that trades in large measure off the strength of the greenback shouldn't be treated as a one-way bet.

site_title: Roxy-Pacific Q2 net profit falls 56.7% to S$6.4m
summary: Roxy-Pacific Holdings' second-quarter net profit plummeted 56.7% to S$6.4 million due to lower revenue recognition from completed projects. Revenue fell 52.5% to S$37 million, primarily affected by the absence of revenue recognition from Trilive and Jade Residences. Earnings per share dropped to 0.49 Singapore cents, down from 1.12 cents last year. The group will continue to take a prudent stance on land acquisitions, with a focus on freehold sites, and declared an interim dividend of 0.195 Singapore cents per share.

site_title: The madman theory won't work in trade talks
summary: The US government's attempts to improve its trading relationship with China have been hindered by inconsistent negotiations. Despite hopes of a restart in talks, the US may raise proposed tariffs on Chinese imports from 10% to 25% within days. This unpredictability is seen as a major obstacle to effective diplomacy, as it undermines the global effort to reduce conflict by increasing predictability in foreign relations. The "madman theory" employed by past US administrations, including Richard Nixon, has been criticized for its failure to achieve meaningful progress and instead creating unnecessary tension.

site_title: 'Psycho' kangaroo leaps to freedom after rescue from Australian home
summary: A kangaroo named Norman Bates, rescued from a Melbourne home after smashing through a window, escaped from a shelter on Tuesday. The 2.2-meter wall at the Five Freedoms Animal Rescue shelter was breached, allowing the kangaroo to jump into a nearby forest. Norman Bates had been rescued from a home where he had crashed into, leaving blood splattered on walls, reminiscent of the thriller Psycho. Rescuers had named him after the character due to the distressing scene.

images.alt_text: A distressed kangaroo leapt over a 2.2 metre wall at a shelter on Tuesday and escaped into a forest after having been rescued from a home he had crashed into in the southern Australian city of Melbourne two days earlier.

site_title: P&G hikes some prices as weak grooming shaves profits
summary: Procter & Gamble (P&G) announced price hikes on toilet paper, diapers, and other staples due to weak profits in the shaving business. The company reported a 14.6% fall in net income in its fiscal fourth-quarter, citing higher commodity prices and increased shipping costs. P&G plans to roll back promotions and consider shrinking package sizes to offset higher costs. Despite this, CEO David Taylor believes retailers will work with P&G to boost prices as long as costs are justified or products improve.

site_title: Why companies need citizen data scientists
summary: Companies face a critical shortage of data talent, with qualified employees unable to keep up with the exponential growth of data. Artificial Intelligence solutions can untangle data, but lack human intuition. To address this, companies are adopting the "citizen data scientist" (CDS) approach, where internal subject-matter experts and line-of-business leaders leverage basic data-science expertise to deliver actionable insights. CDS can be filled by employees with relevant skills, such as industrial engineers, and supported with tools and training. By recognizing the value of CDS and creating a supportive environment, companies can unlock significant returns on investment and stay competitive in the data-driven market.

site_title: Japan Airlines Q1 profit rises on overseas flight gains; ANA sinks on oil costs
summary: Japan Airlines (JAL) reported a modest rise in quarterly operating profit to 24.9 billion yen, driven by strong international flight demand and cost control. In contrast, ANA Holdings Inc's profits fell 21% due to higher oil prices and rising costs. JAL filled 81.3% of international seats, while ANA's margins were squeezed by these costs, forcing it to cancel flights and incur lost revenues. Both airlines maintain their full-year forecasts, with JAL expecting a 4% drop in operating profit and ANA forecasting a roughly flat year.

images.alt_text: JAL says that it has filled a record 81.3 per cent of seats on its international flights during the quarter ending on June 30, due to strong inbound demand and stable outbound demand.

site_title: Europe: BP, trade war optimism help FTSE ends July on a high
summary: Europe's FTSE 100 closed up 0.6% on Tuesday, ending a six-week high and posting a 1.5% monthly gain for July. Hopes of a US-China trade war averted lifted global markets, with BP's strong quarterly profit growth and increased oil prices boosting the index. Diversified miners Fresnillo and Anglo American rose 4.2% and 3.3%, respectively, while Centrica fell 2.6%. The FTSE is up 1.5% for July, driven by optimism and strong energy sector results.

site_title: Brexit: Are markets underestimating the chances of the UK not leaving?
summary: The UK's Brexit negotiations are uncertain, with markets underestimating the chances of the UK not leaving the EU. The proposed "soft Brexit" compromise, similar to the Norway model, has sparked uncertainty, with EU negotiators criticizing it as "magical thinking." The delayed version of soft Brexit avoids making key institutional arrangements, but this scenario also leaves the UK in the unknown. A hard Brexit is also a possibility, with the UK relying on WTO tariff rules to support its view of minimal trade impact. The likelihood of a negotiated "soft" settlement is low, and the mechanics of the decision-making process become increasingly important.

site_title: Tech firms can win bank charters as US bank regulator unveils new policies
summary: The US Office of the Comptroller of the Currency (OCC) has announced new policies allowing tech firms to compete directly with traditional lenders by seeking special-purposes charters. The change aims to promote economic growth, modernization, and innovation in the financial system. Tech firms, including marketplace lenders and payments companies, can apply for charters that would bypass state-by-state regulation, but must meet regulatory hurdles. The OCC will supervise fintech applicants similarly to national banks, with an initial "heightened supervision" period of 120 days.

site_title: Double down or stealth taper: BOJ watchers debate Kuroda's move
summary: Bank of Japan (BOJ) governor Haruhiko Kuroda made adjustments to two pillars of its policy, allowing the 10-year yield to rise to 0.2% from 0.1% and cutting the amount of bank reserves subject to negative rates. Analysts debate whether this marks a "stealth taper" or strengthened long-running stimulus. Some, including former BOJ official Masamichi Adachi, see it as a commitment to easing, while others, like Takahide Kiuchi, label it a "stealth rate hike" and a step towards normalizing policy.

site_title: Credit Suisse charged with rigging foreign exchange rates
summary: Credit Suisse has been charged by European Union antitrust regulators with rigging foreign exchange rates. The Swiss bank received a notification from the European Commission on July 26, alleging anticompetitive practices in its foreign exchange trading business. The charges are part of a broader EU investigation into several banks suspected of manipulating foreign exchange rates. The European Commission typically imposes fines up to 10% of a company's global turnover for such charges. Credit Suisse has not commented on the specifics of the allegations.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Wednesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Wednesday, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.36% and the Topix index gaining 0.49%. Investors were boosted by positive earnings from major firms and minor changes to the Bank of Japan's monetary policy.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The ticker symbol and logo for Goldman Sachs is displayed on a screen on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, U.S., December 18, 2018. REUTERS/Brendan McDermid/File Photo##########cfgoldman##########

site_title: Ascott opens 2 Citadines serviced residences in Vietnam, including its biggest property globally
summary: Ascott Limited, a serviced residence arm of CapitaLand, has opened its largest property globally, Citadines Blue Cove Danang in Vietnam, and its fifth property in Ho Chi Minh City, Citadines Regency Saigon. The 548-unit Citadines Blue Cove Danang is Vietnam's largest serviced residence, while the 229-unit Citadines Regency Saigon is in the prime business and residential area of Ho Chi Minh City. Ascott plans to open over 2,000 units across nine properties in the next three years, aiming to reach 7,000 units in Vietnam by 2020.

images.alt_text: The 548-unit Citadines Blue Cove Danang, which is also Vietnam's largest serviced residence, is located by the Han River in the Son Tra peninsular.

Citadines Blue Cove Danang offers a mix of studio, one-bedroom, two-bedroom and three-bedroom apartments, most of which overlook Danang Bay. It also boasts the world's highest and largest 24k gold-plated infinity pool.

site_title: India hopes to see more Japanese and S Korean steel makers' investments
summary: India has requested Japanese and South Korean steel makers to invest in new plants to produce high-grade automotive steel, amid rising demand for the metal. The country aims to become the world's third-largest carmaker by 2020. Indian Steel Secretary Aruna Sharma said the government will encourage companies to start greenfield projects, and is also discussing with US officials to ease quotas and tariff restrictions on Indian steel exports. The Indian authorities will also express concerns over falling steel exports to the European Union in September.

images.alt_text: Dr Sharma says India is talking to US officials about easing quotas and tariff curbs on Indian steel imports. India will also continue pressing its case against US steel and aluminium tariffs at the WTO.

site_title: New North Korea missiles unlikely to doom talks, experts say
summary: North Korea is reportedly developing at least one or two liquid-fueled intercontinental ballistic missiles, but experts say this development does not necessarily doom US-North Korea talks. Despite President Trump's declaration that Pyongyang was "no longer a Nuclear Threat," North Korean leader Kim Jong Un did not commit to ending nuclear and missile production. Experts say North Korea is following through on Kim's January speech, which included a promise to mass-produce missiles and nuclear weapons. The US and North Korea are still in the early stages of negotiations, with no binding deal yet.

site_title: Trump to propose 25% tariff on US$200b of Chinese imports: source
summary: The Trump administration plans to propose a 25% tariff on $200 billion of Chinese imports, up from the initial 10% proposed in July, according to a source. The tariffs would affect thousands of goods, including food, chemicals, and consumer products. The move is expected to escalate the trade dispute between the US and China, which has already led to retaliatory tariffs and concerns about global growth. The US Trade Representative's Office declined to comment on the proposed tariff rate increase.

site_title: June bank lending makes fastest gains since November
summary: Singapore bank lending surged in June, with a 5.9% increase from the same period last year, driven by a 7% rise in business lending, the fastest pace since November. Business lending rose to S$408 billion, with significant growth in the construction sector and consumer lending. OCBC's head of treasury research and strategy, Selena Ling, attributed the strong loan momentum to financial institutions, business services, and general commerce, but noted that mortgage loans may see a temporary boost due to property cooling measures.

site_title: South Korea's July exports return to growth, but outlook murky
summary: South Korea's exports rebounded 6.2% in July to $51.9 billion, driven by brisk sales of memory chips. However, economists warn that the US-China trade conflict may crimp exports to China, the country's largest trading partner. The trade tension's impact is expected to worsen in the coming months, with some analysts predicting the end of the global chip boom. Despite this, exports to the US and Japan increased, and shipments to China surged 27.3% in July.

site_title: JTC Food Hub to offer rental equipment to manufacturers
summary: Singapore's JTC Food Hub @ Senoko will offer rental equipment to food manufacturers, including spray dryers and microwave-assisted sterilizers, on a pay-per-use basis by the end of next year. This move aims to reduce the financial burden of purchasing processing equipment, which can cost millions of dollars, allowing manufacturers to test new products in small batches.

site_title: UN chief to discuss North Korea in Japan
summary: UN Secretary General Antonio Guterres will meet with Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe on August 8 to discuss the North Korea crisis. The meeting comes amid reports that Abe is seeking a meeting with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un in Vladivostok in September. This meeting is seen as a potential step towards easing tensions between Japan and North Korea.

site_title: Surbana Jurong, NTU launch lab to find solutions to urban challenges
summary: Surbana Jurong and Nanyang Technological University (NTU) have launched a joint laboratory, the SJ-NTU Corporate Lab, to develop next-generation solutions to urban challenges. The $61 million facility will focus on digitalisation, sustainable urban solutions, and the future of industry, with the goal of training 70 research staff and PhD students over five years. Minister for National Development Lawrence Wong emphasized the importance of long-term investments in research and development, citing Singapore's $19 billion R&D budget in 2016-2021, and called for private investment to complement government spending.

site_title: China Aviation Oil Q2 profit up 14.4%
summary: China Aviation Oil (CAO) reported a 14.4% increase in net profit to US$29.3 million in its second-quarter results, driven by higher gross profit and stable profit contributions from associates. Revenue jumped 57.9% to US$5.8 billion, mainly due to higher oil prices and increased trading volume. Earnings per share rose to 3.4 US cents, up from 2.98 US cents in the previous period.

site_title: Burger on wheels: Saudis try once 'lowly' jobs as economy bites
summary: In Saudi Arabia, a shift is underway as the economy bites, with the government trimming oil-funded subsidies and tackling sluggish economic growth and high unemployment. Saudis are increasingly taking on blue-collar jobs, such as cooking and cleaning, traditionally held by foreign workers. This trend is driven by economic necessity, with many Saudis embracing manual labor jobs, including working at gas stations and as Uber drivers. The "Saudisation" policy, aimed at replacing foreigners with Saudi workers, has been met with challenges, including high attrition rates and a displaced sense of entitlement among more expensive Saudi workers.

site_title: MAS slaps 5-year prohibition order on former CIMB VP for insider trading
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has issued a 5-year prohibition order against former CIMB VP Alan Tay Yeow Kee for insider trading. Tay arranged for someone to buy shares of two companies in 2011 while possessing non-public and price-sensitive information. He made a profit of S$30,000 and was previously convicted and fined S$180,000. The prohibition order prohibits him from carrying out regulated activities and taking part in management or director roles. It took effect on Monday.

site_title: India considers sweeping GDPR-style curbs for storage, transfer of online data
summary: India's government considers a draft Personal Data Bill 2018 that would restrict the transfer and storage of personal data of over 1 billion people by global tech companies. The bill proposes that foreign companies store data locally and impose stringent penalties for non-compliance. The draft recommends that personal data be handled in accordance with Indian laws, and companies must obtain explicit consent from individuals before processing their data. If enacted, the bill could significantly impact global tech companies operating in India.

site_title: Serial System engages law firm to advise on Taiwan probe
summary: Serial System, an electronic components distributor, has engaged a leading Taiwan law firm to advise on the Taiwan authorities' request for its executive chairman and CEO Derek Goh's assistance in investigations. The summons was received on June 21, but Goh was in Hong Kong at the time and was unable to meet the authorities. The company has confirmed that Goh appears to be a person under investigation, potentially related to insider trading allegations against Bull Will personnel. The investigation is not related to ongoing Singaporean investigations into Goh announced in 2015.

site_title: a-iTrust to buy 2 office blocks in Hyderabad's HITEC City
summary: Ascendas India Trust (a-iTrust) has agreed to acquire two office buildings in Hyderabad's HITEC City through a two-stage process. a-iTrust will subscribe to debentures worth 7.96 billion rupees and complete the acquisition once leasing criteria is met, with a total purchase price not exceeding 14 billion rupees. The acquisition will increase a-iTrust's portfolio by 10.2% to 20 million sq ft, strengthening its presence in Hyderabad, which is witnessing robust rental growth.

site_title: Nintendo profit tops estimates on strong online game sales
summary: Nintendo reported a quarterly profit of 30.5 billion yen (S$372 million), exceeding analyst estimates, driven by strong online game sales. The company's revenue fell short of projections at 168 billion yen. Despite this, Nintendo maintained its full-year forecasts for profit, hardware, and software sales. The company's online game sales offset weaker Switch console shipments, demonstrating the console's continued appeal.

site_title: CapitaLand launches S$2m fund to empower vulnerable elderly in Singapore
summary: CapitaLand has launched a S$2 million fund, the CapitaLand Silver Empowerment Fund, to support vulnerable elderly in Singapore. The fund aims to improve their quality of life through deeper social integration, better healthcare, and living conditions. Over the next three years, the foundation will partner with Community Chest Singapore to support projects such as a wheelchair-friendly community garden and a Community Hub in an ageing neighbourhood, benefiting over 2,600 elderly. The launch was officiated by President Halimah Yacob, who encouraged corporates to contribute to the care of the elderly.

site_title: US: Stocks rise on earnings, trade optimism
summary: US stocks rose on Tuesday, finishing higher after a three-week pullback, driven by good earnings and economic data, as well as a report that US-China trade talks would resume. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 gained 0.4% and 0.5%, respectively, while the Nasdaq Composite Index rose 0.5%. Analysts cited a mostly positive earnings season and forecasts for future quarters not coming down as reasons for the gains, with industrial shares leading the way and technology shares regaining their footing.

site_title: Corporate governance rankings can yield important investment insight
summary: Singapore-listed real estate investment trusts (Reits) and business trusts are ranked on their corporate governance practices using indices such as the Governance Index for Trusts (Gift) and the Singapore Governance & Transparency Index (SGTI). These rankings assess measures like board complement, disclosure practices, and stakeholder engagement. While corporate governance is an important factor in a company's profitability and share price performance, it's not the sole determinant. Investors can use these rankings to gain insight into a trust's strengths and weaknesses, and make more informed investment decisions.

site_title: China's July PMI slows on US trade dispute, bad weather
summary: China's manufacturing sector growth slowed in July due to the US trade dispute and bad weather, with the Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) falling to 51.2 from 51.5 in June. This is the lowest index reading since February but remains above the 50-point mark, indicating growth. The sub-index on imports contracted in July, and new export orders index remained in contraction. Chinese policymakers are concerned about the slowdown, with the service sector moderating in July. The economy is expected to slow further this quarter and next, potentially prompting policy easing.

site_title: Oil posts biggest monthly loss since 2016 as Opec boosts output
summary: Oil prices fell 6% in July, the largest monthly decline since 2016, due to Opec's decision to boost output to 32.64 million barrels per day, surpassing the 2018 high. US and China may reopen trade talks, which could boost demand, but supply disruptions in the Bab al-Mandeb Strait are still a concern. Oil prices extended losses after data showed domestic US crude inventories rose 5.6 million barrels. Opec's output boost and US sanctions on Iran are expected to offset growing demand led by Asia.

images.alt_text: Oil prices fell on Tuesday, closing out the largest monthly decline in two years on supply worries after Opec output reached a 2018 high in July, overshadowing reports that the United States and China might reopen trade talks that could boost demand.

site_title: Sinochem Energy goes for IPO to power higher-value businesses
summary: Sinochem Energy, a unit of China's state-owned Sinochem Group, has filed for a Hong Kong initial public offering (IPO) of about $2 billion to raise capital for higher-value businesses, including petrochemicals production. The company aims to expand its refining asset and build units to produce ethylene and petrochemical derivatives. This IPO comes amid Beijing's push to inject new life into bloated state-owned enterprises by encouraging private capital investment. The company's IPO plans have been pushed ahead by Sinochem chairman Frank Ning, who aims to shift the group from exploration and production to value-added refining and retailing businesses.

images.alt_text: The Sinochem Group is set to merge with state-owned ChemChina to create the world's biggest industrial chemicals firm worth around US$120 billion.

site_title: Leveraged loan market set to cool
summary: The leveraged loan market, a key area of Wall Street's hottest corners, is expected to slow down due to a pause in warehouse providers' willingness to take on more exposure, according to a fund manager. This pause may signal a deeper shift in sentiment, with investors increasingly scrutinizing the market's durability and ease of exit. Despite robust demand, UBS and JPMorgan strategists are expressing uneasiness about the market's performance in the next default wave, with potential losses potentially eclipsing those on bonds.

site_title: Outflows rock fund managers as Europe's US$1 trillion dream fades
summary: European asset managers face a challenging environment as outflows continue to rock the industry, with investors pulling 22.7 billion euros from long-term funds in May and June. Notable firms such as Jupiter Fund Management and DWS Group have seen significant redemptions, while others like Schroders Plc reported flat inflows. The turmoil highlights concerns over volatility, interest rate hikes, and trade wars, potentially leading to increased consolidation among asset managers.

site_title: URA nod for 4,107 units at Tampines Court, Normanton Park
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) granted provisional permission for two large residential projects in Singapore. Frasers Property secured permission for 4,107 units at Tampines Court and 500 apartments & serviced residences on the Jiak Kim site. These projects were sold through collective sales. The URA also approved other projects, but details were not specified. The news highlights ongoing developments in Singapore's property market.

site_title: Pacific Star Development sells out Bangkok condo's Phase 1 launch
summary: Pacific Star Development's mixed-use project, The Posh Twelve in Bangkok, has sold all 450 units in its first sales phase at an average S$390 per square foot. The project features 1,373 residential units and 7 commercial units, with another 190 units to be launched in August. The development, located near the Ministry of Public Health BTS station, offers amenities such as an infinity edge swimming pool and a club and wine lounge. The strong international take-up highlights Pacific Star Development's ability to create innovative property concepts with premium lifestyle attributes.

site_title: Career centre launched to help finance professionals with skills upgrading, job matching
summary: The Institute of Banking and Finance (IBF) launched IBF Careers Connect, a one-stop career centre to help finance professionals upgrade their skills and find new jobs. The centre, in partnership with various agencies, will provide career advisory and job matching services, aiming to support those in the financial industry and those looking to enter it. Minister for Education Ong Ye Kung emphasized the need for workers to be retrained due to the increasing frequency of job changes in the sector, citing innovation as a double-edged sword that can raise competitiveness but also lead to job disruption.

site_title: Midas figures it'll take 8 months to produce annual report
summary: Midas Holdings, a Singapore-based railway parts maker, has set an 8-month timeline to produce its annual report for the year 2017, amid irregularities in its Chinese subsidiaries. The company's shares have been suspended from trading in Singapore and Hong Kong since February. The Stock Exchange of Hong Kong may cancel Midas' listing if it cannot meet conditions to resume trading within 18 months. The board will discuss options to resuscitate the group with potential buyers and review the impact of ongoing investigations.

site_title: Digital ledger blockchain suffers slowdown
summary: Blockchain technology, a distributed ledger designed for secure data tracking, is facing a slowdown in adoption due to performance, oversight, and operational issues. Despite high-profile champions like Nasdaq and IBM, only 1% of chief information officers have blockchain adoption in their organizations, and most experiments will not become part of a company's operations. The technology remains an exotic fruit for many companies, and its widespread adoption is expected to be slow. Industry experts expect a potential uptick in adoption next year, but for now, projections and investors' expectations may need to be tempered.

site_title: The rise of modern systems of agreement
summary: Digital transformation is making it faster and easier to do business, but companies often struggle with their Systems of Agreement (SofA), the collection of technologies and processes used for preparing, signing, acting on, and managing agreements. Legacy SofAs are rife with manual processes, slow turnaround times, and human errors, causing companies to lose productivity and customer experience. However, some companies, like Salesforce, have implemented e-signature solutions, such as DocuSign, to break the bottleneck of needing a physical signature. These solutions have helped companies like Salesforce complete contracts in under an hour and reduce manual work by 71%. Modernizing SofA is crucial for businesses to gain a competitive edge and realize substantial benefits in cost reduction and customer experience.

site_title: Tech stocks slide on Tuesday following US rout
summary: Tech stocks in Singapore declined by more than 15% on Tuesday, following a US rout, with semiconductor equipment maker AEM experiencing the largest drop of 16.39%. The decline was attributed to fears of over-valued tech stocks and risk aversion ahead of upcoming event risks. This followed a 1.4% decline in the US Nasdaq Composite, led by the FANG stocks, and disappointing results from Facebook and Netflix.

site_title: Malaysia civil aviation chief resigns over MH370 lapses
summary: Malaysia's civil aviation chief, Azharuddin Abdul Rahman, resigned following an investigation report on the disappearance of MH370, a Malaysia Airlines flight that vanished in 2014. The report found lapses in air traffic control procedures, but did not blame the authority for the loss of the aircraft. Investigators concluded that the plane's controls were likely manipulated to take it off course, but could not determine who was responsible. An internal committee will be formed to recommend possible action against the air traffic controllers on duty at the time.

images.alt_text: Mr Azharuddin will be stepping down 14 days from the date of his resignation notice.

site_title: Italian prime minister gets five-star White House welcome
summary: Italian Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte received a warm welcome at the White House, with US President Donald Trump calling him "a really great guy" and stating he "will do a great job." The two share similar views on key issues such as Russia and immigration, with Conte supporting Trump's stance on re-evaluating Rome's relationship with Moscow and toughening EU asylum migration policy. The meeting reflects a resurgent Italian-US political relationship, with potential implications for Europe and beyond, particularly as Italy is a significant economic power in the eurozone.

site_title: Quotation of taxable book-entry Singapore Government Bonds
summary: Singapore Government Bonds quotation: The article does not discuss the quotation of taxable book-entry Singapore Government Bonds, instead, it appears to be a collection of unrelated news articles from July 11, 2025.

site_title: Benchmark spot prices for coal weak in the thick of summer
summary: Benchmark spot prices for coal have retreated in five of the previous six weeks, despite China's peak demand season for air-conditioning use during hot weather. Prices have slid below 600 yuan (US$87.94) a metric ton, resulting in the largest monthly loss for futures in over a year.

site_title: Credit Suisse gives investors reason to stay on revenue gain
summary: Credit Suisse's CEO Tidjane Thiam reported strong earnings in the first half of the year, driven by gains in private banking and the Swiss unit, which compensated for trading weakness. The bank added 9 billion francs of net new money and saw profitability in its wealth management business. Despite a decline in global markets revenue, Thiam's three-year turnaround plan has seen the bank tap investors for capital and cut expenses. The stock rose 2.3% after the earnings release, as analysts praised the bank's outperformance in wealth management.

images.alt_text: Mr Thiam's turnaround plan has seen Credit Suisse tap investors for more than 10 billion francs of capital, pare back trading, and focus on managing money for the wealthy.

site_title: Leaving an indelible mark on the international stage
summary: Three senior female executives from Singapore share their experiences working abroad. Jill Lee, CFO of Sulzer in Switzerland, notes that her international career began with a move to Beijing in 2004, where she became the first woman and Asian CFO for Siemens' China organization. Pearlyn Phau, Deputy Group Head of Consumer Banking Group and Wealth Management at DBS Bank in Hong Kong, found that working in Hong Kong required adjusting to a new work routine, cultural differences, and building trust with colleagues. Jenny Lee, Managing Partner at GGV Capital in China, credits her experience living and competing in China and the US with teaching her to be resilient, creative, and courageous. All three emphasize the importance of women stepping up to take on overseas positions and companies providing support for relocation and career development.

images.alt_text: "Contributing to the success of Sulzer and making my teams get excited with their work and development are what gives me fun and fulfilment. I enjoy "planting seeds and growing trees" when cultivating talents; perhaps that's my DNA from having grown up in the garden city of Singapore." - Jill Lee

"As a Singaporean abroad, we learn to appreciate many of the things we often take for granted, like public housing, CPF... In terms of gender diversity, I find that both markets have moved quite rapidly towards embracing diversity, not just gender but age, race and ethnicity." - Pearlyn Phau

"I learnt that it is possible to not only survive but thrive with the right level of creativity, focus, resilience and courage. Most of all, I now fully appreciate the immigrant "can-do" attitude that our forefathers had when they left their homes to build their new homes and fortunes in Singapore many years ago." - Jenny Lee

site_title: Governance of trusts: sunny, with a chance of isolated showers
summary: Singapore's Governance Index for Trusts (GIFT) assesses 44 listed real estate investment trusts (Reits) and business trusts for governance and business risk. The top five trusts, Keppel DC Reit and CapitaLand Commercial Trust, have retained or improved their scores. The median score increased by 6 points, while the mean improved by 3.5 points. Reits have seen significant gains, with Mapletree Commercial Trust moving to joint third position. However, some trusts face challenges, including First Ship Lease Trust's default and RHT Health Trust's material uncertainty related to going concern. The index highlights areas for improvement, including the lack of transparency on changes in management and the potential for foreign assets to introduce currency risks.

site_title: BOJ revises down inflation forecasts, makes minor tweaks
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) revised down its inflation forecasts, expecting inflation to reach 1.1% in 2018, 1.5% in 2019, and 1.6% in 2020. The central bank maintained its ultra-loose monetary policy, aiming to keep benchmark 10-year government bond yields around zero percent, and introduced minor tweaks to its easing program. Despite the revisions, the BOJ stood by its easing policy, citing the need to maintain momentum towards its 2% inflation goal.

site_title: China steps in as the Quad fades away
summary: China has successfully revitalized its diplomatic efforts with key players India and Japan, largely through quiet talks and cooperation. After a decade of inactivity, the Quad security dialogue, which aimed to counter China's rising assertiveness, has effectively faded away. China's President Xi Jinping has engaged in high-level meetings with Indian Prime Minister Modi and Japanese Prime Minister Abe, discussing trade, infrastructure, and border issues. China has also invited Japanese Prime Minister Abe to visit China, a move seen as a significant step in improving relations with Japan.

site_title: Shipping losses continue to fall but not in SE Asia
summary: Shipping losses worldwide declined by more than a third over the past decade, according to a report by Allianz Global Corporate & Specialty (AGCS). The South China, Indochina, Indonesia, and Philippines maritime region, known as the "new Bermuda Triangle," experienced a 25% annual increase in losses, primarily due to weather, busy seas, and lower safety standards. Friday is also statistically the most dangerous day at sea, with 175 losses reported over the past decade. Despite declining losses, human error remains a major driver of incidents, and the report warns that transferring human error to decision-making algorithms and onshore monitoring bases will not eliminate the risk.

site_title: US consumer spending up solidly in June; inflation moderate
summary: US consumer spending increased 0.4% in June, exceeding expectations, as households spent more on restaurants and accommodations, supporting a strong economy heading into the third quarter. Inflation rose moderately, with the personal consumption expenditures (PCE) price index excluding volatile food and energy components gaining 0.1%. The core PCE price index remained at 2% inflation target for a third straight month. Interest rates are expected to remain unchanged, with the Federal Reserve forecasting two more rate hikes by December.

site_title: Sovereign bonds climb as BOJ maintains policy
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) maintained its ultra-loose monetary policy, keeping interest rates unchanged, and signalled that rates will remain low for an "extended period". This led to a rise in sovereign bonds worldwide, including Treasuries, European government bonds, and Japanese debt. The BOJ also tweaked some policies, including reducing bank reserves subject to negative interest rates and reaffirming its forward guidance for policy rates. The move was seen as a response to underwhelming data from China, with the yield on 10-year Treasuries falling to 2.95%.

site_title: China charges former Internet censorship chief with corruption
summary: China's former top Internet censor, Lu Wei, has been charged with corruption, accepting bribes and using his official position for personal gain. Lu, who oversaw the country's strict online censorship, will face a court in Ningbo, China. The charges mark a significant move by President Xi Jinping to press on with his anti-corruption campaign, which has already netted over 1.5 million officials. Lu's case is seen as a formalization of the end of his role as China's "Internet czar," who was known for regulating online content and blocking services from Facebook, Google, and Twitter.

site_title: SGA must step up effort to send Singaporean to Olympics
summary: Singapore's Golf Association (SGA) must step up its efforts to send a Singaporean golfer to the 2020 Olympics, following the sport's inclusion in the Tokyo Games. The SGA, led by president Ross Tan and vice-president Lyn Sen, aims to capitalize on golf's increased global popularity and Singapore's potential to produce a top-ranked player. Despite recent successes by Quincy Quek and Gregory Foo, the SGA must use the Olympic field's eligibility criteria to its advantage, with a maximum of two eligible players from each country.

images.alt_text: With Gregory Foo performing well in the recent European Amateur Open, there is potential to take on the Olympics in Tokyo.

site_title: StanChart sees 'minimal' hit from US-China trade spat
summary: Standard Chartered reported higher pretax profits and lower bad loan losses for the first half of 2018, with a pretax profit of $2.35 billion, a 34% increase from the same period last year. The bank expects minimal impact from US-China trade tensions, citing its limited exposure to the issue, and plans to deliver better returns in the medium term. Its return on equity (ROE) reached 6.7%, exceeding expectations and validating its restructuring measures.

site_title: CSC Holdings responds to SGX query on Q1 loss
summary: CSC Holdings, an engineering services firm, has responded to an SGX query regarding its Q1 loss, citing a slow start in 2019 due to delays in new project commencements. The company attributed the net loss to these delays, stating that further details will be disclosed in its unaudited financial results on or before August 14.

site_title: New supply of retail space poses larger threat to Reits than online shopping, says Moody's
summary: Moody's report suggests a heightened supply of retail space in Singapore poses a greater threat to Reits than online shopping over the next 12-18 months. The addition of new retail space reduces rent likelihood of a major recovery, while online shopping reduces demand for physical retail space. Analysts maintain credit profiles on Reits such as CapitaLand Mall Trust and Frasers Centrepoint Trust, citing stable ratings of "A2" and "Baa1", respectively.

site_title: Far East H-Trust reports 4.1% rise in DPS for Q2
summary: Far East H-Trust reported a 4.1% increase in distribution per stapled security (DPS) for Q2, driven by better hotel performance. Net property income rose 11.2% to S$25.7 million, mainly due to Oasia Hotel Downtown's contribution. Revenue per available room grew 6.9% year-over-year, but serviced residences saw a 4.5% decline in revenue per available unit due to lower average daily rates. The trust's units closed 2.2% higher at S$0.69.

site_title: Property sector sentiment down, but underlying demand still exists
summary: Singapore's real estate industry sentiment has plummeted following the latest property cooling measures, but underlying demand remains. The Economic Development Board and Department of Statistics report show a decline in business expectations for the services sector, while manufacturing optimism has waned. Despite this, the outlook for the services sector remains positive.

site_title: Harley-Davidson sharpens Asia focus to revive growth
summary: Harley-Davidson is reviving its growth by focusing on Asia and launching lightweight motorcycles and electric bikes globally. The company aims to woo younger buyers, particularly in China and India, with nimbler motorcycles. As part of its "More Roads to Harley-Davidson" plan, Harley expects to spend $675-825 million over four years, generate $5.9-6.4 billion in revenue by 2022, and add $250 million in operating profit. The company also plans to unveil a lightweight motorcycle in India through an alliance with an Asian manufacturer within two years.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Ryobi Kiso, a corporate procurement specialist, warned of a Q2 net loss due to lower sales from its trading business. Jason Holdings, a wood flooring maker, reported a smaller net loss for fiscal 2017. TEE International secured S$65 million worth of engineering contracts, while Soilbuild Construction Group saw its net profit fall 67% and Ipco International faced a US lawsuit over a real property claim.

site_title: Britain's car industry cautions: No-deal Brexit is our nightmare
summary: Britain's car industry warns that a no-deal Brexit would cause significant damage, raising costs and sowing chaos for carmakers and consumers. The industry, employing over 850,000 people and generating $110 billion annually, is dependent on the free movement of parts across borders. A no-deal Brexit could lead to EU import tariffs of around 10% and disrupt trade flows, according to Mike Hawes, chief executive of the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders. With less than eight months until Brexit, the UK government must find a proposal to maintain economic ties with the EU.

site_title: The importance of independence - not least for a financial centre
summary: Financial independence is crucial in various sectors, including external and internal auditors, stockbrokers, journalists, and regulators. To maintain objectivity, firms must implement "Chinese walls" to eliminate conflicts of interest. This principle applies to companies laying off employees, with some getting worse at it. The global financial landscape is also experiencing a regulatory arms race, particularly with the rise of stablecoins. Meanwhile, the EU-China summit will focus on setting a tone for diplomatic relations, following a recent visit by Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi to Europe.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher on tech rebound, US-China trade talks
summary: US stocks opened higher on Tuesday, driven by a rebound in technology stocks and a report that US-China trade talks are set to restart. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.15%, the S&P 500 gained 0.25%, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.32%. The rebound follows a sell-off in the previous session.

images.alt_text: US stocks opened higher on Tuesday as technology stocks rebounded after a widespread sell-off in the previous session and on a report that the US and China seek to restart talks on trade.

site_title: US Fed set to hold rates steady, remains on track for more hikes
summary: The US Federal Reserve is expected to keep interest rates unchanged on Wednesday, but solid economic growth and rising inflation are likely to lead to two more hikes this year. The Fed has raised rates seven times since 2015, and policymakers are closely watching for signs of accelerating inflation and a potential trade war between the US and China. The US economy grew at its fastest pace in nearly four years in the second quarter, and inflation increased at a 2% pace. Despite President Trump's criticism, economists believe the Fed will remain on track for rate hikes until 2019.

site_title: Investors gravitate to defensive stocks in July
summary: Investors favored defensive stocks in July amid escalating trade war tensions and a surprise government raid on property prices in Singapore. The Jardine group, Singtel, Thai Beverage, Genting Singapore, and Singapore Press Holdings were among the biggest gainers by market cap. Defensive consumer stocks, such as those in the Jardine conglomerates, rebounded despite disappointing results, driven by the US dollar rally. In contrast, property names, such as City Developments and Keppel Corp, declined due to the return of property cooling measures. The market cap of the Singapore Exchange rose 0.8% in July, with the largest gainers being defensive stocks.

site_title: a-iTrust to acquire two buildings in India
summary: Ascendas India Trust (a-iTrust) has agreed to acquire two office buildings in Hyderabad's Hi-Tec City, valued at 7.96 billion Indian rupees (S$157.8 million). The acquisition will increase a-iTrust's portfolio by 10.2% to 20 million sq ft. The two buildings, aVance A1 & A2, have a combined leasable area of 1.85 million sq ft. The deal is part of a two-stage process, with a-iTrust providing construction funding to the co-developer entities. The purchase price will be determined based on key factors such as rent, occupancy, and capitalisation rates.

site_title: Cache Logistics Trust Q2 DPU down 17.6%
summary: Cache Logistics Trust reported a Q2 DPU of 1.419 Singapore cents, down 17.6% from the same period last year. Income available for distribution fell 6.3% to S$15.2 million, mainly due to lower net property income from CWT Commodity Hub and the divestment of its Hi-Speed Logistics Centre. Despite this, gross revenue climbed 7.7% to S$30 million, driven by incremental earnings from its Australia portfolio. The trust's DPU fell 15.1% to 2.926 Singapore cents for the six months, but the manager expects market sentiment to improve.

site_title: Ralph Lauren's Asian appeal buoys sales as home market sags
summary: Ralph Lauren Corp reported strong same-store sales in Asia, more than doubling analyst expectations, driving a 8.8% share price surge. However, the fashion house struggled in North America, with a 3% decline in same-store sales. Asian online sales soared 46%, while brick-and-mortar and online sales declined in the US market. Despite this, the company's Asian rebound suggests it is regaining momentum, with more work needed to regain its footing in the US market.

site_title: Market Capitalisation
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. In market news, US stocks opened lower amid fresh tariffs on Canada, while Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Meanwhile, Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case, and Singapore stocks rallied for a 5-day run ahead of GDP data.

site_title: World's biggest king penguin colony shrinks nearly 90%
summary: The world's largest king penguin colony on Ile aux Cochons, with 2 million birds in 1982, has declined by nearly 90% to approximately 200,000, according to a study published in Antarctic Science. Climate change, specifically a 1997 El Nino event, may have contributed to the decline, as warmer waters pushed fish and squid beyond the penguins' foraging range. Overcrowding and other factors, including avian cholera and potential invasive species, may also be contributing to the decline.

site_title: Navigating a challenging landscape of disrupted global trade flows
