summary: The Philippines' economy continues to grow, with a record-breaking $10 billion in foreign direct investments last year. The country's GDP has consistently surpassed 6% growth over the past six years, driven by the expansion of industries such as business process outsourcing, tourism, and manufacturing. Chinese investments, particularly those part of the Belt and Road Initiative, are expected to sustain growth momentum. The property sector is also thriving, with developers ramping up projects and lease rates increasing in major cities like Metro Manila and Cebu.

site_title: Iran's currency extends record fall as US sanctions loom
summary: Iran's currency has dropped to a record low of over 100,000 rials to the US dollar, amid US sanctions set to be reimposed on August 7. The US withdrew from the 2015 nuclear deal in May, lifting international sanctions on Iran. The currency's decline is a sign of economic pressure on the country. Iranians are bracing for the sanctions, which are expected to further weaken the economy.

site_title: Trump auto plan would increase US fuel use by 500,000 barrels a day
summary: US federal regulators are set to propose a draft plan to roll back automobile efficiency requirements, aiming to reduce "societal costs" by roughly half a trillion dollars by 2029, while increasing US fuel consumption by 500,000 barrels per day. The plan would freeze mileage targets from 2020 to 2026, instead of raising them each year, and would also revoke California's authority to regulate carbon dioxide emissions from cars and light trucks. The proposal has been met with criticism, with environmental groups arguing it would increase pollution and threaten public health.

site_title: Trump threatens US government shutdown over immigration
summary: US President Donald Trump threatened to allow a government shutdown if Democrats refuse to support major changes to immigration laws, including a border wall. Trump stated he wants to replace the current system with one based on merit, and the federal government would shut down if his demands are not met. This comes after Trump announced a new tariff on Vietnam, affecting the Asian garment industry.

site_title: Bright new talents emerge at ChildAid 2018 audition
summary: More than 100 children auditioned for ChildAid 2018, showcasing their musical talents under 19 years old to raise money for two charities. The event, helmed by Dick Lee, featured talented beatboxer Brisel Choo, singer Heema Izzati Zainudin, and vocalist Alan Fong, who impressed judges with their polished performances despite being beginners. Many participants had appeared in previous ChildAid editions, and some expressed excitement to return and learn from the event. The concert, titled Jumping Jukebox Jive, will be held on November 25 and 26 at Resorts World Sentosa.

site_title: The junk debt that tanked the economy? It's back in a big way
summary: Junk debt, which tanked the economy in the past, is making a comeback with regulatory and judicial support. Banks are making bigger and riskier loans due to high demand from investors, such as pension funds and sovereign wealth funds, who profit from selling these loans. This trend is driven by the lucrative profit from selling loans, rather than demand from borrowers. The article mentions a shift in focus towards green and transition finance, with the Monetary Authority of Singapore and the People's Bank of China planning to deepen cooperation in this area.

site_title: Asean integration, disaster response, trade on agenda as foreign ministers meet in Singapore
summary: Top officials from Asean countries and their counterparts from the US, EU, China, Japan, and South Korea are meeting in Singapore for the annual Asean Foreign Ministers' Meeting. The agenda includes discussing regional integration, disaster response, and free trade amid rising protectionism. The meetings will take stock of regional issues, including trade, economic growth, and policy challenges. The US, EU, and China are also expected to hold talks with Asean counterparts, highlighting the significance of the event in shaping regional and global policies.

site_title: More capital outflows from emerging Asia expected in H2
summary: Capital outflows from emerging Asia are expected to continue in the second half of the year due to rising trade tensions, a strengthening US dollar, and tightening monetary policies by central banks. Countries with current account deficits, such as Indonesia and India, are at higher risk. The US Federal Reserve's quantitative tightening and the European Central Bank's plan to end its bond-buying program have contributed to the outflows, which have already affected regional markets, including Jakarta's equity market. Economists predict further tightening of monetary policies in the coming months, potentially exacerbating the outflows.

site_title: Rough ride
summary: Singapore's bike-sharing business faces criticism for its negative externalities, including rogue parking and litter. Experts argue that regulating the industry is crucial to balance innovation with public concerns. Proposed solutions include geo-fencing, location-based parking regulations, public awareness campaigns, and designated bike parking zones. The government should also consider caps on the number of bikes, subsidies for operators, and penalties for irresponsible behavior. Some experts advocate for a docked bike-sharing system, where users are incentivized to return bikes to designated spots, while others suggest using technology to track and penalize violators.

site_title: Ear on the Fed, eye on tariffs, stomach for Apple
summary: US stocks ended last week flat, with technology stocks declining due to the "Facebook crash", which wiped out $119 billion in market capitalization. This week, market direction will depend on the Federal Reserve's policy statement, trade disputes, and Apple's earnings. The US stock market has edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty, while the STI rose 0.4% on Thursday. Investors remain positive despite split views on the Fed's policy, with the focus shifting to Apple's earnings and trade disputes.

images.alt_text: The Fed's meeting on Wednesday is unlikely to result in a rate hike, but it still looks daunting for bulls. Stocks could sell off if the Fed raises more concerns about the effects of tariffs on growth or inflation.

site_title: Takashimaya Singapore rises to the challenge
summary: Takashimaya Singapore is celebrating its 25th anniversary with a 3-4% sales increase forecast for the year. Despite flat growth last year, the department store posted a 10% operating profit rise to $44 million. The store's sales and profit are down from highs in 2015 and 2012, respectively, due to competition from online shopping and rising labor costs. To boost sales, the store is focusing on renovations, new brands, and special events, including a lucky draw for a Mercedes-Benz and limited-edition Lucky Cats. Challenges include waning tourist spending in Singapore and the decline of department stores.

site_title: Apple looks set to cross US$1 trillion mark
summary: Apple is poised to surpass the $1 trillion market value, currently leading with a market cap of $939 billion, followed closely by Amazon at $882 billion. The tech giant is expected to cross the milestone after releasing its quarterly results on Tuesday. Analysts attribute Apple's growth to its range of iPhones, iPad sales, and strong services, citing the tech sector as a safe haven for investors. The $1 trillion mark is seen as a significant milestone, but experts caution that the valuation is not comparable to the dot-com bubble of the late 1990s.

site_title: Buyback activity slows; directors build UOB-Kay Hian, Ho Bee Land stakes
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article:

Share buybacks slowed in Singapore, with S$8.33 million spent over five trading sessions, down from S$18.3 million the previous week. UOB-Kay Hian's chairman and managing director Wee Ee Chao increased his stake to 27.55% through open market transactions. Ho Bee Land's chairman and CEO Chua Thian Poh raised his stake to 75.006% through an off-market purchase. Allied Technologies' executive director Kenneth Low Si Ren reduced his stake to 9.49% after disposing of shares. Other companies, including China Jinjiang Environment and Vicplas International, saw significant changes in their director and substantial shareholder transactions.

site_title: Chinese police apply to arrest 18 at scandal-hit vaccine firm
summary: Chinese police have applied to arrest 18 people at Changsheng Bio-technology Co Ltd, a vaccine maker at the center of a safety scandal. The company was accused of falsifying data and selling ineffective vaccines for children. Changsheng's chairwoman Gao Junfang and several executives are suspected of producing and selling substandard drugs. The arrest request is based on an investigation that found systematic falsification of production and testing records. The scandal has triggered public outrage, with President Xi Jinping ordering an investigation. Prosecutors are unlikely to reject the arrest request.

site_title: Hamilton stretches F1 lead with Hungarian GP triumph
summary: Formula One world champion Lewis Hamilton secured his lead in the championship with a win at the Hungarian Grand Prix. Hamilton started from pole position and took the checkered flag ahead of Ferrari's Sebastian Vettel, who finished second. A late collision between Hamilton and teammate Valtteri Bottas prevented a potentially costly incident. With the victory, Hamilton increased his lead over Vettel to 24 points, entering the August break.

site_title: Central bank meetings, US jobs data in spotlight
summary: Singapore's stock market is expected to be active this week with central bank meetings and US macro data, including US employment numbers, in focus. The Bank of England's monetary policy decision and inflation report will also be released. Local banks are set to release their earnings scores, with analysts predicting strong results for DBS and UOB. The Singapore dollar's performance will be influenced by US dollar and global trade developments. Meanwhile, the US Federal Reserve is expected to leave interest rates unchanged, and the US jobs data on Friday may show a slowdown in hiring.

site_title: Deposed Catalan leader Puigdemont to return to Belgium
summary: Catalonia's deposed president Carles Puigdemont is returning to Belgium, where he will continue to push for his region's independence after a Spanish judge dropped the European arrest warrant for him. Puigdemont, who was detained in Germany, will be greeted by a welcoming party and will hold a news conference to discuss his plans. He will establish a "Republican council" in Belgium to work in parallel with the Catalan government and plans to travel to other European countries to promote his cause.

site_title: Trump's friends turned foes
summary: US President Donald Trump's friendships have turned sour, with several close confidants, including lawyer Michael Cohen, strategist Steve Bannon, and former Attorney General Jeff Sessions, feuding with him. Cohen's legal issues led to Trump's silence, while Bannon's book "Fire and Fury" angered the president. Sessions was rebuked for recusing himself from the Russian investigation, but has not been fired. Trump's relationships with his wives, Ivana and Marla Maples, also experienced public conflicts. Despite these feuds, some former allies have reconciled with Trump.

site_title: Silkroad Nickel wants Indonesian export quota for low-grade nickel ore from Sulawesi mining area
summary: Silkroad Nickel, an Indonesian-based miner, has begun applying for an export quota for low-grade nickel ore from its mining area in Central Sulawesi province. The company aims to increase production capacity and generate sustainable returns to shareholders by exporting nickel ore. Silkroad Nickel has explored about two-fifths of its 1,301-hectare mining concession area, valued at US$58 million, and plans to continue exploration and evaluation activities in the remaining area. The company plans to resume trading on Monday after a suspension since 2015.

site_title: As Zimbabwe prepares to vote, what happened to Mugabe?
summary: Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe, who dominated the country for nearly four decades, has not appeared in public since his regime's collapse in November 2017. He has not made a live TV appearance since then. His current whereabouts and activities are unknown.

site_title: This piece of Beverly Hills is selling at US$1b
summary: A 64-hectare hilltop property in Beverly Hills is being sold for US$1 billion, featuring 360-degree views of Los Angeles. The listing agent, Aaron Kirman, believes around 50-100 billionaires on a list of 2,800 could be interested, but the price is considered wildly overpriced. Experts say the market for properties above US$60 million is strong, but the Mountain of Beverly Hills' US$1 billion price tag may be out of reach for Hollywood stars. The property has a history of lawsuits and ownership disputes, but the new ownership is marketing it as a family compound for a single buyer.

images.alt_text: The 64 ha site, which is in an area of Los Angeles known as Beverly Hills Post Office and has been newly branded as the Mountain of Beverly Hills, comes with permission to build nearly 1.5 million sq ft of living space across multiple buildings.

site_title: BOJ policy tweak that matters for global bonds already underway
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) is reportedly reducing its purchases of longer-maturity debt, a move that may already be impacting global bond markets. The BOJ's steady reduction in debt purchases has led to a slowdown in its annual increase in debt holdings, with some analysts predicting that Japanese investors will bring more money back home. This could have significant implications for global bond markets, particularly if the BOJ allows longer-maturity Japanese bond yields to rise, prompting local investors to put more money into Japanese government bonds (JGBs).

site_title: US judge praises government on reunifications, demands more
summary: A US federal judge praised the government for reuniting 1,800 migrant children with their families, but demanded more action for the 400 who remain in custody after parents were deported. Judge Dana Sabraw had ordered reunifications by Thursday, but officials reported hundreds of families still separated. Sabraw emphasized the need for swift reunification of the remaining families.

site_title: Daintree Residence sells 50 of the 80 phase-one units in first condo launch since cooling measures
summary: Daintree Residence, a 327-unit condominium project in Toh Tuck Road, sold 50 of its 80 phase-one units over the weekend, with an average selling price of S$1,710 per sq ft. The sales saw a 5% discount, with most buyers opting for two- and three-bedroom apartments. The developer, S P Setia International, described the take-up rate as "very encouraging," with nine in 10 buyers being Singapore citizens. The sales are seen as a positive start to the condominium market, despite recent cooling measures.

site_title: Trump administration working on consumer data privacy policy
summary: The Trump administration is working on consumer data privacy policies, meeting with major companies like Facebook and Comcast to develop principles and a nationwide plan. The effort aims to strike a balance between privacy and prosperity, following massive data breaches and growing Congressional scrutiny. A government survey found three-quarters of American households have significant concerns about privacy and security risks. The administration plans to publish high-level principles and seek public comment, with the goal of eventually enshrining the policies in legislation.

site_title: Global car powers plot response to Trump threat
summary: Global car-producing nations, including Canada, the European Union, Japan, Mexico, and South Korea, will meet in Geneva on July 31 to discuss potential responses to US President Donald Trump's threat to impose tariffs on car imports. The meeting comes as the US Commerce Department is set to complete its "Section 232" investigation into car imports within weeks, with the president having 90 days to act upon recommendations. The countries are considering a coordinated response, including retaliatory tariffs or filing a complaint at the World Trade Organization, amid fears that tariffs could harm car sales and global industry jobs.

site_title: Why some people crumble when it's crunch time
summary: Some people experience performance anxiety, characterized by a physical reaction to pressure, hindering their ability to perform in high-stakes situations. This is distinct from the anxiety people commonly think of. Experts acknowledge that coping strategies can help manage this anxiety. Joseph Schooling's Olympic performance is cited as an example of someone who thrived under pressure. The article aims to explore why some individuals succeed in crunch time, while others falter, and to provide guidance for those struggling with performance anxiety.

site_title: Polls open in Australia "Super Saturday" by-elections
summary: Polls open in Australia's "Super Saturday" by-elections, with five seats up for grabs. The outcome could boost Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull's parliamentary majority to two, and may impact his re-election prospects. The elections are seen as a referendum on the government's "jobs and growth" agenda versus Labor's focus on better health funding. If the Liberals win, it would be the first time a government has clinched a seat from the opposition at a by-election in 98 years, and could potentially lead to a change in opposition leader Bill Shorten.

site_title: iFast Corp's Q2 net profit jumps 40% despite loss-making mainland China operations
summary: iFast Corp reported a 40.4% surge in Q2 net profit to S$2.94 million, driven by higher revenue of 25.4% to S$30.9 million. Despite a loss-making mainland Chinese operations, the company saw growth in its Singapore and Hong Kong markets. Revenue in Hong Kong increased 53.7% due to strong investment inflows, while Malaysian operations saw significant growth in the bond business. The company expects a healthy improvement in business performance in 2018, barring unforeseen circumstances.

site_title: Facebook is sued after stock plunge 'shocked' market
summary: Facebook and CEO Mark Zuckerberg are sued over a disappointing earnings announcement that wiped out US$120 billion in shareholder wealth. The complaint accuses the company of making misleading statements about slowing revenue growth and declining active users. The lawsuit seeks class-action status and damages, following a 19% plunge in Facebook shares. This marks the first of many potential lawsuits over the earnings announcement, which also hit Zuckerberg's personal fortune.

site_title: Sexual misconduct allegations cloud Moonves's future at CBS
summary: Allegations of sexual misconduct against CBS Chairman and CEO Leslie Moonves have raised concerns about his future at the company. An article in The New Yorker accuses Moonves of harassing six women, including forced touching and kissing, over 30 years. The allegations have led to a call for an independent investigation, and Moonves's board has pledged to look into the claims. If the allegations are found to be true, Moonves may be forced to step down, potentially paving the way for a merger between CBS and Viacom.

site_title: "Blood moon" dazzles skygazers in century's longest eclipse
summary: A rare "blood moon" eclipse, the longest of this century, mesmerized skygazers worldwide on July 28, 2018. The event coincided with Mars' closest approach in 15 years, drawing crowds to witness the celestial spectacle. In Kenya, local Maasai community members watched the eclipse through a high-powered telescope. The phenomenon was a thrilling sight, captivating observers globally.

site_title: Cambodia's Hun Sen has an important election backer in China
summary: Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Sen is expected to win the country's election with the backing of China, his long-time ally. China has announced a major infrastructure project in Cambodia, provided $259 million in concessional loans, and sent its ambassador to attend a ruling party rally. The move is seen as a bold step by China to ensure Hun Sen's re-election and is a significant departure from its previous low-profile approach to domestic politics in Cambodia. China views Cambodia as a strategic state and has learned from its experience with Malaysia's ousted prime minister, who suspended billions of dollars in China-backed projects.

site_title: Big Oil leaves analysts fuming about being in the dark on refinery outages
summary: Big Oil executives, including Darren Woods, Ben van Beurden, and Mike Wirth, are facing criticism for their companies' missed earnings estimates due to refinery issues. ExxonMobil, Royal Dutch Shell, and Chevron, which are integrated oil majors, failed to meet optimistic estimates despite rising crude prices. This contrasts with dedicated refiners like Phillips 66 and Valero Energy, which are performing well. The struggles of integrated oil majors have left analysts puzzled, as their ability to efficiently manage margins at refineries is a key factor in their success.

site_title: Polish avant-garde jazz trumpeter Tomasz Stanko dies at 76
summary: Tomasz Stanko, a renowned Polish avant-garde jazz trumpeter, died at 76. Born in 1942, Stanko began his career in the late 1950s in Krakow, playing with notable jazz musicians like Jack deJohnette and Dave Holland. Influenced by Miles Davis and Ornette Coleman, he gained a global reputation for his free-form jazz and recorded for ECM label. His 1997 album "Litania" was a global bestseller, a tribute to Polish film composer Krzysztof Komeda. Stanko was praised by fellow musician Michal Urbaniak as "an absolute prophet, a great musician, and a consistent one."

site_title: Singaporean family puts Crowne Plaza resort on sale
summary: A Singaporean family has put the Crowne Plaza Surfers Paradise resort in Australia on the market for over A$100 million. The resort, which includes a 269-room hotel, retail space, and multiple food and beverage outlets, is being sold through an international expressions of interest campaign. The owners cited a buoyant investment market and strong investor appetite for the sale. The resort's prime location on the Gold Coast Highway, combined with vacant possession and value enhancement options, is expected to attract strong buyer interest. The sale is seen as a rare opportunity for investors.

site_title: Disney investors worry Beijing could be tricky Fox deal hurdle
summary: Disney investors are concerned that the US$71.3 billion sale of 21st Century Fox's entertainment assets to Disney may face regulatory hurdles in China, despite the deal already receiving US Department of Justice approval. China's State Administration for Market Regulation is required to approve the deal due to a small proportion of Fox's revenue generated in the country. Some investors fear China may use the deal as leverage in a trade war with the US, citing the recent failure of Qualcomm's US$44 billion takeover of NXP Semiconductors by Chinese regulators.

images.alt_text: Now that 21st Century Fox shareholders have signed off on the US$71.3 billion sale of its entertainment assets to Walt Disney, some investors are already fretting about the next hurdle: regulatory clearance from China.

site_title: Exxon, Chevron punished by shareholders as profits disappoint
summary: Big Oil investors punished Exxon and Chevron for disappointing earnings reports, with Exxon's market value plummeting $11 billion after cutting its full-year production target. Chevron, however, rose in New York trading after announcing a $3 billion stock buyback. Both companies fell short of analyst estimates, but Chevron's performance improved due to its focus on value and the Permian Basin. Exxon's CEO stated that the company is focused on value, not volumes, despite a decline in production and profits.

images.alt_text: Big Oil investors showed Friday they're not much interested in grand investment projects for the future. It's all about putting money back in their pockets now.

site_title: Trump 'open' to Moscow visit
summary: US President Donald Trump is open to visiting Moscow, with the White House stating he is willing to travel to the city upon receiving a formal invitation. Russian President Vladimir Putin also expressed readiness to visit Washington, with the two leaders planning to meet at a G-20 summit in Buenos Aires later this year. The potential meetings come after a summit in Helsinki sparked a US political crisis, with Trump facing criticism for his comments on the 2016 election. Conditions for the meetings are expected to be in place, with both leaders emphasizing the need for face-to-face talks on bilateral and international issues.

site_title: Bayer hits back at new Netflix medical device documentary
summary: Bayer has disputed accusations in the Netflix documentary "The Bleeding Edge" that claims medical device makers and the US FDA prioritized profits over patient safety. Bayer stated the documentary lacks scientific support and cherry-picks facts to portray its permanent birth control device Essure inaccurately. The company maintains Essure is safe, despite over 16,000 US lawsuits related to the device. Bayer will phase out Essure in the US, citing sales discontinuation in other countries. The FDA says it strives to allow devices with favorable benefit-risk profiles to be marketed, currently monitoring Essure in postmarket studies.

site_title: Facebook suspends US conspiracy theorist Alex Jones
summary: US conspiracy theorist Alex Jones has been suspended from Facebook for 30 days due to bullying and hate speech. The suspension follows the removal of four videos from Jones' personal profile and pages tied to his Infowars website, which promote hate speech and conspiracy theories. Jones' Infowars pages are close to being unpublished due to repeated community standards violations. This move comes after YouTube also removed four of Jones' videos and threatened to permanently remove his website if it receives three strikes within 90 days.

site_title: Oil prices fall; Brent still set for weekly gain
summary: Oil prices fell on Friday, with Brent crude futures dropping 28 US cents to $74.26 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude futures fell 94 US cents to $68.67 a barrel. Despite a strong US economy growth in the second quarter, oil prices are expected to rise weekly due to easing trade tensions and a temporary shutdown of a key oil shipping lane by Saudi Arabia. The market is also influenced by US stock market declines, with some analysts citing a slowdown in the economy as a factor.

site_title: NH Hotel bidder says counteroffer from Hyatt has come too late
summary: Hyatt Hotels has made a late bid to acquire NH Hotel Group, but Minor International, led by Dillip Rajakarier, has already received a favorable response from NH Hotel's board. Minor's tender offer, valued at 1.64 billion euros, is expected to be completed, and Hyatt's bid may be too late to stop the transaction. Minor is on track to own 44% of NH Hotel, including a planned purchase of 8.4% from HNA Group.

images.alt_text: Hyatt Hotels' interest in acquiring NH Hotel Group has come too late to stop rival Minor International's own tender offer for the Spanish company, Dillip Rajakarier, chief operating officer of the Thai bidder said.

site_title: Main Thyssenkrupp shareholder opposes group break-up
summary: Thyssenkrupp's largest shareholder, Ursula Gather, opposes the break-up of the company amidst a leadership crisis. Gather, who heads the Krupp Foundation with a 21% stake, prioritizes job security and social market economy principles over potential restructuring. The company, which employs 159,000 people worldwide, has been in turmoil since two top executives quit following investor demands for an aggressive restructuring. The German government and union leaders also oppose break-up efforts, urging all parties to work towards a constructive solution. Gather's opposition suggests a possible end to the company's leadership crisis.

site_title: Next 'Star Wars' to use old footage of late Carrie Fisher
summary: Carrie Fisher, who played Princess Leia, will be featured in the next 'Star Wars' movie using previously unseen footage she recorded before her death. The film, directed by JJ Abrams, will start filming in London on August 1 and is due for release in December 2019. Mark Hamill will also appear in the movie, reprising his role as Luke Skywalker. Billy Dee Williams will reprise his role as Lando Calrissian, and the film will feature a returning cast, including Daisy Ridley and Adam Driver.

images.alt_text: Carrie Fisher will be featured in the next Star Wars movie, using previously unseen footage she recorded before her death, Walt Disney studio said on Friday.

site_title: US: Tech stocks weigh on Wall Street
summary: US tech stocks weighed heavily on Wall Street on Friday, with major indexes falling due to weak earnings reports from Intel, Twitter, and Microsoft. Intel's data center business missed estimates, while Twitter reported a decline in monthly active users and warned of further drops. The S&P 500 technology index fell 2%, with Apple, Microsoft, and Alphabet shares also declining. The Nasdaq Composite dropped 1.46%, its biggest daily percentage drop in a month, as investors expressed concerns about the sector's growth prospects.

site_title: Trump hails US economic growth spurt, promises more ahead
summary: US President Donald Trump hailed the country's economic growth as a "miracle" after the GDP expanded by 4.1% in the April-June quarter, surpassing $20 trillion. The growth rate is the fastest in almost four years, but economists warn it could be a temporary blip due to factors like trade tensions with China. Trump attributed the growth to his economic agenda and tax cuts, but noted that the economy is "on track to hit the highest annual average growth rate in over 13 years."

site_title: Professional and business services fastest-moving sector
summary: Singapore's small and medium enterprises (SME) sector has shown good performance, with 50 SME100 Award winners honoured at a recent event. The sector's average revenue growth doubled to 53% in 2018 from 22.4% in 2017, according to publisher Business Media International. The companies were assessed using an 80-20 quantitative to qualitative scorecard, and were identified as the fastest-moving in Singapore. This marks a positive consolidation of expectations for the SME sector.

site_title: Nielsen loses quarter of its value on bevy of bad news
summary: Nielsen Holdings lost a quarter of its market value after cutting profit forecasts and announcing the retirement of its CEO. The company's shares tumbled 27% to a record low, wiping out $2.8 billion in value, after missing analyst estimates for second-quarter profit and revenue. Nielsen has started a strategic review of one of its key segments, the Buy unit, which tracks consumer purchases. The company now estimates 2018 net income will be between 95 cents and $1 per share, down from a previous range of $1.50 to $1.56.

site_title: Writing right, the Zebra Sarasa way
summary: The Zebra Sarasa gel ink pens are a favorite among stationery enthusiasts for their smooth writing, fast-drying ink, and vibrant colors. The pens come in a wide range of ink colors, finishes, and designs, making them both functional and fun to use. With affordable prices starting from S$1.50, they are also a great option for building a collection. The pens' quality and variety have earned them a loyal following, with some even considering them a nostalgic favorite.

site_title: It will be a seven-club challenge at Sembawang
summary: The Sembawang Country Club will host a seven-club challenge at the third leg of The Business Times Corporate Golf League on August 7. This unique twist aims to inject more fun into the event.

site_title: Strong net absorption of office space in first half
summary: Singapore's office space saw strong net absorption of 88,000 sq m in the first half of the year, surpassing annual figures from 2014 to 2017. This growth is attributed to increasing rentals and prices in the central region. Island-wide, this marks a significant increase, with the central region experiencing continued rent recovery.

site_title: Unemployment inches up as better economy lures more back to labour force
summary: Singapore's unemployment rate edged up to 2.1% in the second quarter, with more people entering the labour force to look for work. Total employment expanded by 7,100, but retrenchments increased to 2,500, mainly from the services and manufacturing sectors. Mature workers and professionals were disproportionately affected. Structural challenges such as skills and jobs mismatches remain a main cause of unemployment.

site_title: Chang an all-the-way winner
summary: Malaysia's Ervin Chang secured a wire-to-wire victory in the 71st Singapore Open Amateur Championship at the Singapore Island Country Club's Bukit course, thanks to a first-round eight-under 62.

site_title: A day before Laos dam failed, builders saw trouble
summary: A dam failure in Laos killed at least 27 people and displaced 6,600, with many more still missing. The companies building the dam, a joint venture of South Korean and Laotian firms, had alerted Laotian officials about potential trouble, but many villagers received no warning. Engineers had noticed a depression in the dam on the day before it failed and attempted to repair it, but were unable to get necessary equipment to the scene in time. The UN reported that 14 bridges had been damaged and 1,494 people were evacuated to emergency shelters.

site_title: Nafta teams ready to 'start solving' stalled issues: Mexico
summary: Mexican Economy Secretary Ildefonso Guajardo said negotiating teams for the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta) are ready to start talks again after stalling in June. The teams plan to address complex issues first, with Mexico and the US agreeing to step up talks on updating Nafta by August. Canadian Foreign Minister Chrystia Freeland is expected to join talks soon, and Mexico's President Enrique Pena Nieto hopes for a deal in August. However, economists warn that Nafta talks have a history of optimism and pessimism, and it remains unclear how contentious issues will be resolved.

site_title: Choo's a man of many talents
summary: There is no article provided to summarize. The text appears to be a collection of unrelated news articles from different dates and topics.

site_title: SAP launches infocomm-tech 'university'
summary: SAP has launched the SAP Skills University Singapore, a collaboration with SkillsFuture Singapore and five local polytechnics to train mid-career professionals and polytechnic graduates in information and communications technology (ICT) skills. The initiative aims to prepare individuals for the job market and offers career advisory and placement services. The university will offer two types of work-learn programmes, targeting mid-career professionals and polytechnic graduates, with a focus on specialized ICT courses such as predictive analytics, artificial intelligence, and blockchain technology. The collaboration is expected to benefit 1,000 individuals over the next three years.

site_title: SIA slips on Q1 results
summary: Singapore Airlines' Q1 results showed a 58.6% net profit decline to S$139.6 million, with shares falling 5% to S$10.22. Revenue remained nearly flat at S$3.84 billion, and earnings per share dropped to 11.8 cents. Analysts maintain "hold" ratings, citing expected passenger traffic growth, but also noted weak operating cash flow and competition. The airline is focusing on traffic growth rather than yield increases.

site_title: UIC net profit up 47% in Q2 on fair value gains
summary: UIC, a Singapore property group, reported a 47% increase in net profit to S$108.5 million in Q2, driven by fair value gains. Excluding fair value effects, net profit from operations declined 24% to S$58.6 million. Revenue dropped 50% to S$182.5 million due to lower sales recognition from trading properties. Despite this, UIC's share of operating profits from associated companies surged 72% to S$14.9 million. The company expects office rents to improve and the hotel sector to remain steady, while the residential market is expected to be subdued due to cooling measures.

site_title: Reits
summary: US mortgage rates rise for the first time in five weeks, marking a shift in the market. This comes as a Q3 wave of condo launches in Singapore is expected to test demand for prime projects above S$3,000 per square foot. Meanwhile, Manhattan rents hit a record, with further increases anticipated. In other news, Goldman Sachs acquired a large hotel and retail portfolio in Seoul, and UK homebuyer demand rebounded to a six-month high. New World Development is also selling China property assets after securing a loan deal. WeWork secures new tenants at its Singapore location.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Hyflux, a Singapore-based company, is undergoing a debt restructuring process. The Securities Investors Association Singapore (Sias) will form informal steering committees with note- holders and securityholders to facilitate communication during the reorganisation. Noteholders owe S$265 million, while perpetual and preference shareholders are owed S$900 million. Interested parties must inform Sias by August 2 to join the committees.

site_title: Private home price increases to moderate rest of the year
summary: Private home prices in Singapore rose 3.4% in Q2, driven by a strong resale market and increased transaction volumes. However, analysts expect the cooling measures to moderate growth in the rest of the year. Rentals and occupancy rates are likely to be supported in the near term, with vacancy rates falling to 7.1% and rents posting a one-per-cent increase. Analysts project a slowdown in price growth, with some expecting a seven to 10% increase in prices this year.

site_title: Number of HDB flats resold rises 33.3% in Q2 2018
summary: In Q2 2018, 5,941 HDB resale flats were sold, a 33.3% increase from the previous quarter, with median prices ranging from S$838,000 in Queenstown to S$870,000 in the central district. Rental applications also rose 2.6%, with 12,024 approved, and median rents varied from S$1,400 in Queenstown to S$2,750 in Bukit Merah. HDB offered 11,373 flats for sale, including 7,634 BTO flats, with another 4,300 BTO flats to be offered in August.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary:
The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report covers the tanker and dry bulk market from July 23-27, 2018. Key highlights include:

- The Capesize market corrected after reaching a timecharter average of over $26,000, with West Australia/China route rates peaking at $10.30 and dropping to $9.30.
- Saldanha Bay/China rates climbed over $17.00, but may be short-lived due to a Brazil push.
- Vale took several ships for first half August, while CSN reportedly took five ships on Thursday.
- The North Atlantic market experienced declines, particularly for owners staying within the Atlantic.
- The C7 Puerto Bolivar/Rotterdam fixed a 16-25 August trip at $11.70.
- Panamax vessels saw positive gains, with a modern Kamsarmax achieving $24,000 daily for a trip via NC South America.
- The Pacific market was mixed, with early tonnage in the South fixing via EC South America, while further north, only Kamsarmaxes offered resistance.
- The Supramax market saw Ultramax tonnage fixed over $20,000 to the East.
- The Handysize market remained weak, with the Mediterranean/Black Sea proving the exception, driven by demand for grain shipments.
- Tanker rates were steady, with VLCCs fixed at WS 51.5 for 270,000mt to China.
- Aframax rates rebounded in the Mediterranean, with fresh enquiry seeing rates climb from WS 95 to WS 112.5 for 100,000mt.

site_title: M1 warns of softer second half ahead of TPG roll-out
summary: M1 Singapore reported higher Q2 earnings of S$36.2 million, driven by SIM-only plan growth and improved mobile and fixed service revenue. Despite this, the telco warned of a softer second half ahead of TPG Telecom's roll-out, citing market seasonality and impending new competition. M1's operating revenue grew 1.1% to S$507.3 million, with a 34,000 increase in post-paid customers. The company declared an interim dividend of 5.2 cents per share.

site_title: ComfortDelGro buying up to 1,200 hybrid Hyundai cabs
summary: ComfortDelGro Corp, Singapore's dominant taxi operator, plans to buy up to 1,200 hybrid Hyundai Ioniq cabs, with deliveries expected by mid-2019. This move follows the taxi industry's shift away from diesel, driven by stricter emission standards. The company has started taking delivery of the first 200 cabs this year and has ordered an additional 500. The hybrid taxis now account for 20% of Singapore's 21,000-cab fleet, up from just 2.4% five years ago.

site_title: Central area retail rents, prices resume slide after short recovery
summary: Singapore's central region retail rents and prices resumed their decline in the second quarter of 2018, with the rental index dropping 1.1% and the price index falling 1.3% quarter-on-quarter. The vacancy rate for retail space fell to 7.3% islandwide, with the Orchard Road planning area showing resilience at 5.6%. Experts attribute the decline to retailers trading off high rents for more stable occupancy, while the growing online shopping culture and changing consumer preferences are expected to impact mall rents.

images.alt_text: The Urban Redevelopment Authority's rental and price indices for retail space in Singapore's central region both resumed their downtrend in the second quarter after inching up briefly in the previous quarter.

site_title: Tried & Tested
summary: The i210, a new iron set from Callaway Golf, is designed to cater to better players seeking more forgiveness in their irons. Building on the success of its predecessor, the i200, the i210 offers significant improvements. Although no specific details on the changes are provided, the set is marketed as an evolution rather than a revolution, suggesting it addresses player needs more effectively. The i210 is positioned to target players seeking more forgiveness in their irons, setting it apart from the i200.

site_title: Ruling Grab-Uber deal anti-competitive 'may hurt innovation'
summary: Grab, following a ruling by Singapore's Competition and Consumer Commission (CCCS) that its acquisition of Uber's South-east Asia business threatens competition, has submitted a written response arguing that the deal does not harm competition. GGV Capital, an early investor in Grab, disagrees with the CCCS' ruling, stating that mergers and acquisitions do not necessarily limit competition. Grab claims that its definition of the ride-hailing market is broader than the CCCS', and that its exclusivity obligations for taxi and car rental partners "go against the spirit" of increasing choices for drivers and riders.

site_title: Court gives go-ahead for Albracca en bloc sale
summary: The High Court of Singapore has granted a sale order for the Albracca condo at Meyer Road, allowing the collective sale to proceed. The 11-unit development was sold for S$69.1 million to Sustained Land last July, despite one owner objecting to the deal. The court's decision comes after mediation failed, and the owner had represented himself in court. The sale order will now proceed with the sale of the property.

site_title: Jardine Matheson, Jardine Strategic post lower H1 profits
summary: Jardine Matheson Holdings (JMH) and Jardine Strategic Holdings (JSH) reported reduced profits in 1H18 due to lower non-trading gains. JMH's net profit slumped 57% to US$928 million, while JSH's net profit declined 58% to US$984 million. Despite lower earnings, underlying profit was up 6% and 9% respectively, driven by robust performances from Astra and Jardine Cycle & Carriage. Interim dividends were declared at 42 US cents for JMH and 10 US cents for JSH.

site_title: CRCT raises second-quarter DPU to S$0.0264
summary: CapitaLand Retail China Trust (CRCT) reported a 0.8% increase in its distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.64 Singapore cents for the second quarter ended June 30, driven by new contributions from the Rock Square mall in Guangzhou. If the private placement exercise in December 2017 is restated, DPU would have risen 8.2%. The trust's DPU increase was attributed to the Rock Square mall's contribution.

site_title: CDL Hospitality Trust DPS up 2.9% in Q2
summary: CDL Hospitality Trust posted a 2.9% rise in distribution per stapled security to 2.14 Singapore cents in Q2, despite a 0.3% decline in revenue to S$47.7 million. Net property income fell 3.7% to S$33.6 million, boosted by new hotel acquisitions in Germany. The trust's average weighted debt to maturity increased to 3.2 years, with a gearing of 33.2% and regulatory debt headroom of S$609 million.

images.alt_text: New contributions from The Lowry Hotel (above) and the Pullman Hotel Munich helped boost net property income.

site_title: China's central bank not seeking yuan depreciation
summary: China's central bank is unlikely to allow its currency, the yuan, to depreciate much further despite its current 5-7% decline since mid-April. Analysts attribute the decline to market-driven factors, including China's recent accommodative policies and investors' concerns over trade tensions. The People's Bank of China (PBOC) has ample reserves to defend its currency, and may implement supportive measures to avoid destabilization. A softer yuan could cushion the effects of US import tariffs, but the government prioritizes stability over devaluation to support its economy.

site_title: Foreigners dominate 10th Warren-Mst Amateur Open
summary: Foreigners have finally broken the decade-long streak of dominating the Warren-MST Amateur Open, a golf tournament in Singapore. The 10th edition of the event saw foreign players take the top spots, ending the local players' 10-year winning streak. This marks a significant change in the tournament's history, which began in 2008.

site_title: China eyes infrastructure boost to cushion growth amid trade war
summary: China plans to boost infrastructure spending to cushion the economy's growth amid the ongoing trade war with the US, policy sources reveal. The government aims to ease borrowing curbs on local governments to support infrastructure investment. A four trillion yuan spending package in 2008-09 shielded China's economy from the global crisis but saddled local governments with debt. China's cabinet has pledged to deliver more tax cuts and quicken the issuance of special bonds to support infrastructure investment, with fiscal policy set to become "more proactive".

site_title: Stock exchanges need to find mojo
summary: Stock exchanges in Singapore and Hong Kong have amended their listing rules to allow dual-class share (DCS) structures, a strategy used by companies like Google and Facebook. DCS allows founders and executives to hold a high percentage of voting rights with a relatively low equity stake, giving them control. The move aims to stay competitive, but has been met with controversy. Analysts expect DCS to be effective in attracting companies, but its impact on the market's overall health remains to be seen. The move is seen as a response to the success of DCS companies in the US.

site_title: Kia Cerato 1.6 MPI review: Good for the Seoul
summary: The Kia Cerato 1.6 MPI is a compact executive sedan that has improved its reputation in the market with its sleek design and sophisticated features. The third-generation model boasts a more fastback silhouette, LED lamps, and a sporty 17-inch rim, giving it a sharp and sophisticated appearance. On the road, the Cerato delivers smooth acceleration and a comfortable ride, although its 128hp engine lags behind its turbocharged counterparts. Despite this, the Cerato provides entertaining feedback through its handling and steering, making it a desirable option for those seeking a stylish and capable sedan.

site_title: OUE H-Trust posts fall in Q2 DPS, gross revenue
summary: OUE Hospitality Trust's distribution per stapled security (DPS) fell 3.3% year-on-year to 1.17 Singapore cents in Q2, with gross revenue and net property income (NPI) declining 1.4% and 0.5% respectively. NPI was partly offset by lower property expenses. The trust's hotel portfolio revenue per available room (RevPAR) rose 2.6% to S$195, while the retail segment saw lower revenue due to lower effective rent.

site_title: SGX's Q4 net profit slips nearly 2% as operating expenses rise
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) reported a 1.8% drop in Q4 net profit to S$83.67 million, mainly due to a 6% increase in operating expenses. The bourse operator will switch its dividend policy from percentage-based to an absolute amount of 7.5 cents per quarter from 2019. Revenue rose 2.5% to S$212.95 million, driven by a 4.1% increase in derivatives segment revenue. For the full year, SGX chalked up a five-year high net profit of S$363.2 million, with a proposed final dividend of 15 cents per share.

site_title: Innovate, embrace new ideas to stay on top
summary: TOP International Holding, a leading mining and trading company, has been recognized as one of the top bauxite exporters in Malaysia and received the SME100 award. The company aims to supply high-quality resources globally, contributing to sustainable living standards. CEO Victor Tan attributes the award to the company's innovative approach and drive to break new heights. TOP plans to expand its global presence, become more vertically integrated, and prioritize environmental sustainability.

site_title: Perennial embarks on third HSR integrated development in China
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings' 45%-owned joint venture, Perennial HC Holdings, has invested 2.7 billion yuan (S$564.3 million) in an integrated development next to the Tianjin South High Speed Railway station in China. The 76,900 sq m site was awarded at a price of 718 million yuan for a 40-year tenure.

site_title: How Facebook suddenly went so wrong so fast
summary: Facebook's stock plummeted after the company reported disappointing second-quarter figures, including slower revenue growth and lower profit margins. The company warned of a surge in spending that would drag down profits and predicted operating profit margins of around 35% over the next several years, a significant decrease from recent history. Analysts and investors are speculating on four possible reasons for the decline, including increased spending, regulatory pressure, and a slowdown in user growth. The company's stock value dropped by over $100 billion, its largest single-day loss, but remains valued at over $500 billion.

images.alt_text: Facebook' execs had warned that its rapid rate of revenue growth would become relatively pedestrian for the rest of this year.

site_title: The grass is greener on Nature's side
summary: Recent cooling measures in Singapore have made natural and green nodes more desirable, increasing the value of properties near rivers, green trails, and urban parks. In cities like Guangzhou, China, and Perth, Australia, waterfront properties with views of rivers or natural features command higher premiums. In Singapore, transactions from 2017 to 2018 show a premium for riverfront homes, which is expected to grow in popularity and value over time. Upcoming projects near natural features, such as The Tre Ver and Daintree Residence, are likely to benefit from this trend.

site_title: Panel proposes "India only" policy for critical data
summary: A government panel in India has recommended that all critical personal data on people in the country be processed within India, with a draft bill to be presented to parliament. The panel, headed by former Supreme Court judge BN Srikrishna, proposes a "personal data determined to be critical" to be subject to local processing, with a prohibition against cross-border transfer. The move aims to enhance data protection and address data breaches, with global companies potentially facing changes to their business models and costs.

site_title: Europe: Good earnings help shares stay up
summary: European stocks rose in early trading, ending the week at six-week highs, driven by easing fears over US tariffs and good company results. The STOXX 600 index rose 0.16% following strong earnings from Reckitt Benckiser, Saint Gobain, and Vinci. Carmakers benefited from hopes of a US-EU trade breakthrough, while Renault fell 0.8% despite record profitability in the first half.

site_title: Deliveroo Singapore revenue more than doubles
summary: Deliveroo Singapore's revenue more than doubled to S$26.4 million in 2017, driven by investments in its market and technology. The company now has a positive balance sheet with S$11.7 million in net assets, up from a net liabilities position last year. Deliveroo expanded its rider and restaurant-partner numbers, with 6,000 riders and 4,000 partners, respectively. The app's predictive algorithm improved delivery times by 20% to an average of 32 minutes per order in Singapore, enabling the company to move from a net liabilities to a net assets position this year.

site_title: Hong Leong Asia's JV company wins BCA tender
summary: A joint venture between Hong Leong Asia and Sunway Concrete has won a 30-year lease of land in Singapore for a $25.7 million consideration, with Hong Leong Building Materials bearing 51% of the cost. The construction of a fully mechanized integrated precast plant is expected to begin next month, subject to approvals. The project will be funded through internal sources and bank borrowings.

site_title: Emerging market debt looks attractive once again
summary: Emerging market debt yields have reached their most attractive level since February 2016 at 6.5% due to a rise in risk-free rates and spreads over the past two years. This is driven by the US Federal Reserve's continued rate hikes and fiscal stimulus from the US tax cuts. However, the segment is not without risk, with some markets experiencing political woes and weaker fundamentals, leading to wider spreads. To navigate this, investors should focus on sovereign hard currency debt, with funds such as the Neuberger Berman Emerging Market Debt Hard Currency Fund offering attractive yields and strong track records.

site_title: No job is too small for this forwarder
summary: TRINITY Cargo Link Pte Ltd, a freight forwarder, credits its global success to its team of dedicated professionals who deliver quality customer service. The company provides logistics services and solutions that meet customer needs, focusing on operational excellence and supply chain management. Winning the SME100 award recognizes the company's quality work, credibility, and financial strength, boosting morale and driving further improvement. Trinity aims to strengthen its trade lanes through strategic partnerships and innovation, enhancing customer service experience.

site_title: STI slips ahead of US GDP data and on Wall St's overnight losses
summary: Singapore stocks edged down 0.1% on Friday, despite the US economy's 4.1% growth in the second quarter, ahead of Wall Street losses. The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 3.62 points to 3,324.98, with non-financial stocks like CH Offshore and Singapore Airlines losing 0.8% and 5.37%, respectively. Asian stocks rose, with the Nikkei 225 and Kospi up 0.56% and 0.26%, respectively, after tech giants Amazon and Facebook reported earnings.

site_title: Starhill Global Reit's Q4 DPU dips to 1.09 cents
summary: Starhill Global Reit reported a 8.5% drop in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.09 cents in Q4, due to weaker office portfolio contributions, lower retail revenue, and disruption from asset redevelopment. The company's Q4 income available for distribution slid to S$25.3 million, and gross revenue declined 3.9% to S$51.6 million. For the full year, revenue eased 3.5% to S$208.8 million and net property income inched down 2.8% to S$162.2 million.

images.alt_text: The retail portions of Wisma Atria generated lower revenue for the period under review.

site_title: Twitter tumbles after user base shrinks
summary: Twitter's quarterly results showed a 24% revenue increase to $711 million, but a 1 million decline in monthly active users to 335 million. The decline was attributed to a purge of fake accounts and "bots" that manipulate the platform. Shares dropped 16% in pre-opening trades, overshadowing the company's third straight quarterly profit. CEO Jack Dorsey attributed the results to investments in the platform's long-term health, stating efforts to ensure users feel safe and free to express themselves.

site_title: What people talk about when they talk about Champagne
summary: Champagne house Louis Roederer has undergone a significant transformation under the leadership of Jean-Baptiste Lécaillon, who forecasted the impact of climate change on the industry in the 1990s. The company now emphasizes terroir and sustainable farming practices, with over 70% of its grapes grown in estate vineyards. Biodynamic and organic viticulture are used, with each vineyard block vinified separately and blended as desired. This shift has allowed Roederer to produce high-quality wines that are distinct from its predecessors, redefining the Champagne market and its focus from blending to terroir.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 2.91 points to 1,769.14 on Friday, driven by higher trading volume of 2.3 billion lots worth RM2 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 511 to 382, marking a mixed session.

site_title: The predatory danger of startups
summary: A director at a Singapore startup, Apps Authority, has been accused of making inappropriate offers to female interns, including a student from the National University of Singapore, after a police report was filed against him. This incident is part of a global trend of women facing sexual harassment in the tech scene, with a 2015 survey showing that 65% of women in tech firms had been sexually harassed by a boss. Younger females are particularly at risk of exploitation due to the "move fast, break things" culture of tech firms, which can create grey areas for those in power to manipulate.

site_title: Bayer wins EU watchdog's endorsement for wider Xarelto use
summary: Bayer's Xarelto clot prevention drug has received EU watchdog endorsement to expand its use to atherosclerosis patients. The move could benefit 30 million additional patients, with annual sales expected to rise above $5 billion. The drug will be used at a lower dose with aspirin to treat patients with coronary artery disease or symptomatic peripheral artery disease. The European Commission will make the final decision, but the EMA's endorsement is a significant step forward for the German drugmaker.

site_title: Consumers, soybeans fuel US Q2 growth
summary: The US economy grew at its fastest pace in nearly four years in the second quarter, with a 4.1% annualized rate, driven by consumer spending and government spending. The growth was fueled by a front-loading of exports, including soybeans, before trade tariffs took effect in early July. However, economists warn that trade tensions and rising interest rates may slow down growth in the second half of the year, and the stimulus from a $1.5 trillion tax cut package is expected to fade next year.

site_title: New online portal offers guide to laws of each Asean country
summary: Singapore launched the Asean Judiciaries Portal, an online platform providing access to laws and information on law firms, mediators, and public notaries in each Asean country. The portal aims to boost investors' confidence and promote trade and investment in the region. Developed by the Council of Asean Chief Justices and maintained by the Singapore Academy of Law, the portal will also facilitate collaboration among Asean judiciaries and provide a directory of judicial training courses. The portal is funded by a 3.6 million kroner (S$598,660) grant from the Norwegian government.

site_title: Unemployment, retrenchments in Singapore up slightly in Q2: MOM
summary: Singapore's unemployment rate edged up to 2.1% in Q2, with a 0.1% increase from the previous quarter, and 0.1% increase for Singaporeans. Retrenchments also rose, with 2,500 layoffs in Q2, mostly from services and manufacturing sectors. Total employment grew by 7,100, driven by improvements in construction and manufacturing. Labour MP Patrick Tay warned of further retrenchments due to business disruption and trade uncertainties, citing skills and jobs mismatches as a structural challenge.

site_title: EU says farming 'not part' of US trade deal, contradicting Trump
summary: The EU has denied US President Donald Trump's claim that farming would be included in proposed trade talks between the two nations, contradicting Trump's statement. EU Commission spokeswoman Mina Andreeva stated that agriculture was not part of the discussions, citing a joint communique from White House talks on Wednesday. The EU and US are set to follow up on discussions on soybeans, but farming itself is not included in the talks.

site_title: Putin ready to meet Trump in Washington or Moscow
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin stated he's ready to meet US President Donald Trump in either Moscow or Washington, praising Trump for sticking to his election pledges. Putin said he expects to meet Trump on the sidelines of the G-20 summit in Argentina, but emphasized the need for "appropriate conditions." The two leaders previously met in Helsinki, where Trump sparked controversy by casting doubt on US intelligence agencies' findings on Russia's alleged election meddling. Putin also stated Russia won't abandon holding US dollar reserves, despite sanctions, and is diversifying its foreign currency assets.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher on Amazon boost, GDP data
summary: US stocks opened higher on Friday as Amazon's upbeat earnings boosted consumer discretionary stocks, contributing to the S&P 500's 4.91-point gain and the Nasdaq's 37.56-point rise. The US economy grew at its fastest pace in nearly four years, according to data.

site_title: Frasers Property acquires 75% stake in Vietnam property development company
summary: Frasers Property has acquired a 75% stake in Vietnam's Phu An Dien Real Estate Joint Stock Company (PAD) for 799 billion dong (S$47.3 million). The acquisition is for a mixed-use project in Ho Chi Minh City and will be done via Frasers Property Investments (Vietnam) 2 Pte Ltd. The deal is expected to have minimal impact on Frasers Property's financials for the current year. The project will be developed on a 45 million-share basis, with PAD's remaining 25% stake to be held by Tran Thai Lands Company Limited.

site_title: Emery gunning for success at Arsenal
summary: Unai Emery began his tenure as Arsenal manager with a 1-1 draw against Atletico Madrid in the International Champions Cup, followed by a penalty shootout loss. The young and inexperienced team, missing key players like Mesut Özil and Danny Welbeck, showed promise with goals from Emile Smith Rowe and Matteo Guendouzi. Emery, who won multiple trophies with Sevilla and PSG, aims to fill the void left by Arsene Wenger and lead the team to success in the upcoming season, starting with the Premier League opener against Manchester City.

site_title: Exxon misses on profit as output hits lowest level in decade
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp and Chevron Corp reported disappointing earnings, missing profit expectations and failing to capitalize on rising oil prices. Exxon's production hit its lowest level in a decade, while Chevron resurrected share buybacks. Exxon's stock tanked, falling 4.3%, while Chevron's fell 1.8%. Both companies failed to meet analyst forecasts, with Exxon lagging by $1.4 billion and Chevron by $0.6 billion. Despite this, Chevron's CEO vowed to deliver good profits at $50-a-barrel oil, while Exxon prioritizes big project investments to recover from past missteps.

site_title: Ryobi Kiso receives letters of demand from creditors; winding up petitions filed against subsidiary
summary: Ryobi Kiso Holdings and its subsidiaries have received letters of demand from creditors totaling over S$1.08 million. The company's subsidiary Ryobi Kiso (S) has faced winding up petitions in the High Court of Singapore for S$2.73 million. Ryobi Tactics (RT) has been granted a winding up order after RKS commenced winding up proceedings against it. Ryobi Kiso is assessing the impact on its financials and operations, and is in contact with creditors to explore options to minimize disruptions.

site_title: Starhill Global Reit's Q4 DPU dips to 1.09 Singapore cents
summary: Starhill Global Reit reported a 3.9% decline in Q4 income available for distribution to S$25.3 million, and a 3.9% drop in gross revenue to S$51.6 million. Distribution per unit (DPU) fell to 1.09 Singapore cents from 1.18 cents in the previous year. Net property income declined 3.3% to S$40 million. The decline was attributed to weaker office contributions and lower revenue from its Wisma Atria and Myer Centre properties.

site_title: M1 Q2 net profit up by 1.5% on higher service revenue, but H2 may not be as rosy
summary: M1's second-quarter net profit rose 1.5% to S$36.2 million, driven by higher service revenue, particularly from post-paid and fixed services. However, the company warned that the second half may not be as rosy due to market seasonality and impending competition from new entrants. Mobile revenue increased 3.8% to S$146.2 million, while fixed service revenue grew 27.4% to S$36.7 million. M1 has also started exploring 5G services and ICT for growth, and has recommended an unchanged interim dividend of 5.2 Singapore cents a share.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.1% lower on Friday
summary: Singapore stocks ended lower on Friday, with the Straits Times Index losing 3.62 points, or 0.1% to 3,324.98. Losers outnumbered gainers 198 to 173, with about 1.93 billion shares worth S$936.9 million changing hands. CH Offshore rose 0.8% after a married deal with Baker Technology, while SIA fell 5.37% and Venture Corp declined 2.3%.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks down at open on Friday
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened lower on Friday, following a negative lead from Wall Street, where shares are under pressure from Facebook's plunge and metal tariffs affecting US auto brands. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.35%, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined 0.09% and 0.12%, respectively.

site_title: Truckers' strike hits Indian industry
summary: Indian carmakers face an "unprecedented crisis" due to a truckers' strike, which has caused parts shortages and disrupted exports. The All India Motor Transport Congress, led by hundreds of thousands of members, is demanding lower taxes on fuel, insurance premiums, and highway tolls. The strike has resulted in stranded vehicles at borders, potential food price increases, and disruptions to industrialized states such as Gujarat, Maharashtra, and Tamil Nadu. The Society of Indian Automobile Manufacturers (Siam) reported consignments stuck on roads and losses for its members due to the strike.

images.alt_text: Indian carmakers Friday said they faced an "unprecedented crisis" due to an ongoing strike by truckers which has caused parts shortages and hit exports.

site_title: Sias to help form informal steering committees of noteholders and securityholders, says Hyflux
summary: Hyflux to form informal steering committees with noteholders and securityholders to engage with stakeholders during debt restructuring. The committees will be formed by the Securities Investors Association Singapore (Sias). Noteholders and securityholders interested in joining the committees must inform Sias by August 2 with their contact details and security details via email or phone. Hyflux owes S$1.165 billion to noteholders and securityholders, and is working towards a debt restructuring.

site_title: Jardine Matheson Holdings' H1 2018 net profit down on lower non-trading gains
summary: Jardine Matheson Holdings reported a 57% year-on-year decline in H1 2018 net profit to US$928 million, primarily due to lower non-trading gains. Underlying net profit rose 6% to US$792 million, while revenue increased 14% to US$21.33 billion. The company declared an interim dividend of 42 US cents, up from 40 cents previously. Despite this, shares closed 11 US cents lower at US$66.19.

site_title: OUE Hospitality Trust's Q2FY2018 DPS dips 3.3%
summary: OUE Hospitality Trust's distribution per stapled security (DPS) fell 3.3% to 1.17 Singapore cents in Q2FY2018, with gross revenue and net property income (NPI) also decreasing. The hospitality and retail segments posted lower revenue, while hotel portfolio revenue per available room (RevPAR) rose 2.6% to S$195. The trust's average occupancy at Mandarin Gallery increased to 97.4%, but retail segment revenue and NPI were lower due to lower rents.

site_title: Jardine Cycle & Carriage H1 2018 net profit down 56% on non-trading losses.
summary: Jardine Cycle & Carriage's 6-month net profit fell 56% to US$174 million due to non-trading losses of US$240 million, primarily from unrealized fair value losses on investments. Underlying profit rose 10% to US$414 million, with Astra's contribution increasing 12%. Revenue rose 10% to US$9.19 billion, while earnings per share dropped to 44 US cents. The company declared an interim dividend of 18 US cents, with Chairman Ben Keswick expecting Astra's performance to be satisfactory, despite concerns over competitive pressures in the car market.

site_title: Chinese investors plan US$10b metallurgical complex in South Africa
summary: Chinese investors signed agreements to build a $10 billion metallurgical complex in South Africa, with construction set to begin next year. The complex, which includes stainless steel, ferrochrome, and silicomanganese plants, is expected to create jobs and boost the South African economy. Chinese state-owned companies will lead the project, which aims to meet the country's growing metal demand. The project's environmental approvals are expected to be finalized by the end of March.

site_title: Britons in debt distress at 6-year high as BoE ponders rate hike
summary: The number of people in England and Wales filing for insolvency reached a six-year high in the second quarter, with 28,951 people registering as insolvent between April and June. This represents a 27% increase from the same period last year. High inflation caused by the pound's fall after the Brexit vote has squeezed consumers, leading to concerns about debt problems. Most economists predict the Bank of England will raise interest rates next week, but some argue this could worsen household debt and economic conditions.

site_title: SGX's Q4 net profit falls 1.8%
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) reported a 1.8% decline in Q4 net profit to S$83.67 million, down from S$85.23 million a year ago. Revenue rose 2.5% to S$212.95 million. Earnings per share fell to 7.8 Singapore cents from 8.0 Singapore cents in 2017. The bourse operator proposed a final dividend of 15 Singapore cents per share, up from 13 cents last year. Full-year net profit reached S$363.2 million, up 6.9%, with record revenue and highest profit in five years.

site_title: Consumers, soybeans fuel US second-quarter growth
summary: The US economy experienced its fastest growth in nearly four years in the second quarter, with a 4.1% annualized rate, driven by consumer spending and government spending. The growth was fueled by lower taxes and a robust labor market, with 215,000 jobs created on average in the first half of the year. However, economists caution that the trade-related boost is expected to unwind in the second half of the year, and the stimulus from the $1.5 trillion tax cut package is expected to fade next year, potentially leading to slower growth.

site_title: Thomson Medical, IVI-RMA to form assisted reproduction platform in Singapore
summary: MAINBOARD-listed Thomson Medical Group has signed an agreement with IVI-RMA Global to form a joint venture in Singapore, creating Asia's leading assisted reproduction platform. The partnership aims to deliver industry-leading clinical services, training, and research in assisted reproduction, particularly in China, Indonesia, and Vietnam, where demand is growing. The JV is expected to address the increasing demand for assisted reproduction in Asia, with global IVF cycles projected to more than double by 2020 and the Asia IVF market estimated to reach US$4.2 billion by 2020.

site_title: Australia, New Zealand dollars dogged by China worries, brace for US GDP
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars suffered losses against the US dollar due to ongoing Sino-US trade concerns. The Aussie dollar fell to US$0.7386, while the New Zealand dollar retreated to US$0.6780. Investors are worried about the impact of a potential US-China trade truce on free trade and demand for raw materials, particularly since China is Australia's largest export market. US GDP figures are also expected to influence currency markets, with analysts forecasting growth above 4.1%.

site_title: Indonesia's president begs exporters to bring earnings back home
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo urged exporters to repatriate their earnings to help manage the country's declining foreign exchange reserves. The move aims to prevent the rupiah from falling further amid a heavy selloff in emerging market currencies. Currently, 90% of export earnings are recorded at domestic banks, but only 15-25% are converted to rupiah. The government will maintain close communication with the business community to monitor the situation and may issue new policies if necessary.

site_title: Hyatt signals interest in Spanish bid target NH Hotel Group
summary: Hyatt Hotels Corp has expressed interest in acquiring 100% of NH Hotel Group, a Spanish hotel company, after receiving a letter of interest. The US company believes it can launch a superior cash offer, valuing NH at a higher amount than Minor International's recent offer of up to 2.5 billion euros. This development could spark a takeover battle with Minor International, which had also expressed interest in acquiring the company.

site_title: Yee Lee Development clinches Tuas South industrial site for S$26.8m
summary: Government agency JTC has awarded the tender for the Tuas South industrial site to Yee Lee Development at a tendered sum of S$26.8 million. The 24,129.5 sqm land parcel is zoned as Business 2 with a gross plot ratio of two times and has a 30-year tenure. The project completion period is 60 months. Yee Lee Development submitted the higher of two bids, winning the tender launched on April 24 and closed on June 19.

site_title: Asia: Stocks mixed ahead of US growth data
summary: Asian stocks were mixed on Friday ahead of US economic growth data, which is expected to show a surge in economic growth in the second quarter. US tech giants' earnings reports, including Amazon's better-than-expected profits and Facebook's weaker-than-expected growth, influenced the markets. Tokyo rose, Sydney and Hong Kong fell, while Shanghai retreated. The US data is expected to show growth between 4-5%, partly due to trade disputes, which may drag growth lower in the coming months.

site_title: Biomed sector boosts Singapore June factory output
summary: Singapore's factory output rose 7.4% in June, beating economists' expectations of 3.3% growth, driven by the volatile biomedical manufacturing cluster. Manufacturing performance was supported by a 13.8% rise in biomedical output, while the electronics cluster saw output expand by 7.1%. However, economists warn that the divergence in electronics production and exports may not be sustainable and could lead to a correction in production numbers. Despite this, some economists forecast a manufacturing recovery in the third quarter, citing a modest pick-up in smartphone-related demand and stabilising developed-market capital expenditure.

site_title: Hot stock: Singapore Airlines drops after Q1 results miss expectations
summary: Singapore Airlines' shares fell 5% after the airline reported Q1 results that missed analyst expectations. Net profit fell 58.6% to S$139.6 million due to a 40% increase in jet fuel prices. Despite a "hold" rating from OCBC Investment Research, the airline's core net profit growth exceeded expectations, driven by accounting changes and higher-than-expected cargo yields. UOB Kay Hian also maintained its "hold" recommendation, citing a 22% year-on-year decline in aircraft leasing costs. The stock price dropped to S$10.23.

site_title: Singaporean family puts Crowne Plaza Surfers Paradise resort on sale for over A$100m
summary: A Singaporean family has listed the Crowne Plaza Surfers Paradise resort in Australia for over A$100 million. The 1.2-hectare complex, comprising a hotel, retail space, and multiple dining outlets, is being sold as a single entity or in individual parts. The owners are capitalizing on a strong investment market and investor appetite, citing the Gold Coast's prime location and the resort's value enhancement options. The resort has a development site with approval for 234 apartments and is directly connected to the Gold Coast light rail.

site_title: UIC net profit jumps 47% in Q2 on fair value gains
summary: UIC, a Singapore property group, reported a 47% increase in net profit to S$108.5 million in Q2, driven by a fair value gain of S$49.8 million. Revenue slumped 50% to S$182.5 million due to lower sales recognition from trading properties. Earnings per share (EPS) excluding fair value gains and losses was 4.1 Singapore cents, up from a restated 5.4 Singapore cents in the same period last year. The company expects office rents to improve and the hotel sector to remain steady.

site_title: Fortune Reit posts higher first half DPU of 26.34 HK cents
summary: Fortune Real Estate Investment Trust (Reit) reported a 3.2% increase in its distribution per unit (DPU) for the first half of 2018 to 26.34 HK cents, up from 25.53 HK cents in the same period last year. Revenue rose 2.2% to HK$978.1 million, while net property income increased 3% to HK$748.6 million. The Reit's gearing ratio and aggregate leverage decreased due to a lower borrowing level, and the divestment of Provident Square has reduced refinancing needs until 2020.

site_title: Malaysia shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Friday, down 1.77 points to 1,764.46, with a trading volume of 45.14 million lots worth RM17.56 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 94 to 84.

site_title: Temasek leads Flywire Series-D funding round of US$100m
summary: Flywire, a global payment solutions provider, has secured US$100 million in its Series-D funding round led by Temasek Holdings. Existing investors Bain Capital Ventures and F-Prime Capital also participated. The funds will be used to accelerate growth in North America, Europe, and Asia Pacific, as well as expand into emerging markets.
