site_title: Chinese premier calls for severe punishment in vaccine scandal
summary: Chinese Premier Li Keqiang has called for severe punishment for companies and individuals implicated in a vaccine scandal, following the discovery of faulty rabies vaccines made by Changsheng Biotechnology Co. The scandal has sparked public anger and dealt a blow to China's drug regulator, with the government promising a clear explanation and resolute action against those responsible.

site_title: Oxley appoints CFO as group financial controller resigns
summary: Oxley Holdings appointed Chan Yean Chun as its new chief financial officer and company secretary, replacing Ooi Chee Eng, who resigned to pursue other opportunities. Chan, a former Amara Holdings group financial controller, will oversee Oxley's financial matters. The appointments were effective on July 20, ahead of Oxley's fourth-quarter and full-year results announcement.

site_title: Singapore stocks dip on Monday; STI down 0.2% to 3,291.48
summary: Singapore stocks declined 0.2% on Monday, closing at 3,291.48, with 35.6 million shares changing hands. Losers outpaced gainers 49-43, with mDR Limited plummeting 50% to S$0.001. Other notable declines included SembCorp Marine and SembCorp Industries, while CapitaLand remained flat. The dip follows a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: G-20 urges dialogue to resolve trade tensions that threaten growth
summary: The Group of 20 (G-20) finance ministers and central bankers urged dialogue to resolve rising trade tensions, warning they threaten global growth. The statement emphasized the need for "step up dialogue and actions" to mitigate risks and enhance confidence, without mentioning the US, which is at the center of trade disputes. The IMF predicts that US$430 billion of global GDP could be lost in 2020 if all tariff threats and retaliations are carried out. The G-20 calls for resolving trade disputes directly between governments or through the World Trade Organization to avoid a rupture.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks fall on Trump's tariff remarks; won edges up
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index fell 0.63% on Monday, down 14.39 points, amid US President Donald Trump's threat to impose tariffs on all Chinese imports. The Korean won edged up, tracking Chinese yuan gains, while bond yields rose. Shares of chipmakers SK Hynix and Samsung Electronics dropped 5.4% and 2.3%, respectively. The KOSPI has declined 7.2% this year, and the won has gained 5.73% against the US dollar this year.

site_title: Oilfield service giants miss forecasts despite soaring US production
summary: Oilfield service giants Schlumberger and Baker Hughes missed second-quarter revenue forecasts due to slow international growth, despite record US production boosting domestic demand. The Houston-based companies, viewed as industry bellwethers, reported earnings under scrutiny from analysts. Schlumberger's heavy international exposure offset the growth, indicating the global oil and gas industry's health is uncertain.

site_title: Trump's trade war casts a long shadow over LNG shipping boom
summary: The US-China trade war is casting a shadow over the booming liquefied natural gas (LNG) shipping market. While LNG has been spared from tariffs so far, a change could lead to higher prices and reduced demand, particularly in the US, which aims to become the world's largest LNG exporter. The impact on LNG ships, which are in high demand, could be significant, with some analysts warning of cargo swaps and reduced demand. Despite these risks, LNG shipowners are cautiously optimistic, with some planning to invest in newbuilds.

site_title: Nikko AM offers new SGD corporate bond ETF
summary: Nikko AM has launched the first Singapore-denominated corporate bond ETF, replicating a basket of bonds tracked by the iBoxx SGD Non-Sovereigns Large Cap Investment Grade Index. The ETF, priced at SGD 1 per unit, offers retail investors exposure to high-grade credit issued by local companies and statutory boards, with a current yield to maturity of 3.2%. The fund's total expense ratio will be capped at 0.3% for the first three years, and it aims to reach an AUM of SGD 50 million.

site_title: US dollar extends losses, Asia stocks slide on Trump currency comments
summary: US President Donald Trump criticized the Federal Reserve's tightening policy, causing the US dollar to decline to its lowest in over two weeks. The dollar slid 0.2% against a basket of major peers, while stocks in Asia, including Japan's Nikkei and Australian shares, also fell. Trump's comments, coupled with threats to impose tariffs on China, triggered sell-offs in Wall Street and European stocks. The dollar index is up 2.4% this year, but long-term Treasury yields steepened after the remarks.

site_title: China central bank unexpectedly injects 502b yuan through 1-year MLF, rate unchanged
summary: China's central bank unexpectedly injected 502 billion yuan through a one-year medium-term lending facility (MLF) with interest rates remaining unchanged at 3.30%. The move was unexpected as no MLF loans were due to mature on Monday. The injection aims to ensure ample liquidity, particularly for lenders that have invested in bonds rated AA+ and below. This is the second MLF injection this year, following a 400 billion yuan injection in March. The decision was made despite China's GDP growth expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Firms tap Enterprise Singapore's expertise, connection for water projects in China
summary: Singapore companies are tapping into Enterprise Singapore's expertise and connection to enter China's growing wastewater industry. Companies like AnnAik and Century Water Systems & Technologies are leveraging their technological solutions and capabilities to develop and commercialize water solutions in China. With increasing demand for water treatment and stringent regulations, Singapore companies are well-positioned to meet these needs, with Enterprise Singapore providing assistance through its Capability Development Grant and structuring ventures with local Chinese government officials.

site_title: China launches probe into stainless steel imports from EU, Japan, South Korea, Indonesia
summary: China's Commerce Ministry has launched an anti-dumping probe into imports of stainless steel billet and hot-rolled stainless steel sheet and plate from the EU, Japan, South Korea, and Indonesia, following a complaint by Shanxi Taigang Stainless Steel. China imported 703,000 tonnes of those products in 2017, with 98% coming from the targeted regions. The investigation aims to investigate dumping practices and ensure fair trade.

site_title: US proposals to drop trade barriers taken seriously by allies: Mnuchin
summary: US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin stated that G-7 industrial powers are taking seriously his call to drop tariffs, non-tariff trade barriers, and subsidies. Mnuchin emphasized that President Trump's trade stance is not about protectionism, but rather seeking free and fair trade for the US. The Trump administration plans to press these issues in upcoming talks with the European Union's top executive.

site_title: Iran leader backs blocking Gulf oil exports if own sales stopped
summary: Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei backed President Hassan Rouhani's suggestion that Iran may block Gulf oil exports if its own exports are stopped due to US sanctions. Khamenei rejected talks with the US, calling it an "obvious mistake," and supported continued negotiations with European partners to offset US actions. This comes as Iran's oil exports could fall by two-thirds by the end of the year due to new US sanctions, putting oil markets under strain.

site_title: China is so wild about tech it even loves waiters that can't serve
summary: China's tech industry is rapidly advancing, with robots serving as waiters, artificial intelligence in schoolwork, and facial recognition technology used for various purposes. However, some in the tech scene warn that the excess enthusiasm may be masking the country's lack of progress in other areas. The US has banned Chinese telecom company ZTE for violating sanctions, highlighting the need for China to address its tech shortcomings. Despite this, China is expected to continue its technological dominance, with startups and companies pushing the boundaries of emerging technologies like AI and robotics.

site_title: India's HDFC Bank Q1 profit misses estimates on higher provisions
summary: India's HDFC Bank reported a 18.2% rise in Q1 net profit to 46.01 billion rupees, missing analyst estimates due to higher provisions. The bank chose to include all mark-to-market losses in the first quarter, resulting in a 3.91 billion rupee loss. Despite this, HDFC Bank's loans grew 22% year-over-year, and net interest income rose 15.4%. The bank's smaller rival Kotak Mahindra Bank also missed profit estimates last week due to higher provisions. HDFC Bank's strong retail presence and relatively low bad loan exposure have made it a favourite among investors.

site_title: Apple looking into complaints of fraudulent iTunes charges
summary: Apple is investigating complaints of fraudulent iTunes charges, affecting dozens of customers in Singapore, including those at OCBC Bank, DBS, Maybank, and Standard Chartered. Some customers reported deductions of up to thousands of dollars, with one customer losing S$4,400 in 27 transactions. Apple has set up a support page for customers to report issues, and banks are offering temporary credit while investigations are conducted. The issue appears to be widespread, with multiple banks reporting similar incidents, and Apple has declined to comment on the extent of the problem.

site_title: New GE unable to shake off old woes
summary: General Electric Co (GE) has faced persistent sluggish demand for gas turbines, curbing its cash-flow expectations and leading to a 4% decline in shares. The company's second-quarter results, which topped Wall Street estimates, were overshadowed by the dimmed outlook. CEO John Flannery's ambitious revitalisation plan, unveiled last month, aims to narrow focus, improve performance, and exit health-care equipment and oil and gas. Despite a narrowed profit margin in the aviation division, the company still expects annual earnings of $1 to $1.07 a share, but analysts are more pessimistic, predicting 95 cents.

site_title: Teamwork wins
summary: The 2018 FIFA World Cup showcased the importance of teamwork and collaboration in achieving success. Key highlights include France's victory, led by a strong coach who emphasized teamwork over individual stardom, and Croatia's resilient performance despite being considered underdogs. Other successful teams, such as Belgium and England, demonstrated the value of squad depth, youth, and experience. The tournament also highlighted the need for a strong team dynamic, leadership, and a clear vision. Companies can learn from these lessons, including the importance of embracing diversity, building a robust talent pipeline, and fostering a culture of resilience and collaboration.

site_title: Deutsche Bank owners seek restructuring details
summary: Deutsche Bank's CEO, Christian Sewing, is expected to report on a turnaround plan for the German lender, but investors are pushing for more specifics on scaling back the investment bank. Four top investors have requested details on the plan, with two stating that more radical measures are needed. Sewing is set to report second-quarter earnings on Wednesday. The investors' demands come as the bank faces pressure from a slowing economy and increasing competition.

site_title: France resists as US courts allies with free trade offers at G-20
summary: The US is seeking to woo European and Japanese allies with free trade deals to gain leverage in the escalating tariff war with China, but France is resisting, citing the need for the US to withdraw steel and aluminum tariffs and stand down on a car tariff threat. US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin proposed a free trade agreement, but French Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire said the EU would not consider talks unless the US drops its tariffs. The IMF warned that existing trade restrictions would reduce global output by 0.5%, and the G-20 meeting concluded with no firm agreement on trade policy.

site_title: Top Japanese official has no interest in trade deal with just the US
summary: Japan's Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga stated that the country will resist US efforts to create a bilateral free trade agreement unless it harms Japan's national interest. Suga also expressed confidence in Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's re-election bid and his ability to tackle North Korean issues. Japan's economy is expected to face challenges, including a sales tax hike in October 2019 and a potential recession, prompting the government to consider fiscal stimulus measures. Suga emphasized the importance of addressing Japan's concerns over US trade policies, particularly the return to the Trans-Pacific Partnership agreement.

site_title: Hillhouse, Alibaba said to be cornerstone investors in China Tower's IPO
summary: China Tower Corp, a state-owned wireless infrastructure operator, has attracted Hillhouse Capital and a unit of Alibaba Group as cornerstone investors in its planned Hong Kong initial public offering. The deal, valued at about US$8 billion, will see 10 firms, including Hillhouse funds and Taobao China Holding Ltd, buy approximately US$1.4 billion of stock. China Tower is expected to start taking investor orders on Monday. The IPO is part of the company's plan to raise capital and expand its business.

site_title: China's luck on yuan devaluation risks running out on Trump ire
summary: US President Donald Trump criticized China for allegedly manipulating its currency, which has dropped 5% since mid-June, its lowest level in over a year. Trump's comments suggest the US-China trade war is expanding to include currencies. Chinese officials must consider policy measures to support growth amid export headwinds. Analysts warn of dangers of a repeat of 2015 turmoil, urging a shift to fiscal policies. The impact of the yuan's depreciation on markets has been limited, with futures contracts dropping but not significantly affecting overall markets.

site_title: At Sodexo, nobody gets left out
summary: Sodexo's Asia-Pacific chair, Johnpaul Dimech, emphasizes the importance of inclusive hiring practices, stating that workers should not be stereotyped or pigeonholed into job types based on their social groups. The company has integrated employees with disabilities, including those with hearing impairments and Down syndrome, into the workplace. Dimech advocates for a fair and objective recruitment process, with job-related selection criteria, and supports employees with challenges, while also supporting those who work with them. This approach aligns with responsible corporate practice and makes good business sense.

site_title: Amrock's US$706m lawsuit loss draws out surprise whistle blowers
summary: Amrock Inc, a US mortgage-lending firm, lost a $706 million jury verdict against data-analytics firm HouseCanary Inc. However, Amrock has since uncovered "bombshell" evidence of fraud from two former HouseCanary employees who blew the whistle after the verdict. The whistleblowers claim HouseCanary's technology was not proprietary and was licensed by a third party, contradicting Amrock's allegations. The whistleblowers' sworn declarations have been filed in court, potentially changing the outcome of the case.

site_title: Highlights from the G-20 summit in Buenos Aires this weekend
summary: Finance ministers and central bankers from the top 20 economies met in Buenos Aires, addressing concerns over a trade war and currency markets. US President Trump's comments on a stronger dollar and rising interest rates were met with support from Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and International Monetary Fund chief Cristine Lagarde, who emphasized central bank independence. The G-20 statement noted global growth is strong but less synchronized, facing risks from trade tensions and capital outflows. A unified strategy on digital currencies was not agreed upon, with limited details on regulation.

site_title: Scrap subways to make way for driverless cars?
summary: Cities considering investing in driverless cars risk mortgaging the present for a future fantasy, warns transportation experts. While autonomous vehicles promise to outperform buses, cost less than Uber, and travel faster than cars in traffic, they may not be ready to replace traditional transit systems for decades. Experts caution that investing in driverless cars could lead to the abandonment of essential infrastructure, such as subways, and hinder the development of more efficient and effective public transportation systems.

site_title: Oregon weighs record bond for housing as real estate prices jump
summary: Oregon's Metro agency is proposing a record-breaking $653 million bond to build and renovate housing for people priced out of the local real estate market. The measure would expand Metro's responsibilities, including land use, transportation, and waste management, and is aimed at addressing homelessness in the region. If approved, the bond would create homes for 7,500 people, with the potential to serve up to 12,000. The average homeowner would pay $5 per month to cover the added debt, with funds distributed to counties based on assessed value.

site_title: BOJ ponders how to keep policy sustainable, reduce side effects
summary: The Bank of Japan is considering ways to sustain its stimulus program while minimizing its negative effects on markets and banks. The July 31 policy announcement may see interest rates allowed to rise naturally, no change, or a statement on considering side effects. This speculation led to a decline in Japanese government bond futures. The BOJ aims to balance economic growth with market stability, as China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: French IT services group Atos to buy Syntel of US
summary: Atos, a French IT services group, has agreed to acquire US-based Syntel in a deal valued at around $3.4 billion. The acquisition aims to significantly expand Atos' presence in North America. Syntel generated $924 million in revenue in 2017, with 89% coming from North America, and employs 23,000 engineers globally. The deal is expected to bring $120 million in annual cost benefits and create cross-selling opportunities between the two companies. The acquisition is a major step in Atos' strategy to reach a global scale.

site_title: Singapore-listed firms on share buyback spree in H1 2018
summary: In the first half of 2018, Singapore-listed firms significantly increased their share buybacks amid a volatile trading environment, driven by trade tensions and rising interest rates. Buybacks quadrupled to S$839 million, surpassing the full-year total of S$425 million in 2017. The trend is expected to continue, with market watchers citing sustained growth and a favorable market environment. This uptrend is seen as a bullish signal for the local market, indicating companies' confidence in their prospects.

site_title: Baltimore sues oil and gas companies over catastrophic climate change
summary: Baltimore has filed a lawsuit against 26 oil and gas companies, including BP, Chevron, and Exxon Mobil, for their role in catastrophic climate change. The city alleges the companies knowingly contributed to rising sea levels and damages, despite research linking their production to these effects. The lawsuit seeks unspecified damages and penalties. The move comes after a US judge dismissed a similar suit by New York City, citing federal regulation and foreign policy.

site_title: Trade tensions, greenback to guide local direction
summary: Trade tensions and the US dollar's strength are expected to weigh on Singapore markets this week. The US may open a new front in trade disputes, potentially sparking a currency war, which could lead to the US dollar falling further against the Singapore dollar. Key events include the announcement of Singapore's June consumer price index and industrial production numbers, as well as the release of US GDP figures and corporate earnings reports. The Singapore dollar may fall further against the greenback, but analysts believe it will be limited by the Monetary Authority's policy of mild appreciation.

site_title: Coworking surge in Manhattan raises asset-liability quandary
summary: Manhattan's coworking industry is experiencing a surge, with 1.45 million square feet of office space leased in the first half of 2018, accounting for 8.1% of all new leases. This growth raises concerns about the mismatch between assets and liabilities, as coworking firms often sign short-term contracts while assuming leases of 10 years or more. The industry's shift towards flexible leasing and "plug and play" units is driving demand, but landlords are resistant to short-term contracts, creating a challenge for coworking operators and potentially impacting the market.

site_title: China backs off top-down approach to steel output cuts
summary: China is shifting away from a one-size-fits-all approach to reducing steel output to combat pollution, with production cuts varying from mill to mill next autumn and winter. The country's environmental ministry official stated this change in approach comes after the state council granted 82 cities the ability to draw up their own plans for anti-smog measures. This move is part of China's efforts to address pollution concerns without overly impacting the steel industry. The changes aim to balance economic and environmental goals.

site_title: No room for shelter amid glass towers
summary: New York City's Department of Homeless Services plans to open a men's shelter on West 58th Street, despite opposition from residents who fear it will disrupt the area's upscale neighborhood. The shelter, which will provide job-training services and security, is part of a city plan to establish 90 new shelters across the city. Critics argue that the shelter will exacerbate social issues and threaten the local tourist industry. A social service agency, Win, has successfully implemented shelters in other areas, demonstrating that they can improve residents' quality of life without compromising safety.

site_title: Brexit chief says government must prepare for no deal
summary: Britain's new Brexit secretary, Dominic Raab, says the government must prepare for a no-deal outcome, with planning underway in "every aspect" to ensure the country is ready. He believes a no-deal scenario would not be catastrophic, but warned that the UK would not pay the £39 billion divorce bill to the EU if an agreement cannot be reached. The comments come as the Brexit process continues to divide the country and UK Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservative Party, with some members pushing for a clean break with the EU.

site_title: 1MDB-tainted Falcon bank taps new market in Switzerland's 'Crypto Valley'
summary: Falcon Private Bank, backed by Abu Dhabi, has entered the crypto finance market in Switzerland's "Crypto Valley," a move seen as a response to the bank's tarnished reputation due to its involvement in the 1MDB scandal. Falcon is offering investment strategy and brokerage services, employing a firm to vet new clients and sharing its business plan with Swiss regulators. This is a rare move among Swiss banks, which have been cautious about crypto finance. Liechtenstein's Bank Frick is also expanding its crypto offerings, aiming to capitalize on pent-up demand and turn its troubled past into a new business opportunity.

site_title: Trump says NFL anthem protesters shouldn't be paid
summary: US President Donald Trump tweeted that NFL players who protest during the national anthem should not be paid, despite the league's decision to hold off on enforcing a new policy. The NFL Players' Association had filed a grievance, arguing the policy was "inconsistent with the collective bargaining agreement and infringes on player rights." Trump's comments come as the league and union are in confidential talks to resolve the issue, with some team owners expressing opposition to the new policy.

site_title: Smoked out: Town revered for its hams is losing a slice of its history
summary: Smithfield, Virginia, a town famous for its hams, is facing a significant loss as the last smokehouse that produces the area's signature product, the genuine Smithfield ham, is set to close. The town's history and identity are deeply tied to pork products, with the Queen of England reportedly ordering a Smithfield ham annually. The smokehouse, which has been in operation for over 50 years, will no longer produce hams, leaving local producers to carry on the tradition. The town's reliance on Smithfield hams has created a sense of community, with many residents and businesses tied to the iconic product.

site_title: Currency war erupts, threatening to ripple across global markets
summary: US President Donald Trump accuses China and the European Union of manipulating their currencies and interest rates, sparking a currency war that could ripple across global markets. The yuan has plummeted to its lowest level in a year, while the euro has also declined. The consequences of this escalation could be dire, with potential collateral damage in equities, oil, and emerging-market assets. Analysts warn of a broad-based unravelling of global trade and currency cooperation, with the US dollar likely to suffer further.

site_title: Interviewing for a finance position
summary: A finance professional shares insights from a recent interview process, highlighting the gap between job applicants' expectations and employers' expectations. Key takeaways include: finance roles often require a work-life imbalance, humility, and a willingness to learn. Applicants should focus on what they can contribute to an employer, rather than just what they can gain. Making a personal commitment to deliver more value to employers and customers can set oneself apart from others.

site_title: China's push to export traditional medicine may doom the dwindling pangolin
summary: China's push to export traditional medicine, fueled by the demand for pangolin scales, threatens the extinction of the pangolin, the world's most trafficked mammal. A million pangolins are believed to have been poached in just a decade, mainly to supply China's booming market. Conservation groups are trying to reduce demand by educating people about the dangers of pangolin consumption and promoting alternative treatments. Despite international trade bans, China's ports continue to seize large quantities of pangolin scales, raising concerns that the animal may face extinction.

site_title: US groups argue over what can or cannot be called 'milk'
summary: The US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) is considering whether plant-based alternatives to milk can be labeled as "milk". The National Milk Producers Federation (NMPF) claims the FDA has already answered "no", while the Plant Based Foods Association (PBFA) believes the agency is open to a "maybe". This debate arises as plant-based milk alternatives gain popularity.

site_title: Singapore listing on the cards for Crown Group's Indonesia business
summary: Crown Group, an Australian property developer, is considering listing its Indonesia business on the Singapore Stock Exchange due to the city-state's easy access to capital sources. The company aims to create a pipeline of $3-4 billion worth of projects, contributing $600-800 million in profit. Crown Group has already invested in a $700 million apartment complex in Jakarta and is in talks with other landowners for future projects. The company believes Indonesia's booming economy and huge market size will drive demand for its middle- to upper-market high-rise developments.

site_title: Aramco bid to buy Sabic 'could delay its own IPO'
summary: Saudi Aramco's potential acquisition of a stake in Sabic could delay its own initial public offering (IPO), according to the company's CEO Amin Nasser. The IPO is a key part of Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman's plan to diversify the economy. Preparations for the IPO have slowed, and the acquisition could impact the timeline.

images.alt_text: Aramco CEO Amin Nasser says buying a stake in a petrochemicals company would make the state oil giant Saudi Aramco less vulnerable to price volatility.

site_title: China deleveraging plan may impact S Korea economy
summary: China's deleveraging plan may negatively impact South Korea's economy, according to the Bank of Korea. The plan could reduce South Korea's GDP growth by 0.3 percentage point in 2018 and 1.2 percentage point in 2020 due to reduced financial risks. China's plan to curb financial risks, including shadow banking and corporate debts, may also affect South Korean companies that have invested in Chinese debt. While the impact appears to be lower than in other countries, the Bank of Korea warns that the plan is a "natural procedure" of restructuring zombie firms.

site_title: Nasa prepares to fly probe into Sun's scorching atmosphere
summary: NASA is preparing to launch the Parker Solar Probe, a robotic spacecraft that will fly closer to the Sun than any other spacecraft, reaching 6.1 million km from the solar surface. The seven-year mission aims to study the solar corona, the outermost part of the Sun's atmosphere, and the solar wind. The probe will be the smallest car-sized spacecraft to venture into the Sun's atmosphere, enduring extreme heat to gather data on the Sun's behavior and its impact on the solar system. The launch is slated for August 6.

site_title: Dubai's recipe for economic success takes a beating
summary: Dubai's economic growth is slowing, with luxury apartment rents down 15% from last year and the stock market down 13% this year. The city's traditional growth engines, such as tourism and business services, are losing steam. Passenger traffic through Dubai's international airport has fallen to near zero, and the city's dominance as a travel hub is being challenged by long-range aircraft. Economists see little risk of another financial crisis, but the emirate faces structural challenges, including a tough geopolitical environment and increased competition from neighboring countries.

images.alt_text: Dubai is facing structural challenges including an increasingly tough geopolitical environment.

site_title: A homecoming for Hong Lai Huat in name and substance
summary: Hong Lai Huat Group, a Singaporean real estate developer, is poised to return to the local property market after 10 years of diversifying into agriculture in Cambodia. The company, founded by CEO Johnny Ong, has successfully cultivated cassava on 10,000 hectares of land and developed a luxury housing brand, Camhomes, with a mixed development project in Sihanoukville. Hong Lai Huat plans to focus on the middle-end market in Singapore and explore opportunities in Thailand, with no intention of competing with luxury developers. The company is celebrating its 30th anniversary and has rebranded itself as HLH Group to reflect its heritage.

images.alt_text: "We want to let all the people know that we are Hong Lai Huat, we are back and we want to contribute to the country," says CEO Johnny Ong.

site_title: Trump blasts Fed, China and Europe for putting US economy at a disadvantage
summary: President Donald Trump accused China and the European Union of manipulating their currencies to gain a trade advantage, while also criticizing the Federal Reserve for raising interest rates. Trump claims the Fed's actions are putting the US economy at a disadvantage, despite his own policies, such as the $1.5 trillion tax cut, fueling a booming economy. The US dollar fell sharply after Trump's comments, while Treasury bond yields rose and gold prices increased. Trump vowed to impose tariffs on $500 billion worth of Chinese imports, escalating his trade fight with China.

site_title: New York City sues Airbnb to force compliance with subpoena
summary: New York City is suing Airbnb to force compliance with a subpoena for information about its listings, citing the company's refusal to cooperate with an investigation into illegal short-term rentals. The city claims Airbnb is "largely refusing to cooperate" and is seeking records of listings, hosts, and guests in buildings where units have been advertised on a "nearly non-stop" basis. The lawsuit comes amid a long-standing battle between the city and Airbnb over the impact of short-term rentals on housing supply and rising rents.

site_title: Fiat Chrysler names Jeep boss new CEO
summary: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles (FCA) named Mike Manley, the Jeep division boss, as its new CEO, effective immediately. He will lead the company's mid-term strategy, outlined by outgoing CEO Sergio Marchionne, who is seriously ill after surgery. Marchionne, who rescued FCA from bankruptcy in 2004, will step down as CEO and chairman of Ferrari and CNH Industrial, with John Elkann taking over as Ferrari chairman and Louis Camilleri as CEO. Manley will push ahead with the planned strategy, which includes cost-cutting measures and investments in electrified and autonomous vehicles.

site_title: Canadians feel little pain of rate hikes - so far
summary: Canada's consumers are experiencing minimal impact from the Bank of Canada's four recent rate hikes, with retail sales rising 2.0% in May and expected to expand at an annualized 4% pace in Q2, defying predictions of a downturn. Most Canadians are escaping higher mortgage costs, while others are being priced out of home buying. Meanwhile, income gains are helping to offset the effects of the rate hikes, suggesting that consumers are not feeling the pain of the interest rate increases.

site_title: Keppel O&M secures two contracts for about S$70 million
summary: Keppel O&M secures two contracts worth about S$70 million. In Brazil, Keppel FELS Brasil will fabricate and integrate the FPSO Carioca MV30's topside module. In Singapore, Keppel Shipyard will convert an LNG carrier to an FSRU for a global operator. These collaborations are Keppel FELS Brasil's sixth FPSO project with MODEC and Keppel Shipyard's first FSRU conversion.

site_title: Big Pharma changes spending amid pressure to charge less
summary: Major US pharmaceutical companies reduced lobbying spending in the second quarter of 2018, with Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America spending $5.54 million, down 7.7% from last year. Companies including Johnson & Johnson and Bayer Corp decreased their spending amid President Trump's campaign to lower drug costs. Pfizer's lobbying spending increased by 2.1%, while Merck & Co decreased by 57.9%. The moves come as the Trump administration releases plans to lower prices and out-of-pocket costs through government health programs and incentives for drug-makers.

site_title: Shell in talks to sell US$2b Nigeria oil assets
summary: Royal Dutch Shell Plc is in talks to sell two Nigerian oil licenses worth US$2 billion to Heirs Holdings Ltd, a company run by Nigerian tycoon Tony Elumelu. The sale would exit Shell's exposure in a region of Nigeria plagued by environmental and human rights controversies. The company has sold billions of dollars of Niger Delta assets in the past decade amid local opposition and civil conflict. No deal has been reached, and discussions have been advanced and run into hurdles.

site_title: Got US$250? You can go to Sean Spicer's book party
summary: Former White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer is hosting two book parties to promote his memoir "The Briefing," with ticket prices ranging from $250 for "Assistant Press Secretary" access to $1,000 for "Press Secretary" access. The events will include VIP receptions and signed books. Spicer has also secured a spot as an unpaid pundit on Fox News and is pitching a potential talk show. The book, which characterizes President Trump as a "unicorn riding a unicorn over a rainbow," aims to answer questions about Spicer's experience and provide context for his time in the White House.

site_title: Keppel O&M wins two contracts worth S$70m
summary: Keppel Offshore & Marine (Keppel O&M) secured two contracts worth approximately S$70 million. In Brazil, Keppel FELS Brasil will fabricate the topside module for the FPSO Carioca MV30, while in Singapore, Keppel Shipyard will convert a LNG carrier to an FSRU. The FPSO is expected to process 180,000 barrels of crude oil per day and the FSRU will have a capacity to re-gasify up to 750 million metric standard cubic feet of natural gas per day. The contracts are not expected to impact Keppel Corp's net tangible assets or earnings per share for the current financial year.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary:

The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report covers the tanker and dry bulk market for the week of July 15-21. Tanker rates eased down a point to WS 45.5/46 for VLCCs to China, while Suezmax rates remained steady at WS 85 for 135,000mt. Aframax rates dropped from low WS 140s to WS 120, and Panamax rates nudged up modestly from WS 97.25 to WS 100s. Clean vessel rates hovered between WS 102.5/105 for 75,000mt. The Capesize market saw rates slip to near $8.00s for late July-early August cargoes, but owners are pushing for higher rates.

site_title: Trump's tariffs risk harming US, warn German industrialists
summary: US President Donald Trump's tariffs on steel and aluminum imports from the EU, Canada, and Mexico pose a risk to the US economy, warn German industrialists. The tariffs, imposed on June 1, have already had a significant impact, with estimated losses of over $9.6 billion. German industry groups, including the BDI and DIHK, urge US President Trump to reconsider extending tariffs to EU cars and car parts, which could harm the German economy and the transatlantic relationship. EU officials downplay the possibility of a new trade plan, and German Economy Minister Peter Altmaier hopes for a solution that preserves open markets and low tariffs.

site_title: Trump ups ante ahead of G20 discussions on global trade tensions
summary: US President Donald Trump is set to shape discussions on global trade tensions at the Group of 20 finance ministers' meeting in Buenos Aires. Trump's protectionist policies have led to tariffs on steel and aluminum, angering allies like the EU, Canada, and Mexico. China will be a key topic, with Trump threatening to impose tariffs on the country's $500 billion in imports. The US Treasury Secretary has vowed to respond to concerns on US trade policies, while the EU has warned of a "very serious" situation, ready to respond to further excises.

site_title: Taylor Swift in all-star film version of Cats: reports
summary: Taylor Swift will star in the all-star film version of the musical Cats, alongside Jennifer Hudson, alongside James Corden and Ian McKellen. The movie is being directed by Tom Hooper, who previously directed Les Miserables and The King's Speech. The film adaptation of Cats, composed by Andrew Lloyd Webber, will feature classic musical ballad "Memory" and is based on TS Eliot's poems. No release date has been announced for the film.

site_title: He's supposed to marry a Japanese princess. Just don't call him her fiancé.
summary: Kei Komuro, a paralegal, is the fiancé of Princess Mako of Japan, but Fordham University Law School recently removed the term "fiancé" from a news release after the Imperial Household Agency objected, citing that the betrothal ceremony has not yet been held. The couple's relationship has been scrutinized due to tabloid reports on Mr. Komuro's mother borrowing money and not repaying it. The agency has postponed the wedding to 2020 and indefinitely delayed a formal royal engagement ceremony, fueling speculation about the relationship's future.

site_title: EU demands greater clarity from Theresa May on her Brexit blueprint
summary: The European Union's top negotiator Michel Barnier expressed doubts over Britain's new Brexit blueprint, calling for clarity on issues such as the Irish border and a free trade agreement. Barnier welcomed some points in the proposal, including plans for a free trade agreement, but emphasized the need for answers on EU guidelines and the integrity of the single market. The EU wants to settle outstanding issues before striking a Brexit divorce deal, with 13 weeks left before Britain's departure on March 30.

site_title: Disappointing earnings, trade tensions weigh on European shares
summary: European shares fell on Friday as disappointing earnings updates and trade tensions weighed on the market. Auto stocks, particularly, were hit hard, down 2.1% due to US President Donald Trump's threat to slap tariffs on $500 billion of imported goods from China. The broader Stoxx 600 fell 0.15%, with some sectors, like healthcare and consumer staples, showing gains. Disappointing earnings from paper maker Stora Enso and Swedish builder Skanska also contributed to the decline.

site_title: SMRT to face S$1.9m in fines for 2 incidents in 2016 and 2017
summary: SMRT, Singapore's rail operator, will face fines totaling S$1.9 million for two incidents in 2016 and 2017. The other incident involved tunnel flooding, affecting 230,000 passengers. The Land Transport Authority (LTA) attributed the lapses to inadequate safety measures and supervision of MRT operations. The fines stem from investigations into these incidents, highlighting concerns over safety and employee welfare within SMRT.

site_title: Amazon, Toyota, Alcoa and others working to counter Trump's tariff plans
summary: US companies including Amazon, Toyota, and Alcoa are working to counter the Trump administration's trade policies and potential tariffs. They aim to avoid confrontation with President Trump while exerting influence to dissuade him from introducing tariffs on a wide range of imports. Companies are exploring advertising campaigns and lobbying efforts, with some already hiring former Trump administration officials to advocate for their interests. The goal is to mitigate the impact of tariffs on their businesses, particularly in the tech and automotive sectors.

site_title: 'Contentious' Duterte, Philippines' inflation worry for Moody's
summary: Moody's Investors Service maintained the Philippines' investment-grade rating with a stable outlook, citing robust economic growth and improving fiscal numbers. However, the agency warned of threats from elevated inflation and potential shifts in government structure, including a proposed federal form of government. The country's inflation rate reached 5.2% in June, and Moody's expects it to quicken to 5.3% this month. The agency also flagged concerns over the rule of law, corruption, and the impact of a potential federal shift on public finances.

site_title: Japan's inflation inches higher in June due to energy costs
summary: Japan's inflation rose 0.8% in June, primarily driven by higher energy costs, but core consumer prices remain below the 2% target. The Bank of Japan's yield-curve control programme has eased monetary policy, despite concerns that inflation momentum has not been maintained. Experts believe the BOJ can afford to be patient, citing weak inflation expectations and a tightening labor market. Higher oil prices are expected to aid Japan's inflation, but a potential increase in petrol prices could impact consumers.

site_title: Judge praises US efforts in reuniting migrant families
summary: A federal judge praised the US government's efforts in reuniting 2,500 migrant children separated from their parents at the US-Mexico border. site_title: US stocks: Wall Street slips as trade worries dampen upbeat earnings
summary: US stocks slipped on Friday as escalating trade anxieties driven by President Trump's tariff threats against China offset robust earnings led by Microsoft. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 rose for the third consecutive week, while Microsoft's stock hit a record high after beating earnings expectations. However, the Nasdaq Composite dropped, and long-dated US government bond yields rose due to worries about the Fed's interest rate hikes. Analysts remain divided on the impact of the trade dispute, with some predicting a global recession and others believing the president's comments are overreacted.

site_title: Young voters with smartphones may prove to be a bane for Pakistani politicians
summary: Young voters in Pakistan, many of whom are smartphone-savvy and active on social media, are increasingly holding elected representatives accountable for their actions. Analysts predict that this could lead to higher voter turnout among the under-35 demographic, potentially strengthening trust in the democratic system.

site_title: Oil posts third weekly drop as Trump issues new trade threats
summary: Oil prices posted a third weekly loss, falling 4.2% at the start of the week, as concerns over escalating US-China trade tensions and a weakening US dollar weighed on the market. Saudi Arabia's reassurances that it won't flood the global market failed to offset the decline. President Trump threatened to impose tariffs on $500 billion, citing currency manipulation by China and the EU. Oil futures pared gains on Friday, with West Texas Intermediate crude closing at $70.46 a barrel.

site_title: US lawmakers cut anti-ZTE measure from defense bill
summary: US lawmakers have cut measures from a defense bill that would have reinstated sanctions on China's ZTE Corp, abandoning an attempt to punish the company for illegally shipping US products to Iran and North Korea. site_title: SembMarine posts S$55.62m Q2 net loss
summary: SembMarine posted a net loss of S$55.62 million for the second quarter due to a realized loss from the sale of a semi-submersible rig and lower business volume. site_title: US housing starts hit 9-month low in June, permits drop
summary: US housing starts declined 12.3% to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.173 million units in June, the lowest level since September 2017. Permits also dropped 2.2% to a rate of 1.273 million units, marking the third consecutive month of decline. Single-family homebuilding decreased 9.1% to 858,000 units, while multi-family housing starts plunged 19.8% to 315,000 units. Economists attribute the decline to rising construction costs, land and labor shortages, and moderate wage growth.

site_title: Harry Potter star Tom Felton in new YouTube show

site_title: CapitaMall Trust ups Q2 DPU after sale of Sembawang mall

site_title: SingHealth hack 'worrying' for Singapore but govt response lauded

site_title: Daintree Residence to launch for sale on July 28

site_title: Dinner party guide to the climate change debate
summary: Climate change has become a contentious topic at dinner parties, with some people adopting a binary straitjacket of enlightened affirmation or "anti-science" denial. Extreme weather events are often linked to climate change, but there is limited evidence of a direct causal link. Directed by Shane Black, the movie is a modern take on the 1987 blockbuster, with a diverse ensemble cast. The film's plot sees the alien universe's most lethal hunters returning to Earth, deadlier than ever, after being bested twice by humans. The movie promises a new level of brutality and efficiency in the alien's killing style, with the suburbs serving as the main battleground. The film is set to release on September 14.

site_title: Trump "ready to go" with US$500 billion in tariffs on all China imports
summary: US President Donald Trump announced plans to impose $500 billion in tariffs on Chinese imports, citing unfair trade practices. The move comes after a deepening trade impasse between the two nations. China has accused the US of making false accusations and has vowed to retaliate. The tariffs, which would be equivalent to last year's Chinese imports, were authorized after an investigation found China was violating intellectual property rules. The announcement led to a drop in US equity futures and European stocks.

site_title: SMRT to be fined S$1.9m for deaths of two trainees, tunnel flooding incident
summary: SMRT, a Singaporean rail operator, has been fined S$1.9 million for two incidents, including the 2016 death of two trainees and the October tunnel flooding incident that affected 231,000 passengers. The Land Transport Authority found that SMRT failed to comply with operating procedures and inadequate supervision led to the accidents. The operator's safety and health measures were also deemed insufficient, resulting in the fines.

site_title: Manhattan's commercial-property sales are stirring from a 2-year slump
summary: Manhattan's commercial property sales have rebounded after a 2-year slump, with $22.5 billion in deals completed in the first half of 2018, a 34% increase from the same period last year. This marks a significant turnaround from the 50% decline in transaction volume from 2015 levels. The recovery is attributed to buyers and sellers slowly coming to terms, with concerns over rising interest rates and foreign buyer pullback contributing to the slowdown. The pace of deals is still behind the record levels of 2015.

site_title: Merkel to fight Trump over auto tariffs that could derail trade
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel vowed to continue lobbying US President Donald Trump to avoid auto tariffs, which could escalate a trade war and threaten the global economy. Merkel described the situation as a "serious danger for the prosperity of many in the world" and warned of retaliation. The US and EU are set to meet next week, with the EU proposing a discussion process to avert the threat, and Merkel reiterated her commitment to multilateralism and avoiding harm to both sides.

images.alt_text: German Chancellor Angela Merkel vowed to keep lobbying President Donald Trump to head off tariffs on US auto imports, which could escalate a trade war and threaten the global economy.

site_title: UK stock market isn't paying attention to Brexit chatter
summary: The UK stock market has largely ignored Brexit chatter, outperforming the euro area over the past year. Despite government and corporate objections to a potential no-deal Brexit, domestic investors have been attracted to the market due to higher oil prices and solid growth in earnings and the global economy. Key to maintaining the market's strength is a favourable Brexit outcome. Foreign investors remain cautious, with allocations to British stocks at a net 18% underweight, the highest reading in over two years.

site_title: Pinetree Condominium at Balmoral Park up for collective sale with S$148m reserve price
summary: The Pinetree Condominium in Balmoral Park has been put up for collective sale with a reserve price of S$148 million. If sold, each owner will receive between S$2.57 million to S$4.09 million. The 50-unit freehold development sits on 41,276 sq ft of land, zoned for residential use, and can be redeveloped into a 12-storey project with 75 apartments. The tender for the site closes on Aug 30.

site_title: Former South Korean president Park Geun-hye handed another 8 years in jail
summary: Former South Korean President Park Geun-hye was sentenced to an additional 8 years in prison, bringing her total sentence to 24 years, for causing loss of government funds and interfering in a 2016 parliamentary election. This ruling was handed down after a court found her guilty on these charges.

site_title: Australian shares propped up by financials amid global trade tensions; NZ up
summary: Australian shares rose 0.37% to 6,285.9 on Friday, driven by gains in financials, despite concerns over escalating global trade tensions and a volatile Chinese yuan. The S&P/ASX 200 index ended the week 0.3% higher, with the main financial index climbing 0.5%. New Zealand's benchmark index also ended the week 0.4% higher, reversing earlier losses.

site_title: Russian banks, pension funds buy government bonds after market sell-off
summary: Russian banks and pension funds bought government bonds after a sell-off in the Russian bond market, sparked by fears of sanctions and the central bank's rate-cut cycle ending. Foreigners sold 6.9 percentage points of their holdings in Russian government bonds, from 34.5% to 27.6%, in June. Non-state pension funds, mostly local market participants, bought the bonds at attractive prices, increasing their holdings. Yields in Russian bonds rose to 7.97% in June, their highest since 2017, after the central bank's rate-cut cycle ended and US sanctions were imposed.

site_title: Luxury goods group Hermes posts higher Q2 sales
summary: Hermes International reported a 7.2% increase in Q2 sales to 1.46 billion euros, exceeding analyst expectations of a 10% increase. Strong demand in China, driven by a double-digit growth rate, contributed to the sales boost. The company expects operating profitability in the first half of the year to be close to its record level in 2017.

site_title: Singapore shares end higher on Friday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.6% to 3,297.83, driven by gains from Genting Singapore and Ezion Holdings. About 1.39 billion shares worth S$1.01 billion changed hands, with 239 gainers out of 145 losers. The market awaits GDP data and US-EU trade talks, which may influence investor sentiment.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares close higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed higher on Friday, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.76% to 28,224.48, driven by a weak yuan currency defying US President Trump's attacks on a strong dollar. Chinese shares also ended above water for the first time this week, with the Shanghai Composite Index up 2.05% and the Shenzhen Composite Index up 1.12%. The gains followed a strong rally in Singapore and Asia, with investors brushing off new Trump threats.

site_title: Jakarta covers up 'stinky, toxic' river near Asian Games village
summary: Indonesian authorities have covered a toxic and foul-smelling river near the Asian Games athletes' village in Jakarta with black nylon mesh to conceal its appearance. The 730-meter-long "Black River" will be hidden from view to minimize its impact on the event, which is being held from August 18 to September 2. The move aims to address the city's notorious traffic congestion and prepare venues before the Games. Authorities are also using cutting-edge waste technology to break down organic material and neutralize chemicals in the river, which is a major contributor to annual flooding during the rainy season.

site_title: Airbus renews attempt to sell parts maker PFW Aerospace -sources
summary: Airbus is attempting to sell parts maker PFW Aerospace for 500-600 million euros, a move seen as a temporary measure to ease supply chain concerns. The German company was acquired by Airbus in 2011 to prevent insolvency. After failing to sell the supplier in 2015, Airbus is launching a new auction, with investment bank Lazard involved. The planned divestiture comes amid global trade tensions and geopolitical uncertainty affecting the aviation industry.

site_title: Chip Eng Seng, Lum Chang announce new business acquisitions
summary: Chip Eng Seng and Lum Chang have announced new business acquisitions. Chip Eng Seng acquired 70% of White Lodge Education Group Services for S$13.3 million, while Lum Chang acquired a 50% stake in Daehan Rehabilitation Services, with plans to expand its healthcare services in Malaysia. Both companies expect the investments to be fruitful long-term opportunities.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Friday afternoon at 3,291.13, up 0.4% on day
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.4% on Friday to 3,291.13, driven by gains in Ezion Holdings and Genting Singapore. The Straits Times Index saw 181 gainers for every 129 losers, with 707.4 million shares changing hands worth S$477.6 million. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and despite US trade uncertainty.

site_title: Foreland Fabrictech's independent directors quit, leaving behind a one-man board
summary: Foreland Fabrictech Holdings has lost all of its independent directors, with only executive chairman Yang Meng Yang remaining on the board. Three directors, Seah Chee Wei, Wu Geng, and Lim Aik Bin, resigned to pursue other interests, citing a need to reconstitute the board to comply with Singapore regulations. The company faces multiple challenges, including a Chinese court case from 2013 and a legal dispute involving former executive chairman Tsoi Kin Chit, whom it accused of going rogue with a subsidiary in China.

site_title: GE beats profit estimates as aviation, health buoy results
summary: General Electric (GE) beat profit estimates for the second consecutive quarter, driven by strong demand for aviation and healthcare equipment. The company maintained its 2018 profit forecast and announced plans to implement a turnaround strategy, aiming to improve operating results and increase shareholder value. Adjusted profit fell to 19 cents a share, while sales rose 3.5% to $30.1 billion. GE's shares advanced less than 1% to $13.85, marking the first quarterly gain since 2016. The company also made progress on its restructuring efforts, including agreements to merge its locomotive unit with Wabtec Corp and sell its industrial gas-engine business.

site_title: EU drug regulators step up work to prepare for 'no deal' Brexit
summary: European Union regulators are hiring extra staff and increasing workload to prepare for a potential 'no-deal' Brexit, which would disrupt the EU's medicines supervision system. The UK's exit from the EU is eight months away, but British experts are already stopping new projects and handing over existing work to other countries. This leaves a significant gap, as the UK carries out around a fifth of the work for the European Medicines Agency. Regulators are exploring ways to perform more drug assessment work by multinational teams to mitigate the impact of the Brexit-induced disruption.

site_title: Facebook faces delay to WhatsApp payments in India
summary: India's Ministry of Electronics and Information Technology is delaying the nationwide launch of WhatsApp's payment service due to concerns over user data storage and compliance with regulations. The delay comes amid controversy over lynchings and fake news on the platform. WhatsApp has been asked to provide more details about its payments system and confirm compliance with the National Payments Corporation of India's requirements. The delay could cost Facebook-owned WhatsApp, which faces rising competition from local and global rivals, and may hinder its ability to roll out improvements based on user feedback.

images.alt_text: India's government is holding up Facebook Inc's plans for a nationwide launch of its WhatsApp payments service over concerns about how users' data will be stored and other issues.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Friday; STI up 0.4% to 3,289.79
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.4% to 3,289.79 on Friday, driven by a gain of 0.95% for CapitaLand and 0.61% for Singtel. Gainers outnumbered losers 64 to 36, with 22.3 million shares changing hands. The Straits Times Index moved up 12.21 points.

site_title: Chinese yuan defies Trump comments, continues slide
summary: The Chinese yuan continued its decline, falling to 6.7943 per dollar by late morning, despite US President Donald Trump's comments criticizing a strong dollar. Analysts say the yuan's slide helps China in its trade dispute with the US, aiding exporters with higher US tariffs. The yuan has fallen nearly 10% since mid-April, with China expected to shift to looser monetary policy to shield its economy. Beijing may issue verbal support to maintain financial stability.

site_title: Europe: Disappointing earnings, trade tensions send European shares south
summary: European shares fell 0.1% on Friday amid disappointing earnings and rising trade tensions. Autos stocks declined 1.1% due to US tariff threats, while financials fell 0.1% due to souring US-China relations. Several companies reported profit warnings, including Stora Enso, UPM-Kymmene, and Beazley. In contrast, healthcare and consumer staples sectors gained. The decline in European shares follows a selloff in the Chinese yuan and US stock markets overnight.

site_title: Malaysia cuts 2018 growth projection to 5% as it braces for trade war fallout
summary: Malaysia has cut its 2018 economic growth projection to 5% due to the potential fallout from a brewing trade war. Finance Minister Lim Guan Eng attributed the downgrade to the country's reliance on exports and the impact of global economic slowdown. Despite this, Lim expressed optimism about opportunities for Malaysia, citing its role as a trans-shipment point and neutral country in trade disputes. The government is also focusing on reducing debt and meeting fiscal deficit targets, with a debt burden exceeding RM1 trillion.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: A cyber attack on SingHealth, Singapore's largest healthcare institution, resulted in the theft of records from 1.5 million patients, including Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong. SMRT was fined $1.9 million for its role in two trainee deaths and a tunnel flooding incident. The Pinetree Condominium is up for collective sale with a reserve price of $148 million. Meanwhile, Keppel Corp maintained a "buy" rating, and Golden Springs sold a 75% stake in a Singapore animal feed producer to Aboitiz unit.

images.alt_text: Singapore's largest group of healthcare institutions which include Singapore General Hospital and KK Women's and Children's Hospital - has been the target of a cyber attack said to be the most serious breach of personal data in Singapore's history.

site_title: Malaysia to negotiate high-speed rail link deferment with Singapore
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad announced plans to negotiate the deferment of a high-speed rail project with Singapore. The project, which was previously set to connect Kuala Lumpur and Singapore, will now be put on hold. Mahathir had previously stated that he would cancel the project and discuss compensation with Singapore. The decision is a result of the project's high costs and potential economic impact.

site_title: Rachel Eng resigns from boards of Olam International, StarHub
summary: Veteran corporate lawyer Rachel Eng is stepping down from the boards of Olam International and StarHub, effective July 31. Eng, who is leaving WongPartnership to join PwC, will relinquish her position as an independent non-executive director at Olam and as a non-executive director at StarHub. She expressed pride in her association with Olam and wished the company success in its future endeavors. Olam's chairman Lim Ah Doo thanked Eng for her contributions to the company and wished her well in her new role.

site_title: UBS investors demand a sense of urgency with rivals closing in
summary: UBS investors are urging the bank to demonstrate a sense of urgency as rivals close in, despite the bank's stable performance. Seven years after a turnaround, UBS is trading at a premium to peers, but investors are seeking the next catalyst to drive outperformance. CEO Sergio Ermotti is set to address concerns with a second-quarter earnings report, but investors want to see more details on cost cuts and the merger of wealth-management businesses. The bank's shares have dropped below 15 francs, making them attractive, and some investors question the valuation difference between UBS and its peers.

site_title: Mahathir to revive Malaysia Inc concept
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad announced the revival of the concept of Malaysia Incorporated (Malaysia Inc), a privatisation policy to promote cooperation between the public and private sectors. Introduced in 1981, Malaysia Inc transformed the country into a rapidly industrializing and trading nation. Mahathir stated that reviving the concept will be implemented in the near future to aid in the country's recovery from past mistakes. The government will seek feedback from the business community to ensure the revised concept benefits both the country and businesses.

site_title: Golden Springs sells 75% stake in Singapore animal feed producer Gold Coin to Aboitiz unit
summary: Golden Springs Group sold a 75% stake in Singapore-based animal feed producer Gold Coin to Pilmico International, a subsidiary of Aboitiz Equity Ventures, for $550 million. The deal values Gold Coin at $550 million and adds 3 million metric tons of feed volume to Pilmico's production capacity. Golden Springs will retain a 25% stake in Gold Coin, maintaining a long-term partnership with the Aboitiz Group. The acquisition marks a significant expansion for Pilmico and positions Gold Coin as a leading animal nutrition producer in the Asia Pacific region.

site_title: Asia: Markets fall after Trump criticises Fed rate hikes
summary: Asian markets fell on Friday, tracking a decline on Wall Street, after US President Donald Trump criticized the Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes. Trump broke with tradition by commenting on the Fed's decisions, stating he's not thrilled about rate hikes. The criticism sparked fears of a global trade war, contributing to the market downturn.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rise as China shares rebound; won edges lower
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index rose 0.30% on Friday, snapping a four-session losing streak, after Chinese shares rebounded. The won edged lower, down 0.04% on the onshore platform and 0.9% on a weekly basis. Carmakers, including Hyundai Motor, climbed after the European Union's trade commissioner mentioned a list of US imports to hit if tariffs are imposed. The KOSPI fell 0.9% for the week, its fifth weekly drop in six.

site_title: Malaysian Embassy in Beijing has no information on Jho Low's reported arrest
summary: The Malaysian Embassy in Beijing has no information on the reported arrest of fugitive businessman Jho Low, also known as Low Taek Jho, in China. A report by Sarawak Report claimed Low was being detained pending Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad's planned visit next month, but embassy officials and Inspector-General of Police Mohamad Fuzi Harun could not confirm the report. Low is wanted in a global corruption probe related to the 1MDB state fund.

site_title: Saudis reap benefit from US-China trade war
summary: Saudi Aramco is benefiting from the US-China trade war, with sales of liquefied petroleum gas to China reaching 90% of 2017 levels. The surge in demand is driving up contract prices for Saudi cargoes, benefiting the state-run producer. Buyers in China are seeking alternatives to US LPG due to tariffs targeting billions of dollars worth of products. Saudi shipments to China have risen to 970,000 tons this year, compared to 1.08 million tons in 2017. Higher prices are expected to continue due to healthy demand in China and India for cooking fuel and petrochemicals.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares open marginally higher on Friday
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose marginally on Friday, with the Hang Seng Index increasing 0.1% to 28,039.10, following a decline in US equities due to President Trump's criticism of the Federal Reserve's interest rate policy. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.10% and the Shenzhen Composite Index slipped 0.41%.

site_title: US must wage united battle against vote meddling: top prosecutor
summary: The US Justice Department, led by Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein, has called for a unified government approach to combating foreign meddling in the mid-term elections. This comes as the administration is divided on the issue, with President Trump's Helsinki summit with Russian President Putin seeming to contradict US intelligence agencies' findings on election interference. The report outlines the FBI's efforts to prepare for the 2018 congressional elections, highlighting Russia's daily cyber threats and the need for a strategic approach across all government agencies.

site_title: US intel chief: 'I don't know' what Trump, Putin discussed
summary: US Director of National Intelligence Dan Coats stated that he doesn't know what discussions took place between President Donald Trump and Russian leader Vladimir Putin during their private meeting. Coats acknowledged that the US intelligence community assesses Russia interfered in the 2016 election, contradicting Trump's assertion of Putin's denial. Coats expressed surprise over Trump's decision to meet with Putin one-on-one and suggested a different approach would have been more suitable.

site_title: 'Dangerous complacency' looms over world AIDS meeting
summary: Thousands of experts and activists gather in Amsterdam to address the growing concern of "dangerous complacency" in the fight against AIDS, warning that a resurgence of the epidemic is possible due to declining global and domestic funding for HIV eradication and treatment programs. Despite progress in reducing new HIV infections and deaths, the report highlights the need for a renewed focus on prevention, citing the importance of condom use, virus-suppressing treatment, and providing safe needles to drug users. The world needs an additional $7 billion per year to achieve the goal of ending AIDS as a public health threat by 2030.

site_title: North Korea economy declines at sharpest rate in 20 yrs in 2017
summary: North Korea's economy contracted at its sharpest rate in 20 years in 2017, with a 3.5% decline in gross domestic product, according to South Korea's central bank. Industrial production dropped 8.5% and agriculture and construction industries also suffered, with output falling by 1.3% and 4.4%, respectively. The decline is attributed to international sanctions imposed to stop North Korea's nuclear and missile programs, which led to a significant drop in external trade volume and export bans on key industries.

site_title: Australia: Shares supported by healthcare, financials; New Zealand down
summary: Australian shares rose 0.2% to 6,275.7, driven by gains in financial and healthcare sectors. Banks, including Westpac, led the way, while healthcare stocks like CSL and healthcare companies benefited from a weaker Australian dollar. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index fell 0.3% due to declines in a2 Milk Company and Fletcher Building. Global trade tensions and weaker commodity prices kept overall sentiment in check.

site_title: Auto industry pleads against new Trump tariffs
summary: The US auto industry has urged President Donald Trump's administration to reject tariffs on vehicle imports, citing potential job losses and crippling domestic manufacturing. The Trump administration had proposed an investigation into auto imports, which could lead to tariffs of up to 25%. The European Union hopes to defuse the trade dispute, but is prepared to retaliate if efforts fail. The auto industry's plea comes as the US-China trade tensions continue to escalate.

site_title: Former Hong Kong leader Donald Tsang jailed again for misconduct
summary: Former Hong Kong leader Donald Tsang was jailed again for 12 months after a failed appeal bid against a misconduct conviction related to failing to disclose his plans to lease a luxury flat from a major investor in a broadcaster. Tsang, 73, is the most senior city official ever convicted in a criminal trial, and his trial came amid a string of corruption cases fueling suspicions over links between public officials and business figures. His misconduct was characterized as an abuse of power to further his own personal interests.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower on higher yen, trade worries
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Friday due to a higher yen, with investors cautious ahead of Japan's corporate earnings season and trade tensions. The Nikkei 225 index lost 0.29% to close at 22,697.88, while the Topix index fell 0.26% to 1,744.98. The lower yen, which makes imports cheaper, is a concern for Japan's exporters. Investors are also watching the US-Japan trade talks for potential impact on the markets.

site_title: Brent crude falls as oversupply fears mount
summary: Brent crude fell 78 cents to $72.12 per barrel, reversing earlier gains, as concerns about mounting global supply returned. Saudi Arabia's OPEC Governor Adeeb Al-Aama said the kingdom expects crude exports to drop by 100,000 bpd in August, but major producers continue to lift output, outweighing the impact of the planned cuts. The market's focus shifted to potential oversupply, with US crude prices paring gains after reaching a session high of $70.17.

site_title: G-20 finance ministers to tackle trade war impact on global economy
summary: Global trade conflicts triggered by US President Donald Trump's protectionist policies will dominate the G-20 finance ministers' meeting in Buenos Aires. IMF chief Christine Lagarde warns that increasing trade restrictions pose the greatest near-term threat to the world economy, with a worst-case scenario of $430 billion cut from global GDP in 2020. The meeting will also discuss the future of the North American Free Trade Agreement and the impact of US-China trade tensions.

site_title: Trump's Fed bashing could backfire by stiffening rate-hike resolve
summary: US President Donald Trump's criticism of the Federal Reserve may lead to higher interest rates, contrary to his intentions. Fed Chairman Jerome Powell and his colleagues may respond to Trump's pressure by demonstrating their independence and increasing rates in a close decision. This could be due to the perception that the Fed is "kowtowing" to the president, potentially swaying them towards a hawkish stance. Economist Michael Feroli notes that Trump's comments may "bias" the Fed towards raising rates.

site_title: Malaysia shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Friday, down 0.88 points to 1,758.36. Volume reached 69.77 million lots worth RM37.98 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 108 to 77. This is a one-day update and does not reflect the article's broader context.

site_title: WhatsApp to limit message forwarding
summary: WhatsApp is launching a test to limit message forwarding, a move aimed at curbing the spread of false information that contributed to violent incidents in India. The test will apply to all users, with a lower limit of five chats at once and removal of the quick forward button next to media messages. This comes after a series of violent incidents in India, where Indians forward more messages, photos, and videos than any other country, sparking calls from authorities for immediate action. The move is part of WhatsApp's efforts to prevent the spread of misinformation.

site_title: Japan inflation speeds up slightly in June, keeps BOJ goal elusive
summary: Japan's annual core consumer inflation rose 0.8% in June, slightly surpassing market forecasts, but still short of the Bank of Japan's 2% target. The increase was largely driven by oil costs, with other goods prices barely rising. This data may prompt the BOJ to accept that its inflation goal cannot be reached quickly, with over 40% of Japanese businesses believing it will take more than three years to reach the target. The BOJ's rate review on July 30-31 will closely scrutinize the data.

site_title: Tesla's battery maker Panasonic suspends cobalt supplier amid sanctions concern
summary: Panasonic, the exclusive battery supplier to Tesla, has suspended relations with a Canadian supplier after concerns over the sourcing of cobalt from Cuba, a country under US sanctions. The Japanese company cited "co-mingling of sources" in its manufacturing process, making it unclear how much cobalt from Cuba ended up in Tesla's batteries. Panasonic had used cobalt from the Canadian supplier for Tesla Model S and Model X batteries after February, and has sought guidance from the US Treasury Department on its interpretation of the sanctions.

site_title: Trump 'not happy' with Federal Reserve interest rates
summary: President Donald Trump criticized the US Federal Reserve, saying its interest rate increases counteracted his efforts to grow the economy. Trump stated he's "not happy" with the Fed's decisions, which he believes leave the US at a disadvantage compared to other countries. The dollar index turned negative following Trump's remarks, which broke with the long-established practice of the executive branch not commenting on the Fed's decisions. Economists warn state intervention can lead to hyper-inflation and devalued currencies.

site_title: Microsoft profit climbs as cloud grows
summary: Microsoft reported a 10% increase in net income to $8.8 billion and a 17% increase in revenue to $30.1 billion in its recently ended quarter. The company's cloud computing services and artificial intelligence investments are driving growth, with LinkedIn revenue rising 37% and productivity and business processes category revenue increasing 13%. Microsoft's shares edged up 0.6% in after-hours trade, with analysts praising the company's "super solid" financial performance and "healthy growth" in every business segment.

site_title: US: Stocks fall as some company earnings disappoint
summary: US stocks fell on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.5% and the S&P 500 dropping 0.3%. Investors reacted to mixed earnings results, with companies such as eBay and Alcoa disappointing. However, some companies like IBM and Comcast reported positive results, with IBM jumping 3.3% and Comcast gaining 2.6%. The decline in stocks came despite expectations of a 20% jump in earnings overall following the US tax reform.

site_title: Fresh grads' woes examined in BT Weekend
summary: Young people entering the job market face a tough reality, with a lower proportion of fresh graduates landing full-time jobs quickly, while part-time, temp, and contract hiring is on the rise. Experts warn of increasing graduate unemployment and underemployment, raising concerns about the future of education. A special edition, "Brunch: Graduate Unemployment and Underemployment," explores the issue, featuring articles on navigating the job market and the impact of changing employment paradigms.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on stronger yen
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Friday, extending falls on Wall Street, as the yen strengthened against the dollar after US President's comments on the Fed's rate policy. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.19% and the Topix index dropped 0.15%. This follows the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.
