site_title: Xi's campaign to draw people back to greying rural China faces uphill battle
summary: China's President Xi Jinping is launching a campaign to draw people back to rural areas, which have seen a brain drain due to low wages and limited economic growth. The rural rejuvenation campaign aims to improve infrastructure and develop sectors such as modern farming and tourism, with local governments offering incentives to attract returnees. However, many rural residents, including farmers like Liu Deke, are skeptical, citing low earnings and limited job opportunities. The campaign faces an uphill battle, with only 7 million people returning to the countryside between 2012-2017, and a median annual disposable income of rural residents being less than one-third of urban residents.

site_title: Director fined record S$57,000 for breaching Companies Act
summary: A Singapore company director, Lawrence Fong Kok Liong, was fined a record S$57,000 for breaching the Companies Act, including failing to hold annual general meetings and file annual returns. Fong's conviction was the latest in a series of similar cases, prompting the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (Acra) to strengthen its regulatory actions. The fine and disqualification serve as a deterrent, with directors facing disqualification if they are convicted of three or more filing-related offenses in five years or have three or more companies struck off the register within the same period.

images.alt_text: A company director was on Tuesday fined a record S$57,000 for various breaches of the Companies Act, prompting the authorities to step up regulatory actions against persistent offenders.

site_title: Asia: Stocks mostly gain despite trade war fears
summary: Asian markets largely advanced on Thursday despite concerns about a global trade war, driven by Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's upbeat assessment of the US economy. Powell expressed optimism over the economy but cautioned about the negative impact of the trade row on US companies. US President Donald Trump's trade policy has imposed steep tariffs on China, but Powell said that lower tariffs would be good for the US economy. Markets rallied in response, with Hong Kong, Tokyo, and Sydney gaining 0.3% and Singapore rising 1%.

site_title: Facebook cracks down on bogus posts inciting violence
summary: Facebook has announced a new policy to remove bogus posts likely to spark violence, following the 2019 Sri Lankan Easter bombings that were linked to false information on the platform. The social network will remove inaccurate or misleading content, such as doctored photos, that may ignite volatile situations. The policy change is part of Facebook's efforts to prevent the spread of misinformation and hate speech, and will be implemented over the coming months. The company is partnering with local organizations and authorities to identify and remove such content.

site_title: UOB invests and partners in AI firm Personetics
summary: Singapore's UOB has invested and partnered with Israeli fintech firm Personetics to boost its use of AI across its markets in South-east Asia. UOB took a minority stake in the firm, which uses machine learning and pattern recognition algorithms to analyze transaction data and provide personalized guidance to customers. The partnership aims to help UOB identify individual transaction demands, detect suspicious activity, and offer real-time guidance on financial decisions. This investment follows UOB's joint venture with Avatec.ai, which also uses AI for credit assessment.

site_title: Japan's trade minister suggests tougher line on any auto tariffs
summary: Japan's Trade Minister Hiroshige Seko warns that if the US imposes tariffs on cars, Japan will respond more strongly than it did with the imposition of steel and aluminum tariffs. Seko says Japan and the EU are working together to address US protectionist trade policies and need to cooperate on auto tariffs, which he believes will have different effects. Japan has refrained from striking back at the US over metals tariffs, but has been discussing a plan to cut tariffs on cars with the EU.

site_title: Tat Hong to delist on Friday morning after successful buyout
summary: Tat Hong Holdings will be delisted on Friday after a successful buyout bid led by the family of CEO Roland Ng and Standard Chartered's private equity arm, acquiring 93.62% of shares at S$0.55 per share. The privatisation is expected to give management more flexibility and allow for better allocation of company resources. All shareholders who did not accept the offer have been compulsorily bought out, completing the takeover bid.

site_title: China bike-sharing giant Ofo to close most US operations after less than a year: WSJ
summary: China's bike-sharing giant Ofo Inc plans to shut down most of its US operations, cutting the majority of its workforce, after less than a year of entering the US market. The company currently operates over 40,000 bicycles in more than 30 US markets, but will likely continue to operate in a handful of larger cities. Ofo's decision comes after struggling to compete with local bike-share companies and facing financial challenges. The company is still determining which cities it will continue to operate in.

site_title: Death toll from India building collapse hits nine
summary: A six-storey apartment block in Greater Noida, east of Delhi, collapsed on Tuesday, trapping over a dozen people. The death toll has risen to nine as four more bodies were pulled from the rubble. Emergency workers and sniffer dogs are continuing to search the site. Police have arrested four people, including the landowner, on charges of manslaughter. The incident highlights common issues with construction firms cutting corners with cheap materials in India's fast-growing satellite towns.

images.alt_text: The death toll from a collapsed apartment block outside Delhi rose to nine on Thursday as emergency workers pulled four more bodies from a huge pile of rubble and metal, India's fire brigade said.

site_title: Tariffs worry US manufacturers nationwide, raise prices: Federal Reserve
summary: US manufacturers nationwide are concerned about President Trump's trade policies, which have led to higher prices and supply disruptions. The Federal Reserve's "beige book" survey found tariffs have caused slight to moderate increases in prices for metals and lumber, but the impact on consumer prices is still expected to intensify. The trade war has also led to labor shortages and rising shipping costs, with only modest wage gains reported across the US. Despite the economic concerns, the White House claims the president's goals are focused on long-term economic principles and protecting American workers.

images.alt_text: Manufacturers across the United States are worried by President Donald Trump's trade policies, which many blame for higher prices and supply disruptions, according to a Federal Reserve survey released Wednesday.

site_title: Australia jobs jump in June, still plenty left to hire
summary: Australia's employment surged by 50,900 in June, the largest monthly gain this year, with 41,200 full-time jobs added. The unemployment rate remained steady at 5.4% due to more people entering the labor force, and annual jobs growth reached 2.8%. The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) sees no near-term trigger for interest rate hikes due to labor supply still outpacing demand. Despite the positive employment data, economists caution that wage growth remains sluggish and more job growth is needed to ease labor market slack.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher after US gains
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Thursday, extending a winning streak, driven by investor confidence in the US economy. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.39% to 22,882.64, while the Topix index added 0.15% to 1,753.85. The US dollar held firm against the yen, and strong US earnings boosted Wall Street. Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's comments on trade policy and interest rates also supported the market.

site_title: Largest oil shipment sent from Vancouver to China since 2015
summary: A Canadian Aframax tanker, Serene Sea, is set to deliver the largest oil shipment from Vancouver to China since 2015, carrying 514,000 barrels per day. The shipment, valued at 16,600 barrels per day, will arrive in Guangdong, China on July 26, increasing Canadian exports to China. This rare shipment is driven by the narrowing Brent-WTI spread and decreased demand for US-based crude, allowing Canadian oil to be exported to Asia.

site_title: New AI lab to leverage Grab and NUS data
summary: Grab, a Singapore-based ride-hailing platform, has partnered with the National University of Singapore (NUS) to launch an AI lab with a joint initial investment of S$6 million. The lab will leverage Grab's vast data, including over three petabytes, and NUS's data to improve transportation efficiency and examine larger challenges like congestion and liveability in South-east Asia. The partnership aims to utilize data for the common good, with the goal of making the region a more liveable place.

site_title: Europe hits Google with record 4.34b euro antitrust fine, appeal ahead
summary: The European Union fined Google a record 4.34 billion euros for its antitrust practices, including using its Android mobile operating system to block rivals. The penalty, nearly double the previous record, is aimed at forcing Google to stop pre-installing its search engine and browser on Android devices. Google has 90 days to comply or appeal the decision, which could add to trade tensions between Brussels and Washington. The fine is expected to have a minimal impact on Google's cash reserves but could lead to changes in the company's business practices.

site_title: Malaysian who threatened to kill King among seven suspected militants arrested in four-state swoop
summary: Seven suspected Islamic State (IS) militants, including a Malaysian who threatened to kill the Malaysian king and top leaders, were arrested in a four-state operation from July 12 to 17. The suspects, four Malaysians and three Indonesians, were detained in Terengganu, Selangor, Perak, and Johor. The Malaysian suspect, a 34-year-old man, had posted a threat on Facebook, while another suspect, a 26-year-old Indonesian man, was found to have received weapons training and planned to join IS in Syria. The arrests were part of a special operation led by Inspector-General of Police Mohamad Fuzi Harun.

site_title: Mirach Energy to pay RM21m for 70% stake in Malaysian plantation company
summary: Mirach Energy has agreed to buy a 70% stake in Malaysian plantation company RCL Kelstar Sdn Bhd for RM21 million (S$7.07 million). The deal is part of Mirach's diversification strategy and aims to bring the company back into the black. The investment will give Mirach a majority interest in RCL, which is developing a multi-storey project in East Malaysia. The deal must be completed within six months after the payment of vendors, who must be paid in full.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Wheelock Properties, Capitaland Commercial Trust, United Overseas Insurance, Keppel T&T
summary: Wheelock Properties' parent company is offering S$2.10 per share to take the property developer private. Capitaland Commercial Trust reported a 4% fall in its distribution per unit to 2.16 Singapore cents. United Overseas Insurance's second-quarter net profit fell 15.5% to S$6.9 million. Keppel T&T's net profit surged 137.8% to S$26 million after a dilution gain from Keppel DC Reit's private placement.

site_title: As the world moves forward on trade, US policy stagnates
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stated that the country must work with like-minded partners, including Europe, Japan, Asean, and China, due to the growing wave of populism globally. This sentiment contrasts with the past, when the US was a key ally and supporter of the Trans-Pacific Partnership trade deal. Lee's comments highlight the shift in global politics and trade dynamics, with Singapore adapting to the changing landscape.

site_title: Japan trade balance returns to surplus after dip
summary: Japan logged a trade surplus of 721.4 billion yen in June, reversing a deficit from the previous month, driven by increased exports of power generating equipment, airplanes, electronic parts, and auto parts. Exports rose 6.7% while imports edged up 2.5%. The surplus also marked a reversal in Japan's trade deficit with the US, which grew 0.5% from a year earlier. The data comes amid ongoing international trade tensions and US President Trump's protectionist trade policies.

site_title: Turkey's two-year state of emergency ends: state media
summary: Turkey's two-year state of emergency, imposed after the 2016 coup, ended on July 18, 2018, after seven three-month renewals. The emergency was declared by President Recep Tayyip Erdogan on July 20, 2016. During this time, tens of thousands were arrested and dismissed from their jobs. The government chose not to extend the emergency, bringing it to an end at 1:00 am local time.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Thursday; STI up 0.4% to 3,252.57
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.4% to 3,252.57, driven by a strong US earnings season and investor confidence in the US economy. Gainers outnumbered losers 70 to 44, with notable movers including CapitaLand, Wheelock Properties, and OCBC Bank. The gains follow a winning streak in Tokyo stocks and a record close for the Nasdaq Composite Index in the US. Despite tariff uncertainty, investors remain positive, with the STI marking its fifth consecutive day of gains ahead of GDP data.

site_title: US: Strong earnings boost Dow, S&P 500
summary: US stocks rose Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average increasing 0.3% to 25,199.36, and the S&P 500 advancing 0.2% to 2,815.62, driven by mostly positive earnings reports. Despite rising trade war anxiety, the gains outweighed concerns. The Nasdaq Composite Index declined slightly after closing at a fresh record on Tuesday.

site_title: Swiss finance minister says franc 'overvalued' but liveable
summary: Switzerland's Finance Minister Ueli Maurer stated that the Swiss franc is overvalued relative to the euro, but the country can "live with" the current rate. The franc's safe-haven status has bolstered its strength, making life difficult for Swiss exporters. Maurer expressed optimism about finding solutions to Switzerland's trade disputes with the EU, despite disagreements over a new bilateral treaty.

site_title: Europe: Tech lifts shares as currency weakens; autos climb
summary: European shares rose 0.6% on Wednesday, a one-month high, driven by tech stocks' 2.5% gain, led by Ericsson and ASML's 8.5% and 8.1% increases, respectively. The pan-European Stoxx 600 benchmark index rose for the second day, supported by a positive assessment of the US economy from Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell. Currency weakness also contributed to the rally.

site_title: Manufacturing Integration Technology to sell semicon business
summary: Manufacturing Integration Technology (MIT) is selling its semiconductor business to Ningbo MIT Semiconductor Company for an estimated S$84.5 million. The sale will allow MIT to unlock shareholder value and focus on contract equipment manufacturing and automation. The semiconductor business, which designs and manufactures automated equipment, will continue to operate with the same management team. The sale is expected to be completed through a special dividend or capital reduction, with MIT shareholders receiving 24 cents per share upon completion.

site_title: Cliff Richard wins BBC privacy case, sparking media alarm
summary: Veteran British pop star Cliff Richard won a privacy case against the BBC, awarding him £210,000 in damages after the broadcaster broadcast live on television a police raid on his home in 2014. The BBC's coverage was deemed "sensationalist" and "unlawful" by a High Court judge, who ruled that the broadcaster infringed on Richard's rights. The case has sparked concerns over press freedom, with the BBC warning that the ruling will "make it harder to scrutinise the conduct of the police".

site_title: Wheelock Properties parent offers S$2.10 per share to privatise developer; stock hits S$2.19
summary: Wheelock Properties' parent company, Wheelock and Company, has made an S$2.10 per share offer to privatize the property developer. The offer, which is unconditional, values the company at S$2.51 billion and is higher than its previous closing price since 2010. The offer price is also up 25.9% from its previous close, with investors betting on a potential price increase. The offer is seen as a strategic move to give the owner and management more flexibility and a "longer time horizon" to manage the business.

images.alt_text: Ardmore Three, a freehold development by Wheelock Properties.

site_title: CCT's Q2 DPU slips 1.6% to 2.16 S cents on enlarged unit base
summary: Capitaland Commercial Trust (CCT) reported a 1.6% decline in distribution per unit to 2.16 Singapore cents in Q2, due to an enlarged unit base. Despite this, total distributable income grew 14.3% year-on-year to S$79.4 million. Net property income rose 12.5% and gross revenue grew 12%. CCT issued 130 million new units for an equity placement to finance the acquisition of Gallileo in Frankfurt, Germany. The trust's divestment of Twenty Anson generated S$516 million in proceeds, which will be used to repay debt and fund growth opportunities.

site_title: US 'especially vulnerable' in trade war, says IMF chief
summary: IMF chief Christine Lagarde warns that the US economy is "especially vulnerable" to damage from the global trade war, which could shave hundreds of billions of dollars off global GDP. The IMF estimates that global growth could decline and that the US economy is particularly at risk due to its high reliance on global trade. The IMF predicts a 0.5-0.6 point reduction in US GDP in 2020 if tariffs on the US vehicle sector are imposed. Lagarde urges policymakers to prepare for potential decline in global growth.

images.alt_text: Ms Lagarde says growth is already beginning to slow in the Euro Area, Japan and the UK, and recent US fiscal stimulus would soon wane.

site_title: Trump is the biggest buyer of political ads on Facebook
summary: US President Donald Trump is the largest buyer of political ads on Facebook, spending over $270,000 on ads since early May, according to a New York University study. This surpasses Planned Parenthood Federation of America, which spent $188,000 on Facebook ads over the same period. Trump's ads were viewed by at least 37 million people, making them the most viewed by Facebook users. The study highlights the growing use of social media for political advertising ahead of the mid-term elections in November.

site_title: Malaysia's June inflation rate at three-year low, but rate cut unlikely
summary: Malaysia's June inflation rate fell to 0.8%, its lowest in over three years, following the abolition of a 6% consumption tax. The removal of the Goods and Services Tax (GST) and discounts during the Eid al-Fitr holiday season contributed to the decline. Despite this, economists believe the central bank is unlikely to cut interest rates, citing low inflation and steady economic growth. The Bank Negara Malaysia is expected to maintain its neutral stance and keep interest rates unchanged for the rest of the year.

site_title: Democrats want Trump interpreter to testify about Putin summit
summary: Democrats are pushing for Congress to subpoena Donald Trump's interpreter, Marina Gross, to testify about his private summit with Vladimir Putin in Helsinki. The interpreter, who took notes during the meeting, is seen as a potential source of critical information about the discussions. Lawmakers on both sides of the aisle have condemned Trump's positive take on Putin and are seeking to determine what was discussed during the meeting. The White House is likely to invoke executive privilege, arguing that no president is required to reveal private conversations.

images.alt_text: Democratic lawmakers on Wednesday pushed for Congress to subpoena Donald Trump's interpreter, amid a growing sense of alarm over the private summit in Helsinki between the US president and Russia's Vladimir Putin.

site_title: Oil rises on bullish demand signals, even as US stockpiles grow
summary: Oil prices rose on Wednesday, with Brent crude futures up 1% to $72.90 a barrel and WTI crude futures up 1% to $68.76 a barrel. US crude inventories rose by 5.8 million barrels, despite a 2.2 million barrel increase in imports. Strong demand for gasoline and distillates, as well as lower-than-expected gasoline stockpiles, supported the price increase. However, concerns over US trade policy and its impact on global demand weighed on the market, with some analysts predicting a potential slowdown in energy demand.

site_title: Goldman Sachs names David Solomon as new CEO
summary: Goldman Sachs named David Solomon, 56, as its new CEO on October 1, succeeding Lloyd Blankfein. Solomon, a former Bear Stearns banker, will also take over the chairman's seat. The appointment comes as Goldman expands its consumer market efforts, with deposits in its newer business reaching over $23 billion at the end of the second quarter. The shift aims to capitalize on a tighter regulatory environment and compete with other banks in the retail branch market. Solomon's leadership will focus on growth and client service.

site_title: Tiffany & Co banks on jewellery lab for new designs and a way out of its rut
summary: Tiffany & Co is revamping its design process with a new jewellery lab in Manhattan, aiming to attract a younger clientele and boost revenue growth. The workshop, led by Dana Naberezny, features rapid prototyping and cost-analysis processes, where designers and engineers collaborate to create new products. The company has seen positive results, with last quarter's revenue growth being its highest since 2012. Reed Krakoff leads design at Tiffany, having launched his first jewellery line in May, and the company is counting on the workshop to churn out new ideas and keep pace with the industry.

site_title: Bullish comments by Fed's Powell boost US dollar
summary: The US dollar rose to a three-week high on July 18, 2018, after Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell expressed confidence in the US economy's steady growth and downplayed the risks of a trade conflict. Powell's comments suggested the Fed is not overly concerned about the impact of a trade war, boosting the dollar's value. The dollar rose 0.3% against a basket of six major currencies, with most gains reserved against higher-yielding currencies. Analysts expect more dollar upside due to rising US interest rates and differing monetary policies among major central banks.

site_title: Toll group's S$228m hub takes logistics to new level
summary: Singapore's S$228 million Toll City logistics hub has been launched, featuring automation and efficiency technologies to improve traffic and supply chain management. The 100,000 sq m hub includes innovations such as Unmanned Aerial Vehicles, Automated Guided Vehicles, and smart cabinets to increase space and manpower efficiency by 40% and 30%, respectively. The hub aims to improve Toll's Asia Pacific network and is expected to contribute to Singapore's efforts to address the "grey tsunami" of aging population and labor shortages.

images.alt_text: Automation and efficiency are at the heart of the Tuas-based Toll City, the S$228 million logistics hub officially launched on Wednesday.

site_title: SIA to add 4th daily flight to Tokyo's Haneda; A380 to service Osaka route
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) will add a fourth daily flight to Tokyo's Haneda Airport from December 28, increasing daily services to six. The airline will operate the Airbus A380 on its Osaka route from October 28 to March 30, 2019, adding over 720 seats per week. The move aims to meet growing travel demand between Singapore and Japan, with a combined 105 weekly services between the two countries.

site_title: McQueen, suicide and the celebrity fairy tale's dark side
summary: Celebrity chef Anthony Bourdain and fashion icon Kate Spade's suicides in June 2018 reignited discussions about the dark side of celebrity culture, mirroring the tragic deaths of rock stars Chester Bennington and Chris Cornell, and Hollywood figures Tony Scott and Robin Williams. A new documentary about Alexander McQueen, who took his own life at 40, explores the tortured artist's life and singular vision. McQueen, a British fashion icon, struggled with mental health issues, loneliness, and depression despite his success, leaving a lasting impact on the fashion world and raising awareness about the challenges of celebrity suicides.

site_title: UK to consult public on possible bid to join Pacific trade pact
summary: British Trade Minister Liam Fox announced plans to consult the public on a possible bid to join the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP), a Pacific trade group including Canada, Australia, and Mexico. This comes as the UK seeks to establish free and fair trade agreements post-Brexit. Fox also plans to consult on trade deals with the US, Australia, and New Zealand. The move aims to position the UK at the heart of the world's fastest-growing regions.

images.alt_text: British Trade Minister Liam Fox said on Wednesday he will consult the public about a possible bid to join a Pacific trade group that includes Canada, Australia and Mexico, once Britain leaves the European Union.

site_title: COEs for cars rebound; Cat A premium up 30.8%
summary: Singapore's Certificate of Entitlement (COE) prices for cars rebounded after plummeting to an eight-year low two weeks ago. COEs for cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp rose 30.8% to S$32,699, while open COEs finished 5.8% higher at S$32,809. Commercial vehicle COEs eased, and motorcycle premiums dipped to an eight-month low. The upcoming August-to-October quota period will see a 12.5% increase in COEs, with car buyers receiving 5.7% more COEs and motorcyclists getting 55.7% more.

site_title: Brexit and the problem of sovereignty
summary: The UK's Brexit White Paper proposes a close but not too close relationship between Britain and the European Union, attempting to reconcile 'Brexit is Brexit' with EU treaties. However, the plan faces significant weaknesses, including substituting rule of law with non-binding mechanisms and compromising the cost-benefit balance among EU member states. The UK parliament's potential approval of the plan is uncertain, with concerns that it may lead to mutual recriminations and deter businesses from investing in the UK. The EU is unlikely to accept the proposal, which would give away sovereignty to independent arbitrators and EU institutions.

site_title: Swatch Group sees Asia, US fuelling sales growth this year
summary: Swatch Group expects strong sales growth in Asia and the US this year, driven by "very high growth rates" in Asia and a "double-digit sales increase" in North America. The company's net profit jumped 67% to 468 million Swiss francs, and the operating margin improved to 14.7%. Despite analysts expecting deceleration in the second half, shares rose 1.1% ahead of the European sector index. Strong demand from younger millennial consumers and interest in pre-owned products are key factors in the company's recovery.

site_title: Casinos face last milestone in Japan on road to legalisation
summary: Japanese lawmakers are set to vote on a casino implementation bill, the final hurdle for the legalization of gaming resorts. The bill, if passed, will allow international operators to enter a market projected to be worth up to US$25 billion by 2023. Casino resorts are expected to open in 2023 at the earliest, with the Upper House of the Japanese parliament voting on the bill before the current session ends on Sunday.

site_title: Safety issues still loom for futuristic air travel
summary: Regulators and aircraft manufacturers, including Boeing, must address safety concerns for flying taxis before they can become a reality. Complex traffic systems are needed to prevent collisions with buildings, cars, and drones. The issue of backup energy is also a concern, as current battery technology limits flight duration to 20-30 minutes. The need for reserve fuel, similar to commercial jetliners, must also be addressed, raising questions about the feasibility of flying taxis and the regulatory framework required to support them.

site_title: As Amazon slashes prices, Bezos sees jump in wealth
summary: Amazon founder Jeff Bezos' net worth reached $150 billion, surpassing Microsoft's Bill Gates as the world's richest person in decades, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index. Bezos' wealth increased by $50 billion this year due to Amazon's share price surge, with the company's market capitalization rising to nearly $880 billion. Bezos' rise has been spectacular since 2014, when his fortune was estimated at $32 billion, and he now holds the top spot, far ahead of other billionaires.

site_title: Why investors don't care about crude's drop
summary: European oil companies are weathering the slump in crude prices, with the Stoxx Europe 600 Oil & Gas index retreating only 3.9% despite a 9% drop in benchmark Brent crude. This indicates that oil companies have become more disciplined and can withstand crude-price corrections, a change in fortunes for last year's laggards. Their ability to withstand the 2014-2016 crash has proved to investors that they can easily handle such corrections.

site_title: Sias urges Shanghai Turbo shareholders to reject proposal to remove board
summary: The Securities Investors Association (Singapore) is urging minority shareholders of Shanghai Turbo Enterprises to reject a proposal to remove the current board of directors at an upcoming extraordinary general meeting. The two new shareholders, Lin Chuanjun and Zhang Ping, hold a 10.6% stake and have not provided sufficient reasons for the proposed removal. Sias questioned the legality of the lawsuit against former CEO Liu Ming, who has a 30% interest in the company, and raised concerns about the potential for a conflict of interest among the three individuals.

site_title: Khazanah Nasional faces crossroads amid potential assets sale
summary: Malaysia's Khazanah Nasional, the country's sovereign wealth fund, faces a crossroads amid potential asset sales to address its RM1 trillion government liabilities. With a potential downgrade of its sovereign credit rating looming, the government is reviewing big-ticket projects and considering asset sales as a way to slash public debt. Khazanah's portfolio, valued at RM116 billion, includes major companies such as Tenaga Nasional and IHH Healthcare, and its assets may be sold to other GLICs to raise cash and refinance debt.

site_title: Foodtech startups: Too many chefs in the kitchen?
summary: Singapore's foodtech scene is experiencing rapid growth, with over 15 startups in meal subscription, food delivery, and restaurant booking services. Notable investments include Burpple, Chope, and Oddle, with venture capital firms like SPH Ventures and Insignia Ventures Partners backing the sector. Experts believe daily-use apps like Grab and Meituan-Dianping have a high potential for success, citing network effects and government support. However, some startups face challenges in building a competitive advantage, and established platforms must adapt to succeed in the space.

site_title: Nature to play big part in future HDB estates
summary: Singapore's Housing and Development Board (HDB) has introduced an updated framework, the Biophilic Town Framework, to integrate nature into new HDB estates. The framework assesses the landscape and residents' benefits from natural ecosystems during planning and design. It considers soil, flora and fauna, outdoor comfort, water, and people, and incorporates strategies such as nutrient recycling, pest control, and natural water filtration. The framework was first adopted in Punggol Northshore District in 2015, and will be progressively applied to new projects starting this month.

site_title: The greatest auto show on earth
summary: The Le Mans Classic, a biennial auto fashion show, took place in Le Mans, France, with over 135,000 spectators attending the event. The show featured 8,500 classic cars from 1925 to 2018, competing in different races on the 13 km circuit. The event also showcased the history and legend of the medieval city, where King Henry II was born.

site_title: CIMB answers queries on latest advisory letter in Vard takeover bid
summary: CIMB Bank has responded to shareholder queries regarding its latest advisory letter on Vard Holdings' proposed delisting. The bank clarified its use of benchmarks, citing the removal of the CH Offshore takeover from a list of precedent transactions due to its non-shipbuilding activities. It also explained the use of a 2016 price benchmark, stating that Fincantieri made significant purchases of shares during that period. The bank's exit offer, priced at S$0.25 for every share not owned, remains under consideration by shareholders at an upcoming vote on July 24.

site_title: 4 shophouses opposite Singapore Khalsa Association for sale
summary: A row of four adjoining freehold conservation shophouses at Tessensohn Road in Singapore have been put up for sale with a reserve price of S$25 million, working out to S$1,399 per square foot. The properties, held by three separate owners, offer a rare opportunity to acquire four adjoining shophouses in the Farrer Park/Serangoon Road locality. The successful bidder can construct a corner six-storey rear extension, subject to authorities' approval, and explore mixed-use retail/residential development or unique co-living concept.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Nordic Group secured S$13 million in contracts, including S$5.3 million from scaffolding and insulation division and S$4.2 million from precision engineering division. The company reported an outstanding order book of S$99.3 million in May.

site_title: Kentish Green joins en bloc fray
summary: The owners of Kentish Green, a 122-unit condo on Oxford Road near Farrer Park MRT Station, are seeking a reserve price of S$230 million for its 59,143 sq ft site. A sale would net each owner between S$1.736 million and S$2.086 million. The site can be redeveloped into 219-259 apartments with a small commercial component, and marketing agent ERA Realty cites the upcoming Russian Cultural Centre and nearby schools as potential draws. The buyer would need to pay a premium for the lease and a differential premium for plot ratio increase, with the tender closing on August 21.

site_title: CapitaLand bags 4 awards, DBS strikes 'royal flush' at Singapore Corporate Awards
summary: CapitaLand and DBS Group emerged as top winners at the 13th annual Singapore Corporate Awards, with CapitaLand securing four awards and DBS receiving the Special Recognition Award for its "all-round excellence in corporate governance". DBS also achieved a "royal flush" by winning in each of the five award categories from 2013 to 2017. The awards recognize companies and individuals for their exemplary performance in corporate governance and shareholder communication.

site_title: Lion Global launches active low-cost multi-asset funds
summary: Lion Global Investors has launched an actively managed multi-asset fund series with a total expense ratio of 0.5%, targeting underserved institutional investors with assets under S$5 million, including charities and clan associations. The funds, available through OCBC and online channels, aim to help investors reduce costs. This move is part of Lion Global's effort to provide more cost-effective investment options.

site_title: Indonesian central bank aims to revive country's sluggish property market
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia (BI), is introducing measures to revive the country's sluggish property market. Starting next month, the bank will scrap the 15% minimum mortgage downpayment for first-time buyers and relax rules on loan disbursements. The goal is to support economic growth, which is expected to be around 5.1-5.2% this year. Analysts, however, are skeptical, citing a lack of a hot commodity market and rising interest rates. Standard & Poor's expects property sales to remain flat this year, despite BI's new measures.

images.alt_text: Bank Indonesia governor Perry Warjiyo says the central bank has to act to support the country's economic growth.

site_title: A president with no shame and a party with no spine
summary: US President Donald Trump has proven to have no shame, using his power to misbehave and ignore consequences. Backed by a party with no spine and a network with no integrity, Trump's actions have become a huge source of power for him and trouble for the country. The Republican Party's inability to hold Trump accountable has allowed him to continue his destructive behavior, including his trade policies with China and his handling of European allies. A change in the mid-term elections is the only way to curb Trump's power and restore a healthy conservative party.

site_title: Modi to face no-confidence vote as opposition ramps up pressure
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi's government faces a no-confidence vote in Parliament as the opposition ramps up pressure ahead of general elections next year. The Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) coalition, led by Modi, is expected to defeat the no-confidence motion due to its majority in the lower house of Parliament. The opposition, including the Congress party, will use the debate to pressure Modi on issues such as women's safety, mob lynchings, and Jammu and Kashmir. The government has faced recent challenges, including losses in state elections and regional allies defecting.

site_title: China EV battery boom set to turn ugly as subsidies revised
summary: China's electric vehicle battery sector is undergoing a significant reshuffle as the government reforms subsidies to meet the demands of next-generation transport. Only two major producers, Contemporary Amperex Technology Ltd and BYD Co, are deemed capable of surviving the industry's transformation, while others will struggle to adapt. The government's plan to step up development of longer-range EVs with larger, more complex batteries will reshape the industry's landscape, posing pressure on companies to cut emissions and invest in more advanced technology.

site_title: MAS joining the dots on illicit fund flows with data analytics
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is using data analytics to combat illicit fund flows, with over 25,000 suspicious transaction reports annually reviewed. The regulator aims to identify higher-risk accounts and entities through thematic-based inspections and supervisory visits. MAS also flagged risks of financial exclusion, particularly for ex-offenders denied banking services, and plans to create basic bank accounts for individuals, restricting their use to prevent misuse. The regulator encourages banks to adopt fine-grained techniques to identify money laundering and terrorism financing risks while meeting basic banking needs.

site_title: Leading corporate lights crowned
summary: Leading corporate lights in Singapore were crowned at the Singapore Corporate Awards, held at Resorts World Sentosa. The awards honored companies in five categories, including Best Chief Financial Officer, Best CEO, and Best Managed Board. Winners included Singtel, SATS, and NTT DC Reit, which saw its Singapore public offer oversubscribed 9.8 times. The event recognized companies that excelled in corporate governance and shareholder communications.

site_title: STI flat as investors stay on sidelines
summary: Singapore stocks finished flat on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) closing 0.03% higher at 3,240.50 points. Gainers outnumbered losers 189 to 182, with Oversea-Chinese Banking Corporation being the only bank to end higher. Shares of Koufu Group and Keppel Corporation rose, while Creative Technology Limited saw its share price jump 9.15%. The lack of direction in the market, similar to US markets, contributed to the cautious stance.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Soilbuild Business Space REIT's Q2 FY18 results were within expectations, with net property income dropping 12.4% year-on-year to S$33.2 million. Distribution per unit also fell 12.4% to 2.588 Singapore cents. The portfolio occupancy rate remains steady at 87.6%. The decline was mainly due to the divestment of KTL Offshore in February 2018. On a quarter-on-quarter basis, net property income fell 4.4%.

site_title: RWS leverages its areas of specialisation to help needy
summary: Resorts World Sentosa (RWS) has trained its dive instructors to become certified Disabled Divers International professionals, offering swimming experiences to disabled individuals. The company, Singapore's first and only accredited DDI Dive Centre, partnered with a charity organisation to provide the programme. RWS also leverages its expertise in CSR initiatives, such as the aRWSome Volunteer Day and apprenticeship programme, to give back to the community and support socially disadvantaged individuals and groups.

site_title: Tame UK inflation knocks BOE rate hike expectations
summary: UK inflation unexpectedly held steady at 2.4% in June, denting expectations of a Bank of England interest rate hike. Sterling fell to a 10-month low against the US dollar, and 10-year British government bond yields dropped to their lowest since May. Economists had expected a 2.6% increase, and the data also showed weakening in an underlying inflation measure. The Bank of England may reconsider a rate hike, with a 70% chance of no move next month, according to financial market pricing.

site_title: US housing starts drop by most since 2016 to nine-month low
summary: US housing starts fell to a nine-month low in June, with single-family home starts dropping to 858,000 and multifamily home starts falling to 315,000. Higher mortgage rates, labor and material costs, and a shortage of qualified workers are constraining the market. Economists may reassess the trend after July data, but some analysts believe the decline is a one-month glitch. The report shows a decline in construction and sales, with the housing market possibly having peaked for this expansion.

site_title: Nato needs new thinking, not new money
summary: US President Donald Trump's Nato summit in Brussels was marked by criticism and controversy, with the president accusing allies of not spending enough on defense. Trump's approach was seen as chaotic and bullying, with media describing it as a "bull-in-a-china-shop" approach. Despite this, the fundamental work of reconfiguring Nato's mission and forces for the 21st century remains. The article concludes that Trump needs to reflect on new threats and rapid power transitions, rather than simply increasing defense spending.

site_title: Lloyd Blankfein poised for US$85m payout after Goldman exit as CEO
summary: Goldman Sachs CEO Lloyd Blankfein is set to receive up to $84.7 million in compensation when he leaves the company in October after 36 years. The majority of the payout will be in performance-based shares and cash awards, but the exact amount and payment structure are unclear due to the lack of employment agreements guaranteeing severance payments. Blankfein, 63, has been CEO since 2006.

site_title: Iron ore overpowers bears as trade fight batters commodities
summary: Iron ore prices have remained stable amidst global trade tensions, with benchmark prices in the US$60s a tonne. Despite a decline in copper and other commodities, iron ore has maintained its run due to strong demand from China's booming steel industry, which has reported record production figures. The premium for high-grade iron ore has reached an all-time high, benefiting global miners such as Rio Tinto and Vale. China's steel industry is driving demand for high-quality iron ore, which is being used to improve air quality and boost mill margins.

images.alt_text: Iron ore prices have been holding up amid market turmoil as importers in top user China scoop up cargoes to feed booming mills.

site_title: Vibrant's auditors note irregularities in certain Blackgold units
summary: Vibrant Ltd's auditors have found irregularities in certain units of its wholly owned subsidiary Blackgold International Holdings, including coal mining and coal trading receipts. The auditors were unable to complete the audit due to these irregularities, which may have a significant impact on Blackgold's financial statements. The company has appointed a special auditor to conduct an investigation and has placed its chairman on leave pending the outcome. This has led to a 39.7% decline in Vibrant's shares, making it one of the biggest losers on the Singapore bourse.

site_title: easyJet lifts profit forecast as rivals falter
summary: easyJet has raised its profit forecast by up to 45% due to the collapse of rivals and strikes at Air France, predicting pre-tax profits of £550-£590 million for the year. The airline credits strong demand for holidays and the failure of smaller rival Monarch last year for its improved outlook. Despite cancellations and higher costs, CEO Johan Lundgren expressed confidence in easyJet's ability to maintain operations post-Brexit, with the airline set to receive new Airbus A321neo planes.

site_title: Chip equipment maker ASML sees stronger growth ahead
summary: ASML Holding NV, a leading chip equipment supplier, reported better-than-expected second-quarter earnings and expects stronger growth for the rest of the year. The company's net income rose 25% to 584 million euros, driven by a 30% surge in sales to 2.74 billion euros. CEO Peter Wennink forecast continued growth and improved profitability, citing strong demand from both logic and memory chip makers. ASML expects to sell 20 of its newest machines this year and 30 more in 2019, indicating a strong outlook for the company.

site_title: United Air jumps after boosting profit outlook, bucking rivals
summary: United Continental Holdings Inc surged to a six-month high after boosting its profit outlook, citing a strategic overhaul and improved pricing power, particularly on international routes. The airline raised its adjusted earnings forecast to $8.75 per share, 25 cents higher than previous estimates, bucking rival cuts. United's on-time departure rate improved, and its unit revenue rose 3% in the second quarter, driven by stronger pricing. The airline also trimmed its expansion plans and expects higher fuel costs in the third quarter.

site_title: Koufu shares close flat at S$0.63 on trading debut
summary: Koufu Group, a Singapore-based food court operator, listed on the Singapore Exchange's mainboard with a market capitalisation of about S$350 million. The company's shares closed flat at S$0.63 on its trading debut, with a 4.8% increase from its initial public offering price. The listing boosts SGX's consumer cluster to 152 listings with a combined market capitalisation of over S$135 billion. Koufu Group aims to strengthen its presence in Singapore and overseas, drive productivity through innovation, and expand into the online food ordering and delivery space.

site_title: A new norm for SGD corporate perps
summary: The Singapore dollar corporate bond market has seen a shift in the pricing of perpetual securities (perps), with nine out of 18 issued since 2017 having mismatched call and reset dates. This mismatch can lead to a higher incentive for issuers to redeem their perps sooner, potentially triggering a sell-down. Despite this, investors have already factored in non-call risk for some vulnerable perps, and there is no evidence of credit stress among the issuers. The market is still evolving, and investors should be cautious of the potential for a wider selldown.

site_title: EU sets provisional import duties on Chinese e-bikes
summary: The European Union has imposed provisional import duties on Chinese electric bicycles, ranging from 27.5% to 83.6%, in an effort to curb cheap imports flooding the European market. The move is part of a series of EU measures against Chinese exports, following the US-China trade war. The investigation found that Chinese e-bike exports to the EU more than tripled between 2014 and 2017, with a market share of 35% and average prices falling by 11%. The duties will apply until January 2019, with the possibility of definitive duties lasting five years.

site_title: In China, yellow robots deliver snacks to your home
summary: China introduces autonomous delivery robots, called "little yellow horses," to ferry daily essentials to residents in a Beijing compound. Equipped with GPS, cameras, and radar, these robots aim to revolutionize logistics in China, where a billion packages are expected to be delivered daily. The robots use cashless payments and smartphone shopping, and their creator, Liu Zhiyong, predicts a future where robots will replace human delivery personnel, reducing costs and increasing efficiency.

site_title: Ethical use of AI can augment, not kill jobs
summary: OCBC Bank emphasizes the importance of ethical AI use, aiming to augment jobs rather than replace them. The bank's four key principles include augmenting jobs, flourishing alongside AI, keeping AI fair, and protecting customer data. OCBC's initiatives, such as its HR in your Pocket app and Future Smart programme, demonstrate its commitment to developing digital skills and ensuring a strong learning culture. The bank's approach prioritizes trust and integrity, recognizing the potential risks of AI misuse and the importance of upholding customer data protection.

site_title: Buffett's Berkshire gains as company lifts cap on stock buybacks
summary: Berkshire Hathaway's board lifted the cap on stock buybacks, allowing CEO Warren Buffett and CFO Charlie Munger to repurchase shares when the price is below Berkshire's intrinsic value. The move follows a decade-long period with a US$109 billion cash reserve, prompting investors to question whether Buffett should distribute profits. Berkshire's Class A shares rose 3.9% to US$299,770, with analysts estimating Buffett could afford to spend in the "low tens of billions" of dollars on buybacks annually.

site_title: Programme launched to lift Singapore food manufacturing skills
summary: Singapore launches the Skills Framework for Food Manufacturing to raise worker skills and build a strong talent pool in the sector. The framework, part of a $4.5 billion industry transformation program, aims to identify emerging skills and provide training programs for workers. Minister Chan Chun Sing emphasized the importance of quality, innovation, and collaboration in the food manufacturing sector, alongside workers, in achieving success.

site_title: Dilution gain boosts Keppel T&T Q2 profit to S$26m
summary: Keppel T&T's second-quarter net profit rose to S$26 million, driven by a dilution gain following Keppel DC Reit's private placement exercise. Revenue declined 4.9% to S$45.3 million compared to the previous year. The company's operations expenses increased, contributing to the lower turnover. The dilution gain offset the decline in revenue, resulting in a higher net profit compared to the same period last year.

site_title: Vitol partners Peabody to grind coal
summary: Vitol, the largest independent oil trader, and Peabody Energy Corp, a mining giant, are partnering with startup Arq Ltd to revive the coal industry. Arq's process pulverizes coal, removes impurities, and blends it with crude or fuels, producing lower-emission products. The companies have invested $20 million and plan to build plants near coal mines in the US and Australia, aiming to produce 100,000 barrels a day within two years. The partnership could add value to Peabody's coal, reduce its environmental footprint, and expand its market, while providing a lower-cost alternative to hydrocarbons.

site_title: Keppel T&T Q2 profit up 138% to S$26m
summary: Keppel T&T's Q2 net profit soared 137.8% to S$26m, driven by a dilution gain from Keppel DC REIT's private placement exercise. Revenue decreased 4.9% to S$45.3m, while earnings per share rose to 4.6 cents. For the six months, net profit surged 59.5% to S$35.4m, and earnings per share jumped to 6.3 cents. The company's net asset value per share increased to S$1.54, but no dividend was proposed.

site_title: Palm oil from Indonesia's shrinking forests taints global brands: report
summary: A new report by Eyes on the Forest (EoF) reveals that major global brands, including Nestle and Unilever, continue to source palm oil from Indonesian mills that have cleared rainforests, despite commitments to stop buying non-sustainable oil. The report found that these companies purchased oil from 21 "tainted" mills, which are located in protected forest areas. The investigation highlights the need for improved traceability in the palm oil supply chain to prevent further deforestation.

site_title: OCBC launches new online marketplace for mums
summary: OCBC Bank has launched a new online marketplace, mumstruly.com, catering to mothers with products and services such as baby gear, antenatal screenings, and lactation services. The platform is built with a S$300,000 investment and aims to tap into OCBC's "deep understanding of young families." With collaborations from Robinsons, NTUC FairPrice, and Doctor Anywhere, the online platform offers a one-stop shop for expectant and new mothers, providing convenience and personalized services. OCBC plans to expand its marketplaces to remain competitive in the digital age.

site_title: 2017 a bumper year for insurance par fund returns
summary: Singapore's traditional participating (par) insurance policies experienced a robust 2017 with a 9.55% one-year average return, exceeding the 4.65% 12-year average return from 2006-2017. However, the outlook for 2018 appears more modest due to trade tensions, rate hike expectations, and tighter financial conditions. Insurers Prudential, AIA, and Manulife are expected to deliver consistent returns, but policyholders may still face deductions eating into their returns. The industry average performance has been lifted by 2017's outstanding performance, with Prudential remaining the most consistent insurer.

site_title: Continental AG prepares to list powertrain unit mid-2019
summary: Continental AG plans to list its powertrain unit in mid-2019, generating cash for investments in electric vehicles and self-driving features. The unit, which generated 7.7 billion euros in sales last year, will retain control under the new corporate structure. The move is part of the company's biggest overhaul in decades, aiming to adapt to the auto industry's shift towards electric cars. The listing will also allow Continental to consider expanding into battery cell production, with a decision to be made after 2020.

site_title: Oil prices fall on US stock rise, higher supply
summary: Oil prices fell on Wednesday, with Brent crude hitting a three-month low, after a rise in US crude inventories highlighted increasing global supply and concerns over weak demand. US light crude fell 75 US cents to $67.33 a barrel, and Brent crude recovered to around $71.50 a barrel after reaching a low of $71.23. Analysts expect a rapid lengthening in the global oil supply balance, citing increased production by Saudi Arabia and other OPEC members, as well as easing supply disruptions.

site_title: China Mining International proposes name change and diversifying into agriculture
summary: China Mining International proposes a name change to Zhongnong Huasheng International and plans to diversify into agriculture, investing in cultivation and production of agricultural resources. The company will acquire a 63.11% stake in Henan Zhongnong Huasheng Agricultural Science and Technology for S$37.2 million. This move aims to build diversified returns and long-term growth, following the expiry of a long-stop date for a sale-and-purchase agreement. The company's shares last closed at S$0.29, and a name change and business diversification are proposed in an extraordinary general meeting.

site_title: Manufacturing Integration Technology to sell semiconductor business for S$84.5m
summary: Manufacturing Integration Technology (MIT) is selling its semiconductor business to Ningbo MIT Semiconductor Company for S$84.5 million, focusing on contract equipment manufacturing and customised automation. The sale includes assets and two subsidiaries, and MIT expects to distribute net proceeds as a special dividend. The disposal aims to unlock accumulated value for shareholders and establish a second pillar in the PRC market. A shareholder approval is required for the sale, which is expected to be completed soon.

site_title: WhatsApp seeks to stem fake news ahead of Pakistan election
summary: WhatsApp launched a week-long campaign in Pakistan to combat fake news ahead of the general election. The campaign, featuring a full-page ad in Dawn, provides 10 tips to differentiate between rumors and fact. The tips include looking for spelling mistakes and verifying information. The move comes as the country prepares to hold its first general election in seven years. WhatsApp aims to help users make informed decisions and reduce the spread of misinformation.

site_title: Elon Musk apologises to British caver for 'pedo' slur
summary: Elon Musk has apologized to British caver Vernon Unsworth for using a derogatory term to describe him, retracting the comment that sparked widespread outrage. Musk's apology comes after Unsworth ridiculed Musk's plan to rescue the trapped Thai boys using a miniature submarine. Musk took responsibility for his actions, stating that the fault was his alone and apologizing to Unsworth and the companies he represents. The apology comes after shares in Tesla briefly tumbled due to the controversy.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 15.79 points to 1,753.07, with 2.6 billion lots traded worth RM2.2 billion. The market saw 594 gainers compared to 295 losers.

site_title: Protecting financial services sector from security threats gets boost from public-private partnership
summary: The Cyber Security Agency of Singapore (CSA) and the Financial Services Information Sharing and Analysis Center (FS-ISAC) have signed a three-year memorandum of understanding to advance security threat intelligence sharing and conduct joint exercises to protect the financial services sector. The partnership aims to enhance cybersecurity in Singapore and the region, providing a global perspective on cyber threats through FS-ISAC's 7,000 members. The collaboration will facilitate cooperation and intelligence sharing to address pressing cybersecurity issues and stay ahead of cybercrime.

site_title: Singapore shares end flat on Wednesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index closed flat on Wednesday, ending at 3,240.5, with 1.43 billion shares worth S$1.02 billion changing hands. The index rose 0.02% or 0.86 point. Gainers outnumbered losers 189 to 182, with Jasper Investments Limited being the most actively traded stock. No major announcements were made, except for Mirach Energy's trading halt.

site_title: Morgan Stanley beats estimates on higher trading revenue
summary: Morgan Stanley reported a better-than-expected quarterly profit, driven by gains in its fixed income and equities trading businesses. Net income rose to $2.4 billion, beating the average analyst expectation of $1.11 per share. The bank's net revenue rose 12% to $10.6 billion, with institutional securities accounting for 54% of the gains. Increased market volatility, largely due to escalating trade tensions, contributed to the bank's strong earnings season.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore regulators plan to enhance anti-money laundering measures by utilizing data analytics and improving information sharing with financial institutions. Singapore Airlines will add a fourth daily flight to Tokyo's Haneda and operate an A380 on its Osaka route. The Cyber Security Agency and Financial Services Information Sharing and Analysis Center signed a memorandum of understanding to advance security threat intelligence sharing. Tat Hong Holdings will be delisted after a successful compulsory acquisition by its CEO and Standard Chartered's private equity arm.

site_title: Sias calls on Shanghai Turbo shareholders to vote against proposed resolution to remove board
summary: Sias, the Securities Investors Association (Singapore), has urged all minority shareholders of Shanghai Turbo Enterprises Ltd to vote against a proposed resolution to remove the incumbent board of directors at the upcoming EGM on July 24. Sias questioned the legitimacy of two new shareholders holding a 10.6% stake, who are seeking to remove the current board. The association expressed concerns over the lack of experience and training of the new shareholders and their potential coordination with former CEO Liu Ming.

site_title: EU to curb steel imports in response to Trump tariffs
summary: The European Union plans to implement measures to curb steel imports, following the US imposition of tariffs on incoming steel and aluminium. The EU Commission proposes a quota and tariff to counter potential flooding of European markets. This is the EU's third response to US tariffs, following the imposition of tariffs on $4.46 billion of US imports and a World Trade Organization challenge. The EU aims to protect its steel industry from US tariffs.

site_title: ECB bond-buying creates zombie companies, possible successor to Dimon warns
summary: The European Central Bank's bond-buying program has created a "dangerous" environment for investors by masking risks in the corporate debt market, according to Mary Callahan Erdoes, head of JPMorgan Chase's asset and wealth management business. The program has artificially inflated the market for investment-grade corporate debt, making it harder to invest and creating "walking-zombie companies" that may struggle once the central bank stops supporting borrowing costs. Erdoes warned that this could lead to a correction in the market, posing a risk to investors.

site_title: South America soy growers may get 2-year window for China sales
summary: Uruguayan soy growers may benefit from China's higher demand for soybeans due to the Sino-US trade war. China's tariffs on US agricultural products, including soybeans, could lead to increased purchases from South American countries like Uruguay. The country's soybean prices have risen above benchmark futures, and producers are advised to hold onto their supplies until the market calms down, according to Union Agriculture Group Corp. This could provide a 2-year window for Uruguayan soy sales to China, potentially displacing US soy in Europe.

images.alt_text: South America's main soybean-producing nations could benefit from higher demand from China through 2020 thanks to a Sino-US trade war, according to one of Uruguay's largest farm companies.

site_title: Swatch Group expects sales growth this year as Asia recovers
summary: Swatch Group expects strong sales growth this year driven by Asia's recovery and North America's double-digit sales increase. The company's first-half net profit bounced back 67% to 468 million Swiss francs, with sales rising 12.6% to 4.266 billion francs. Analysts expect growth to decelerate in the second half, but Swatch's shares rose 1.1% ahead of the European sector index, driven by strong demand from younger consumers and increasing interest in pre-owned products.

site_title: Malaysia's June inflation rate at 3-year low after GST withdrawal
summary: Malaysia's consumer price index rose at its slowest pace in over three years in June, with an inflation rate of 0.8%. The rate was lower than forecast and down from May's 1.8% due to the abolition of the goods and services tax (GST) and discounts during Eid al-Fitr celebrations. The Statistics Department attributed the decrease to lower costs across all goods and services, except for transport, which rose 5.5% due to higher domestic fuel prices. The central bank left its key interest rate unchanged at 3.25%.

site_title: EU fines Google record 4.34b euros in Android case
summary: The European Union has fined Google a record 4.34 billion euros for using its Android mobile operating system to squeeze out rivals, nearly doubling the previous record. EU antitrust chief Margrethe Vestager said Google's practices denied rivals the chance to innovate and compete on the merits, and denied European consumers the benefits of effective competition. Google will appeal the fine and must halt anti-competitive practices within 90 days or face additional penalties. The EU's decision could add to a brewing trade war between Brussels and Washington, with US President Donald Trump set to meet EU leaders to discuss trade tensions.

site_title: Tat Hong to be delisted after successful completion of compulsory acquisition
summary: Tat Hong Holdings will be delisted after completing a compulsory acquisition by Standard Chartered's private equity arm, THSC Investments. The offeror received valid acceptances from 93.62% of shareholders, with the offer price rising from S$0.50 to S$0.55 per share. The company's management cited low trading volume and listing compliance costs as reasons for the privatization, which will allow for more flexibility and efficient use of resources. Tat Hong will be a wholly owned subsidiary of THSC Investments.

site_title: United Overseas Insurance Q2 net profit falls 16% to S$6.9m
summary: United Overseas Insurance (UOI) reported a 16% decline in Q2 net profit to S$6.9m, with gross premium written falling 0.9% to S$29.5m. Annualised earnings per share dropped 15.5% to 45.12 cents. The company attributed the decline to market-wide premium rate erosion and risk-control efforts. UOI shares remained unchanged at S$6.60. The company's Q2 results mirrored a 24.8% decline in Q2 net profit and a 3.5% decline in Q1 gross premium written.

site_title: Yuan hits one-year low, testing China's tolerance for weakness
summary: The yuan fell to its lowest level since August, weakening 0.29% to 6.7229 per US dollar, amid US dollar rallies and speculation that Chinese officials are comfortable with the currency's weakness. The yuan has slid 4.7% since mid-June, becoming Asia's worst performer. While a trade spat with the US continues to weigh on sentiment, the People's Bank of China is unlikely to set a line in the sand for the exchange rate. A potential compromise would likely result in a sizable reduction in China's trade surplus, weakening the fundamentals and exchange rate.

site_title: Australia economy set to keep growing, even as clouds gather: poll
summary: Australia's economy is expected to grow 2.9% in 2018, surpassing previous forecasts, driven by population growth and public investment. A strong first quarter with 3.1% GDP growth has contributed to the upward revision. However, high debt levels at home and trade tensions abroad, including US tariffs, pose threats to the economy. Despite these challenges, economists remain optimistic about Australia's economic momentum.

site_title: US: Stocks flat on solid earnings, weak housing data
summary: US stocks remained flat on Wednesday, following mixed economic data. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose slightly, while the S&P 500 increased a small amount. The Nasdaq Composite Index retreated 0.2% despite a record close on Tuesday. The Federal Reserve reported a nine-month low in US home building in June, and the pace of building permits also decreased. Notable earnings reports included Morgan Stanley's 39% jump in second-quarter earnings and United Continental's 5.6% increase in its full-year earnings forecast.

site_title: Australian shares cheered by BHP's record annual iron ore output; NZ down
summary: Australian shares rose 0.7% to 6,245.1 on Wednesday, boosted by BHP's record iron ore output for fiscal 2018, which sent its shares up 3.3% and lifted the mining index 1.4%. The US dollar strengthened after Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's testimony on the US economy, while oil prices dropped. New Zealand's benchmark index fell 0.4% to 8,946.1, with healthcare stocks leading the losses.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Wednesday afternoon at 3,252.44, up 0.4% on day
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.4% on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index reaching 3,252.44, driven by gains in Koufu Group and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding. The most actively traded counters included SGX debutant Koufu Group and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, with 25.4 million and 22.3 million shares traded respectively. Gainers outnumbered losers 157 to 135, as about 636 million shares worth S$500 million changed hands.

site_title: South Korea cuts economic growth outlook, wage hikes seen choking jobs recovery
summary: South Korea has cut its economic growth forecast for this year to 2.9%, citing a weak labour market recovery and global trade tensions. The country's finance ministry also revised down its projections for inflation to 1.6% and private consumption growth to 2.7%. Steep minimum wage hikes are seen as a major concern, potentially choking a labour market recovery, with businesses expected to cap hiring. The government plans to increase fiscal spending to boost domestic demand, but will not sell more treasury bonds to avoid increasing government debt.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher on cheaper yen
summary: Tokyo stocks rose on Wednesday, driven by a cheaper yen against the dollar. The Nikkei 225 index gained 0.43% to close at 22,794.19, while the Topix index rose 0.35% to 1,751.21. The stronger yen typically weakens Japanese exports, but the market's reaction was unexpected.

site_title: Lion Global launches low-cost active funds; total expense ratio at 0.5%
summary: Lion Global Investors has launched a low-cost actively managed multi-asset fund series with a total expense ratio (TER) of 0.5%, aiming to reduce costs for underserved institutional and individual investors. The funds are available through OCBC and online channels, targeting charities and clan associations with assets under S$5 million. The launch follows Lion Global's previous success with a real estate investment trust ETF, with the goal of attracting S$100 million in assets by year-end and demonstrating the feasibility of low fees in the industry.

site_title: Google said to be fined record 4.3b euros by EU over Android
summary: Google has been fined a record 4.3 billion euros by the European Union over its Android operating system, exceeding the previous record of 2.4 billion euros. The fine is related to Google's contracts with smartphone manufacturers and telecoms operators, which require them to install Google's search and browser apps. The decision is seen as a significant blow to Google's market share, which is currently over 90% for general Internet search. The fine is expected to be announced midday on Wednesday, and it may also include an order freeing up phone manufacturers to choose non-Google apps.

site_title: Thai cave boys to leave hospital, speak to media
summary: Thirteen Thai boys, including their football coach, rescued from a cave in Thailand are set to leave the hospital and speak to the media for the first time. The session, called "Sending the Wild Boars Home," will be informal and moderated, with questions screened by psychiatrists. The boys, aged 11-16, are in good mental and physical health but will undergo additional psychological monitoring for potential lingering trauma. They will likely return home immediately after the press conference, which is expected to last 45 minutes.

site_title: Celebrating good governance at the Singapore Corporate Awards
summary: The 13th annual Singapore Corporate Awards honored 34 companies and six individuals for their excellence in corporate governance and shareholder communication. DBS Group received the Special Recognition Award for its "all-round excellence in corporate governance." Property groups CapitaLand and Tuan Sing topped the winners, with CapitaLand winning four awards and Tuan Sing winning three. The awards were presented at a black-tie event dubbed the "Oscars" of the Singapore business world, recognizing the best managed boards, CEOs, CFOs, investor relations, and annual reports.

site_title: Grab, NUS launch first-of-its-kind AI lab
summary: Grab and the National University of Singapore (NUS) launched an AI lab with a joint initial investment of S$6 million, marking Grab's first major AI lab and NUS's first with a commercial partner. The lab will leverage Grab's 3 petabytes of data and NUS's data from various research units to improve transportation efficiency and address challenges in South-east Asia. Researchers will create a robust AI platform for large-scale machine learning and visual analytics, and the lab will focus on creating novel applications, including assisting transport authorities in monitoring and optimising traffic flow.

site_title: Champagne as historic commercial flight links Ethiopia and Eritrea
summary: Ethiopia and Eritrea resumed commercial airline flights for the first time in 20 years, marking a significant step in their peace process. Ethiopian Airlines' flight 312 landed in Asmara, Eritrea's capital, after a one-and-a-half hour flight from Addis Ababa. The flight, which took place just six weeks after a surprise thaw between the neighboring countries, was met with singing and cheering onboard. This development follows a whirlwind peace process between the former foes, with the two countries agreeing to end a state of war and establish diplomatic relations.

images.alt_text: Ethiopia and Eritrea on Wednesday resumed commercial airline flights for the first time in two decades, marking the latest phase in a whirlwind peace process between the former foes.

site_title: Malaysia appoints Singapore law firm to start 1MDB legal action against 53 individuals and companies
summary: Malaysia has appointed Singapore law firm Tan Rajah & Cheah to initiate legal action against 53 individuals and companies for allegedly embezzling funds from 1MDB, a state-owned development company. Attorney-General Tommy Thomas approved the appointment, and the Malaysian government plans to file an application at the High Court in Singapore to recover the allegedly stolen monies. The move aims to recover billions of dollars in losses suffered by 1MDB.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open higher on Wednesday
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.68% in early trade on Wednesday, driven by a Wall Street rally following the US Federal Reserve chief's positive economic outlook. The Hang Seng Index climbed to 28,374.48, while the Shanghai Composite Index added 0.13% to 2,801.78.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks fall on dim economic growth outlook; won bows to strong dollar
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index fell 0.34% to 2,290.11, while the won dropped to its lowest since October 2017, at 1,132.3 per dollar. The country cut its economic growth forecast citing a weak labour market recovery and global trade tensions. A military helicopter crash in Pohang, killing five, and a decline in bond yields were also contributing factors.

site_title: HSR project: Malaysia's economic affairs minister to lead delegation to Singapore for talks
summary: Malaysia's Economic Affairs Minister Mohamed Azmin Ali will lead a delegation to Singapore to discuss the high-speed rail (HSR) project and safeguard diplomatic relations. The Attorney General's Chambers has examined the bilateral agreement, which includes clauses allowing either country to opt out of the project. The matter will be resolved based on laws and involves bilateral negotiations. The move aims to resolve outstanding issues and maintain a positive relationship between the two nations.

site_title: Skills framework for food manufacturing industry launched
summary: Singapore's Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing launched a skills framework for the food manufacturing industry, aiming to build a strong talent pool by identifying key skills, career pathways, and emerging skills. The framework covers 71 technical skills, 18 generic skills, and will support the industry's manpower needs. It will also introduce masterclasses to familiarize professionals with emerging skills, in collaboration with the Food, Drinks and Allied Workers Union and the Singapore Institute for Food Science and Technology.

site_title: Price tag for HSR project includes costs not disclosed by previous government: Malaysian minister
summary: Malaysia's Economic Affairs Minister Mohamed Azmin Ali revealed that the estimated RM110 billion price tag for the High Speed Railway (HSR) project includes hidden costs not disclosed by the previous administration. The previous Barisan Nasional government had estimated the project at RM72 billion. Azmin questioned the affordability of the project, considering Malaysia's national debt of RM1 trillion. The government will hold talks with Singapore to discuss the fate of the HSR project, which has sparked concerns over the project's cost and impact on the economy.

site_title: Texas Instruments CEO resigns on code of conduct violation
summary: Texas Instruments CEO Brian Crutcher resigned six weeks into his role after violating the company's code of conduct, citing a personal behavior issue. Chairman Rich Templeton will resume his duties as CEO and president. The company reported second-quarter earnings and sales that beat estimates, with shares falling 2.5% in after-market trading. Templeton stated that the board responded promptly to the report, emphasizing accountability and ethics.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Wednesday, STI up 0.5% to 3,256.87
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 17.23 points, or 0.5%, to 3,256.87, driven by an upbeat assessment of the US economy from Fed chairman Jerome Powell. The market saw 63 million shares traded, with gains outnumbering losses 67-38. Key movers included Keppel Corp and OCBC Bank, while regional markets, such as Japan's Topix and Australia's S&P/ASX 200, also posted gains. The US stock market advanced, with the Dow Jones and S&P 500 reaching new records.

site_title: Asia: Markets rise after Federal Reserve chief boosts US confidence
summary: Asian markets rose on July 18, 2018, after Federal Reserve chief Jerome Powell expressed confidence in the US economy, citing a strong job market and inflation figures. This boosted US stocks, leading to a fourth consecutive day of gains for the Dow and a new high for the Nasdaq. The positive outlook from Powell was seen as music to investors' ears, tracking the rally.

site_title: Thailand June tourist arrivals rise 11.6% y-o-y: tourism ministry
summary: Thailand's international tourist arrivals rose 11.6% year-over-year to 3.03 million in June, driven by visitors from China, Malaysia, and India. Tourists spent 148.4 billion baht (S$6.10 billion) in June, a 14.5% increase from the previous year. January-June arrivals reached 19.48 million, with spending up 15.8% to 1.02 trillion baht.

site_title: Nordic clinches S$13m of contracts
