summary: Nordic Group secured S$13 million of contracts from various divisions, including S$4.3 million for scaffolding and insulation works, S$4.2 million for precision engineering, and S$2.3 million for system integration. The company also clinched S$1.2 million of maintenance service contracts from a new customer. This brings Nordic's outstanding order book to S$99.3 million. The scaffolding and insulation division received S$4.3 million of maintenance service contracts, while the precision engineering division secured S$4.2 million of capital projects.

site_title: MAS to ramp up measures to fight money laundering, terrorism financing
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) plans to ramp up measures to combat money laundering and terrorism financing by leveraging technology and collaboration with financial institutions. Assistant managing director Ho Hern Shin emphasized the need to strike a balance between fighting financial crime and improving financial inclusion. The MAS will utilize data analytics tools to better identify high-risk areas and is exploring the introduction of basic bank accounts with restrictions to mitigate risks. A private-public partnership launched in 2017 will be improved through enhanced information sharing with financial institutions.

site_title: Hong Kong, China bourses agree to work towards adding dual-class shares to trading link
summary: Hong Kong's Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing (HKEX) has agreed to work with China's bourses to include dual-class shares in a cross-border trading link, resolving a dispute. The shares must demonstrate trading stability before being included in the stock connect scheme. A working group will be formed to establish specific programs and rules for dual-class shares. The move comes after mainland exchanges blocked foreign firms and companies with weighted voting rights from participating in the scheme, aimed at protecting less sophisticated investors. Xiaomi shares jumped 6% after the announcement.

images.alt_text: A worker pulls a handcart loaded with firewood for the cremation of a Covid-19 coronavirus victim at Nigambodh Ghat Crematorium in New Delhi on April 28, 2021. (Photo by TAUSEEF MUSTAFA / AFP)##########nahaid30##########

site_title: Government launches plan to get smaller security agencies to use basic technology
summary: Singapore aims to have most security agencies adopt basic technology solutions, such as automated visitor management and closed-circuit television cameras, by 2025. Currently, only 30% of 240 security firms have leveraged such technology. The government has launched the Security Industry Digital Plan, which provides a step-by-step guide for companies to adopt technology solutions at each stage of growth. The plan aims to double the number of agencies adopting technology by 2020 and make these technologies a "norm" by 2025. The government will also provide funding support to local small and medium enterprise security agencies to help them adopt pre-approved digital solutions.

site_title: US police capture suspected serial killer in Texas
summary: US police have captured a suspected serial killer, Jose Gilberto Rodriguez, in Texas. Rodriguez, 46, is accused of killing at least three people in seven days. He was arrested after a 14-minute car chase with police and faces two capital murder charges, with a third expected. A resident tipped off authorities to Rodriguez's vehicle location, leading to his capture.

site_title: Workers feared trapped in India building site collapse: report
summary: A six-storey building under construction in Greater Noida, India, collapsed on Wednesday, trapping at least 12 workers. Rescue efforts are underway to free the labourers. This is the latest construction accident in India, where enforcement of safety rules is weak and substandard materials are often used. Building collapses are common during the monsoon season, resulting in multiple fatalities in recent incidents, including 18 deaths in May when a flyover collapsed.

site_title: China cuts Air China's flight hours, launches safety review after incident
summary: China's aviation regulator has cut Air China's Boeing 737 flight hours by 10% and cancelled pilot and co-pilot licenses after an emergency descent incident on July 10, where the aircraft dropped to 10,000 feet with oxygen masks deployed. The incident was linked to a co-pilot smoking an e-cigarette. As a result, the regulator will also launch a three-month safety crackdown and fine the airline 50,000 yuan.

site_title: Singapore Airlines to add 4th daily flight to Tokyo's Haneda; A380 to service Osaka route
summary: Singapore Airlines will add a fourth daily flight to Tokyo's Haneda Airport, operated by the Boeing 777-300ER, from Dec 28, increasing daily services to six per day. The airline will also operate the Airbus A380 on its Osaka route from Oct 28, 2018 to March 30, 2019, adding over 720 seats per week. This move will increase the SIA Group's combined weekly services between Singapore and Japan to 105.

images.alt_text: In a bid to meet growing travel demand between Singapore and Japan, Singapore Airlines (SIA) will add a fourth daily service to Tokyo's Haneda Airport from Dec 28 and operate the Airbus A380 on its Osaka route from Oct 28, 2018 to March 30, 2019.

site_title: Trump now says no 'time limit' to denuclearise North Korea
summary: President Donald Trump said there is no "time limit" to denuclearize North Korea, reversing his previous statement that the process would start "very soon." Trump discussed North Korea with Russian President Vladimir Putin at their Helsinki summit and stated that discussions with North Korea are "going very, very well." The US and North Korea's agreement did not specify a timetable for denuclearization, leaving diplomats to hammer out the details. Despite initial optimism, no concrete progress has been reported, with North Korea complaining of unilateral American demands.

site_title: Four years on, Dutch remember those lost on flight MH17
summary: Bereaved relatives of 298 people killed in Malaysia Airlines Flight MH17 held a solemn ceremony in the Netherlands four years after the plane was shot down over Ukraine in 2014. The Russian-made Buk missile struck the plane on July 17, 2014, killing everyone on board. The ceremony was organized by the victims' families at a memorial near Schiphol airport, where they continue to await justice. The incident remains a major unresolved issue in international relations between Russia and Ukraine.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on cheaper yen
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Wednesday, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.95% to 22,912.20, driven by a cheaper yen against the dollar. The move extended Wall Street rallies following the US Federal Reserve chief's strong economic outlook. The Topix index also rose 0.89%.

site_title: McQueen, suicide and the dark side of the celebrity fairy tale
summary: Celebrity chef Anthony Bourdain and fashion icon Kate Spade's suicides in June 2018 sparked a national conversation about the dark side of celebrity fairy tales. The recent deaths of Alexander McQueen, Chester Bennington, Chris Cornell, Tony Scott, and Robin Williams have highlighted the shocking trend of high-profile suicides. McQueen's new documentary "McQueen" explores the life and struggles of the 40-year-old designer who died by suicide in 2010, revealing a tortured artist with a singular vision. The film sheds light on the pressures of fame, loneliness, and depression that can lead to devastating consequences.

images.alt_text: When celebrity chef Anthony Bourdain and fashion icon Kate Spade killed themselves within the space of three days in June, many couldn't fathom the tragedy of two people who seemed to have it all.

site_title: BHP hits record iron ore output, flags Samarco charge
summary: BHP, the world's largest miner, reported record iron ore output and a $650 million charge from the Samarco dam collapse in Brazil. The company aims to sell its US shale assets, which it bought for $20 billion in 2011, amid price headwinds. BHP boosted iron ore production, aided by improved productivity, and expects to announce US shale asset sales within the coming months. The company also expects to record a $650 million charge from the Samarco mine failure, which killed 19 people in 2015.

site_title: Malaysia shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Wednesday, down 3.39 points to 1,733.89 at 9am. Volume was 41.56 million lots worth RM17.06 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 111 to 39.

site_title: US: Nasdaq ends at record after Federal Reserve upbeat on US economy
summary: The Nasdaq Composite Index reached a record high on Tuesday, closing at 7,855.12 after the Federal Reserve chief expressed an upbeat view of the US economy. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 also gained, with the Nasdaq's 0.6% increase surpassing its previous record set on July 13. The positive sentiment was attributed to the Fed's optimism, despite ongoing trade uncertainty.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Vard, Vibrant Limited, SIIC Environment, Nordic Group
summary: Stocks to watch on July 18, 2018: Vard Holdings faces a bid to delist by Fincantieri due to CIMB Bank's concerns over precedent transaction and price benchmark decisions. Vibrant Limited's auditors, KPMG, found irregularities in coal mining and trading receipts, and sales invoices. SIIC Environment Holdings' CFO Tan Kai Teck resigned, citing no disagreement with the board. Nordic Group secured S$13 million in contracts, including S$4.3 million for scaffolding and insulation works.

site_title: Shaping corporate culture from the top, Events & Awards - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: Vietnam expressed surprise over US President Donald Trump's announcement of tariffs on the country, with the goal of pressuring Hanoi to lower its trade deficit. The tariffs, expected to be implemented in August, target various Vietnamese goods including steel, aluminum, and footwear. Vietnam's government has urged the US to reconsider the move, citing concerns about the impact on bilateral trade and economic ties. The country is seeking a more favorable trade agreement, with lower tariffs, to boost exports and stimulate economic growth. Diplomatic efforts are underway to address the issue.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Key corporate news includes China Sky Chemical Fibre Co's CEO Ling Yew Kong resigning due to limited access to information about Chinese subsidiaries. Abterra Group's general manager BAEY Yam Chye retired after nearly 12 years. Metech International served a writ of summons against the trustee of Mapletree Industrial Trust for unpaid rental of about S$540,338.

site_title: Influential cancer researcher Alan Rabson dead at 92
summary: Renowned cancer researcher Alan Rabson, who made significant contributions to defining cancer pathology and understanding the role of viruses in cancer, has passed away at 92 due to complications of vascular disease. As a pathologist, he helped generations of pathologists identify cancer, and his work also led to discoveries about herpes viruses causing shingles and recurrent cold sores. A dedicated administrator, Rabson served as director of the Division of Cancer Biology at the National Cancer Institute and deputy director of the institute, earning the respect of colleagues and patients alike for his kindness, empathy, and willingness to help those with cancer diagnoses.

site_title: Vibrant's auditors unable to complete audit in Blackgold unit; shares down S$0.13 or 40%
summary: Vibrant Limited, a Singapore-listed company, reported that its auditor KPMG was unable to complete an audit of its financial statements for the year ended April 30 due to irregularities and discrepancies in coal mining and coal trading receipts and sales invoices in its Blackgold International Holdings unit. The shares dropped 40% to S$0.20 after resuming trading. The company's board has authorized a special auditor to investigate the irregularities and appointed a special committee to supervise the Blackgold subsidiaries.

site_title: Koufu at S$0.64 after midday break on trading debut, up 1.6% from IPO price
summary: Koufu Group, a food court operator, made its debut on the Singapore Exchange's mainboard at S$0.65, 2 cents above its IPO price of S$0.63. The company's shares rose 1.6% to S$0.64 at the end of the trading day, with 25.5 million shares changing hands. The listing boosts SGX's consumer cluster to 152 listings with a combined market capitalisation of over S$135 billion. Koufu's CEO Pang Lim expressed confidence in the company's track record and growth plans.

site_title: French automaker PSA eyeing Canada amid Trump auto tariff threat
summary: French automaker Groupe PSA may shift its US market plans to Canada if the US imposes a 25% tariff on imported autos. PSA had been planning to return to the US market by 2026, but regional chief Larry Dominique says tariffs would delay and increase costs. Canada, however, offers duty-free admission to European-made cars under a new free trade deal, making it a more attractive option. PSA is also considering entering the US market with a car-sharing service before selling autos, with studies showing American consumers generally have positive views of French automobiles.

site_title: Teens glued to phones risk 'modest' rise in ADHD symptoms: study
summary: A new study found a "modest" but significant rise in new ADHD behaviors among nearly 2,600 Los Angeles teens who engaged in excessive smartphone use over a two-year period. The study, published in the Journal of the American Medical Association, suggests that digital overload could be linked to an increase in ADHD symptoms. The findings offer a warning to parents about the potential dangers of too much screen time, highlighting the need for parents to monitor their children's phone use and encourage a balance between technology and other activities.

site_title: Oil steadies on US stockpile forecasts, Venezuela worries
summary: Oil prices steadied on Tuesday as inventories in the US are expected to decline 3.5 million barrels, but supply disruptions in Venezuela and Libya remain a concern. Two of Venezuela's four crude upgraders are scheduled to undergo maintenance, which could further reduce output. US crude inventories rose 629,000 barrels in the week ending July 13, contrary to expectations. The market is awaiting clear signals on supply, including Libya's oil production rebound and Saudi production levels.

images.alt_text: Crude oil futures steadied on Tuesday as the focus turned to falling inventories in the United States and further output constraints in Venezuela and Libya.

site_title: Trump says he misspoke on Russia election meddling
summary: President Donald Trump said he accepts that Russia sought to influence the 2016 US election, contradicting his earlier statement. He claimed to have misspoken when appearing to accept Vladimir Putin's denial of interference, stating "I don't see any reason why it would be." Trump clarified that he actually meant to say "I don't see any reason why it wouldn't be Russia." The move comes after Trump publicly challenged US intelligence on Russia's election meddling, sparking criticism from both Democrats and Republicans.

site_title: United Airlines raises profit forecast, trims capacity expansion
summary: United Airlines raised its 2018 profit forecast to between $7.25 and $8.75 per share, up from its previous range, due to rising average fares and traffic. The airline also trimmed its capacity expansion amid soaring fuel costs. The company's second-quarter profit topped analysts' estimates, causing its shares to rise as much as 4.2%. This move is seen as a response to increasing competition and fuel costs, allowing the airline to maintain its financial stability.

site_title: Netflix shares dive as subscriber growth misses mark
summary: Netflix's Q2 subscriber growth fell short of expectations, with 5.2 million new members bringing the total to 130 million, missing a forecast of 130 million. Shares plummeted 14.11% to $343.97 in after-market trade. Despite this, the company reported in-line earnings, margins, and revenue, and has been gaining ground artistically with its original content. Analysts see the miss as a "speed bump" and predict the company will continue to grow, with a content arms race expected to drive the company's success.

site_title: As Amazon slashes prices, Bezos sees jump in wealth
summary: Amazon founder Jeff Bezos' net worth surpassed $150 billion, making him the world's richest person in decades, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index. His net worth increased by $50 billion this year due to Amazon's surge in the share price. Bezos now holds a lead over fellow billionaires, including Microsoft founder Bill Gates, and has become the only person to top the $100 billion milestone since 1999. Amazon's market capitalization has risen to nearly $880 billion, ahead of Google parent Alphabet but behind Apple, following the company's "Prime Day" sales event.

site_title: US dollar firms after Federal Reserve chair's upbeat remarks, stocks gain
summary: The US dollar rose against a basket of major currencies after Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's upbeat economic assessment, while world stocks climbed as corporate earnings kicked into gear. Powell stated the US economy is on track for steady growth, dismissing concerns about a trade tariff war. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 55.53 points, the S&P 500 gained 11.12 points, and the Nasdaq Composite added 49.40 points, amidst a busy week of corporate earnings. The dollar index rose 0.47% and the euro fell 0.4% to US$1.1662.

site_title: First Reit Q2 net property income up 5%; DPU at 2.15 cents
summary: First Reit reported a 5% increase in Q2 net property income to S$16.9 million, driven by contributions from acquired assets in 2017. Distribution per unit (DPU) rose to 2.15 Singapore cents, a 0.1% increase from the year-ago period. The results were lifted by the healthcare real estate investment trust's existing properties.

site_title: Didi to spin off car services unit in deal worth of up to US$1.5b: sources
summary: Chinese ride-hailing giant Didi Chuxing Technology Co Ltd is planning to spin off its car services unit in a deal worth up to US$1.5 billion ahead of its expected initial public offering. The unit, which provides car rental and maintenance services, has been valued between US$2 billion and US$3 billion. Didi has tapped investors including SoftBank Group to raise funds for the spin-off. The move comes as the company prepares for its expected IPO, which is expected to be one of the biggest in recent years with a valuation of US$56 billion.

site_title: Gems, precious metals dealers face new rules to curb money laundering, terrorism
summary: Singapore's precious stones and metals dealers may be required to register with the Ministry of Law to curb money laundering and terrorism financing. The new rules also mandate dealers to implement processes to tackle the risk of such misdeeds.

site_title: UK PM May narrowly avoids defeat in parliament on EU trade laws
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May narrowly avoided a defeat in parliament on Tuesday, with 307 MPs voting against an amendment to trade legislation and 301 in favor. The amendment would have required the government to negotiate a customs union with the EU by January 2019, but May's government sidestepped defeat. The vote was seen as a test of May's ability to deliver a smooth Brexit, and sterling rebounded from day's lows against the dollar. Despite the narrow victory, May faces further challenges to her Brexit strategy and will need to navigate a divided parliament in the coming weeks.

images.alt_text: British Prime Minister Theresa May narrowly avoided a defeat in parliament at the hands of pro-EU lawmakers from her own party on Tuesday, fending off a rebellion that had threatened to deepen a crisis over her Brexit strategy

site_title: Federal Reserve to continue to raise US interest rates gradually: Powell
summary: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell announced that the US will continue to raise interest rates gradually due to a strong economic outlook, despite uncertainty over trade policy. Powell stated that the Fed is satisfied with its efforts to normalize monetary policy and is confident that a strong job market, inflation near the 2% target, and balanced risks support further rate hikes. However, he acknowledged the potential harm to the US and global economies if trade tensions escalate, particularly for American farmers.

images.alt_text: The Federal Reserve will continue to raise rates gradually as the US economic outlook remains strong despite uncertainty over trade policy, Fed Chairman Jerome Powell said Tuesday.

site_title: Singtel unit acquires Videology assets for about US$101m
summary: Singtel's subsidiary Amobee has acquired Videology assets for approximately US$101 million. The acquisition includes Videology's technology platform, intellectual property, and other assets valued at US$5.3 million. The deal is expected to boost Amobee's omnichannel platform and provide marketers with premium video and connected TV content. The acquisition is subject to court and regulatory approvals and closing conditions. Amobee's CEO Kim Perell stated that the acquisition will strengthen the company's capabilities and bring marketers next-generation solutions to reach and engage consumers globally.

site_title: Vard: CIMB responds to queries on fresh IFA letter in Fincantieri's delisting bid
summary: CIMB, the financial advisor for Fincantieri's delisting bid of Vard Holding, has responded to shareholder queries regarding the proposed deal. CIMB stated that it has removed Falcon Energy's 2015 takeover of CH Offshore from its list of precedent transactions due to its lack of relevance to Vard. Despite this, CIMB maintained that the exit offer is "not fair" but "reasonable" and that the mean and median price-to-net asset value ratios of precedent transactions are below the ratio implied in the Vard exit offer price. The delisting resolution must be approved by shareholders with a combined stake of at least 75% to proceed.

site_title: Impact of latest curbs has Redas seminar abuzz
summary: Singapore's property market is abuzz after the implementation of cooling measures on July 6, which include higher buyer's stamp duty (ABSD) and tighter loan-to-value (LTV) ratios. Redas president Augustine Tan warns that the measures will dampen demand, particularly for second homes and beyond, exacerbating the high supply situation. However, JLL's Tay Huey Ying forecasts moderate price growth and a match between supply and demand over the next four years, provided launches are paced sensibly. The collective sale market is also expected to continue, but with narrowed profit margins.

site_title: Europe: Shares take heart from Powell testimony as earnings flow in
summary: European shares rose 0.2% on Tuesday, driven by Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's upbeat testimony on the jobs market and low inflation. Telecom stocks fell 1.2%, led by Telenor's 4% drop, while banks and mining stocks rebounded. The Stoxx 600 index outperformed its US counterparts, with the DAX index rising 0.9% despite the euro's decline. Positive earnings updates from companies like SEB, Casino, and Getinge also boosted shares.

site_title: Pitch invasion, penalties and payment fraud: the dark side of the World Cup
summary: The 2018 World Cup in Russia was marred by various forms of fraud, including pitch invasions, penalties, and payment scams. Fraudsters targeted tourists, harvesting card details through phishing scams and fake URLs. Merchants also struggled with fraud, with 15% of international tourists expected to visit Russia, creating opportunities for scammers. To combat this, merchants can utilize stream analytics and global consortium data for positive profiling, increasing conversions and reducing fraud and chargebacks.

site_title: BoE warns no-deal Brexit will have 'big economic consequences', leave bankers idle
summary: Bank of England Governor Mark Carney warned that a no-deal Brexit would have "big economic consequences" and prompt a review of interest rates, leaving many bankers idle. The UK could crash out of the EU without a ratified transition deal, potentially disrupting cross-border contracts and affecting financial services. Carney expressed concern that the EU has not yet indicated a solution, and the private sector cannot solve these issues, but noted that Britain's banks have sufficient capital and cash reserves to withstand a disorderly Brexit.

site_title: Singapore's first woman architect Designer of the Year
summary: Singapore's first woman architect, Angelene Chan, was named Designer of the Year at the President's Design Award, along with product designer Hans Tan. The award recognizes projects that have significant design impact. Chan, CEO of DP Architects, said she is ambivalent about the title, citing the struggle women architects face in balancing their profession and personal life. Other recipients include Oasia Hotel Downtown, named Best Tall Building Worldwide, and weatherHYDE, a portable shelter designed to end homelessness.

site_title: Still hopelessly devoted after 40 years
summary: Grease, the 1978 classic musical, is celebrating its 40th anniversary, still captivating audiences worldwide with its universal themes, chemistry between its leads, and nostalgic appeal. The film, which grossed $400 million, was initially panned by critics but became a massive hit, thanks in part to the chemistry between John Travolta and Olivia Newton-John. Director Randal Kleiser credits the film's longevity to its flaws, which add to its charm, and the trio's enduring friendship, despite their separate careers and personal struggles.

site_title: Tesla's latest CEO outburst raises doubts about leadership
summary: Tesla CEO Elon Musk sparked controversy after insulting a British diver, Vern Unsworth, on Twitter, calling him "pedo guy." The insult drew widespread criticism and raised concerns about Musk's leadership abilities and stability. Analysts compared Musk to US President Donald Trump, citing his use of Twitter to vent frustration and insult others. The incident led to a 2.75% drop in Tesla shares and pressure on the electric carmaker to meet production targets. Experts urge Musk to issue a huge apology to avoid long-term damage to the company's reputation.

images.alt_text: Mr Musk found himself mired in controversy after insulting Mr Unsworth, a British diver who worked on the Thai soccer team rescue and who dismissed his plan to recover the trapped group from a cave.

site_title: World's biggest miners want more copper but nobody is selling
summary: The world's largest miners are struggling to secure copper deals, despite their bullish outlook on the metal's future demand. Cities' expansion and electric vehicles' growth are expected to drive copper demand, but no major producers are willing to sell. Major copper producers, including those in London, are looking for growth in the metal, but are unable to secure deals. This shortage has created a dilemma for the mining world, with no end in sight as the demand for copper continues to rise.

site_title: What's keeping the shipping industry up at night
summary: The shipping industry's confidence levels have remained steady, with a four-year high of 6.4 out of 10.0 recorded in February 2018. However, the likelihood of major investments or significant developments over the next 12 months decreased from 5.5 to 5.2. Key factors affecting confidence include demand trends, competition, and finance costs, with regulation and oil prices also playing a significant role. The industry is bracing for potential challenges, particularly the 2020 implementation of the global 0.5% sulphur fuel cap, which could impact shipowners with non-compliant vessels.

site_title: 'Amazon effect' turns warehouses into London's hottest properties
summary: The "Amazon effect" is transforming London's real estate market, with online retailers like Amazon seeking local hubs to reduce delivery times and drive growth. As a result, warehouse space is becoming the hottest property in the city, with rents soaring. This trend is driven by the need for faster and more efficient delivery services, and it is expected to continue as more retailers follow Amazon's lead. The impact of this shift is expected to be felt across the city's real estate market.

site_title: Taiwan's offshore wind market a breath of fresh air for O&M sector
summary: Singapore-based offshore and marine (O&M) players are seeking to capitalize on Taiwan's offshore wind market, which offers billions of dollars in contracts. PACC Offshore Services Holdings (POSH) has joined other players in the bid, but must balance meeting bottomline objectives with meeting Taiwan's local content aspirations. Industry players need to find viable ways to increase local content, as the market is expected to be competitive due to slower oilfield services demand.

site_title: Growth at risk as trade conflicts, electronics slowdown take toll on Singapore exports
summary: Singapore's exports showed marginal growth in June, driven by non-electronics exports, but fell short of economists' expectations with a 1.1% year-on-year increase. Electronics shipments continued to contract for the seventh straight month, weighing on the country's growth outlook. Economists warn that trade conflicts, slowing growth in China, and property cooling measures may impact Singapore's growth in the months ahead. Non-oil re-exports rose 5.1% in June, but exports to China declined for the second straight month, sparking concerns about the US-China trade conflict's impact on Singapore's economy.

images.alt_text: Singapore's exports showed signs of faltering as it notched marginal gains in June, dragged down by electronics shipments which continued to contract for the seventh straight month.

site_title: Rolls-Royce unveils hybrid flying taxi at Farnborough
summary: Rolls-Royce unveiled a hybrid flying taxi concept at Farnborough, aiming to develop a prototype within 18 months and take to the skies in the early 2020s. The EVTOL vehicle will seat 4-5 people, have a 500-mile range, and a top speed of 200mph. It combines a gas turbine engine with an electrical system, offering a balance between range and environmental friendliness. Rolls-Royce is not the only company exploring the hybrid "flying taxi" market, with Uber, Kitty Hawk, Lilium Aviation, and others also researching the sector.

site_title: Thyssenkrupp chairman steps down, piling turmoil on top ranks
summary: Thyssenkrupp chairman Ulrich Lehner has resigned amid turmoil at the German engineering conglomerate, following CEO Heinrich Hiesinger's sudden departure under pressure from shareholders. Lehner, who had clashed with major shareholders, including the Alfried Krupp von Bohlen und Halbach foundation, stepped down on July 31, leaving a leadership vacuum at the company. The move comes after activist investors sought to transform the business into a higher-value industrial services company.

site_title: 'Mercedes still fastest despite lost points'
summary: Mercedes remains the fastest team in Formula One despite losing points in their last three consecutive races. Team boss Toto Wolff attributed the losses to their own mistakes. The team is still eight points behind Ferrari, with Lewis Hamilton looking to close the gap at the German Grand Prix. Mercedes brought the quickest car to all three races and have a fast car, giving them reason to be optimistic for the second half of the season.

site_title: Japan, EU sign free trade pact amid worries about Trump
summary: Japan and the European Union signed a free trade deal on July 17, 2018, amid concerns about US President Donald Trump's protectionist policies. The deal, creating the world's largest open economic area, aims to counterbalance the US-China trade tensions. Key benefits include reduced tariffs on Japanese cars and EU food products, and increased access to large public tenders in Japan. The agreement is seen as a statement by Japan and the EU to promote free trade and counter protectionism, with both sides expecting economic benefits, including a 0.8% boost to the EU economy and 0.3% to Japan's.

site_title: ZTE ban in US forces telecoms to rethink suppliers
summary: US trade ban on Chinese telecom equipment maker ZTE has forced wireless carriers worldwide to consider broadening their supply networks. The ban, which lasted three months, disrupted operations at Russian and emerging markets mobile operator Veon, one of the world's 10 largest mobile firms. To avoid being stuck with a supplier, operators may start using multiple vendors, altering their telecoms strategies. The Commerce Department lifted the order on Friday, ending the disruptions.

images.alt_text: The US Commerce Department in April banned US firms from selling goods to ZTE after it failed to comply with a 2016 settlement involving evasion of sanctions against Iran. The ban was lifted on Friday.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Hutchison Port Holdings Trust (HPHT) has declined 30% year-to-date, outperforming the Straits Times Index's -3% due to trade tensions. Despite significant volatility, analysts at OCBC Investment Research believe the counter has significant value. Q2 FY17 throughput numbers showed a 2.7% and 4% increase in April and May 2018, respectively. Investors are advised to collect units after the Q2 results release next Monday.

site_title: Weak export figures keep lid on STI gain
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) grew 1.1% in June, missing economists' projections of 7.8%, casting a shadow on the country's expansion for the second half of 2018. The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.2% to 3,239.64, while the US market fell mostly lower on Monday ahead of corporate earnings and economic news. The IMF warned that global expansion is at risk from the potential escalation of trade tensions, which could cause global output to drop by about 0.5% below projections by 2020.

site_title: Robots will create as many jobs as they destroy: PwC
summary: PwC's analysis predicts UK jobs will be destroyed by 7 million but created by at least the same number over the next two decades due to automation. Manufacturing may see 25% of staff cut by 2037, while health and social work will benefit from 22% more jobs created. The report recommends investing in "STEAM" skills and encouraging workers to update their skills to complement machines. Those with strong digital skills, creativity, and teamwork capabilities are likely to thrive in the fourth industrial revolution.

site_title: Don't let cybersecurity be an afterthought
summary: Cybersecurity incidents can result in significant financial loss, damage to customer satisfaction, and market reputation for organisations that do not prioritize security. A recent study found that the potential economic loss in Singapore due to cybersecurity incidents could reach $17.7 billion, equivalent to 6% of the country's GDP. Organisations must prioritize cybersecurity in their digital transformation strategies to prevent such losses and ensure a secure foundation for future growth.

site_title: Public offer for Koufu shares 17 times subscribed
summary: Koufu, a Singapore-based food court operator, has seen its public offer for shares 17 times subscribed. The initial public offering (IPO) included 90.7 million placement shares and 6.3 million public offer shares, with application monies amounting to S$67.8 million. The offering raised net proceeds of S$70.5 million, with Koufu's market cap expected to be about S$349.8 million post-offering. The company has outlined a growth roadmap, including expanding its network of F&B outlets and online food ordering services.

site_title: Industrial production up 0.6% in June
summary: US industrial production rose 0.6% in June, boosted by a 0.8% surge in manufacturing output, with motor vehicle production increasing 7.8% after a decline in May. The increase, combined with stronger-than-expected retail sales and smaller trade deficits, suggests the economy accelerated sharply in the second quarter, with GDP estimates potentially reaching a 5.2% rate. However, escalating trade tensions and the International Monetary Fund's warning of a slowdown in global exports pose a risk to business spending and economic growth.

site_title: Sias to hold shareholder dialogue ahead of Shanghai Turbo EGM
summary: Singapore's investor watchdog, Sias, is holding a shareholder dialogue for Shanghai Turbo Enterprises ahead of a vote on July 24 to replace its entire board of directors. The move comes amid "serious concerns" over the company's recent events, including a months-long standoff at a Chinese factory and a baton attack on a Singaporean director. The dialogue invites concerned shareholders to meet on July 18 to discuss the proposed action, which Sias says may not be in the interest of minority shareholders and the company.

site_title: In use of public resources, greater accountability and transparency is key
summary: The Auditor-General's Office in Singapore released its annual report, uncovering lapses in government ministries and agencies, including contract management issues, IT weaknesses, and financial control failures. The report found human error as the primary cause of these issues, but Auditor-General Willie Tan emphasized the need for strengthened financial governance and controls. The government must ensure accountability and transparency in public resource use, and agencies must implement corrective actions and disclose outcomes. Full disclosure and transparency are crucial for maintaining trust and confidence in the government.

site_title: Tencent-backed Pinduoduo Inc eyes US$1.6b in latest mega IPO
summary: Pinduoduo Inc, a Chinese e-commerce operator backed by Tencent Holdings, plans to raise up to $1.6 billion in its US IPO. The company is offering 85.6 million American Depositary Shares at $16 to $19 each. Tencent and existing shareholder Sequoia Capital have expressed interest in buying $250 million worth of stock. Pinduoduo aims to use the funds to compete with rivals such as Alibaba.

site_title: Dollar holds steady below a one-year high
summary: The US dollar held steady below a one-year high, as investors became cautious about its outlook due to concerns about US economic momentum peaking and escalating trade conflicts. Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's testimony before the US Senate Banking Committee is being closely watched for clues on interest rate rises and the central bank's response to the trade war. The dollar rose to a 12-month high in late June but has been capped by worries over the US-China trade dispute, with 60% of investors seeing a trade war as the biggest risk for markets.

site_title: Warnings on market complacency grow louder
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has joined warnings from investors that financial markets are too complacent about the threat of a US-instigated trade war, which could upend the global economy. The IMF predicts that a trade war could lead to lower asset values and crimp economic growth. Experts, including BlackRock's Larry Fink and HSBC's Steven Major, are warning of higher borrowing costs, a potential credit crunch, and a gradual deflation of over-valued assets. The IMF's warnings come as global markets have been experiencing low volatility and a rebound in share prices, with some analysts predicting a potential downturn in the US and global financial cycle.

site_title: Trump claims he's avoiding new Cold War; everyone else accuses him of appeasing Putin
summary: US President Donald Trump's meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin in Helsinki, Finland, has sparked a heated debate in Washington about the US's relationship with Russia. Critics accuse Trump of appeasing Putin and failing to protect US interests, while supporters claim he's trying to improve relations and avoid a new Cold War. Despite no evidence of collusion, Trump's approach is seen as a departure from the traditional US foreign policy stance, which views Russia as an anti-American power. Trump believes in a "frenemy" relationship with Russia, prioritizing cooperation on issues like nuclear proliferation and terrorism.

site_title: Time for Hong Kong's leader to act on pressing issues
summary: Hong Kong's leader, Carrie Lam, has largely avoided sensitive issues in her first year as Chief Executive, adopting a softer tone to appease Beijing. The Chinese government, under President Xi Jinping, has given her more room for maneuver, with officials of the Liaison Office no longer calling legislators for advice. Lam has focused on economic issues, such as housing, and has taken steps to increase housing units, including a tax on vacant flats. However, Beijing still wants her to enact national security legislation and make progress on national education. Lam needs to deliver on her promises to maintain Beijing's trust and avoid losing momentum.

site_title: Mahathir accepts people's rebuff of new national car idea
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad expressed disappointment after the public largely rejected his plan for a new national car, citing a preference for imported Japanese and German cars. Mahathir stated that the private sector is capable of designing and mass-producing cars, but the government's rejection of the idea has left the automotive industry without jobs. He warned that Malaysia may become a country of consumers, with no automotive industry, and referred to the failure of the previous national car company, Proton.

site_title: DLF to raise net proceeds of S$2.9m through IPO
summary: DLF Holdings, a mechanical and electrical engineering services firm, plans to raise S$2.9 million in net proceeds from its initial public offering (IPO) through a placement of 18.5 million shares at S$0.23 apiece. The firm aims to use the funds to seek out mergers and acquisitions, joint ventures, and strategic alliances. DLF's order book for project management and turnkey contracting services stands at S$2.6 million and S$3.8 million, respectively, translating to potential revenues over the next one to three years.

site_title: Putting listed firms on the Fast Track
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) has implemented a "tiering" approach to regulate listed companies, categorizing them into three tiers: Tier-1 (compliant), Tier-2 (cavalier in complying with rules), and Tier-3 (involved in fraud and other crimes). SGX's role is to investigate and hold Tier-2 companies accountable, while law enforcement agencies handle investigations of Tier-3 companies. The exchange has also introduced a "Fast Track" program to recognize law-abiding companies, which can enhance credibility with investors and attract new listings.

site_title: Keppel-KBS US Reit's Q2 DPU surpasses forecast
summary: Keppel-KBS US Reit's Q2 DPU surpassed forecast, rising to 1.5 US cents from 1.49 US cents. Despite a drop in rental income from a tenant at Westmoor Center in Denver, the trust's income available for distribution edged up 0.1% to US$9.5 million. Net property income increased 1.5% to US$13.8 million, driven by lower property expenses and one-off compensation income. The trust's DPU also outperformed forecast for the period from November 2017 to June 2018.

site_title: AGO finds recurring issues in government finances
summary: The Auditor-General's Office (AGO) found recurring issues in government finances in Singapore, including lapses in contract management, financial controls, and IT controls. Despite a clean opinion on the government's finances, the AGO urged strengthening of financial governance and controls. Lapses were found in the Singapore Civil Defence Force, People's Association, and Ministry of Education, including fake records and unapproved works. The AGO also detected weaknesses in IT controls at various ministries and agencies.

site_title: Balanced funds, meant for the long haul, bypass fear or greed
summary: The balanced fund, a long-haul investment strategy, has gained popularity since 2013, with assets swelling to $1.7 trillion. Balanced funds invest in both stocks and bonds, with a traditional 60/40 asset allocation, and tend to avoid inspiring fear or greed. Investors in balanced funds have historically had better returns than those in actively managed funds, with a 5.93% average annualized return over the past decade. Balanced funds offer a stable and patient approach, discouraging impulsive buying and selling, and are suitable for those who want to stay invested in the market.

site_title: Frankfurt loses edge in Brexit race to snag bankers as Paris gains ground
summary: Frankfurt's efforts to attract bankers escaping Brexit are losing momentum as Paris gains ground. Several companies, including JPMorgan Chase & Co and Goldman Sachs Group Inc, plan to relocate staff to multiple EU locations to maintain relocation options. Despite this, Frankfurt still expects to create up to 10,000 positions over five years due to Brexit. The city's chances of snagging bankers are further threatened by the European Banking Authority's relocation to Paris, which will likely cost the city jobs.

site_title: Alibaba's Ele.me seeking at least US$2 billion in funding
summary: Ele.me, a food delivery platform acquired by Alibaba Group Holding Ltd, is seeking at least $2 billion in funding to combat losses. The company, valued at $9.5 billion after its April acquisition, aims to expand its business amidst a fierce market battle with Meituan Dianping. Both companies incur massive losses due to heavy discounts, while maintaining payments to drivers. This funding round would make Ele.me a candidate for a future initial public offering, and investors would gain a piece of the company, which is strategically important for Alibaba and Tencent Holdings Ltd.

site_title: Goldman expects oil market volatility as supply outages loom
summary: Goldman Sachs expects volatile oil prices in the short-term due to uncertainty over possible disruptions to supply, with benchmark Brent crude in a $70-80 per barrel range. Production disruptions and supply shifts driven by US political decisions are the drivers of this new fundamental volatility. Despite this, Goldman expects a deficit in oil demand once US secondary sanctions are reintroduced, and prices are expected to reach $80 per barrel later this year.

site_title: Trump raises conspiracy theories despite evidence of Russian hacking
summary: US President Donald Trump downplayed the evidence of Russian hacking during the 2016 election, instead raising conspiracy theories and questioning the conclusion that Russia was behind the hack. Despite detailed evidence presented by the Justice Department, Trump avoided mentioning the indictment of 12 Russian military intelligence officers and instead asked about unrelated issues, such as the DNC's server and Hillary Clinton's emails. Trump's actions were described as a "smoke-and-mirrors effort" by US intelligence officials, who noted that the president has never accepted evidence of Russian involvement and is more focused on preventing future cyberattacks.

site_title: Tesla Model 3 is most profitable electric car - consultant
summary: Tesla's Model 3 is the most profitable electric car, generating net profit margins of over 30%, according to automotive consultant Sandy Munro. Munro, who previously criticized the car's fit and finish, acknowledged the Model 3's success after a teardown analysis revealed its profitability. The Model 3, priced at $35,000, is key to Tesla's profitability and production expansion efforts. Tesla's shares rose 1.7% following the news, with the company pushing to increase Model 3 production to drive profitability.

site_title: Ezra's restructuring proposal with Asia Fund Space falls through
summary: Ezra Holdings, an offshore and marine group, announced that its restructuring proposal with Asia Fund Space (AFS) has fallen through. The proposal, made in March, aimed to spin off assets into a separate trust and inject new businesses into the company. The deal was terminated due to AFS' failure to meet certain requirements, including listing a trust on the Catalist board. As a result, Ezra has amended its restructuring plan and filed amendments to its US Bankruptcy Court filings. The company will now proceed with implementing the amended plan and seeking judicial management in Singapore.

site_title: Temasek expands US footprint with wary eye on trade tensions
summary: Temasek Holdings, a Singaporean state investor, is expanding its US footprint despite trade tensions and a potential global economic slowdown. The firm has invested US$95 billion globally in the past five years, with 13% of its portfolio allocated to US assets, up from 10% two years earlier. Temasek has established three US outposts and will consider investments in companies at an early stage, with no specific deal size or type constraints. However, escalating trade tensions with China remain a concern, and the firm is mindful of the risk of a full-blown trade war.

site_title: UOB to support Singapore's launch of Razer Pay
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) has partnered with gaming company Razer to support the launch of Razer Pay Singapore, an e-wallet app targeting millennials. The partnership allows UOB customers to top up their e-wallets using eNETS debit or credit service, and process payments for Razer's global network of merchants. UOB will also provide cross-border foreign exchange and digital payment solutions, including the use of PayNow Corporate for seamless transactions. Razer Pay Singapore is set to launch within the next few months, with plans to expand to other Southeast Asian countries.

site_title: Amazon crashes on Prime Day, threatening US$3.4b haul
summary: Amazon's Prime Day sales event was marred by technical glitches, including difficulties shopping online and losing connections with Alexa digital assistants. The issues, which spiked just as the event began, declined significantly within a couple of hours but still sparked widespread frustration. Despite Amazon's assurance that the problems were being resolved quickly, the company's stock slid 1.5% in extended trading. Shoppers were expected to spend $3.4 billion during the 36-hour promotion, but the glitches may have dampened sales.

site_title: 'Several years' of strong jobs, low inflation still ahead: Powell
summary: US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell stated that the economy is on track for "several years" of strong job growth and low inflation, with inflation near the Fed's 2% target. Powell believes the economy will remain stable if the Fed raises interest rates gradually, supporting growth without weakening it. The Fed is expected to raise rates two more times this year, and inflation is currently at 2.3%, close to the target. Powell acknowledged uncertainty surrounding trade policies, but deemed the risks to the economy roughly balanced.

site_title: Global economy's future is electric, but still dirty, IEA says
summary: The International Energy Agency's latest report states that the world will increasingly rely on electricity, but most of the power will remain dirty. Global investment in renewables declined by 3% in 2017, and is expected to continue falling. The share of fossil fuels in the global energy supply rose to 60% due to increased spending in oil and gas, while coal production has declined but new plants are being built in developing countries. The IEA warns that investment uncertainty and policy changes may hinder the transition to cleaner energy sources.

site_title: EU's Juncker to visit Trump to talk trade on July 25
summary: European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker will visit US President Donald Trump on July 25 to discuss improving transatlantic trade and forging a stronger economic partnership amid strained trade ties. The visit comes after the US imposed import tariffs on EU steel and aluminum in June, prompting a response from the EU. The meeting aims to address potential tariffs on EU cars and other trade issues.

site_title: Plastoform unit served court summons for 2.7m yuan in amounts due
summary: Plastoform Holdings' subsidiary, Plastoform Electronics (Shenzhen), received a court summons for approximately 2.7 million yuan (S$547,000) due to outstanding amounts owed for supplied products. The company is arranging for negotiation and settlement with vendors. Plastoform Holdings is also under scrutiny from the Singapore Exchange for failing to meet financial and minimum-trading price criteria.

site_title: BT World Cup challenge nets S$25,000 for Budding Artists Fund
summary: A group of 16 business leaders participated in The Business Times-World Cup CEO Challenge, raising S$25,000 for charity. The challenge, where each leader "adopted" a nation and backed it for the rest of the World Cup, resulted in a total of S$25,000 being donated to The Business Times Budding Artists Fund. The fund supports arts training for financially disadvantaged children and youth, with plans to bring joy to 1,000 underprivileged children this October.

site_title: EU, China align with each other as tensions intensify with Trump
summary: European Union and China leaders gathered in Beijing for the 20th annual China-EU political and business summit, solidifying their alliance against US President Donald Trump's trade and climate policies. The two powers emphasized the importance of a "rules-based order" and a unified front against Washington. Key areas of cooperation included climate change, investment, and trade, with China committing to a nationwide emissions trading system and the EU recognizing China's massive green economy investment plans. The meeting marked a significant step in deepening EU-China ties, with both sides seeking to capitalize on their growing cooperation to counter US influence.

site_title: Tony Blair calls for second vote to fix Brexit 'mess'
summary: Former UK Prime Minister Tony Blair calls for a second Brexit referendum, stating that the current plan is a "total and complete mess." Blair believes Prime Minister Theresa May's plan will not be accepted by Brussels and that it's time for the UK to admit "there's no way out" and hold another vote. Blair suggests that a fresh vote is the only way to resolve the Brexit impasse, which has left parliament "paralysed."

site_title: SIIC Environment CFO resigns
summary: SIIC Environment Holdings announced the resignation of CFO Tan Kai Teck, effective July 17, citing a desire to pursue other interests. Tan confirmed he has no disagreement with the board and no other issues. Xu Zhan, executive director since 2014, will oversee accounting and financial matters until a new CFO is appointed. SIIC will continue to search for a suitable candidate to strengthen its management team.

site_title: Ford to pay US$299.1m to settle Takata consumer lawsuit
summary: Ford Motor Co has agreed to pay $299.1 million to settle consumer claims related to the Takata air-bag recalls. The settlement covers approximately 6 million vehicles and provides free loaners for owners or lessees waiting for repairs, as well as reimbursement for out-of-pocket expenses. This is the latest settlement in the massive Takata recall, following agreements by Toyota, Subaru, Mazda, and BMW. The deal does not cover personal injury or wrongful death claims, and General Motors, Fiat Chrysler, Volkswagen, and Mercedes-Benz continue to litigate these claims.

site_title: Bitcoin funds should be viewed with caution
summary: Bitcoin's value is driven by hype and hope, making it difficult to predict its future. Funds allowing investors to capture both rewards and risks are emerging, often with high minimum investments. As dollar asset diversification grows in Asia, the sector is expected to continue to drive growth. Despite record highs in the S&P 500, investors are advised to exercise caution when investing in cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin.

images.alt_text: "Don't go into this space saying you're going to pick this or that cryptocurrency without knowing anything. And you should not be using your living money." - Lee McKnight, associate professor.

site_title: From spy to surrogate, exhibition celebrates Britain's female trailblazers
summary: A photo exhibition at the Royal College of Art in London celebrates 100 years of women's suffrage in Britain, showcasing trailblazing women who have made significant contributions in various fields. Photographer Anita Corbin documented 100 women, including pioneers in the arts, sports, military, and science. The exhibition highlights their achievements and the challenges they faced in male-dominated environments. The event aims to inspire and promote gender parity, with the overall gender pay gap in Britain standing at 18.4%. The exhibition is a positive celebration of women's progress and a call to action for continued change.

site_title: Let's be a world champion in good corporate behaviour, small-nation style
summary: Singapore is poised to become a world champion in good corporate behavior, following the unveiling of a new Code of Corporate Governance and recent changes to its listing rules and Companies Act. The Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) has outlined a "chain of accountability" to deal with corporate malfeasance, tracing wrongdoing back to its source and holding individuals or entities accountable. However, critics argue that more needs to be done to fine-tune the system, increase transparency, and ensure swift and effective enforcement of current laws.

site_title: British caver says he approached by US, British lawyers over Musk's comments
summary: British caver Vern Unsworth has been approached by lawyers over Twitter abuse from Tesla CEO Elon Musk after rejecting Musk's offer of a mini-submarine for the Thai cave rescue. Unsworth plans to seek legal advice and may consider action against Musk. The spat began after Musk criticized Unsworth, calling him a "pedo guy," in a deleted tweet. Unsworth's actions and subsequent backlash have raised concerns among investors and analysts about Musk's ability to manage distractions.

site_title: Singapore banks clear up on coal lending policies
summary: Singapore's three major banks - DBS, OCBC, and UOB - have disclosed their policies on lending to coal-fired power plants, stating they will stop financing new projects that do not run efficiently, with a carbon emissions intensity of over 850g CO2/kWh. This move comes as NGOs intensify scrutiny on the banks' energy lending practices. The banks' increased transparency aims to align with global efforts to reduce carbon emissions and meet climate change goals.

site_title: CDL takes another green step forward
summary: CDL, Singapore's largest real estate player, has become the first local company to have its carbon reduction targets validated by the Science Based Targets Initiative (SBTi). The company aims to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions per square meter by 59% by 2030, primarily through renewable energy installations. CDL's CEO, Sherman Kwek, emphasized the importance of accelerating climate action and exploring low-carbon technologies to enhance climate resilience. This move follows Singapore's impending 2019 carbon tax and the global transition to a low-carbon economy.

images.alt_text: The Singapore Sustainability Academy has a solar PV panel footprint of 3,200 square feet. The solar PV panels are estimated to generate an annual energy yield of over 60,000 kWh, exceeding the building's annual energy consumption, thus enabling it to be self-sufficient.

site_title: Alibaba's US$2b food sale hints at indigestion
summary: Alibaba's US$2 billion food sale sale to investors may indicate financial struggles with its meal delivery unit Ele.me. Just three months after acquiring Ele.me for US$9.5 billion, Alibaba is seeking new funds, citing the high costs of battling rival Meituan for market share. Labour costs, promotions, and delivery times are among the expenses adding up for Ele.me, which has spent heavily to accelerate its growth. This move may be a sign of indigestion for Alibaba, which has multiple battles to fight, including fending off rivals in e-commerce and investing in cloud services.

site_title: Garden tools maker Husqvarna hit by weak US retail market
summary: Husqvarna, the world's largest gardening machine maker, reported a drop in second-quarter operating profit to 1.9 billion crowns due to a weak US retail market. The company's Consumer Brands division, which includes petrol lawnmowers and garden tractors, swung to a loss of 37 million crowns. CEO Kai Warn attributed the loss to rising commodity prices and a challenging US retail market environment, and announced plans to restructure the division, exiting lower-price segments and focusing on premium offerings.

site_title: Inheritance matters to Germans looking for a spouse
summary: A study by the Bundesbank found that inheritance is more important to Germans when choosing a spouse than income. According to researchers Junyi Zhu and Etienne Pasteau, inheritance is about 2.5 times more crucial than income in explaining marriage choices in Germany. This preference is linked to social stratification and the growing importance of inherited wealth in Germany's economy. The study suggests that while marriage is often driven by mutual affection, individuals may also consider inheritance when making decisions. This finding is similar to France, where aristocratic wealth has dwindled, and social mobility is higher.

site_title: Lloyd Blankfein poised for US$85m payout when he leaves Goldman
summary: Lloyd Blankfein, Goldman Sachs' CEO since 2006, is set to receive up to $84.7 million in compensation when he leaves the investment bank in October. His pay will be based on performance-based shares and cash awards, with a target value of $35 million and $43.5 million. Blankfein, 63, will be succeeded by David Solomon, 56, and will relinquish his role as chairman at year-end. The payout structure is unclear due to Goldman Sachs' lack of employment agreements guaranteeing severance payments. Blankfein's net worth is approximately $1.3 billion.

site_title: Singtel unit acquires Videology assets for about US$101m
summary: Singtel's subsidiary Amobee acquired Videology's assets for approximately US$101 million. The purchase includes Videology's technology platform, intellectual property, and other assets, subject to adjustments for accounts receivable. The acquisition aims to boost Amobee's omni-channel platform and provide marketers with solutions for premium video and connected TV content. The deal is subject to court and regulatory approvals, with Amobee's CEO stating that it will strengthen the company's capabilities and bring marketers next-generation solutions.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 10.61 points to 1,737.28. The index saw a volume of 2.3 billion lots worth RM2.1 billion, with 473 gainers outpacing 376 losers.

site_title: Industrial production increases 0.6% in June
summary: US industrial production increased 0.6% in June, driven by a sharp rebound in manufacturing and further gains in mining output, according to the Federal Reserve. This boost in industrial production, combined with stronger-than-expected retail sales and smaller trade deficits, suggests economic growth accelerated sharply in the second quarter, with GDP estimates reaching as high as 5.2%. Manufacturing output surged 0.8% in June, supported by a strong domestic and global economy, but escalating trade tensions could undercut business spending.

site_title: Singapore shares end higher on Tuesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.2% to 3,239.64 on Tuesday, driven by about 1.6 billion shares worth S$1.1 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 197 to 188. The most actively traded stock, Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, fell 3.4%. The rally follows a 5-day streak ahead of GDP data and amid market optimism despite US trade uncertainty.

site_title: "Several years" of strong jobs, low inflation still ahead, says Powell
summary: US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell stated that the economy is poised for "several years" of strong job growth and low inflation, with inflation near the Fed's 2% target. Powell believes the Fed can achieve its dual policy targets with gradual rate hikes, and that the economy's growth is supported by low interest rates, a stable financial system, and ongoing global growth. He acknowledged uncertainty surrounding the Trump administration's trade policies but deemed the risks to the economy roughly balanced, with a likely path of continued job gains, moderate inflation, and steady growth.

images.alt_text: US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell, discounting the risk that a trade war may throw a global recovery off track, said the economy is on the cusp of "several years" where the job market remains strong and inflation stays around the Fed's 2 per cent target.

site_title: Metech seeks rental refund from Mapletree Industrial Trust
summary: Metech International, an e-waste management company, has filed a writ of summons against DBS Trustee, trustee of Mapletree Industrial Trust, seeking a rental refund of approximately S$540,338. The dispute stems from a fire at Metech's premises in January 2015, which rendered the property inaccessible for 2 months. Metech signed the lease agreement in 2007, but the agreement does not provide for payment of rent during periods of inaccessibility. The company will continue to update shareholders on the progress of the suit.

site_title: Johnson & Johnson profit beat fueled by strength in pharma business
summary: Johnson & Johnson topped analysts' estimates with a 20% surge in pharmaceutical sales, driven by strong demand for cancer drugs Zytiga and Darzalex. The company trimmed its full-year sales forecast due to a strengthening dollar and falling sales of Remicade. Net earnings rose to $3.95 billion, beating estimates, but shares were volatile in premarket trading.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks dive, energy firms hit by oil losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted over 1% on Tuesday, with energy firms taking the biggest hit due to a sharp decline in oil prices. The Hang Seng Index dropped 357.98 points to 28,181.68. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.57% and the Shenzhen Composite Index lost 0.17%. The decline was attributed to the drop in oil prices, affecting energy firms.

site_title: Keppel DC Reit DPU up 4.6% in Q2
summary: Keppel DC Reit reported a 4.6% increase in second-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.82 Singapore cents, driven by higher contributions from data centers in Frankfurt, Singapore, and Dublin. Gross revenue jumped 21.5% to S$41.9 million, while net property income rose 21.4% to S$38.1 million. Portfolio occupancy was 92% as of end-June, with a weighted average lease expiry of 8.8 years. Net asset value per unit increased to S$1.01, up from S$0.97 at the end of December.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports grew 1.1% in June, missing expectations, due to trade war tensions and slowing electronics momentum. The government's cooling measures also raised homeownership costs, cooling property demand. The Auditor-General's Office found repeated lapses in contract management among public sector entities. Meanwhile, the Singapore shares ended higher on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index up 0.2%. The article also highlights international news, including Vietnam's reaction to US tariffs, China's slowing GDP growth, and the UK economy shrinking for the second month.

site_title: UK employment hits record high as job creation continues
summary: UK employment reached a record high in the three months through May, with 137,000 new jobs created, taking the employment rate to 75.7%, the highest since records began in 1971. Unemployment remained at a 43-year low of 4.2%. Pay growth eased to 2.7%, while money markets expect an 80% chance of an interest-rate hike in August due to inflationary pressures. The pound rose to $1.3261 following the data.

site_title: Singapore manufacturers show most improvement in bill payment: study
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector has shown the most improvement in bill payment behavior, reducing the average time to pay debts by 14 days from 42 days in Q2 2016 to 28 days in Q2 2018. In contrast, retail companies have increased their payment time by over 157%, from 14 days to 36 days. The sector's strong performance is attributed to a manufacturing renaissance, driven by double-digit growth in the biomedical and electronics sectors, leading to better cash flow and creditworthiness among manufacturers.

site_title: Singapore's precious stones and metals industry to face tighter scrutiny on money laundering risks
summary: Singapore's precious stones and metals industry will face stricter regulations to combat money laundering and terrorism financing risks. The Ministry of Law proposes a new regulatory regime, requiring dealers to register and implement measures to mitigate risks. The industry is currently not subject to the same anti-money laundering obligations as the financial sector. The ministry will develop the rules in consultation with industry stakeholders and hold a public consultation. The move aims to close the gap in regulations and reduce the risk of money laundering and terrorism financing in the sector.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower as Netflix weighs
summary: US stocks opened lower on Tuesday, July 17, 2018, due to a sharp drop in Netflix following weak subscriber growth. The Dow Jones fell 0.12%, the S&P 500 dropped 0.32%, and the Nasdaq Composite fell 0.69%. Investors are also awaiting Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's Congressional testimony.

images.alt_text: US stocks opened lower on Tuesday, as Netflix's sharp drop following weak subscriber growth weighed on consumer discretionary stocks and as investors awaited Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's Congressional testimony.

site_title: Asiana Airlines shares surge after media report on SK Group weighing takeover
summary: Asiana Airlines shares surged 7.3% after a local media outlet reported that SK Group is considering a takeover. Despite SK Holdings denying the acquisition, shares rose to a 23% gain on the news, with some analysts speculating that the conglomerate could help reduce transportation costs for SK Hynix's memory chips. Asiana has struggled in recent years and has undergone a creditor-led restructuring program to improve its performance.

site_title: US ban on China's ZTE forces telecoms to rethink business - sources
summary: The US trade ban on Chinese telecom equipment maker ZTE has had significant effects on wireless carriers worldwide, forcing them to rethink their business strategies. The three-month ban, lifted on Friday, disrupted operations at operators like Veon, Wind Tre, and Kyivstar, with launch delays, network outages, and supply chain disruptions reported. Industry experts say the ban may prompt operators to diversify their supplier networks to avoid being exposed to trade sanctions or disruptions. The ban has also accelerated Ericsson's growth, with the Swedish equipment supplier winning a major contract with Wind Tre.

site_title: Goldman Sachs expects volatile oil market, prices between US$70 and US$80 per barrel
summary: Goldman Sachs expects volatile oil prices between $70 and $80 per barrel in the short-term due to uncertainty over possible supply disruptions. The bank cites production disruptions and large supply shifts driven by US political decisions, despite robust demand. However, the bank notes that weak global oil inventories and a potential deficit in the third quarter could support prices in the long term. It still expects Brent crude to retest $80 per barrel, possibly late this year, and a deficit in 2019.

site_title: Keppel-KBS US Reit's Q2 DPU surpasses forecast at 1.5 US cents despite tenant exit
summary: Keppel-KBS US Reit reported a Q2 DPU of 1.5 US cents, surpassing the forecast of 1.49 US cents. The increase was despite a tenant exiting the Westmoor Center, which had paid a compensation fee in the first quarter. The trust will use this fee to offset the drop in rental income and maintain distribution until a replacement tenant starts contributing cash rental income.

site_title: Cooling measures raised homeownership costs, cooled property demand: Redas president
summary: Singapore's Real Estate Developers' Association of Singapore (Redas) president Augustine Tan says the recent cooling measures, including additional buyer's stamp duty and tightened Loan-To-Value ratios, have raised homeownership costs and cooled demand, potentially eroding developer confidence. Analysts forecast reduced sale transactions of 9,000 to 10,000 in 2018 and beyond. Tan notes that the measures may exacerbate the high supply situation and dampen demand for non-housing property, affecting first-time homebuyers and the industry's "imbalanced supply-demand situation".

site_title: Australian shares weaker as oil slump hits energy stocks; NZ flat
summary: Australian shares fell 0.6% to 6,203.6, with the energy index down 2% due to a 4% drop in oil prices, and weaker commodity prices affecting miners. Woodside Petroleum and Oil Search were major losers, while Rio Tinto slipped 0.3%. New Zealand's benchmark index remained flat. Concerns over China's slowing economy also weighed on sentiment.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks slip as oil extends fall; won gains ahead of Fed chief's testimony
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index fell 0.18% to 2,297.92, as crude oil prices continued to decline. The won rose ahead of Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's testimony, while bond yields increased. Asiana Airlines jumped 3% after a report of a potential takeover, and cryptocurrency shares surged after BlackRock's interest in blockchain technology. The won was quoted at 1,124.1 per dollar, and the KOSPI is down 6.7% so far this year.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks rise for third straight session
summary: Tokyo stocks rose for a third consecutive session, with the Nikkei 225 index increasing 0.44% to 22,697.36. The yen remained cheaper against the dollar, easing worries over a US-China trade war. The broader Topix index rose 0.87%. The gains followed a recent rally in Singapore stocks and a surge in the US stock market, despite ongoing US-China trade tensions.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure Trust Q2 DPU stable at 0.93 Singapore cent
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust (KIT) reported a stable second-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) of 0.93 Singapore cents, unchanged for six quarters. The loss attributable to unitholders was S$4 million, reversing from a profit of S$15.8 million last year due to lower fees from Basslink. Revenue fell 10% to S$142.9 million, with City Gas revenue rising 10% and Keppel Merlimau Cogen revenue falling 6%. Distributable cash flows decreased to S$36.2 million, and net asset value per unit declined to 28.8 Singapore cents.

site_title: The world's biggest miners want more copper but nobody's selling
summary: The world's largest miners, including Rio Tinto and BHP Billiton, are seeking to acquire copper assets but are facing a significant challenge: nobody is willing to sell. Despite having deep pockets and a strong demand for copper, companies are reluctant to give up their assets due to concerns about overpaying in the market. Analysts believe that companies will focus on development assets, where they can extract value, rather than buying existing copper mines. Rio Tinto and BHP Billiton are keeping a "watching brief" on potential deals, but their appetite for big acquisitions is uncertain due to concerns from skeptical shareholders.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Tuesday afternoon at 3,243.24, up 0.3% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Tuesday afternoon, with the Straits Times Index (STI) up 0.3% to 3,243.24. About 795 million shares changed hands, with AusGroup being the most actively traded stock. The rally follows a 5-day streak ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: 'Grease' at 40: still the one that we want
summary: "Grease," the classic musical, celebrates its 40th anniversary with a lasting impact on moviegoers worldwide. The film, released in 1978, grossed nearly $400 million and became the most successful live-action movie musical of its time. Director Randal Kleiser credits the film's enduring popularity to its universal themes, chemistry between leads John Travolta and Olivia Newton-John, and its nostalgic appeal for a simpler era. Despite initial criticism and a rocky production process, "Grease" remains a beloved favorite among audiences of all ages.

site_title: Sias to hold shareholder dialogue ahead of Shanghai Turbo EGM
summary: Singaporean investor watchdog Sias is holding a shareholder dialogue for Shanghai Turbo Enterprises ahead of a vote on July 24 to replace its entire board of directors. The company has been locked in a legal battle with former executive director Liu Ming since 2017. Concerns about the proposed board replacement have been raised, with Sias citing "serious concerns" about the events unfolding at the company. A meeting has been scheduled for Wednesday to discuss the proposal, which includes replacing four board members with new directors.

site_title: Australia dollar soft on RBA minutes, kiwi rangebound
summary: The Australian dollar eased 0.1% to US$0.7412 due to diverging interest rate outlook, with the Reserve Bank of Australia reaffirming its stance on keeping policy steady amid high household debt. The New Zealand dollar remained rangebound, awaiting a further pick-up in inflation. The RBA minutes reiterated concerns about the impact of high debt on the economy, while data showed a slowdown in China's economy amid trade tensions with the US.

site_title: India orders all Mother Teresa care homes inspected
summary: India orders immediate inspection of all childcare homes run by the Missionaries of Charity order, founded by Mother Teresa, after a nun was arrested over an alleged adoption racket. The scandal involves allegations that at least five infants were sold for thousands of dollars. The Women and Child Development Minister has asked state governments to inspect all childcare homes and register them with the central adoption authority within a month. This follows India's Supreme Court order in December to mandatory register childcare institutions and bring orphanages under the central adoption system.

images.alt_text: India has ordered an immediate inspection of all childcare homes run by a religious order founded by Mother Teresa after a nun was arrested over an alleged adoption racket.

site_title: Engineering firm DLF Holdings to raise S$4.26m through IPO
summary: Engineering firm DLF Holdings plans to raise S$4.26 million through an initial public offering (IPO), with 18.5 million placement shares at S$0.23 apiece. The placement will close on July 23, and shares are expected to list on the Catalist board on July 25. This marks the company's entry into the public market, providing investors with an opportunity to invest in the mechanical and electrical engineering services firm.
