These entrepreneurs, who are part of the baby boomer generation, are taking charge of their lives and creating new businesses to fulfill their passions.

site_title: Hidden Gem
summary: Tiny Cefalù on Sicily's island packs distinct attractions, including the Unesco World Heritage Site-listed Cathedral of Cefalù, featuring Byzantine mosaic decorations. The town's varied history is reflected in its architecture, with influences from Greeks, Romans, Byzantines, Arabs, and Normans. Visitors can explore the narrow cobbled streets, admire the mishmash architecture, and enjoy local specialties like cannoli and arrancini. The town's beach is a major draw, and a recently renovated Club Med resort offers luxurious accommodations. A short drive away lies the Madonie Regional Natural Park, offering scenic hiking trails and medieval villages.

site_title: Dutch city to unveil world's first 3D-printed housing complex
summary: The southern Dutch city of Eindhoven plans to unveil the world's first 3D-printed housing complex, Project Milestone, by June 2019. The complex, comprising five homes, will be built using robotic arms and concrete, speeding up construction and allowing for customization. Financed by private investors, the project aims to make homes more affordable by reducing the need for skilled artisans. The technique is still more expensive than traditional methods, but prices are expected to decrease as 3D technology improves.

site_title: Rosé is a wine like any other - some excellent, some mediocre
summary: A wine panel recently tasted 20 American rosés from the 2017 vintage, finding that many were exceptional and deserving of attention. Unlike the mass-market rosés often prioritizing marketing over quality, these wines showcased dryness, citrus flavors, and earthy fruitiness. Top-rated wines included a gamay noir rosé from Edmunds St. John, a dry and succulent rosé from Folk Machine, and a lively pinot noir rosé from North Valley. The panel concluded that good rosés are available, even if they may not be widely known, and that fans of a particular producer's reds or whites are likely to enjoy their rosés as well.

site_title: US fiscal, trade policies make Fed call tougher: ex-Treasury secretary
summary: Former US Treasury Secretary Jack Lew warns that the US's current fiscal and trade policies have increased the risk of miscalculation for monetary policymakers, making it harder to time their moves. Lew advises investors to focus on fundamentals rather than excessive confidence in rising equity markets and global growth.

site_title: Resolute Croatia sends young England packing
summary: Croatia defeated England 2-1 in a World Cup match, ending their campaign. Mario Mandzukic scored the winning goal in extra time, beating Jordan Pickford to seal the victory. The match marked a disappointing end to England's "Football's Coming Home" campaign, with fans' chants fading away. The loss leaves England without a World Cup appearance for the first time since 1958.

site_title: Standing Ovation
summary: The annual Happy Ever Laughter comedy show returns in Singapore with a lineup of top comedians, including Kumar, Selena Tan, and Judee Tan. The event also features veteran sitcom actresses Koh Chieng Mun and Irene Ang, alongside young millennial stars Fakkah Fuzz and Preetipls. The show runs from July 11 to 29 at Capitol Theatre.

site_title: WeChat Pay now available at Changi Airport
summary: Changi Airport in Singapore has announced a three-year marketing partnership with WeChat Pay, allowing over 150 outlets to accept the online payment platform as a mode of payment. This makes Changi Airport the first airport in South-east Asia to offer WeChat Pay airport-wide. The partnership aims to provide targeted promotions and better serve Chinese passengers, who comprised about a third of Changi Airport's total sales last year.

site_title: Macedonian town is 'fake news' epicentre for US
summary: In the Macedonian town of Veles, hundreds of websites and Facebook pages were created to produce "fake news" in support of Donald Trump during the 2016 US presidential election, earning locals up to €200 a month. The sites distributed articles with false or misleading information, targeting Trump's opponents. The influx of income generated by these sites helped alleviate youth unemployment, which stood at 55% in the country. Although many of the sites have disappeared, some locals continue to profit from creating clickbait content, with one individual earning €100-150 a month.

site_title: Singapore, EU free trade agreement a 'pathfinder' deal: Chan
summary: Singapore's Trade and Industry Minister Chan Chun Sing views the pending EU-Singapore Free Trade Agreement (EUSFTA) as a "pathfinder" deal that could pave the way for similar agreements between the EU and other Asian nations. The agreement aims to counter rising protectionism globally, particularly in response to the US-China trade spat. Chan emphasized the importance of the deal in maintaining the EU's position in South-east Asia's economic development and warned that a delayed or unsuccessful ratification could erode the EU's commitment to the region.

site_title: Chipmaker Broadcom inks US$19b deal to buy software company CA
summary: Broadcom Inc. announced a $18.9 billion deal to acquire US business software company CA Inc, marking the chipmaker's farthest expansion beyond its semiconductor business. The acquisition, which takes Wall Street by surprise, comes after Broadcom CEO Hock Tan's previous bid for Qualcomm was blocked due to national security concerns. CA specializes in software for mainframes, which will benefit Broadcom primarily from CA's recurring revenue. The deal, valued at $44.50 per share, is a 20% premium to CA's closing price, and Broadcom will finance it with cash and new debt financing.

site_title: Season Of Change
summary: The Spring 2019 menswear season saw the debut of Kim Jones at Dior Homme, delivering a collection rich in couture sensibility and intricate fashion. Jones worked with artist KAWS to create a set featuring a 10 ft floral effigy of Mr. Dior. Meanwhile, Virgil Abloh's Louis Vuitton debut was highly anticipated, with a 56-piece collection that showcased a mix of upscale streetwear and luxury designs. Abloh emphasized inclusivity with a diverse model lineup and successfully made his debut a trending topic.

site_title: Australia completes tightening of property loan standards
summary: The Australian banking regulator, APRA, has completed a three-year project to improve mortgage lending standards, with the results of a stress test providing "general reassurance" that the banking system is sound. The test, which included a 35% fall in property prices, suggests that lenders can withstand a severe economic downturn without breaching minimum capital requirements. Loan rules are expected to remain relatively unchanged, with banks focusing on getting a better handle on borrower expenses and debt commitments. Overall, APRA has seen "clear improvements and moves to better practice" in the industry.

site_title: Face Off
summary: A non-surgical, clinically proven treatment called the Ultra V High Intensity Focused Ultrasound Facelift is available at The Wellness Clinic. It stimulates collagen production to lift and tighten the face, neck, and body, with a V-shaped appearance possible after a few days. The painless treatment takes 30 minutes and requires no downtime or numbing cream, with a session priced at S$425.

site_title: GIC puts more in tech firms but is mindful of surging valuations
summary: Singapore's Government Investment Corporation (GIC) has expanded its investments in technology companies, focusing on blockchain and avoiding cryptocurrencies due to high valuations. The move aims to be cautious and selective in its investments. GIC's decision comes as global economic and trade tensions rise, with the US announcing tariffs on Vietnam, and the UK economy shrinking for the second month. GIC's expansion into tech companies reflects its efforts to diversify its portfolio amidst economic uncertainty.

site_title: Canada pension board to co-invest in China rental housing
summary: Canada's Canada Pension Plan Investment Board (CPPIB) will invest $817 million in China's rental housing sector with local developer Longfor Group. The investment will focus on developments, acquisitions, and master-leases of commercial assets in major cities. This is CPPIB's first investment in China's rental housing sector, with Longfor aiming to add 45,000 new units by 2020. The move aims to capitalize on China's growing demand for modern rental housing, particularly among young professionals and new graduates.

site_title: World's oil supply cushion could be stretched to the limit: IEA
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) warns that the world's oil supply cushion could be stretched to its limit due to prolonged outages, driving oil prices to their highest since 2014. Disruptions in Iran, Venezuela, Libya, Canada, and the North Sea have reduced global supplies, with Opec producers easing a supply-cut agreement. The IEA expects US sanctions on Iran to hit hard in the fourth quarter, potentially further reducing global supplies. Despite boosted production, the agency says the world's spare capacity cushion "might be stretched to the limit," threatening demand growth and prices.

site_title: The shifting sands of Brexit
summary: The UK's Brexit negotiations have hit a stalemate two years after the referendum, with the government proposing a watered-down version of the original plan. The proposal, which includes a customs union and free movement of labor, has been met with ridicule from both major parties and is unlikely to be adopted. The EU has also rejected similar proposals, leading to a hard Brexit becoming increasingly inevitable. The UK's concessions have been seen as too much, and the EU's inflexibility has made negotiations difficult, with a general election or change in government potentially being the only way to renegotiate terms.

site_title: There's Something About Mary
summary: Mary's Kafe, an Eurasian eatery, has relocated to Bendemeer Centre after nine years at Queen Street. The no-frills eatery, run by celebrated cookbook author Mary Gomes, continues to serve authentic home-style Eurasian dishes made from scratch daily. Key menu items include curry debal, babi assam, beef rendang, and signature sugee cake. Mary Gomes' younger daughter Michelle Seah has joined her in the kitchen, and the mother-daughter duo works together to maintain the restaurant's traditional cooking methods.

images.alt_text: Mary Gomes at her new cafe.
Mary's bestselling curries and braised dishes.

site_title: Heirs can access Facebook account of deceased relatives - German court
summary: A German court ruled that heirs have the right to access the Facebook accounts of deceased relatives, similar to inheriting letters. The decision sets a precedent in Germany and has far-reaching consequences for other social media accounts. Facebook has expressed disagreement with the ruling, citing the need to balance user privacy with the wishes of relatives. The ruling comes amid increased scrutiny of social media companies' handling of user data, including the recent leak of 87 million users' data by a UK-based researcher.

site_title: Perfect Cuppa
summary: Singapore-based tea company A.muse Projects has launched Tea Pods, Nespresso-compatible tea capsules that eliminate the need for loose leaf tea, temperature control, and steeping time. The capsules, available in Earl Grey and Peach Green flavors, can be used twice for a bigger cup of tea. Founder Angela Phua claims the capsules preserve the natural taste and essence of loose leaf teas. A box of 12 capsules is priced at S$18, making it a convenient option for tea drinkers. The Tea Pods can be used in 22 seconds, significantly reducing the traditional steeping time of five minutes.

site_title: Singapore, Aussie infrastructure players 'should join hands to capture more opportunities'
summary: Singapore and Australian infrastructure players should collaborate to capitalize on rising demand for infrastructure investments in the region, according to Senior Minister of State for Trade and Industry Koh Poh Koon. The strong partnership between Singapore and Australia can be expanded in the infrastructure sector, with significant potential gains anticipated.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rebound from trade spat concerns
summary: European stocks rebounded 0.3% after a two-week low, driven by gains in media, healthcare, and travel shares. The Stoxx Europe 600 Index rose despite US-China trade talks and a slump in oil prices. A takeover bid for Sky Plc by Comcast Corp also contributed to the gains. Meanwhile, Asian markets remained positive, with Singapore stocks notching a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: UK's summer sunshine masks simmering Brexit civil war
summary: The UK's Brexit process is masking a deepening civil war within the government, despite the recent resignation of ministers, which has had minimal impact on markets. Prime Minister Theresa May's proposed "soft" Brexit is unlikely to be accepted by EU member governments, and polls show widespread discontent among voters. The decision to hold a referendum, which David Cameron and Tony Blair's Labour government also made mistakes on, has led to a series of blunders and an unstable political impasse. A hard-left Labour Party successor is a growing possibility, and a hard Brexit could lead to a rapid deterioration in market sentiment and a loss of foreign investment.

site_title: US dollar firms before inflation data; euro struggles
summary: The US dollar rose to a new nine-day high against a basket of rivals, edging 0.2% higher to 94.91, driven by a bounce in equities and concerns about US inflation pressures. The euro struggled, while safe-haven currencies like the yen and Swiss franc fell. Analysts differ on the dollar's trajectory, with some predicting a peak and others warning of a potential recession, which could impact the dollar's value. US consumer inflation data was due, providing further clues on interest rate hikes.

site_title: Alliance's institutional shareholder will vote for proposed merger
summary: Regal Funds Management, an institutional shareholder of Catalist-listed Alliance Mineral Assets, has announced its intention to vote in favor of the proposed merger with Australia-listed Tawana Resources, provided no superior proposal is made. The merger is contingent on the extraordinary general meeting's approval.

site_title: Monthly COEs to rise 12.5% in upcoming quarter
summary: The Land Transport Authority of Singapore announced a 12.5% increase in monthly certificates of entitlement (COEs) for the next three months, starting from August. This means 9,225 COEs will be available, with 6,912 for cars, 1,639 for motorcyclists, and the remainder for commercial vehicles. The increase is attributed to the deregistration of older cars, which have been scrapped due to low premiums. Motor industry players expect this expanded supply to keep premiums stable, with the latest bidding exercise seeing a 26.7% drop in car COE prices.

site_title: Nasa's plan to use private contractors 'delayed'
summary: NASA's plan to launch astronauts to the International Space Station from the US using private contractors SpaceX and Boeing is set to be delayed due to incomplete safety measures and accountability holes in the agency's commercial crew programme. The federal report, released on Wednesday, cited concerns over the contractors' ability to meet NASA's requirements. The astronauts were initially expected to launch in 2019, but the delay may push the timeline further back. The report's findings have raised concerns about the effectiveness of NASA's commercial crew programme.

site_title: Rachel Eng leaves WongPartnership for PwC role
summary: Rachel Eng, a partner at WongPartnership, is leaving the firm to join PwC Singapore as part of its global legal network. Eng will stand down on August 31 after 23 years with the firm. She was involved in several significant IPOs, including Sasseur Reit and Dasin Retail Trust. WongPartnership's partners expressed gratitude for Eng's contributions, but welcomed her to PwC's network, citing opportunities for future collaboration.

site_title: Trump appears to question May's Brexit plan on eve of visit
summary: US President Donald Trump questioned the UK's Brexit plan, suggesting Britons may not have voted for it. Trump made the comments during a press conference on the eve of his visit to the UK. The plan, published by Prime Minister Theresa May, aims to restart talks with the EU. Trump also downplayed mass protests against his visit and claimed he has support from the British public. The plan has faced opposition from eurosceptic ministers, leading to a cabinet rebellion.

site_title: ECB sees rates at record low levels for as long as needed: minutes
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has decided to keep interest rates at record low levels for as long as necessary to raise inflation, with its guidance seen as "open-ended". The ECB concluded that progress in raising inflation has been substantial, and policymakers are confident that price growth will continue to move towards the bank's target of almost 2%. The ECB will wind down its bond-buying program at the end of the year, but will keep the end date conditional on incoming data due to uncertainty.

site_title: Canada housing prices show signs of stabilizing, reports show
summary: Canada's housing market is showing signs of stabilization, according to recent reports. Home prices rose 0.9% in June, pushing prices just above the 2017 peak, while new home prices remained flat in May. The stabilization is attributed to rule changes, mortgage lending restrictions, and interest rate hikes. Prices in Toronto and Vancouver have remained robust, while the condo market continues to lead price gains, excluding apartments and condominiums.

images.alt_text: Canadian home prices rose in June from May, pushing prices just barely above their 2017 peak, while new home prices were flat again in May, according to separate reports on Thursday that signaled a housing market swoon may be stabilizing.

site_title: US consumer inflation keeps 6-year record in June
summary: US consumer inflation remains at a six-year high in June, with prices for food, gasoline, shelter, and medical care contributing to the 0.1% increase. Despite a dip in electricity and natural gas prices, the core inflation rate rose 0.2% and 2.3% compared to the same period last year, driven by higher costs for medical care, autos, and recreation. The Federal Reserve is expected to raise benchmark lending rates due to rising price pressures, which could fuel further inflation.

site_title: Japanese food goes casual at Jypsy
summary: PS Cafe's newest concept, Jypsy, offers a casual Japanese dining experience with effortless chic in stylish surroundings. The menu features a mix of California-style maki, robatayaki snacks, and Asianized carbs, with standout dishes including unagi fried rice and obasan's sticky beef sliders. While some dishes, like sashimi and beef tartare maki, fall short, the restaurant's focus on presentation and design makes it a pleasant spot for mindless nibbling. Overall, Jypsy scores 6 out of 10 for its promising but not exceptional food.

images.alt_text: The unagi fried rice is immensely satisfying with chewy rice kernels fried over high heat, a soft slab of very fresh grilled eel, extra eel bits worked into the rice itself, shredded omelette, tofu slices, cabbage strips for crunch and pickled ginger to counter the richness of the eel.
Styled like a deconstructed fishing village in hues of blue and large wicker lamps, Jypsy is designed to make you want to linger over your meal, hopefully ordering one small plate after another.
Wafu dressing and savoury tomato jelly dress up a whole momotaro tomato (above).
Gyoza (above) with a filling of finely minced crab and lobster meat, is served like ravioli in a creamy bisque sauce.

site_title: Concrete jungle cements potential for developers' profits
summary: China's urbanization trend is expected to drive growth in the country's real estate market, particularly in key city clusters. The Greater Bay Area (GBA), comprising Hong Kong, Macao, and Guangdong's Pearl River Delta, is poised to become a major economic hub, with infrastructure connectivity and investment opportunities set to boost property prices. Developers such as KWG Property and Agile Group are expected to benefit from the region's growth, with shares potentially re-rated due to favorable developments. By 2030, the GBA is expected to assume a leading role in advanced manufacturing, innovation, shipping, trade, and finance, creating a formidable rival to other global cities.

site_title: Fast Retailing posts record Q3 profit on overseas Uniqlo sales
summary: Fast Retailing, the parent company of Uniqlo, reported a record high quarterly operating profit of 68.4 billion yen, up 37% from the previous year. The company's overseas Uniqlo sales drove the growth, with international sales rising 28% and overseas operating profit jumping 65%. Domestic sales also increased, with Uniqlo's online sales in Japan up 33%. The company reiterated its full-year operating profit view of 225 billion yen and aims to expand Uniqlo's presence in Europe and Asia.

images.alt_text: Fast Retailing's international sales rose 28 per cent and overseas operating profit jumped 65 per cent in the nine months to May.

site_title: Trump reaffirms Nato ties
summary: US President Donald Trump reaffirmed the country's commitment to NATO, stating his allies have agreed to increase military spending "like they never have before." Trump dismissed concerns about his relationship with Russia and took "total credit" for persuading his allies to meet the spending goal. However, this claim was quickly undercut by European leaders. Trump's impromptu news conference came after two days of tense negotiations over military spending and burden-sharing within the alliance. Despite the controversy, Trump maintained that the US-NATO relationship remains "very strong."

site_title: UK watchdog tells banks to show plans for ending Libor use
summary: The UK's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) has told banks to submit plans by the end of 2021 to shift away from using the LIBOR interest rate benchmark, which has been marred by rigging scandals and manipulation. The FCA's Chief Executive Andrew Bailey urged banks to transition to alternative benchmarks, such as the Sterling Over Night Index Average (SONIA), to avoid LIBOR-related risks. Banks must demonstrate how they plan to reduce their dependency on LIBOR, with the FCA setting a deadline of 2021 for the transition.

site_title: Tapping the cloud to make water smarter for all
summary: Singapore is leading the way in harnessing "smart water" technology to manage its water resources efficiently. The city-state's water system has reduced water loss to less than 5%, with a closed national water system ensuring every drop is used to its full potential. This approach has been successful in reducing water waste and pollution. The Singapore government and private sector are collaborating to develop smart water systems, with projects such as the Ulu Pandan wastewater treatment plant and the Marina East Desalination plant, set to be completed by 2020. This model is inspiring other countries in the region, including Malaysia, Vietnam, and Thailand, to adopt smart water technologies.

site_title: US: Wall Street bounces back on deals, earnings hope
summary: US stocks opened higher on Thursday, recovering from a selloff a day earlier as higher oil prices and merger activity helped offset fears of a Sino-US trade war. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 102.45 points, or 0.41%, to 24,802.90, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also opened higher, reaching fresh records. The market bounce follows a day of uncertainty, with investors reacting to new Trump threats and tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Frasers Property unit takes 75% stake in Vietnam property development company
summary: Frasers Property, a multinational property company, is acquiring a 75% stake in Phu An Dien Real Estate Joint Stock Company (PAD) in Vietnam for S$47.3 million. The acquisition will fund the development of a residential-cum-commercial project in Ho Chi Minh City. The deal does not expect to impact Frasers Property's earnings per share for the current financial year. PAD will undertake the project on a mixed-use development plot in Linh Trung Ward, Thu Duc District. The acquisition is based on the estimated net asset value of PAD at completion.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 14.8 points to 1,703.57 on Thursday, with gains outnumbering losses by nearly double. The index closed higher following a strong trading day with 2.7 billion lots traded worth RM2.5 billion.

site_title: Michelin to acquire farm-tyre maker Camso for US$1.45b
summary: Michelin to acquire farm-tyre maker Camso for US$1.45 billion, bolstering its specialty business. The combined off-road operations will be run from Camso's headquarters in Quebec, Canada. The deal aims to diversify Michelin's business away from car and truck tyres, with the French company expecting cost savings and increased sales by 2021. The acquisition values Camso at US$1.7 billion, including net debt, and is Michelin's second deal worth over US$1 billion this year.

images.alt_text: French tyre-maker Michelin is bolstering its specialty business with a US$1.45 billion deal to buy Camso, a Canadian producer of rubber tracks for farm equipment and snowmobiles.

site_title: Accordia Golf Trust shuts three golf courses in Japan
summary: Accordia Golf Trust has shut three golf courses in Japan due to flash flooding and landslides in western Japan. The courses, Hongo Country Club, Takehara Country Club, and Fukuoka Pheasant Country Club, are currently closed until further notice. While there are no reported casualties, several of the trust's golf courses have suffered damage. The trust's manager noted that the closures are precautionary measures against possible landslides and repair works.

site_title: May unveils UK soft Brexit blueprint, but banks are cut loose
summary: Theresa May unveiled a 98-page "white paper" blueprint for a soft Brexit, aiming to maintain the UK's close ties to the EU single market. The proposal includes a "free trade area" with interlinked customs regimes and identical regulations for industrial goods and agri-food, but will significantly disrupt the UK's services sector, particularly banks, which will lose access to the EU market. Despite opposition from within her own party, May is pushing forward with her plan, despite the resignation of two pro-Brexit Cabinet ministers.

site_title: Saudi wealth fund plans first multi-billion dollar loan
summary: Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund (PIF) has begun approaching banks for its first-ever multi-billion dollar loan, aiming to establish a core banking group for future deals. The loan is part of the PIF's efforts to diversify the kingdom's oil-dependent economy and boost returns from investments. The fund, which aims to control over $2 trillion by 2030, currently has assets of $230 billion. Lenders that participate in the deal will form the core banking group for the PIF, which has ambitions of becoming the world's largest sovereign fund.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's COE supply expanded to 9,225 per month from August to October, with lower premiums expected. Retail sales in May rose 0.1% to S$3.8 billion, driven by online sales. Singapore and South Korea signed a partnership to facilitate SMEs and startups' collaboration and global expansion. Ogilvy's chief creative officer, Tham Khai Meng, was fired over alleged misconduct. GoBear appointed Adrian Chng as its new CEO, while DBS and SGX launched a financial education program. Singapore shares rose 0.1% on Thursday, closing at 3,253.01 points.

site_title: Deutsche Bank wins nod to underwrite corporate bonds in China
summary: Deutsche Bank has received approval to underwrite corporate bonds in China's onshore debt market, becoming the latest foreign bank to participate. The move, part of China's efforts to open up its debt market, allows Deutsche Bank to help both onshore and offshore clients issue primary debt in the interbank market. This expansion is expected to boost yuan-denominated bond investment flows to 5.3 trillion yuan over the next five years, as foreign investors continue to attract to China's bond market. Several other foreign banks, including Citigroup and HSBC, are also participating in the market.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks edge up; won slips after latest US tariff threat
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index rose 0.19% to 2,285.06, while the won fell 0.52% to 1,125.9 per dollar, amid fears of an escalation in the US-China trade spat. The central bank held its base rate steady, citing sluggish employment conditions. Shares of Samsung BioLogics Co Ltd rose 3.4% ahead of an announcement on potential accounting rule violations. The won's decline weighed on the country's exports, with the KOSPI down 7.6% this year.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks bounced as bargain buyers move in
summary: Hong Kong stocks rebounded 0.60% on Thursday as bargain buyers entered the market following the previous day's sharp losses. The Hang Seng Index rose to 28,480.83, while the Shanghai Composite Index surged 2.16% and the Shenzhen Composite Index gained 2.74%. This follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and comes as investors remain optimistic despite US trade uncertainty and mixed Federal Reserve views.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks bounced on Thursday as bargain buyers moved in after the previous day's sharp losses, while Shanghai surged more than two per cent.

site_title: Singapore shares up on Thursday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 3.93 points, or 0.1%, to 3,253.01 on Thursday, with about 2.32 billion shares changing hands. Gainers outnumbered losers 251 to 150, led by Noble's 3.6% gain. The rally extended the 5-day streak, despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: CBRE launches sale of four freehold shophouses on Macpherson Road
summary: CBRE has launched the sale of four freehold shophouses on Macpherson Road through an expression of interest (EOI) exercise. The properties, zoned for residential with commercial use, offer high visibility and existing F&B approvals. With immediate rental income from fully-tenanted units, the shophouses can be redeveloped to a maximum gross floor area of about 18,267 sq ft. The EOI exercise will close on August 8. The properties are expected to attract interest from developers, contractors, family offices, and private equity funds.

images.alt_text: CBRE has launched for sale four freehold shophouses along Macpherson Road via an expression of interest (EOI) exercise.

site_title: Broker's take: CGS-CIMB downgrades Venture to 'hold', cuts target price to S$17.83
summary: Brokerage CGS-CIMB downgrades Venture Corporation to 'hold' and cuts target price to S$17.83 due to ongoing US-China trade tensions, despite the electronics services provider not being heavily impacted. Venture remains on track for FY2018 growth and has unchanged customer guidance. The downgrade reflects caution in the market.

site_title: Hunt for Jho Low, wanted in connection with 1MDB probe, shifts to West Indies
summary: Malaysian authorities are shifting their hunt for fugitive businessman Jho Low, wanted in connection with the 1MDB state fund corruption probe, to the West Indies islands. Low, a citizen of Saint Kitts and Nevis, is believed to have properties on the island and may seek refuge there. Authorities suspect he has nowhere else to run to, following a global manhunt. The move comes after Low was deemed a high-priority target by Malaysian authorities.

site_title: Australian shares rebound, banks and health care support; NZ down
summary: Australian shares rose 0.9% on Thursday, driven by gains in banks and healthcare stocks. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 6,268.30, rebounding from a 0.8% drop on Wednesday following US threats to impose tariffs on $200 billion of Chinese imports. Banks accounted for nearly half of the gains, while healthcare stocks reached a record high. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark index slipped 0.2% due to a decline in dairy firm a2 Milk Company.

site_title: Tokyo's Nikkei rallies on weak yen
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei index rose 1.17% to 22,187.96, driven by a weaker yen against the dollar, despite US-China trade war concerns. The broader Topix index gained 0.46%. A cheaper yen supported Japanese shares, according to Okasan Online Securities. The rally comes despite US shares experiencing falls.

site_title: GoBear hires former Fintonia, JobsDB.com chief Adrian Chng as next CEO
summary: Singapore-based GoBear hires former Fintonia and JobsDB.com chief executive Adrian Chng as its new CEO, effective July 16. Chng will step down as Fintonia CEO and remain as non-executive chairman and director of its portfolio companies. He succeeds Andre Hesselink, who will move back to the Netherlands as a special adviser to GoBear and its shareholders. GoBear will launch new products and expand across Asia, starting with Indonesia.

site_title: Rachel Eng retires from WongPartnership for PwC role
summary: Rachel Eng, a partner at WongPartnership, is retiring to join PwC Singapore as part of the global legal network firm. Eng's last day as partner and deputy chairman will be August 31. PwC Singapore's executive chairman Yeoh Oon Jin expressed excitement about Eng's new role, while WongPartnership managing partner Ng Wai King praised Eng's contributions to the firm. Eng's departure marks the end of a strong working relationship between WongPartnership and PwC, with both firms set to continue collaborating on future initiatives.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open lower on Thursday
summary: Hong Kong stocks declined on Thursday, with the Hang Seng Index dropping 0.18% to 28,260.09. The losses were attributed to investor concerns over a potential trade war between China and the US, which could impact the global economy. The Shanghai Composite Index also fell 0.24% and the Shenzhen Composite Index edged down 0.03%. The decline was in contrast to the Singapore Stock Exchange, which saw a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Thursday afternoon at 3,253, up 0.1% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading Thursday afternoon, with the Straits Times Index up 3.92 points to 3,253, a 0.1% gain. About 1.2 billion shares worth S$521 million changed hands, with gains outnumbering losses 180 to 103. Genting Singapore was the most actively traded stock, gaining S$0.03 to S$1.24. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and despite US trade uncertainty.

site_title: CAAS partners European safety regulator and Airbus to develop standards for unmanned aircraft systems
summary: The Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore (CAAS) has partnered with the European Aviation Safety Agency (EASA) and Airbus to develop safety standards for unmanned aircraft systems (UAS) in urban environments. The partnership aims to facilitate the exchange of information and technical expertise among the three parties to establish a framework for safety standards and regulatory requirements. The collaboration will focus on operational and technological assessments for the deployment of UAS in urban areas, promoting safe and efficient integration of UAS into existing air traffic systems.

site_title: Malaysia shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Thursday, down 0.61 points to 1,688.16, with 107 losers outweighing 66 gainers. The market saw 44.9 million lots traded worth RM20.4 million.

site_title: Online payment platform WeChat Pay now available at Changi Airport
summary: WeChat Pay has partnered with Changi Airport Group to make the online payment platform available at the Singapore airport, marking the first airport-wide acceptance in South-east Asia. Over 150 outlets, including duty-free shops and online store iShopChangi, will accept WeChat Pay for shopping and dining. The three-year marketing partnership aims to provide targeted promotions for WeChat Pay users and enhance the airport's services for Chinese passengers.

site_title: Asean FTAs: An overview
summary: Asean Free Trade Area (FTA) agreements have expanded since 1992, with six FTAs currently in force or signed, including AAZNFTA, Asean-China FTA, Asean-Hong Kong FTA, Asean-India FTA, AJCEP, and AKFTA. These agreements aim to reduce barriers, increase market access, and promote trade and investment among member countries. Key partnerships include China, Japan, and South Korea, with the RCEP proposal aiming to create a regional trade deal among 16 countries, accounting for 30% of global trade.

site_title: Singapore, South Korea sign pacts to help SMEs, startups collaborate and go global
summary: Singapore and South Korea signed memoranda of understanding to strengthen bilateral trade and investment, promote collaboration between SMEs and startups, and facilitate global expansion. The partnerships include establishing "landing pads" for SMEs and startups to access local ecosystems, sharing venture capital information, and boosting market access for companies in the smart city, infrastructure, lifestyle, and consumer sectors. The agreements aim to foster greater economic ties and leverage ideas, technology, and investment flows between the two countries.

site_title: Asia: Stocks edge higher; oil steadies after slump
summary: Asian stocks rose modestly, despite concerns over the US-China trade war, with shares in Japan, China, South Korea, and Australia gaining. Oil steadied after a two-year low, and the dollar advanced. The S&P 500 dropped 2 weeks ago, but may recover due to earnings growth, while commodities are expected to underperform in a trade war. Traders await a resolution to trade talks between the US and China, which could impact global growth and corporate supply chains.

site_title: Hurricane Chris weakens on way to Newfoundland
summary: Hurricane Chris weakened to a Category One hurricane on its way to Newfoundland, Canada, with maximum wind speeds of 90 miles per hour. The storm is expected to pass near or over southeastern Newfoundland on Thursday, potentially becoming a strong post-tropical cyclone. Swells generated by Chris may cause life-threatening surf and rip current conditions along the US East Coast, particularly in North Carolina and the mid-Atlantic states. Chris is the second hurricane of the 2018 Atlantic season.

site_title: Asian emerging markets vulnerable to risk: Amro
summary: Asian emerging markets face a risk of financial instability due to rising trade tensions and concerns about inflation, according to the Asean+3 Macroeconomic Research Office (Amro). The region experienced robust growth in 2017, but concerns in 2018 have increased global financial market volatility. Despite this, Asian emerging markets have benefited from foreign capital inflows, which have eased rebalancing to domestic-led demand growth. However, the region is vulnerable to large capital flow reversals and spikes in volatility, particularly if the European Central Bank ceases its quantitative easing program in 2019.

site_title: Singapore retail sales up 0.1% in May
summary: Singapore's retail sales increased 0.1% in May, reaching S$3.8 billion, driven by a 9.1% rise in furniture and household equipment sales. Excluding motor vehicles, sales rose 2.2%. Food and beverage services also saw a 1.2% year-on-year increase. However, sales of computer and telecommunications equipment fell 11.3%, and motor vehicles fell 8.4%. The growth was constrained by lower motor vehicle sales, but online retail sales contributed 4.3% to total sales.

site_title: Papa John's chairman Schnatter quits after racial remarks
summary: Papa John's chairman John Schnatter resigned after using a racial slur and making graphic comments about minorities on a conference call. This comes just seven months after he stepped down as CEO for making critical comments about the NFL's national anthem dispute. Schnatter's resignation was accepted by the company's independent directors, and a new chairman will be appointed in the coming weeks. The incident has battered the shares of the pizza chain, which Schnatter founded.

site_title: LHN clinches first management service project in Myanmar
summary: LHN Group, a real estate management company, secured its first management service project in Myanmar with a serviced residence contract in Yangon. The 13-storey property will be renovated to comprise 88 one-bedroom units and managed under LHN's 85 SOHO brand, with operations expected to begin in early January 2019. The contract size was not disclosed, and LHN shares rose 3.4% following the announcement.

site_title: Japan rains disaster toll rises to 199: government
summary: Japan's death toll from record rains has risen to 199, with dozens still missing. Search operations continue in the worst-affected areas, with hopes for finding survivors fading a week after the disaster. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has cancelled a foreign trip to focus on the crisis and has pledged emergency funding to help people return home. At least 10,000 people are living in shelters, and Abe has vowed to do everything to alleviate their situation.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Thursday, helped by cheaper yen
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Thursday, driven by a cheaper yen against the dollar. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.40%, or 88.54 points, to 22,020.75, while the Topix index gained 0.32%, or 5.46 points, to 1,707.34. The rally was partly attributed to the weaker yen, which boosted export-oriented stocks.

site_title: COE supply expands for August to October; lower premiums expected
summary: The Land Transport Authority in Singapore announced an expansion of certificates of entitlement (COEs) for the next three-month quota period, starting from August. The number of COEs will increase by 12.5% to 9,225 per month, with car buyers receiving 6,912 COEs and motorcyclists receiving 1,639 COEs. The increased supply is expected to dampen premiums, which have reached their lowest in almost 10 years, with prices falling by 26.7% for cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp.

images.alt_text: There will be 12.5 per cent more certificates of entitlement (COEs) for the next three-month quota period starting from August.

site_title: Gold holds steady near 1-week low as dollar firms against yen
summary: Gold prices held steady near a one-week low at $1,241.20 an ounce as the US dollar strengthened against the yen amid an intensifying trade war between the US and China. The dollar index was flat at 94.733, while the US Senate backed a non-binding motion to give Congress a role in imposing tariffs for national security reasons. Investors pulled $1 billion from commodity funds, including gold investments, amid global trade war concerns.

site_title: BMW set to become first beneficiary of China's auto reforms
summary: BMW is set to become the first foreign carmaker to own a majority stake in a Chinese joint venture, as part of China's auto reforms. The Munich-based luxury-car maker plans to unveil the new ownership structure, taking control of its 50% stake in the venture with Brilliance China Automotive Holdings Ltd. This move shows Beijing is following through on a pledge for greater market access, following an agreement between China and Germany to facilitate the change. Shares of Brilliance and BAIC Motor Corp declined due to concerns over missing out on future profit growth.

images.alt_text: BMW AG, among major companies most exposed to a trade war, is poised take majority control of its venture in China, becoming the first beneficiary of the reforms the government has unleashed in the world's largest car market.

site_title: Singapore shares open flat on Thursday; STI down 0.2% to 3,242.14
summary: Singapore stocks opened 0.2% lower on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index retreating 6.94 points to 3,242.14. Gainers and losers were mostly evenly matched, with 48 advancing and 45 declining shares. The most actively traded counter was CapitaLand, which rose two Singapore cents to S$3.04. In contrast, US stocks fell overnight due to trade war fears, while Tokyo stocks opened higher on Thursday, partly supported by a cheaper yen.

site_title: DBS, SGX launch financial education programme for budding investors
summary: DBS Bank and the Singapore Exchange (SGX) launched a financial education program, "FLY with DBS and SGX," aimed at budding retail investors. The program, targeting the "Not Invested But Interested" segment, will provide interactive webinars, e-tutorials, and web articles to improve financial literacy. The initiative aims to empower women, young adults, and Generation X to make informed investment decisions and supplement their retirement funds. The program will leverage DBS's data-driven approach and SGX Academy's investment education expertise to offer a seamless learning experience.

site_title: IMF not encouraged after Brazil visit
summary: IMF experts concluded a technical visit to Brazil, warning that the economy is performing below its potential, with high public debt and uninspiring medium-term growth prospects. The preliminary forecast suggests Brazil's economy could grow 1.8% in 2018, primarily driven by domestic consumption and investment, which is a significant downgrade from the IMF's previous prediction of 2.3%. The IMF notes that Brazil's economic recovery is still underway but faces significant risks due to uncertainty about reform continuity and tightening global financial conditions.

site_title: Singapore SMEs could do with more to help them go global: accounting body
summary: Singaporean small and medium enterprises (SMEs) want more information and support to help them expand globally, with nearly half of respondents citing this as a need. Competition is the biggest barrier to international trade, with securing new or improved trade agreements also crucial. The Association of Chartered Certified Accountants (ACCA) recommends providing more information and support on trade opportunities and adopting a strategic mindset to develop international standing. This could drive growth benefits for both SMEs and the broader economy, and policymakers have a clear incentive to address these barriers.

site_title: Europe: FTSE 100 miners, energy stocks slide on new US tariff list
summary: The FTSE 100 index in Europe declined 1.3% on Wednesday, snapping a four-day winning streak, amid US threats to impose 10% tariffs on $200 billion worth of Chinese imports, escalating a trade war. European markets, particularly commodities sectors, were hit hard. Analysts expect China's retaliation to further impact the markets.

site_title: Mexico earthquake unearths ancient temple
summary: A devastating earthquake in central Mexico last September uncovered remnants of a rain god temple within an Aztec pyramid in Cuernavaca, Morelos state. The temple, dedicated to Tlaloc, belonged to the Tlahuica culture and was discovered after the pyramid suffered considerable rearrangement of its structure. Archaeologist Barbara Koniecza stated that the earthquake revealed the previously hidden temple, which is now being studied by the National Institute of Anthropology and History (INAH). The discovery provides valuable insights into the region's ancient culture and history.

site_title: US fiscal, trade policies make it harder for Fed to time moves: ex-Treasury secretary
summary: US fiscal and trade policies have made it challenging for the Federal Reserve to time its moves to tackle inflation without cutting off economic benefits. Former US Treasury Secretary Jack Lew warns that the current policies, including spending and trade tariffs, are "pouring oil on a fire," bringing short-term growth but with medium and long-term consequences. The Fed may consider another interest rate hike in September, but a fourth hike in December is uncertain. The global economy is still experiencing low inflation and steady growth, but faces geopolitical risks and economic uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Former US Treasury secretary Jack Lew speaking at the OCBC Global Treasury Economic and Business Forum 2018 at The Ritz-Carlton, Millenia.

site_title: Pacific leaders sign on to Australian internet cabling scheme, shutting out China
summary: Pacific nations Papua New Guinea and the Solomon Islands have signed a joint undersea internet cable project with Australia, funded by Australia's A$136.6 million. The project aims to connect the nations to the Australian mainland and outlying islands, bypassing plans by Chinese telecom giant Huawei. The deal comes amid strained ties between Australia and China, with Australia viewing the Pacific as its "backyard". The project's cost is split 2:1, with Australia paying two-thirds, and is seen as a practical way to invest in regional economic growth.

site_title: South Korea says US-China trade war may hit exports of intermediary goods
summary: South Korea warned that an escalating US-China trade dispute could hit its exports of intermediary goods used in home appliances, computers, and communications devices. The country's trade ministry prepared responses to cope with the economic impact of the trade row. China's exports to South Korea jumped 30% in June, driven by chips and other intermediary goods. A US-China trade war could impact South Korea's GDP growth by 0.3 percentage points, according to OCBC Bank estimates. The heightened trade tensions pose risks to South Korea, Asia's fourth-largest economy, as both the US and China are major trading partners.

site_title: POSH, Kerry TJ Logistics team up for Taiwan's offshore wind market
summary: POSH and Kerry TJ Logistics have formed a joint venture to penetrate Taiwan's offshore wind market. Leveraging their capabilities and assets, the joint venture will provide comprehensive solutions for wind turbine transportation and marine services. The partnership has signed memoranda of understanding with Rolls-Royce and Macquarie Capital, exploring designs for walk-to-work vessels and securing development rights for Taiwan's first offshore wind projects. Taiwan aims to generate over 5 gigawatts of wind power by 2025, with an investment of US$30 billion.

site_title: First Sponsor unit inks supplemental agreement over Chengdu project payment
summary: A unit of First Sponsor, Chengdu Gaeronic Real Estate Co, has signed a supplemental agreement with Minyoun Industrial Group over the proposed disposal of parts of Chengdu Cityspring project. Minyoun will pay an amended first instalment of 116.5 million yuan, comprising of 50 million yuan already paid and 66.5 million yuan by July 18, 2018. This replaces the original 206.5 million yuan instalment. The sale involves a commercial building, retail space, and basement car park lots.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks gain; won tumbles on trade war fears
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index rose 0.39% to 2,289.61, while the won plummeted 0.88% to 1,130 per dollar, its lowest level since October 2017, amid escalating US-China trade war fears. The US threatened to impose fresh tariffs on $200 billion of Chinese goods. South Korea's central bank left monetary policy steady for a fifth straight meeting, citing a fragile job market and concerns over the trade war's impact.

site_title: EU watchdog criticises Malta for anti-money laundering shortcomings
summary: The European Union's top banking watchdog, the European Banking Authority, criticized Malta for its application of EU anti-money laundering rules, citing "general and systematic shortcomings" in the country's Financial Intelligence Analysis Unit. The criticism came after an enquiry into alleged wrongdoings at Pilatus Bank, which has had its assets frozen and a banking license withdrawn. The Maltese authorities had initially failed to impose sanctions on the bank despite initial findings of suspicious activities in 2016. The EU justice commissioner described the EBA findings as "troubling news."

site_title: Tham Khai Meng fired from chief creative officer role at ad giant Ogilvy over alleged misconduct
summary: Singaporean advertising veteran Tham Khai Meng was fired as worldwide chief creative officer of Ogilvy due to alleged misconduct, following an internal investigation into complaints. The agency's CEO John Seifert terminated his employment with immediate effect, citing a breach of company values and code of conduct. Meng, who joined Ogilvy in 1999, was a prominent player in the industry, leading campaigns for major brands like Coca-Cola and Louis Vuitton, and was one of four recipients of the Designer of the Year award in 2009.

site_title: Nasa commercial crew program for space station faces delays: report
summary: NASA's commercial crew program for the International Space Station is facing delays due to incomplete safety measures and accountability issues, according to a federal report. SpaceX and Boeing, the main contractors, have further delayed certification milestones to early 2019, potentially causing a nine-month gap in US astronaut presence on the ISS. The report warns that NASA risks losing its multibillion-dollar investment in the space station without a viable contingency option. NASA is working with its partners to resolve the issues and develop contingency plans.

site_title: US threat of more tariffs on China hits yuan
summary: The Chinese yuan dropped to an 11-month low after the US threatened 10% tariffs on $200 billion worth of Chinese imports, sparking concerns about a ratcheting of Sino-US trade tensions. The yuan fell to 6.7010 per dollar, while the Australian dollar slipped 1% to 0.7384. The euro and Japanese yen also declined, while the US dollar index rose 0.2% to 94.367. The tariffs threat raised concerns about the impact on global markets and economies, particularly in China and Asia.

site_title: Booming LNG market steps out of the dark as transparency push grows
summary: The liquefied natural gas (LNG) industry is slowly gaining transparency, with commodity price agency S&P Global Platts and trading marketplace Global LNG Exchange (GLX) facilitating the first transparent physical trades in their platforms. This marks a significant shift in the industry, which has been dominated by secret deals. The move aims to boost liquidity in the market, with analysts stating that it will encourage greater market participation. Major LNG buyers and producers, including Japan's JERA and Vitol, are expanding their trading desks, further contributing to the push for transparency.

site_title: Aussie shares gain as banks offset trade war fears; NZ slips
summary: Australia's main stock index rose 0.7% to 6,258.50, led by gains in bank and healthcare shares, as investors offset fears of a US-China trade war. The index had fallen 0.8% on Wednesday due to concerns over US tariffs on Chinese imports. The benchmark had been boosted by gains in healthcare shares, while miners and oil producers fell. The rally was seen as a positive sign for the market, despite ongoing trade uncertainty.

site_title: Stocks to watch: POSH, Duty Free, SPH, Chaswood Resources
summary: PACC Offshore Services Holdings (POSH) and Kerry TJ Logistics formalized a joint venture to penetrate Taiwan's offshore wind market. POSH's deputy CEO described Taiwan as one of the fastest-growing offshore wind markets in Asia. Duty Free International posted a 39.9% decline in net profit to RM9.0 million for the first quarter, with a 28.9% decrease in revenue.

site_title: Setting out vision for future ties, Britain's May presses Brexit plans
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May is set to unveil a "principled and practical Brexit" plan, including a free trade area for goods and measures to ensure frictionless trade. The plan aims to meet demands from businesses, pro-EU voters, and Brexit supporters, and will be published on Thursday. The UK is due to leave the EU next March, with May's government seeking to move on with Brexit talks that have stalled. The EU has warned that time is running out, and some officials see May's plan as an opening bid.

site_title: Walmart plans to sell Japanese supermarket chain Seiyu: Nikkei
summary: US retailer Walmart plans to sell Japanese supermarket chain Seiyu, approaching major retailers and private equity funds. The potential sale, valued at 300-500 billion yen (S$3.7-6.1 billion), is reportedly underway. The deal's outcome has yet to be confirmed, but it could mark a significant change for Seiyu, which operates over 400 stores in Japan.

site_title: China stepping up efforts to forcibly integrate minorities
summary: China is intensifying efforts to forcibly integrate minority groups, particularly the Uighurs in the Xinjiang region, into the dominant Han Chinese population. The government has introduced a new concept of "Chinese nation" in the constitution, emphasizing unity over diversity. However, the reality is stark, with hundreds of thousands of Uighurs reported to be held in re-education camps, where they are pressured to give up their religion and culture. Amnesty International has reported the disappearance of a Uighur student, highlighting the extreme repression in Xinjiang, where schools are being shut and daily life is controlled.

site_title: Sacha Baron Cohen's US TV show disrupts ahead of first broadcast
summary: British comedian Sacha Baron Cohen's new US TV show "Who is America?" has generated controversy before its premiere. Conservative figures Sarah Palin and Joe Walsh claim to have been duped by the show, which features a trailer with former US defense secretary Dick Cheney signing a waterboarding kit. The seven-episode series, airing on Showtime, marks Baron Cohen's first TV project in a decade, following his 2006 film "Borat." The show's provocative nature and potential for deception have raised concerns about its impact on public discourse.

site_title: France warns against rushing into tariff cut to defuse tensions
summary: France's Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire warns against hastily lowering EU tariffs on US car imports to ease tensions, urging France and Germany to assess the impact on the car industry first. Germany's Chancellor Angela Merkel has expressed support for a tariff cut, but Germany's Economy Minister Peter Altmaier says no decision has been made. The US imposes a 2.5% tariff on EU passenger cars and 25% on pickup trucks, while the EU imposes a 10% tariff on US cars. The EU has limited room to reduce tariffs for only US-made cars under WTO rules.

site_title: US warns of sanctions risk for firms invested in Russian pipeline
summary: The US has warned Western firms invested in Russia's Nord Stream 2 pipeline that they risk sanctions, citing the pipeline's potential to undermine Europe's energy security and stability. US President Donald Trump accused Germany of being "captive" to Russia due to its energy reliance on the pipeline. Five Western firms, including Shell and Engie, have invested in the project, which Moscow is using to divide Europe. The US claims the pipeline would give Russia another tool for political coercion, particularly against Ukraine.

site_title: England's inexperience shows as World Cup dream is dashed
summary: England's World Cup semi-final campaign ended in a 2-1 defeat to Croatia after extra-time, dashing their historic opportunity to reach a first final in 52 years. England's young and daring team had exceeded expectations with meticulous attention to detail, but ultimately struggled with creativity in open play. A turning point came when Harry Kane's rebound shot was denied, allowing Croatia to level the score 22 minutes from time. England's inexperience showed as they retreated and allowed Croatia to control the game, ultimately losing to Ivan Perisic's late winner.

site_title: Next Nafta meeting likely in Washington at end of month: Mexican minister
summary: Mexican Economy Minister Ildefonso Guajardo announced that the next North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta) meeting is likely to take place in Washington by the end of July. Guajardo is working with US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer to find a solution that works for everyone. The talks have stalled over US demands on autos and other issues, but Guajardo expressed optimism about reaching a conclusion before Mexico's president-elect Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador takes office on December 1.

images.alt_text: The next meeting about the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta) will likely take place in Washington during the last week of July, Mexican Economy Minister Ildefonso Guajardo said on Wednesday.

site_title: Kylie Jenner, 20, on cusp of billionaire status: Forbes
summary: Kylie Jenner, 20, is on track to become America's youngest self-made billionaire, according to Forbes. Her cosmetics company, Kylie Cosmetics, has sold over $630 million worth of makeup and is valued at $800 million. With earnings from TV programs, endorsements, and dividends, her overall worth is estimated to be $900 million. She would be the youngest self-made billionaire ever, beating Mark Zuckerberg's age of 23. Jenner's success is attributed to her fame and social media following, with over 110 million followers on Instagram.

site_title: Crude oil benchmark Brent sees biggest one-day fall in two years
summary: Global benchmark Brent crude oil fell 6.9% to $73.40 a barrel, its largest one-day drop in two years, amid escalating US-China trade tensions and Libya's decision to reopen its ports. The decline was triggered by concerns about demand and a stronger US dollar. Hedge funds and money managers pared long positions, contributing to the sell-off. The US-China trade tensions and potential tariffs on Chinese goods also weighed on oil prices.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Duty Free International posted a 39.9% drop in net profit to RM9 million for the first quarter due to lower revenue and donations. Top Glove Corp had its interim injunction order against Adventa Capital's directors lifted after a court hearing. Chaswood Resources received letters of demand from Ambank seeking repayment of outstanding amounts due on banking facilities. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed.

site_title: HK rejected Singapore's request to nab Jho Low in 2016: Police
summary: Singapore has denied making a request to Hong Kong authorities to arrest and extradite Malaysian tycoon Jho Low, who is at the center of the 1MDB scandal. The Singapore Police Force stated that reports claiming otherwise are "untrue."

site_title: Pfizer delays price hikes after discussion with Trump
summary: Pfizer has delayed price hikes for its drugs, deferring them until the end of the year or until US President Donald Trump's drug pricing blueprint goes into effect. The company's CEO had a conversation with Trump, leading to the decision. Pfizer will return prices to their pre-July 1 levels as soon as possible, with the price increase set to go into effect on July 1.

site_title: June condo, HDB rents fall as volumes drop
summary: Rentals for private condos and apartments in Singapore fell 0.2% in June, while HDB rents dropped 0.8% from the previous month. Volumes also declined, with private home rentals falling 1% to 4,637 units and HDB flats falling 5.8% to 1,735 units. This marks a 19.3% decrease in non-landed private rentals year-on-year, with the lowest compared to January 2013. The decline in rental volumes is attributed to last year's trend, with 7% decrease in May 2017.

site_title: Mexico's president-elect will cancel planned US helicopter order
summary: Mexico's president-elect, Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador, has announced the cancellation of a planned $1.86 billion helicopter purchase from the US, citing cost-cutting measures. The purchase was intended to be used by Mexico's navy, but Lopez Obrador stated that the expenditure was not feasible. This decision comes as part of his campaign promises to reduce government waste and fight corruption.

site_title: Services, motor vehicles lift producer prices in June
summary: US producer prices increased 0.3% in June, driven by gains in services and motor vehicles costs, marking the largest annual increase in 6-1/2 years. The producer price index (PPI) rose 3.4% year-over-year, exceeding expectations. Underlying producer inflation picked up, supporting views of steadily rising price pressures, which may lead to two more interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve this year.

site_title: Focus equally on risks, not just returns
summary: A US investment bank's prediction of a moderate economic impact from US-China trade tensions has been proven incorrect, with retaliatory tariffs imposed by Canada, China, and the European Union. Despite this, many investment houses continue to urge customers to stay invested, citing positive economic growth and corporate earnings. However, a key lesson is that risk is often overlooked, with too much emphasis on potential returns and not enough consideration of potential downsides, particularly in a volatile and unpredictable market environment.

site_title: UK politics is the wild card for BOE's August rate increase
summary: The Bank of England is expected to raise interest rates in August, despite UK political turmoil and Brexit uncertainty, with investors betting on a quarter-point hike. The economy is showing signs of recovery, with consumers willing to spend again, but an election or no-deal Brexit could add uncertainty. Policymakers have previously indicated that Brexit may restrain the economy, but have so far seemed prepared to push ahead with tightening. The central bank's decision will be influenced by the latest growth figures and the impact of political uncertainty on investment and growth.

site_title: The European Union's Dublin Regulation poser
summary: The European Union's Dublin Regulation, which determines which country is responsible for processing asylum seekers, has been criticized for its ineffectiveness. Despite the EU's efforts to reduce irregular arrivals, with over 100,000 annual crossings, the regulation has failed to provide a clear solution. The first country of arrival is typically assigned responsibility, but exceptions and loopholes allow asylum seekers to contest the decision. This has led to tensions within EU member states, particularly Germany, and calls for reform. Strengthening the European Asylum Support Office and providing financial incentives for accepting refugees may alleviate tensions, but a radical overhaul of the asylum system is needed to address the issue.

site_title: SIA to expand direct services to US
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) is expanding its direct services to the US, launching non-stop flights to Los Angeles in November and increasing frequencies on its existing non-stop service to San Francisco. The airline will offer 27 weekly non-stop flights between Singapore and the US by year-end, including flights to New York. SIA will also increase its service to San Francisco and suspend its one-stop service to Los Angeles via Seoul.

site_title: Singapore ranks 5th in Global Innovation Index
summary: Singapore ranks 5th globally in the Global Innovation Index, ahead of the US, Finland, Denmark, and Germany, and is the top performer in Asia. The country improved two spots and retained its top spot in education spending and regulatory quality. However, it scored lower in areas such as expenditure on education and environmental performance. The ranking highlights Singapore's efforts to drive growth through innovation, attracting talent and resources. China advanced five spots to 17th, while the US dropped to 6th.

site_title: Convene raises US$152m to fuel expansion
summary: Convene, a New York-based real estate startup, has raised $152 million in funding from investors including Revolution Growth, valuing the company at over $500 million. The startup plans to expand its business in the US and globally, with London as its first overseas outpost. Convene aims to increase its footprint from 582,000 square feet to 1.7 million square feet in 10 cities by the end of next year. The company's co-founder and CEO, Ryan Simonetti, plans to use the funding to introduce a single app that connects tenants with services and amenities, transforming the workplace experience.

site_title: Smaller plots still in en bloc game
summary: Several en bloc deals in Singapore are moving forward despite recent cooling measures, with smaller plots carrying lower risks and more digestible prices. A 12-unit freehold development, Casa Sophia, is up for sale with a reserve price of S$36 million, offering owners a potential S$2.69 million to S$3.4 million each. Another site, Fortune Park near Kovan MRT, is also on the market with an asking price of S$126 million. Analysts note that while smaller sites may be less attractive to some developers due to lower margins, they are still attractive for those looking to acquire sites with lower risks and costs.

images.alt_text: Casa Sophia, a 12-unit development off Orchard Road, has a reserve price of S$36 million. If a sale is successful at that price, each owner could receive between S$2.69 million and S$3.4 million.

site_title: Comcast battle for Fox dominates Sun Valley Conference
summary: Media and tech leaders gathered at the Sun Valley Resort in Idaho for the Allen & Co conference, where Comcast's bid for 21st Century Fox's entertainment assets is being closely watched. Disney's $71.3 billion cash-and-stock offer appears to be the closest to sealing the deal, but Comcast is still in the running. Fox Chairman Rupert Murdoch arrived with News Corp CEO Robert Thomson, while SoftBank's Masayoshi Son ruled himself out of traditional media assets, focusing on AI and robotics investments instead. The conference drew commentary on the high valuation of Fox and its potential impact on Discovery Inc.

site_title: Asian emerging markets risk financial instability: Amro
summary: Asian emerging markets face a risk of financial instability due to rising trade tensions and inflation concerns, according to the Asean+3 Macroeconomic Research Office (Amro). Despite robust real GDP growth of 5.6% in 2017, the region is vulnerable to large capital flow reversals and spikes in volatility, exacerbated by the European Central Bank's potential quantitative easing program cessation in 2019. Amro recommends vigilance from policymakers, as trade tensions and Fed policy interactions could prompt a cautious investor stance, weighing on asset markets and capital flows into Asian emerging markets.

site_title: US dollar hits 6-month high against yen on strong inflation
summary: The US dollar reached a 6-month high against the Japanese yen, rising 1.3% to 112.17 yen, driven by strong inflation data and investor confidence in the US economy. The dollar's strength suggests a bullish market sentiment, despite trade tensions with China, which accused the US of bullying. The US inflation data supports views of rising price pressures, potentially leading to two more interest rate hikes this year, and boosting the dollar's value.

site_title: Viva Energy prices at bottom of range for Australia's biggest IPO in four years
summary: Viva Energy's Australian IPO, valued at A$4.86 billion, priced at A$2.50 a share, the bottom of its indicated range. The energy refiner and marketer, backed by Vitol, is Australia's largest IPO in nearly four years. Institutions bid within A$2.50 and A$2.65, and the shares will debut on the Australian stock exchange on Friday. The IPO is seen as reasonably priced, with good demand, and the company's management team is considered capable.

site_title: Severe trade war could lop 0.3 percentage point off Singapore's growth
summary: OCBC economists predict a severe trade war between the US and China could reduce Singapore's GDP growth by 0.3 percentage points in 2018, depending on the scope of tariffs. Two scenarios are considered: a mild trade war with US$50 billion in tariffs or a more severe one with US$250 billion in tariffs. The impact on Singapore's economy would vary based on its reliance on US-China trade, with Asian economies potentially feeling the effects more significantly.

site_title: Opec does not want to see volatility in oil prices: Opec president
summary: OPEC President Suhail al-Mazrouei expressed concern over volatility in oil prices, stating that a more stable price environment is preferred. Following Libya's reopening of key oil exporting ports, global oil prices plummeted 6.92% in the largest one-day drop in two years. Al-Mazrouei emphasized the need for a long-term plan to build spare capacity to cushion the market from unexpected outages. He expressed confidence that OPEC and non-OPEC have enough spare capacity to meet production targets.

images.alt_text: Opec President Suhail al-Mazrouei said on Wednesday that volatility in the crude market was undesirable and Opec prefers a more stable price environment, speaking after crude had its biggest one-day drop in two years.

site_title: Wage growth outpaced productivity growth in recent years
summary: Singapore's real wages rose 1.9% per year from 2011 to 2017, outpacing productivity growth of 1.1% over the same period. This trend was observed by Senior Minister of State Koh Poh Koon, who warned that if real wage growth outstrips productivity, businesses may lose competitiveness. However, some sectors, such as construction and services, saw faster real wage growth due to a tight labor market, while externally-oriented sectors like manufacturing and finance experienced productivity growth that supported real wage growth. The government aims to maintain competitiveness through productivity drive initiatives.

site_title: From high street to main street
summary: HSBC's retail banking arm is expanding in Singapore and South-east Asia, driven by the region's growing wealth and middle class. The city-state's GDP per capita is among the highest in the Asia-Pacific, with nearly 50% of its population holding between $100,000 and $1 million in wealth. HSBC aims to become a "scale market" in Singapore, offering digital tools and retail banking propositions to cater to the growing demand for financial services. The bank plans to invest $15-17 billion globally in growth and technology, partnering with fintech firms to create a digital scale that will enable it to bank Singaporeans and those from the region.

site_title: Singapore stock pullback offers buys, but no clarity on H2 outlook
summary: Singapore's stock market has pulled back amid uncertainties from US-China trade tensions, property cooling measures, and rising interest rates. Analysts are divided on the outlook for the second half, with some predicting a rebound and others warning of further losses. Despite the volatility, some experts see the current pullback as an attractive buying opportunity, citing the market's 12-month forward price-to-earnings ratio of 12 times, which is below its 10-year average. Year-end forecasts for the Straits Times Index (STI) range from 3,600 to 3,800, with HSBC Private Banking maintaining a "overweight" on Singapore equities.

site_title: Burberry's Q1 sales up 3%
summary: Burberry reports a 3% rise in underlying sales in its first quarter, beating forecasts. The luxury brand is repositioning itself in the higher luxury segment under new designer Riccardo Tisci. CEO Marco Gobbetti aims to catch up with faster-growing rivals while implementing a £100 million cost-saving plan. Retail revenue remained flat at £479 million, and the company expects no change to guidance at constant exchange rates. Burberry benefits from easing currency headwinds and is on track to deliver the cost savings.

site_title: Safe as houses, from Singapore to Qatar
summary: Certis Cisco, a billion-dollar security firm, is expanding globally with a bespoke suite of security services. Founded in Singapore, the company has grown significantly, with group revenue increasing from $323 million in 2008 to $1.2 billion in 2018. Its proprietary Business Process Re-engineering and Operations (BPRO) framework and blockchain-based digital record-keeping service are key to its success. The company has operations in Australia, Hong Kong, Qatar, and the UAE, and is poised to enter the aviation and retail security markets. Certis is owned by Temasek Holdings and has no plans for a public listing.

site_title: Straits Times Index falls as fears resurface
summary: Asian markets were rattled on Wednesday after the US announced plans to impose 10% tariffs on a new list of Chinese imports worth $200 billion. The Straits Times Index fell 0.8% to 3,249.08 points, while regional markets such as the Nikkei 225, Hang Seng, and Shanghai Composite also declined. Investors had initially been optimistic about upcoming earnings, but concerns over the potential impact of the tariffs led to a pullback. Chinese policymakers have vowed to take countermeasures, but analysts believe China's options are limited due to its low imports from the US.

site_title: New Malaysia central bank chief strikes neutral tone on rate
summary: Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara Malaysia, kept its benchmark interest rate steady at 3.25% in its first policy meeting under new Governor Nor Shamsiah Mohd Yunus, supporting an economy Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad is revamping. The economy's growth momentum is expected to be sustained, with inflation forecast to be lower than initially projected. The central bank has ample room to keep policy unchanged despite emerging-market sell-offs and a looming trade war with the US and China, with growth forecasts remaining solid at over 5% this year.

site_title: Trump and Merkel trade barbs over Russia pipeline at Nato meet
summary: US President Donald Trump criticized Germany's support for a Russia gas pipeline, saying it's "very sad" and "billions of dollars a year to Russia." Chancellor Angela Merkel responded that Germany makes its own sovereign decisions. Trump's comments sparked a prickly start to a NATO summit, with Merkel not backing down. The exchange highlighted differing views on Russia and NATO's role in European security.

site_title: Ex-Apple worker charged with stealing self-driving car trade secrets
summary: A former Apple employee, Xiaolang Zhang, has been charged with stealing trade secrets related to the company's self-driving car project. Zhang allegedly downloaded a blueprint for a circuit board to a personal laptop and attempted to flee the country for China. Authorities arrested him at San Jose airport on July 7. Zhang was hired to develop software and hardware for Apple's autonomous vehicle project, where he accessed secret databases and came into contact with proprietary chip technology.

site_title: As Q3 earnings jump 64%, SPH plans new growth thrusts
summary: SPH's third-quarter net profit rose 64.3% to S$47.44 million, driven by lower impairment charges and revenue from its aged care business. The company plans to expand its real estate asset management and aged care businesses overseas, focusing on "recession-proof defensive sectors."
