summary: Singapore's National Development Minister Lawrence Wong has assured that the vision for the Jurong Lake District remains unchanged, despite Malaysia's plans to scrap the high-speed rail (HSR) project between the two countries. The district, touted as Singapore's second central business district, will proceed with its development plans, with adjustments to timing and details as circumstances change. The 360ha district will feature a commercial precinct, up to 20,000 new homes, and a major transport hub, with plans already developed before Malaysia proposed the HSR project.

site_title: Japan cremates body of sarin attack cult guru
summary: Japanese authorities cremated the body of Shoko Asahara, the executed head of the Aum Shinrikyo cult behind a deadly 1995 sarin attack, on Monday. Asahara, 63, was executed with six followers on Friday for their role in the attack on the Tokyo subway that killed 13 people and injured thousands. Relatives of Asahara, including his fourth daughter and his wife, are now vying for his remains, with the Justice Ministry declining to comment on the matter.

site_title: May faces crisis over Brexit after key ministers quit
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May faces a crisis over Brexit after key ministers, including Brexit Secretary David Davis and junior minister Suella Braverman, quit in disagreement with her plan to maintain close ties to the EU after leaving the bloc. The resignations come just nine months before Britain's departure from the EU, casting doubt on May's leadership. A replacement for Davis will be announced on Monday, offering insight into May's future tactics.

site_title: Singapore will honour 1962 Water Agreement, expects Malaysia to do the same: Vivian
summary: Singapore will honor the 1962 Water Agreement with Malaysia, including the price of water stipulated in it, and expects Malaysia to do the same, Foreign Minister Vivian Balakrishnan said. The agreement allows Singapore to draw 250 million gallons of raw water daily at 1.01 Singapore cents per 1,000 gallons. Malaysia has previously criticized the water supply deal, but Dr Balakrishnan stated that neither country can unilaterally change the terms of the agreement. The agreement has been in place since 1962 and has been guaranteed by both countries, including the United Nations.

site_title: Donors raise nearly RM500,000 to help ex-Malaysian PM Najib settle bail
summary: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak has received nearly RM500,000 in donations to settle his remaining bail, totaling RM490,000. The funds, collected by Solidariti Bersama Datuk Najib, will cover the remaining RM402,000 needed for his bail. Najib is expected to pay the remainder of his RM1 million bail, which was set by a High Court judge, in two instalments. The donations have brought financial and moral support to Najib, who is currently on trial for three counts of criminal breach of trust and abuse of power.

site_title: Duterte says he will put a halt to mining 'one of these days'
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte has reiterated his plan to halt mining in the country due to environmental damage. He made the threat nearly two years ago, and it is expected to be implemented 'one of these days'. The Philippines is the world's No 2 nickel ore supplier, but mining has been marred by environmental mismanagement cases. The move is aimed at addressing the negative impacts of mining on the environment and the country's ecosystem.

site_title: Report accuses China firms over ozone-depleting gas
summary: An environmental pressure group, the Environmental Investigation Agency (EIA), claims 18 Chinese factories in 10 provinces admitted to using banned ozone-depleting CFCs, despite China's supposed ban in 2007. Chinese companies allegedly use CFC-11 due to its better quality and lower price, and export the substance by mislabeling it as HFC compounds. The EIA report comes ahead of a Montreal Protocol working group meeting, where the issue of rogue CFC-11 emissions will be discussed, and warns that continued production could imperil the ozone layer and contribute to global warming.

site_title: Australia tycoon James Packer quits family firm, citing mental health issues
summary: Australian tycoon James Packer has quit his family firm Consolidated Press Holdings due to mental health issues, months after stepping down from gaming empire Crown Resorts. Packer, 50, cited his recovery from illness as the reason for his departure from the board. This decision comes after a series of turbulent business and personal struggles, including a high-profile engagement and a 10-month detention of Crown employees in China. Packer's departure is the latest step in his recovery from mental health issues, following a psychiatric hospital stay in the US and spending time in the French Riviera.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks, won edge up on positive sentiment after US jobs data
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose 0.64% to 2,287.49, while the won strengthened 0.37% to 1,111.8 per dollar, following positive US jobs data. The won's value against the US dollar has risen 4.27% this year. Shares of South Korean steel producers declined as the European Union voted to curb steel imports. The Kospi is down 7.9% this year, but foreign investors were net sellers of 5,460 million won worth of shares.

site_title: China June FX reserves unexpectedly rise to US$3.112t
summary: China's foreign exchange reserves unexpectedly rose to US$3.112 trillion in June, up US$1.51 billion, contrary to expectations of a US$10.6 billion drop. This increase comes despite concerns of a trade war between China and the US, and a faltering yuan. The yuan has fallen 3.25% against the US dollar in June, its biggest monthly drop on record. Meanwhile, China's gold reserves fell to US$74.071 billion. The unexpected reserve increase may suggest that capital controls are effective in stabilizing the economy.

site_title: Top Glove says discovery of alleged irregularities in Aspion's accounts led to legal suit
summary: Top Glove Corporation is suing Adventa Capital and two directors for up to RM714.9 million, alleging a "conspiracy" to defraud the company over the RM1.4 billion acquisition of Aspion in April. The alleged irregularities include overstatement of assets and overvaluation of RM714.9 million, with RM74.4 million in overstated assets and RM640.5 million in overstated acquisition price. Top Glove hired an accounting firm to investigate after discovering "irregularities" in Aspion's balance sheet items.

site_title: Xiaomi's shares open 2.9% down on debut in Hong Kong
summary: Xiaomi Corp's shares dropped 2.9% on their Hong Kong debut, pricing at HK$17 per share and raising $4.72 billion, the world's largest tech IPO in four years. The weak pricing valued the company at $54 billion, lower than its original $100 billion goal. The IPO came at a challenging time for Hong Kong's stock market, which has seen a 2.7% decline last week and a 5.8% decline this year due to escalating US-China trade tensions. The listing failed to attract strong investor interest, with demand only 9.5 times the number of shares offered.

site_title: Lim Kit Siang asks if ex-Malaysian PM Najib allowed Jho Low to 'hide in plain sight' in Hong Kong
summary: Lim Kit Siang questions former Malaysian PM Najib Razak about allowing Jho Low, alleged 1MDB scandal mastermind, to 'hide in plain sight' in Hong Kong despite having an opportunity to arrest him. A South China Morning Post report revealed Jho Low occupied multiple rooms at the Pacific Place Apartments for months with an entourage, raising suspicions that Najib let him slip past authorities due to lack of formal arrest request from Malaysia. This raises concerns about Najib's intentions in allowing Jho Low to evade justice.

images.alt_text: Iskandar Puteri MP Lim Kit Siang has questioned whether former prime minister Najib Razak intentionally let controversial businessman Low Taek Jho, better known as Jho Low, slip past the authorities despite having an opportunity to have him arrested in Hong Kong.

site_title: Tencent says to spin off online music unit in US
summary: Tencent Holdings has submitted a proposal to spin off its online music unit, Tencent Music Entertainment Group, for a separate listing on a US stock exchange. The move, confirmed by the company's chairman, aims to give the business more flexibility and independence. No further details on the listing, including the offering size and price range, have been disclosed. The spin-off is subject to Hong Kong Stock Exchange approval.

site_title: US-China tensions to hurt countries' GDP: Indonesian central bank governor
summary: Indonesia's central bank governor, Perry Warjiyo, warns that US-China trade tensions will negatively affect the economic growth of other countries, including Indonesia. The country plans to strengthen domestic demand, control the current account deficit, and attract capital inflows to mitigate the effects. Bank Indonesia has already raised its benchmark rate to defend the falling rupiah currency. The strategy aims to reduce the impact of investor risk aversion and global supply chain disruptions caused by the trade war.

site_title: China's foreign reserves hold steady in June as trade war loomed
summary: China's foreign currency holdings rose $1.51 billion to $3.112 trillion in June, exceeding economists' estimates. The increase came as the yuan slumped amid a looming trade war with the US. The People's Bank of China attributed the rise to stable cross-border flows, a rising dollar, and asset price changes. Despite this, analysts note that the yuan's depreciation may lead to capital flight, prompting the central bank to defend the currency with its reserves. The reserves are expected to remain stable with some volatility.

site_title: Singapore has already spent S$250m on HSR project; to lay out S$40m more by December: Khaw Boon Wan in Parliament
summary: Singapore has spent over S$250 million on the Kuala Lumpur-Singapore high-speed rail (HSR) project, with an additional S$40 million expected to be spent by December. The costs include land acquisition, infrastructure setup, and specialist teams. Despite Malaysia's public statements on terminating the project, Singapore has incurred more costs, including over S$6 million in June and S$6 million in July, with another S$40 million expected from August to December. The government aims to recover value from some expenditure, but a significant amount will be wasted if the project does not proceed.

site_title: Singapore banks to gain from property cooling measures: Moody's
summary: Singapore banks are expected to benefit from property cooling measures, which reduced speculative demand for residential properties and increased banks' buffers. Moody's ratings agency stated that the measures will dampen bank loans for residential property purchases and improve asset quality. The measures include higher additional buyer's stamp duty rates and tighter loan-to-value limits, reducing the risk of a property price bubble. With household loan delinquencies expected to remain low, banks' exposure to the property sector is also expected to decrease. This is credit positive for Singapore's banks.

images.alt_text: Moody's said the higher ABSD rates and tighter loan limits reduce the risk of a property price bubble, future price shocks and losses from mortgage loans, which is credit positive for Singapore's banks.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Monday, rising 0.10 points to 1,663.96. The market saw 52.06 million lots traded worth RM12.07 million, with 81 gainers outnumbering 61 losers.

site_title: Broker's take: OCBC downgrades CDL to 'hold'; cuts fair value to S$9.59
summary: OCBC Investment Research downgraded City Developments Limited (CDL) to "hold" and reduced its fair value to S$9.59 from S$15.78, citing weaker demand and pressure on local residential sales momentum and margins due to the Singapore government's cooling measures. Analysts expect CDL's rebound to be muted, with the stock trading up 3.8% at S$9.82. The measures, including a hike in stamp duty and tighter loan limits, are expected to impact CDL's land bank and unsold inventory.

site_title: China securities regulator says to ease A-shares restrictions for foreigners
summary: China's securities regulator announced plans to ease restrictions on foreign investment in Shanghai and Shenzhen exchanges, aiming to attract more foreign capital and support the economy. Foreign nationals working in China and qualified foreigners working overseas for Chinese firms can now open A-share securities accounts. This move is expected to increase foreign investment in the country's stock market.

site_title: Alliance, Tawana update terms of merger agreement
summary: CATALIST-LISTED Alliance Mineral Assets and Australian-listed Tawana Resources have updated their merger agreement, with amendments including the cancellation of Tawana options expiring in 2021 for Alliance shares and treatment of South African Tawana shareholders as ineligible for receiving Alliance shares. Under the merger, Tawana shareholders will receive 1.1 new Alliance shares for every Tawana share, resulting in a combined 50% stake in the new merged group. Alliance shares rose 2.9% following the update.

site_title: Four boys rescued from flooded Thai cave
summary: Four boys among 13 trapped in a Thai cave were rescued on Sunday after surviving a treacherous escape, raising hopes for the rescue of the remaining group. The boys, aged 11-16, emerged from the Tham Luang cave complex after a 4km route guided by divers, and were rushed to hospital. The rescue was a stunning victory, but extraction efforts for the remaining 9 are on hold until Monday morning to allow rescue divers time to resupply.

site_title: Local players tackle industrial water demand
summary: Local companies in Singapore are developing innovative solutions to address the country's growing industrial water demand. The Economic Development Board notes that demand will rise in the non-domestic sector, including manufacturing plants and commercial buildings. In response, companies are investing in water management technologies, such as AI and digital innovation, to improve efficiency and reduce waste. This effort aims to support Singapore's goal of meeting its water needs while minimizing its environmental impact.

site_title: BOJ's Kuroda expresses resolve to keep ultra-easy monetary policy
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda reaffirmed the central bank's commitment to maintaining ultra-easy monetary policy until Japan's inflation reaches 2% target. The BOJ will guide short-term interest rates at minus 0.1% and the 10-year government bond yield around zero%. Kuroda expressed confidence that Japan's economy will continue to expand moderately as the output gap improves and medium- to long-term inflation expectations increase.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rally at open on Monday
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 1.03% in the first few minutes of trade on Monday, driven by a positive lead from US stocks, which showed another healthy rise in job creation. The Hang Seng Index reached 28,606.16, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also increased.

site_title: Singapore woman jailed in 'Fat Leonard' US Navy graft case
summary: A Singaporean woman, Gursharan Kaur Sharon Rachael, was sentenced to 33 months in jail for her role in the "Fat Leonard" US Navy graft case. She leaked confidential information to Malaysian businessman Leonard Francis in exchange for cash and luxury vacations. Francis, dubbed "Fat Leonard," admitted to bribing US Navy officers with cash, booze, and prostitutes to secure contracts for his firm, Glenn Defense Marine Asia. Francis and 12 US Navy officers pleaded guilty, with nine receiving jail terms and fines, including retired rear admiral Robert Gilbeau, who was jailed for 18 months.

site_title: Paypal to spend US$3b a year on M&A: CEO
summary: PayPal CEO Dan Schulman stated the company plans to spend up to $3 billion annually on mergers and acquisitions (M&A) to acquire specific capabilities. Following its $2.2 billion acquisition of iZettle, PayPal is ready to invest in further deals that enable its digital payment services. Schulman expressed his willingness to consider larger acquisitions if there's a good fit for the company, indicating PayPal's commitment to expanding its capabilities through strategic acquisitions.

site_title: Justin Bieber engaged to model Baldwin: reports
summary: Justin Bieber has become engaged to model Hailey Baldwin after proposing to her over dinner at a restaurant in The Bahamas. The 24-year-old pop star, who has a history of trouble, asked Baldwin, 21, to marry him just one month into their relationship. Relatives of the couple confirmed the news, with Bieber's father Jeremy and mother Pattie expressing their excitement on social media. This marks Bieber's second high-profile romance, following his breakup with Selena Gomez.

site_title: Vard's independent financial adviser maintains 'not fair but reasonable' recommendation on Fincantieri offer
summary: Vard's independent financial adviser CIMB Bank maintains its "not fair but reasonable" recommendation on Fincantieri's buyout offer, citing a 9.2% discount to NAV and a 20.1% premium to NTA as of March 31, 2018. The exit offer price of S$0.25 per share is also compared to earlier circulars, with discounts ranging from 9.2% to 14.9%. The offer is conditional on the delisting resolution being passed at Vard's EGM on July 24, and will lapse if the condition is not fulfilled.

site_title: Addvalue Technologies reports wider FY2018 loss, lower net asset value after audit
summary: Addvalue Technologies reported a wider loss for FY2018, increasing to US$12.8 million, 14.8% higher than the unaudited result. Total equity fell 18% to US$7.5 million, resulting in a net asset value per share of 0.42 US cents, down from 0.52 US cents. The company's basic loss per share worsened to 0.73 US cents. Addvalue's pre-tax losses for the past three consecutive years have been recorded, and it is at risk of being placed on the Singapore Exchange's watch list due to its six-month average daily market capitalization of S$70.2 million.

site_title: British woman dies after exposure to Novichok nerve agent
summary: A British woman, Dawn Sturgess, 44, has died after exposure to the nerve agent Novichok in southwest England. Sturgess and a 45-year-old man, Charlie Rowley, fell ill last weekend in Amesbury, near Salisbury, where former Russian spy Sergei Skripal and his daughter Yulia were attacked with Novichok in March. Police launched a murder inquiry, and Prime Minister Theresa May offered condolences to the family. The investigation is ongoing, with around 100 counter-terrorism officers involved, and police confirm a link between the Amesbury case and the Salisbury attack is a main line of inquiry.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher with yen stable against US dollar
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Monday, extending rallies in New York, as the yen remained stable against the US dollar. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.23% to 21,839.22, while the Topix index gained 0.34%. This follows a positive trend in New York, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite ongoing US-EU trade uncertainty.

site_title: Britain's Brexit minister David Davis steps down: reports
summary: Britain's Brexit minister David Davis has resigned, two days after the cabinet approved a plan to keep strong economic ties with the European Union after leaving the bloc. Davis, who was appointed to head the Department for Exiting the European Union, had reportedly threatened to quit due to Prime Minister Theresa May's stance in Brexit talks. His resignation comes as the UK faces a fresh blow to its economy, with the UK economy shrinking for the second month in a row.

site_title: Gaylin to acquire marine services firm Amos International for S$48.6m in all-shares deal
summary: Gaylin Holdings has agreed to acquire marine services firm Amos International Holdings for S$48.6 million in an all-shares deal. The acquisition involves Gaylin's executive chairman, Kyle Shaw, who holds a 69.4% stake in Amos International through associate Lighthouse Logistics. Amos International's founder, Danny Lien, will sell his shares, and Lighthouse will exercise drag-along rights to require other shareholders to sell their shares to Gaylin. The deal will be completed through the issuance of new Gaylin shares at $0.06 each.

site_title: Amazon used to promote white supremacist merchandise and views, says report
summary: Amazon has been criticized for allowing white supremacist and racist merchandise on its platform, according to a report by the Partnership for Working Families and the Action Center on Race and the Economy. The report found that Amazon's policies are "weak and inadequately enforced," allowing hate groups to generate revenue and propagate their ideas. The report identified dozens of items, including onesies with Nazi symbols and e-books published by hate organizations, which were available for purchase on Amazon. Amazon has since removed many of the items, but critics say the company must do more to police its platforms and prevent hate speech.

site_title: Allianz Real Estate aims to raise China investment in new economy, logistics: APAC CEO
summary: Allianz Real Estate plans to increase its investment in China's new economy and logistics sectors, aiming for 50% of its Asia-Pacific fund allocation. The company has bought an office tower in a Beijing software park and expects to complete another purchase in a Shanghai business park within weeks. This move is part of its strategy to align with China's growth in the new economy and contribute to the country's sector development.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Top Glove, Asiatravel.com, Addvalue Technologies, Gaylin Holdings
summary: Top Glove has sued Adventa Capital and two directors for up to RM715 million over an alleged conspiracy related to the acquisition of Aspion. Asiatravel.com Holdings suspended trading after its controlling shareholder missed a payment, while Addvalue Technologies reported a wider loss of US$12.8 million. Gaylin Holdings entered into an agreement to acquire Amos International Holdings valued at S$48.6 million. These developments may affect trading of the mentioned companies' shares on Monday.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Monday; STI up 0.27%
summary: Singapore shares opened higher on Monday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 8.55 points to 3,200.37. About 26.5 million shares changed hands, with gainers outnumbering losers 70 to 46. Key players like CapitaLand and Golden Agri-Res were among the active stocks, with CapitaLand rising 1% and Golden Agri-Res falling 1.7%. The rally follows a 5-day streak ahead of GDP data and amid global market optimism, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite US trade uncertainty.

site_title: Singapore's Temasek set to report record portfolio
summary: Temasek Holdings Pte Ltd, Singapore's state investor, is expected to report a record portfolio value of S$300 billion for the year ended March 31, up 9% from the previous year. The gain is largely attributed to investments in DBS Group Ltd and Chinese banks. Temasek is also increasing its investment in tech startups, including virtual reality and fintech companies, and has participated in funding rounds for Indonesian ride-hailing firm Go-Jek and US startup Magic Leap Inc. Analysts expect Temasek to maintain its focus on tech investments while also investing in real estate and infrastructure.

site_title: Cosco clears US hurdle on Orient Overseas deal
summary: Cosco Shipping Holdings Co has agreed to sell a California container terminal, addressing US national security concerns, and clearing the way for its $6.3 billion acquisition of Orient Overseas International Ltd. The sale, announced after a national security agreement with the US, will transfer ownership to a US trust with a US citizen principal trustee. This move follows a review by the Committee on Foreign Investment in the US, which had raised concerns about the deal. The sale clears the way for Cosco to become the world's No. 3 container line by capacity after AP Moller-Maersk and Mediterranean Shipping Co.

site_title: Lose-lose for investors, banks as Japanese bonds go unsold
summary: Japanese investors are suspicious of a practice where underwriters keep unsold bonds, despite declaring a full sale. This "retention system" benefits issuers by completing deals at lower yields, but harms investors and underwriters. Industry-wide, brokerages push for underwriting deals, and the Bank of Japan's negative-rate policy makes it harder to price corporate notes. The issue is attracting attention as the BOJ continues its negative-rate policy, with some companies, like Denso and ANA, having unsold bonds. The practice is slowly changing, with some issuers opting for more transparent "pot system" used in the US and Europe.

site_title: Torrential rains kill at least 88 in western Japan
summary: Torrential rains in western Japan have killed at least 88 people, with dozens still missing, and forced over 2 million to evacuate. Landslides and flooded rivers trapped many, and emergency services used helicopters and boats to rescue over 2,000 stranded in the city of Kurashiki. The death toll exceeds 77 from heavy rains and landslides in 2014 and is the highest since a 2004 typhoon. The rain has caused widespread destruction and disruptions, with 276,000 households without water supply and road closures reported.

site_title: Chinese savers won't save China
summary: Chinese households are not saving as much as previously thought, with actual savings rates closer to 13% of GDP, less than a third of the headline national savings rate. This is due to government-mandated social-security contributions and a relatively thin safety net, with most savings held in land and real estate. As a result, households have gone into debt, with a debt-to-household income ratio of 112%, higher than in the US and Japan. This poses challenges for China's economic growth, as it relies heavily on investment and struggles to find savings to fund growth.

site_title: US warships pass through Taiwan Strait amid China tensions
summary: Two US warships, the destroyers Mustin and Benfold, passed through the Taiwan Strait on July 7-8, amid heightened tensions with China. The move is seen as a sign of support by President Donald Trump for self-ruled Taiwan, which China claims as its own. The passage follows a series of Chinese military drills around the island and comes as a US-China trade fight continues. The US has no formal ties with Taiwan but is bound by law to help it defend itself, and the move is likely to escalate tensions between Beijing and Taipei.

site_title: Sustainability the key theme for upcoming mega sourcing event
summary: The upcoming mega sourcing event in Singapore, featuring the Singapore Gifts & Premiums Fair, Office Expo Asia, and PrintPack+Sign, will focus on sustainability. Over 300 exhibitors from 14 countries will showcase eco-friendly products and solutions, including locally designed gifts, sustainable office furniture, and energy-efficient signages. Exhibitors such as Deo Silver and Datumstruct Solutions will highlight their environmentally-friendly offerings, while Micronprint will demonstrate its use of 3D printing technology for sustainable packaging. The event aims to cater to the demand for unique, durable, and eco-friendly products and services.

site_title: Pompeo urges North Korea's Kim to follow Vietnam's example
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo urged North Korea's Kim Jong Un to follow Vietnam's example, saying President Donald Trump believes Pyongyang can replicate Hanoi's path to normal relations with Washington and prosperity. Pompeo cited Vietnam's post-Vietnam War engagement with the US as a key factor, which led to a 8,000% growth in bilateral trade and billions of dollars in US investments. Pompeo emphasized the importance of North Korea seizing the moment to create a brighter future alongside the US, saying the US would follow through on its promises.

site_title: US dollar hits 3-week low on jobs report
summary: The US dollar hit a three-week low after the June jobs report showed the economy created 213,000 jobs, exceeding expectations, but with a lower-than-forecast wage growth increase and an increase in the unemployment rate to 4%. This dimmed expectations for a fourth interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve this year. The dollar index fell 0.5% and the euro rose 0.5% against the US dollar, amid ongoing trade tensions between the US and China.

site_title: Six SGX stocks commence buybacks
summary: Six Singapore Exchange (SGX) stocks commenced share buybacks, with a total consideration of S$28.4 million over the past five trading sessions. The buybacks were led by United Overseas Bank, which purchased 433,784 shares for S$11.7 million. The buybacks were part of a larger trend of director and substantial shareholder transactions, with 68 primary-listed stocks reporting changes in director interests or substantial shareholders' transactions over the same period.

site_title: Levelling the playing field for youth through all-round development
summary: NTUC Income's OrangeAid Future Development Programme provides 800 bursaries worth S$2.04 million to underprivileged youth in Singapore from 2018 to 2019, supporting their school fees and living expenses. The programme aims to provide a level playing field for youth to have opportunities in school and the workplace. This initiative is part of NTUC Income's efforts to promote all-round development of young people.

images.alt_text: Since 2015, 150 individuals have graduated from the programme, with most participants faring better in their studies since being a part of FDP.

site_title: Going hand in hand
summary: Lauren Sorkin, Managing Director of Asia Pacific 100 Resilient Cities, emphasizes the importance of aligning profit and purpose in Singapore's competitive business environment. Companies must consider their role in supporting the community, city, and country, including demographic changes, climate change, and social issues such as empowering female leadership and providing opportunities for older workers. By thinking holistically, businesses can build stability and resilience, contributing to the country's overall resilience and well-being. This requires a holistic approach to corporate behavior and policy, understanding the interconnections between business operations and the community.

site_title: China has big bumpers to fend off car wars
summary: China's carmakers remain resilient to external forces, particularly US tariffs, due to their domestic market's stability and limited globalization. Despite the imposition of $34 billion in US tariffs, China's auto exports to the US have increased, and the country's domestic market, which produces over 20 million units annually, provides a buffer against pricing pressures. Chinese consumers prioritize brands over prices, and foreign companies are incentivized to partner with local automakers. This stability is expected to shield China's carmakers from the impact of US tariffs, which are likely to hurt the US market instead.

site_title: Property stocks to remain the hot topic in town
summary: Singapore's property stocks are expected to remain a hot topic due to cooling measures and trade tariffs. The Straits Times Index fell 2% last week, with property stocks experiencing a 1.5% decline. The government's ninth round of property cooling initiatives, including increased ABSD and higher down payment requirements, are expected to curb home sales this year. Despite this, UOB analysts predict the property market will continue to be a "buzz in town".

site_title: Orange says it is open to French telecom tie-up discussions, but won't instigate talks
summary: Orange, a leading French telecom firm, is open to discussing potential tie-ups with other operators in its home market. However, financial chief Ramon Fernandez stated that Orange will not instigate talks. This comes amid an aggressive price war in the sector, sparking expectations of consolidation. Orange's openness to discussions suggests that the company is willing to explore opportunities for cooperation, but its reluctance to be the instigator implies that it may not be actively seeking a merger.

site_title: Trade war, US-Korean diplomacy to decide market stability
summary: US stocks finished slightly higher last week despite the outbreak of a trade war between the US and China. Investors celebrated strong jobs growth and ignored the market's concerns, which may be short-lived if the trade war escalates or US-South Korean diplomacy deteriorates. The Baltic Dry Index and soybean prices have retreated, and investors are discounting the prospect of a trade war. The stock market rally is expected to be tested by earnings season, particularly in the technology sector, and the level of Treasury yields could impact the financial sector.

site_title: Mind the gap? No, not yet, say chip exporters
summary: Singapore's electronics manufacturing cluster has seen a year-on-year surge in factory output despite declining exports. Experts attribute the gap to various factors, ranging from cautious optimism. The surge in output could position Singapore as a global hub for advanced chip packaging, according to a study. The government is also exploring ways to support businesses and workers, including a new grant of up to S$100,000 for tariff-hit businesses.

site_title: Hyflux receives grant of extension for reporting Q2 and Q3 financials
summary: Hyflux, a Singapore-based water treatment firm, has received a six-month extension for reporting its Q2 and Q3 financials from the Singapore Exchange (SGX). The company, which is undergoing a reorganisation, had originally been due to announce its Q2 financials by August 14 and its Q3 financials by November 14. The extension, granted on July 6, is linked to a six-month moratorium on debt payments, and the company will only release financial statements when it has certainty regarding the terms of its reorganisation and financing proposals.

site_title: Fullerton raises S$200,000 for President's Challenge
summary: The Fullerton Heritage Group raised S$200,000 for President's Challenge to celebrate the 90th anniversary of the iconic Fullerton Building in Singapore. The funds were generated through private auctions and table ticket sales at a gala dinner and concours d'elegance event. Auction items included a timepiece and a commissioned painting by artist Stephen Peng. The funds will support beneficiaries of the President's Challenge, promoting community engagement and social causes in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Sino Group deputy chairman Daryl Ng presenting the proceeds raised by the Fullerton Heritage Group to President Halimah.

site_title: Digitalisation to help drive Applied Materials' Singapore operations
summary: Applied Materials' Singapore operations, accounting for nearly half of its semiconductor output, are expected to benefit from rising industry digitalization. The company's vice-president, Brian Tan, sees growth in pharmaceuticals, transport, and handsets, driven by increased data and computer processing needs. Tan notes that packaging, a critical step in the process, is a key driver of growth, with all packaging research and development done in Singapore. The company expects strong double-digit growth in 2018 and a $90-100 billion wafer fabrication equipment market by the end of 2019.

site_title: Chilling effect on property market as cooling measures hit developers, buyers
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore has introduced new cooling measures, increasing acquisition costs for developers and buyers, with a 30% potential decline in primary home transaction volume. The measures, including higher Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD) rates and tightened loan-to-value (LTV) rates, are expected to affect foreigners, Singaporean/Permanent Resident investors, and real estate developers. The market is expected to be quiet for the next couple of months, with prices unlikely to drop significantly due to the mismatch in price expectations between buyers and sellers.

site_title: 'Super polluting' trucks get a break as disgraced environment chief leaves
summary: The US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has granted a loophole allowing a significant increase in the manufacturing of diesel freight trucks that produce high levels of air pollution. The move, made by EPA Administrator Scott Pruitt before his resignation, effectively lifts a cap on glider trucks, which are older engines transplanted into new truck bodies. Environmental groups and industry players have strongly opposed the decision, citing health concerns and the need to reduce air pollution. The EPA has announced it will not enforce the annual cap of 300 glider trucks per manufacturer until 2020.

site_title: Business booms for plastic giants even as change beckons
summary: The global demand for plastic continues to rise despite environmental concerns and regulatory efforts to curb its use. From 2006 to 2016, plastic output increased by 43% to 348 million tonnes, with production rising 3.9% in 2017. The growth of the plastics industry is linked to economic development, with single-use plastic packaging in demand in developing countries. Western manufacturers are adapting to the changing market by developing specialty plastics for industries like construction, medicine, and aerospace. Regulatory measures, such as bans on single-use plastics, are expected to impact the industry.

site_title: Forget Trump: Europe plans to push for more ambition on climate
summary: The European Union plans to push for more ambition on climate change despite US President Donald Trump's withdrawal from the Paris Agreement. The EU aims to lower greenhouse gas emissions by 80% by 2050 and potentially reach net-zero emissions by mid-century. The bloc will set long-term targets and encourage companies to front-load actions to reduce costs. A high-level conference will be held to consult stakeholders on the new strategy, which will also be used to persuade other countries to follow the EU's lead at the upcoming UN climate talks.

site_title: Health insurers warn of turmoil as Trump suspends billions in payments
summary: The Trump administration has suspended a $11.3 billion program that pays health insurers to stabilize health insurance markets under the Affordable Care Act. This move could increase uncertainty in the markets and drive up premiums this autumn. Insurers that enroll large numbers of unhealthy people rely on the "risk adjustment" payments to reduce incentives to shun those with chronic illnesses. Affordable Care Act supporters see this as the latest attempt to undermine the health law.

site_title: Metal markets are preparing for a new world disorder
summary: US President Donald Trump's trade policies have sent the metals world into disarray, with copper and zinc retreating globally while steel prices and aluminum premiums surge in the US. Tariffs on US imports, particularly from China, are threatening to wreak havoc on manufacturers, while foreign metal becomes more appealing. Analysts predict a significant impact on the industry, with potential offshoring of steel production and demand destruction, and some countries, such as Canada and the European Union, imposing their own barriers to prevent dumping.

images.alt_text: While sky-high US metal prices are great for local producers, manufacturers have to pick up the bill, undermining their competitiveness.

site_title: Banks should recognise Asia's growing FX stature
summary: London's status as the top global financial centre is under threat as Asia's growing FX stature continues to rise. Singapore, Hong Kong, and Tokyo have seen significant increases in FX trading volumes, with Singapore emerging as the third-largest market after London and New York. Asia's growing economic influence, coupled with the increasing importance of Asian currencies in global trade and investment, has led to a shift eastwards in the FX trading market. Singapore, in particular, has become a major player, with its average daily trading volume reaching $517 billion in 2016, up 35% from three years prior.

site_title: May seeks to bind ministers to her Brexit plan
summary: Theresa May seeks to unite her Cabinet behind her Brexit plan, with key ministers such as Liam Fox and Michael Gove publicly supporting her proposal. Despite initial criticism from hard-line Brexiteers, the plan has been deemed the best option, with Boris Johnson stating he will remain in the Cabinet to fight for it. However, May now faces a challenge in winning over the rest of her Conservative Party, with some lawmakers circulating a briefing paper warning of a "Black Hole Brexit" and potentially triggering a vote of confidence in her leadership.

site_title: Adjusted Ebitda masks higher leverage on buyout loans
summary: Investors in European leveraged loans are concerned that private equity firms are making overly aggressive adjustments to portfolio companies' earnings to support higher debt loads. Ebitda adjustments, which reflect assumptions about future earnings potential, may not be achievable and mask true leverage and debt levels. This practice, common during the 2008 financial crisis, is resurfacing, and investors are demanding changes. Adjustments linked to mergers and acquisitions are more likely to be accepted by the market, according to ratings agency Moody's.

site_title: HDB looking at expanding use of floating system for solar panels in open sea
summary: HDB is collaborating with ISO Landscape to research and develop a floating solar system for coastal marine conditions in the open sea. The system aims to harness energy from the sun in Singapore, where land constraints limit the use of solar panels. The study will explore how the system can withstand harsher environmental conditions, such as stronger winds and wave action, and consider factors like biofouling and soiling from birds. The goal is to expand the use of solar energy in Singapore and reduce reliance on fossil fuels, aligning with the country's target to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

site_title: New M&C CEO gunning for asset-driven growth
summary: MILLENNIUM & Copthorne (M&C), a London-listed hotel chain, has appointed Jennifer Fox as its new group CEO. Fox plans to drive growth through acquisitions, management contracts, and improving hotel performance, with a focus on expanding into untapped markets such as Australia and the US. M&C owns over 135 hotels worldwide with 40,000 rooms, and Fox believes its ownership-driven model is a competitive advantage. She aims to groom talent, improve hotel performance, and explore opportunities for portfolio purchases.

site_title: Zuckerberg tops Buffett to become world's third-richest person
summary: Mark Zuckerberg has surpassed Warren Buffett to become the world's third-richest person, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index. This achievement comes as Facebook shares climbed 2.4% on Friday. Zuckerberg trails only Jeff Bezos and Bill Gates, solidifying technology's role in creating wealth.

images.alt_text: Mr Zuckerberg, 34, is now worth US$81.6 billion.

site_title: Loan funds see outflows for first time in 20 weeks amid trade war
summary: US loan funds saw the first week of outflows in 20 weeks amid market volatility triggered by the escalating US-China trade war. Investors pulled $184.2 million from loan funds in the week ending July 4, citing market volatility and preference for safer investment-grade securities. The trade conflict has generated risk-off sentiment across global markets, with average bids for US secondary loans dropping to 98.64 and the percentage of loans trading above face value declining to 25%. This trend is expected to continue as investors seek less credit-risky assets.

site_title: As facial-recognition use grows, so do fears of being watched
summary: Facial recognition technology is increasingly being used in law enforcement, border security, and other purposes, raising concerns about a "Big Brother" surveillance state. Studies have shown that the technology may not be accurate, especially for people of color, and that errors or abuse could lead to severe harm. Civil liberties activists and experts argue that law enforcement should not deploy facial recognition in real-time through drones, body cameras, and dash cams, and that specific policy safeguards should be in place to prevent misuse.

site_title: Navigating critical illness plans
summary: Singaporeans have a significant protection gap of S$893 billion for critical illness and mortality, with only 20% of their critical illness needs covered. The Life Insurance Association recommends 3.9 times annual income for critical illness coverage, but the average policyholder has less than one standalone policy. Insurers have introduced standalone critical illness plans with various features, such as multiple claim payouts and caps on amounts claimed. Advisers are essential to clarify issues and consider individual needs and family history. Standalone plans can provide up to 600% of the sum assured, with premiums ranging from S$2,110 to S$3,538 per year.

images.alt_text: Hardly anyone would argue against the need for some critical illness (CI) protection, but the big question is - how much do you need?

site_title: Equity outlook positive as US capital goods data still expanding
summary: US capital goods data remains positive, signaling a bullish outlook despite escalating trade tensions. Core capital goods orders continue to expand, indicating growing company spending on business expansion. This has historically shown a strong positive correlation with the S&P 500 index, with the data peaking at the dot-com bubble and Global Financial Crisis. The current expansion in core capital goods orders suggests robust economic growth, with consumer sentiment, ISM manufacturing PMI, retail sales, and unemployment rates at multi-year extremes.

site_title: Japanese wine-growers saved from French deportation
summary: Japanese wine-growers Rie and Hirofumi Shoji have won the right to stay in France after a massive petition campaign in support of them. The couple, who own an award-winning vineyard in Banyuls-sur-mer, were initially ordered to leave after failing to prove they earned the minimum required income. However, local authorities have decided to re-examine their administrative status and have granted them an extension on their residency permits for at least three more months. The couple, who studied wine-making and worked for a French super-chef, had been threatened with deportation due to their low earnings.

site_title: China's economy to expand 6.7% in H1
summary: China's economy is predicted to expand 6.7% in the first half of 2018, slightly retreating from the 6.8% growth seen in the first quarter, according to forecasts by financial institutions and economists. The improving trend is attributed to the global economic recovery, rising new growth momentum, and a warming property market. Despite a negative contribution from net exports, exports and investment are expected to drive growth, with consumption and investment contributing 70% and 35% to economic growth, respectively.

site_title: Twitter suspends over 70m accounts in 2 months: Washington Post
summary: Twitter suspended over 70 million accounts in May and June, and the pace has continued in July, according to a report by the Washington Post. The platform aims to reduce misinformation, but the effort has had "a ton of impact" on active users, according to Twitter's vice president for trust and safety, Del Harvey. The suspension rate is around 1 million accounts per day.

site_title: Global stocks mostly rise even as US-China trade war gets real
summary: Global stock markets rose on Friday despite a US-China trade war escalating, with the US imposing 25% tariffs on $34 billion of Chinese goods. The move, seen as a "largest trade war" in economic history, prompted China to retaliate with its own tariffs on US goods. Despite concerns, markets remained upbeat, with Asian markets leading the gains, and European and US indices ending higher. Analysts say the impact of tariffs on economic growth appears limited for now, giving markets a "breathing spell."

site_title: US mall landlords push to cut escape clauses for smaller tenants
summary: US mall landlords are pushing to eliminate or narrow co-tenancy clauses in leases with smaller tenants, which allow them to cut or pay less if key anchor tenants depart. This move comes after hundreds of department-store closings, leaving many malls struggling to replace lost merchants. Landlords are seeking to reduce flexibility for remaining tenants, but experts note that co-tenancy clauses already offer limited protection, and tenants may negotiate shorter leases or reduced rents as alternatives.

site_title: Mexico's next president aims to end foreign fuel imports in 3 years
summary: Mexican President-elect Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador aims to end the country's reliance on foreign fuel imports within three years, boosting refining at home and increasing domestic crude oil production. He plans to revive oil activity, exploration, and drilling to achieve this goal, with a goal to build one large or two medium-sized oil refineries during his six-year term. Lopez Obrador also seeks to strengthen Mexico's state-owned oil company, Pemex, and reverse a 14-year-long oil output slide.

site_title: World Cup: England target semis after Belgium stun Brazil
summary: England will face Sweden in the World Cup quarterfinals after Belgium stunned Brazil 2-1, eliminating the five-time champions. The match against Sweden will determine England's path to a potential semi-final spot against either Croatia or Russia. Belgium will play France in the semifinals after defeating Uruguay 2-0. The tournament has seen no traditional favorites advance to the final, leaving it as one of the most unpredictable World Cups in history.

site_title: Washington and Pyongyang get down to 'nitty gritty' in nuclear talks
summary: US and North Korean officials have set up working groups to discuss "nitty gritty" details of denuclearization, verification, and repatriation of American war dead. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo met with North Korean official Kim Yong Chol, stating the US aim for "complete denuclearization" of the North. Despite no nuclear tests since the Singapore summit, satellite imagery shows upgrades to the Yongbyon nuclear plant, raising concerns. The talks come after a month since the Singapore summit between Trump and Kim Jong Un, with no clear progress on denuclearization.

site_title: Samsung's profit falls short on weak phone demand
summary: Samsung Electronics Co. reported operating income of 14.8 trillion won (S$18 billion) for the three months ended June, falling short of analysts' estimates of 15.3 trillion won. The company's profit is impacted by weak phone demand, which has been affecting global smartphone sales for months. This marks a change in Samsung's ability to weather the downturn, as the company was previously seen as more resilient to slowing smartphone sales.

site_title: Grasshopper leaps to new paradigm
summary: Grasshopper, a proprietary trading firm, is launching an over-the-counter cryptocurrency marketplace, Tilde, to capitalize on the growing demand for cryptocurrency trading. Founded by John Lin, a veteran trader, the company aims to bring education, efficient execution, and competitive pricing to the cryptocurrency market. With its expertise in trading and technology, Grasshopper seeks to contribute to the development of a healthy cryptocurrency ecosystem and provide outstanding execution for its clients. The company's goal is to build sustainable, liquid markets based on a new and sound market structure.

site_title: UOB's annual Heartbeat Run/ Walk event raises over S$1.25 million
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) has raised over S$1.25 million for children's charities across Asia through its annual Heartbeat Run/Walk event. The event drew 17,000 participants and used PayNow to facilitate donations. The proceeds will support 13 beneficiaries in Singapore, including organizations that provide art and literacy programs for underprivileged and special needs children. This is the first time UOB colleagues in Vietnam have participated in the event, with deputy chairman Wee Ee Cheong expressing the bank's commitment to giving back to the community.

site_title: Metal fatigue caused fatal Airbus helicopter crash: final report
summary: A fatal Airbus helicopter crash in 2016 killed all 13 people on board due to metal fatigue in its gearbox, Norway's Accident Investigation Board (AIBN) confirmed in its final report. The Super Puma's main rotor blades separated during a ferry flight from a Norwegian offshore oil platform, and investigators attributed the accident to a fatigue fracture in the gearbox's second stage planet gear. The report excluded other potential causes and recommended Airbus revise the helicopter's main gearbox design to improve robustness, reliability, and safety.

site_title: The board's oversight of corruption risk
summary: Singapore's low corruption levels remain a priority, with the Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau stating that corruption "remains under control." Despite low private sector cases, recent high-profile scandals have prompted a reevaluation of corporate ethics and culture. The country's clean system and low corruption levels have been consistently ranked among the best globally, making it the sixth least corrupt country in the world. The government aims to leverage a strong corporate culture to steer management and employees clear of graft and other illegal activities.

site_title: Over 100 'chimneys' drilled into mountain in bid to reach trapped boys
summary: Rescue efforts in Thailand's Tham Luang cave complex have intensified with over 100 chimneys drilled into the mountainside to reach trapped boys. The boys, aged 11-16, have been trapped for two weeks. Rescuers estimate they are 600 meters down, but lack technology to pinpoint their location. Fresh air has been pumped in, and non-essential workers have been withdrawn from the rescue base to preserve oxygen levels. The operation aims to establish new ways to extract the boys if underground chambers flood, making it too risky to evacuate them through submerged passageways.

site_title: United Airlines to post US$105m Q2 charge on Brazil routes
summary: United Airlines expects to record a US$105 million Q2 charge due to an Open Skies agreement between Brazil and the US impairing the value of its Brazil routes. The charge is non-cash and unrelated to a decline in passenger traffic. The airline will publish second-quarter results on July 17 and hold a conference call on July 18. United's share price rose to US$70.96 following the announcement.

site_title: Have shares in a blockbuster IPO? Dump them, quick
summary: Investors in big tech IPOs may want to consider selling their shares quickly, as research found that 81.3% of IPOs rose on day one but only 49.2% continued to climb over the subsequent year. Between six months and one year post-listing, only 40% of companies showed sustained growth. The biggest IPOs tend to be the worst performers, with only six of the top 20 by sale size rising in the first year. Investors should consider waiting at least a year for the "IPO hangover" to pass before buying into new tech firms.

site_title: Weinstein Co sales price increased by US$2m in push to close deal
summary: The Weinstein Co. has reached a deal to increase its sales price from $287 million to $289 million to ensure the deal's closure. The agreement clears the path for the sale to Lantern Capital Partners, which had initially offered $310 million. The deal resolves disputes over "cure amounts" and breaches of representations and warranties in the asset purchase agreement. A hearing to approve the new sales price is scheduled for July 11 in US Bankruptcy Court in Delaware. The sale is part of the studio's bankruptcy proceedings, which followed a scandal surrounding co-founder Harvey Weinstein.

site_title: Manafort says he can't prepare for trial because of jail
summary: Paul Manafort, former campaign chairman of Donald Trump, has asked a Virginia judge to delay his July 25 trial on bank fraud and tax charges due to being held in a jail 100 miles from his lawyers' offices. Manafort claims the isolation has hindered his ability to prepare for the trial, which he claims will be ready after his separate money-laundering case in Washington, scheduled to start on September 17. Special Counsel Robert Mueller opposes the request.

site_title: BP is front-runner to buy BHP's US shale unit
summary: BP Plc has emerged as the front-runner to buy BHP Billiton's US onshore oil and gas operations, with the London-based oil major making the highest offer. BHP prefers selling the assets in a single package, valued at up to $9 billion. The deal could be weeks away from completion. BP's acquisition would give the company a presence in the Permian Basin, one of the world's most productive oilfields, where Exxon Mobil Corp has aggressively expanded through acquisitions.

site_title: English to resign from US Consumer Financial Protection bureau, withdraw suit against Trump
summary: Leandra English, Deputy Director of the US Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, will step down early next week after President Donald Trump's nomination of Kathy Kraninger for the position. English had filed a lawsuit seeking to be acknowledged as Acting Director of the CFPB. English's attorney plans to file court papers to close the litigation. English was elevated to Deputy Director by Richard Cordray before he resigned as Director. The Senate will consider Kraninger's nomination to succeed Mulvaney as CFPB head.

site_title: China eyes eastern Europe investment as US trade war sizzles
summary: Chinese Premier Li Keqiang is meeting leaders from central and eastern Europe in Bulgaria to discuss investment opportunities amid the US-China trade war. The 16+1 cooperation aims to fund road and rail projects, as well as joint ventures in industry and infrastructure. However, concerns have been raised that China is seeking to divide the EU by funding infrastructure under its Belt and Road initiative. Li downplayed these concerns, stating that China supports European integration and a united EU. The summit comes as the US has imposed 25% tariffs on $34 billion of Chinese goods, prompting China to retaliate and commit to opening its markets to foreign companies.

site_title: Who has Federal Reserve Chair Powell's ear? Lawmakers and bankers
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell spends more time with lawmakers, White House advisers, and bankers than his predecessor Janet Yellen, according to calendars detailing his first four months on the job. In the four months through May, Powell had 117 meetings or calls with non-Fed staff, including 27 with members of Congress and seven with economists. He also met with President Trump's economic advisers seven times, compared to four in Yellen's first four months.

site_title: BT-World Cup CEO Challenge
summary: There is no article to summarize. The provided text appears to be a list of article titles and publication dates, but no specific article content is provided.

site_title: Abandoned, unwanted and detained
summary: In Syria's Roj Camp, over 2,000 foreign women and children, including Sarah Ibrahim, are being held in a legal and political limbo after their husbands joined the Islamic State. The wives and children, from countries like the US, France, and Germany, are unwanted by their home countries due to fears of spreading radical ideology, and the Kurdish authorities do not want to detain them indefinitely. The international community is criticized for abandoning its responsibilities in dealing with the detainees, with many facing uncertain futures and potential trials upon return.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for last week's tanker and dry bulk market highlights key trends and events. Tanker rates eased for eastbound 270,000-ton cargoes, with China discharge rates at WS 50, South Korea at WS 47, and Japan at WS 48.5. US Gulf discharge rates eased around 3.5 points, with Exxon taking the 'Sea Ruby' at WS 18 and Vitol fixing an options cargo at WS 22. The Suezmax market remained steady, with Repsol taking the 'Front Thor' for 140,000 tons from Sidi Kerir to Spain at WS 69. The Aframax market struggled, with rates flat at around WS 80 for 80,000 tons and Black Sea paying between WS 80/82.5 level.

site_title: Starbucks back in hot water, 'disrespects' stutterer
summary: A Starbucks employee in Philadelphia was fired after mocking a customer with a stutter by writing "SSSAM" on the customer's drink label. The incident occurred on June 27 when the customer, Sam, gave his order while stuttering his name. Starbucks apologized and offered a $5 credit, but the customer's friend, Tan Lekwijit, took to Facebook to raise awareness about the incident, stating that the company had "missed the point" of treating people with speech impairments with respect. Starbucks subsequently announced the employee's termination.

site_title: No rationale for tough cooling measures: Redas
summary: The Real Estate Developers Association of Singapore (Redas) has expressed no rationale for the government's latest cooling measures in the private residential market, citing the property market as being in the early stages of recovery in line with economic fundamentals. The measures include a new 5% non-remittable additional buyer's stamp duty (ABSD) on developers buying residential properties for development. Redas asserts that the market should be allowed time to find its own course and that existing ABSD and Total Debt Servicing Ratio (TDSR) remain a restraining factor for buyers.

site_title: World Cup: Brazil fans frustrated by exit
summary: Brazil's World Cup hopes were dashed as they lost 2-1 to Belgium in the quarter-finals, sending them tumbling out of the tournament. The match, an end-to-end thriller, earned Belgium a semi-final spot against France. Brazilian fan Flavio Montez traveled over 12,500 km from Sao Paulo to watch the game, but it was not enough to secure a sixth World Cup title for Brazil, ending their five-time championship streak.

site_title: Pruitt was told to resign in call from White House: sources
summary: Scott Pruitt resigned as EPA chief after a call from White House Chief of Staff John Kelly, who delivered a message from President Donald Trump that it was time for Pruitt to leave. Pruitt was devastated by the news, but had allegedly been aware of his departure due to mounting allegations of unethical conduct and improper spending. The final straw was the alteration of public schedules to shield meetings from view, a potential violation of the Federal Records Act. Trump announced Pruitt's departure on Twitter, saying he had done an "outstanding job," despite earlier public criticism.

site_title: Cost of one of those 'expensive' US-South Korea military exercises? US$14m
summary: US President Donald Trump's decision to suspend a joint military exercise with South Korea, Freedom Guardian, is reportedly cost-effective at $14 million, rather than the estimated $700 million initially cited. The exercise was scrapped after Trump's surprise concession to North Korean leader Kim Jong Un during their Singapore summit. The US military argues that scrapping exercises does not save significant amounts of money, as troops still require training and certification. The decision has baffled allies, military officials, and lawmakers, with many questioning Trump's reasoning behind the move.

site_title: Poor start for Xiaomi - IPO draws bids at discount in grey market
summary: Xiaomi's initial public offering (IPO) drew bids at a discount in the grey market, with some investors offering US$2.63 per share, 11% below the issue price. The company raised US$3.1 billion, cutting its valuation to US$54 billion, and scrapped plans to sell shares on the mainland due to regulatory concerns. This follows a disappointing debut for other tech companies in Hong Kong, including Ping An Healthcare & Technology and Razer, which trade below their issue prices.

site_title: Slower growth in home loans expected from cooling measures
summary: Singapore's home loan growth is expected to slow down to 6-7% in 2018 due to the latest property cooling measures, which include reduced loan-to-value limits and increased buyer stamp duty. New property buyers will need to pay more cash and CPF funds for downpayments, posing a deterrent for some. Analysts predict a 1-2 percentage point reduction in bank loans growth, with some banks, such as United Overseas Bank, potentially seeing a larger impact.

site_title: STI slumps 2% on Friday on cooling measures, trade tariffs
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 2% on Friday, its lowest point this year, due to cooling measures introduced by the Singapore government and US-China trade tariffs. Property stocks led the decline, with CapitaLand and Oxley Holdings falling 5.98% and 15.85%, respectively. The US and China retaliated against each other with duties, with the US imposing tariffs on $34 billion worth of Chinese goods. Despite this, analysts see resilience in external demand for China and potential for shipment re-routing through other countries.

site_title: Temporary slide in US mortgage rates could give new hope to first-time home buyers
summary: US mortgage rates declined to 4.52% for a 30-year fixed rate, offering temporary hope to first-time home buyers amid soaring home prices and stagnant wages. The rate decrease could provide room for further declines, with mortgage applications showing a slight decrease. Experts, including Freddie Mac's Sam Khater and the National Association of Realtors' Lawrence Yun, attribute the decline to the mortgage spread returning to normal levels, giving buyers more room to grow in the housing market.

site_title: New York jury convicts two men for trading on hacked press releases
summary: A federal jury in Brooklyn convicted two men, Vitaly Korchevsky and Vladislav Khalupsky, for their roles in an international scheme to trade on hacked corporate press releases. The defendants, a former Morgan Stanley vice president and a Ukrainian hacker, were found guilty on two securities fraud and three conspiracy counts. They were among 10 people criminally charged in Brooklyn and New Jersey over a hacking scheme to game financial markets, with authorities calling it the largest known hacking scheme to impact financial markets.

site_title: May wins support from divided UK government on Brexit plan
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May secured a cabinet agreement on her Brexit plan, which includes a "free trade area for goods" with the EU and maintaining close trade ties. The proposal, aimed at spurring stalled Brexit talks, has won support from most vocal Brexit campaigners in the cabinet. However, EU negotiators may still be skeptical, and critics have accused May of "cherry-picking" the best bits of the EU. The agreement now needs to be assessed by Brussels, and the UK has nine months to present a detailed vision for future ties before its departure from the EU.

site_title: In farewell to US shoppers, Toys 'R' Us urges 'Play on!'
summary: Toys "R" Us stores across the US closed on Friday, marking the end of the iconic toy retailer. The company posted a farewell message on its website, thanking customers for their support and urging them to "Play on!" The message, which included a reference to the company's famous jingle, expressed gratitude to customers who had shared their childhood memories and experiences with the brand. The closure marks the end of an era for the beloved toy retailer.

site_title: US dollar slumps after US nonfarm payrolls data, tariffs kick in
summary: The US dollar fell to three-week lows after the release of June nonfarm payrolls data, which showed 213,000 jobs created, exceeding expectations. However, wage growth rose less than forecast, and the unemployment rate increased to 4.0%, dampening expectations of a fourth interest rate hike this year. The dollar's decline was partly muted by investors awaiting the jobs report, as the US and China imposed tariffs on each other's imports. The dollar's drop was also influenced by the weaker-than-expected inflation gauge.

site_title: China retaliates as US tariffs kick in; Trump vows another round of duties
summary: The US imposed tariffs on $34 billion in Chinese goods, prompting China's immediate retaliation. This marks the start of a commercial battle that could impact global markets and business. Analysts fear the trade tensions could slow China's GDP growth, adding pressure on policymakers. The US has vowed to impose another round of duties, with Trump indicating further action is likely. The retaliatory measures are part of a three-month escalation of rhetoric between the two nations.

images.alt_text: Some veteran China observers predict Beijing's tactics may go beyond tariffs to include arbitrary quarantines and a costly uptick in customs inspections.

site_title: Maybank gives Hyflux till Oct 15 to find Tuaspring buyer
summary: Maybank has agreed to give Hyflux until October 15 to find a buyer for the Tuaspring integrated water and power plant, with conditions including obtaining approvals and shareholder approval by December 11 and February 4, 2019, respectively. Maybank will refrain from enforcement proceedings and become more involved in the divestment process if Hyflux meets the deadlines. The plant's book value is S$1.3 billion, and any surplus from the sale can be used to settle Hyflux's other debt.

site_title: Australian fund loads up on Chinese shares
summary: UniSuper, an Australian fund, has increased its investment in Chinese shares, citing the sell-off as "overdone" due to trade war fears and yuan weakness. The fund's chief investment officer believes the market has corrected too much and sees opportunities for growth. UniSuper has hired BlackRock to manage its China equity book, while the rest will be handled by its in-house team. The fund's balanced investment option has returned 10.4% for the year to June, with the Shanghai Composite Index down 20% from its January high.

site_title: En bloc fever set to be tamed, big sites at greatest risk: analysts
summary: Singapore's en bloc fever is expected to slow down due to property cooling measures, which will increase residential land acquisition costs, higher buyer's stamp duty, and lower loan-to-value limits. The measures will clip prices developers are willing to pay for land, and home buying demand will decrease. The impact will vary depending on the site's location, intended market, and price expectations. While the measures won't completely halt the en bloc cycle, they will drastically slow it down.

site_title: Cosco Shipping selling HK$7.4b worth of OOIL shares to restore public float
summary: Cosco Shipping Holdings Co Ltd plans to sell HK$7.43 billion worth of Orient Overseas International Ltd (OOIL) shares to CK Hutchison Holdings Ltd and others to restore the required public float of OOIL. The sale, which will take place if the public float falls below 25%, will see CK Hutchison acquire 4.99%, State Development & Investment Corp Ltd acquire 2.38%, and Silk Road Fund acquire 7.73% of OOIL's issued share capital. The proceeds will be used to replenish working capital, with Cosco Shipping aiming to restore the public float after receiving a decision from China's anti-monopoly watchdog.

site_title: Mega IPOs are spawning Asian billionaires at a torrid pace
summary: Mega IPOs in Asia are rapidly creating new billionaires, with 27 Asian billionaires emerging this year, many through initial public offerings in Hong Kong and Shenzhen. Companies like Meituan Dianping and Xiaomi Corp are expected to fuel this trend, but market volatility and global trade tensions may pose challenges, with some analysts warning of valuation bubbles in Chinese technology companies. The success of these IPOs will be crucial in determining whether the torrid pace of wealth creation can continue.

site_title: Watch for market signals amid trade war jitters
summary: The US market has paused amid ongoing trade war tensions, with investors waiting for signals to act. The Dow has formed a trading band, with a lower edge near 23,300 and an upper edge near 25,400. A strong rebound above 25,400 would confirm the downtrend, while a move below 23,300 would indicate the market is developing a consolidation behavior. Investors are watching for signs of consolidation, including a pause and rebound from the 2,650 level, reduced volatility, and compression in moving averages, before making moves.

site_title: Wage gains slow, unemployment up from 18-year low
summary: US hiring topped forecasts in June, with payrolls rising 213,000, while unemployment increased to 4% from 3.8% and wage gains slowed to 2.7% from a year earlier. The labour market still absorbs spare capacity, with the employment-population ratio unchanged at 60.4%. A steady pace of hiring and rising wages are supporting consumer spending, but the intensifying trade war and shrinking qualified workers may slow employment gains.

site_title: Over 1,000 condo units sold in one night as buyers race the clock
summary: Over 1,000 condo units were sold in one night in Singapore as developers brought forward property launches and lowered prices to meet the July 6 deadline for cooling measures. The sales were driven by strong liquidity and pent-up demand, with average prices ranging from S$1,200 to S$1,800 per square foot. The measures are expected to cool the market, with sales volume predicted to fall 15-20% and prices remaining steady. Developers may delay launches to reassess pricing strategies, but prices are unlikely to be reduced due to committed land costs.

images.alt_text: In just one night, over a thousand units were sold in three condominium projects, which were launched in knee-jerk reaction to the announced changes to the additional buyer's stamp duty (ABSD) and loan-to-value (LTV) limits.

site_title: 'Sticky' money investors return to once-shunned oil sector
summary: Institutional investors are returning to the oil sector, driven by stronger returns, changes in management incentives, and higher forward oil prices. Energy companies have seen a 23% increase in US benchmark crude this year, making them the third-best performer in the S&P 500 index. However, specialized funds are cautious about Permian Basin explorers due to pipeline bottlenecks, and investors are looking for signs of delayed well completions and idling rigs. Analysts predict that oil prices could reach $90 or higher in the next two years, driven by lower upstream investment and growing demand.

site_title: Take control of your card
summary: Ondot, a Santa Clara-based startup, has developed CardControl, a solution allowing cardholders to control their credit cards' usage, reducing the risk of credit card fraud. The platform provides features such as on/off, location, merchant categories, transaction types, and spending cap, enabling cardholders to manage their cards remotely. With over 3,000 customers, including major banks like HSBC and Citi, Ondot's technology is integrated into mobile banking apps, providing a convenient and secure way for cardholders to monitor and control their cards.

site_title: Prepping your business for an IPO
summary: A company considering an initial public offering (IPO) should weigh factors such as raising funds, spreading risk, and generating publicity. Choosing a suitable adviser, such as an experienced merchant bank, is crucial. Managing the transition from private to public company requires a change of mindset, including providing transparent information and handling shareholder expectations. Entrepreneurs should balance their investors' demands with their own vision for growth, ensuring that forecasting and decision-making are reasonable and explainable.

site_title: Evergrande-backed E-House attracts Alibaba to US$727m IPO
summary: Enterprise Holdings Ltd, backed by China Evergrande Group, China Vanke Co and Country Garden Holdings Co, is seeking US$727 million in a Hong Kong IPO. Alibaba Group Holding Ltd has agreed to buy US$50 million of shares as a cornerstone investor. The company, which was previously listed in New York, aims to raise funds amid a slump in Hong Kong's equity market. Trading is expected to start on July 20, adding to this year's US$12.3 billion in Hong Kong first-time share sales.

site_title: DBS gives out S$500 hongbao each to 26,000 staff to mark 50th birthday
summary: DBS, Singapore's largest listed company, is celebrating its 50th anniversary by giving a S$500 hongbao to its 26,000 employees. This comes after the bank previously handed out a gold-plated jewellery gift and a bumper payout to shareholders, with a one-time special dividend of S$0.50 per share. DBS CEO Piyush Gupta stated that the jubilee celebrations aim to give back to stakeholders, recognizing the bank's success relies on their support.

site_title: Singapore-listed tech stocks whacked by US-China trade spat
summary: Singapore-listed tech stocks have been negatively impacted by the US-China trade spat, with the FTSE ST Technology Index down nearly 12% year-to-date. Top tech stocks, including Venture Corp and UMS Holdings, have seen significant declines, with some down 60% from their recent highs. Analysts warn that companies with high exposure to manufacturing in China could feel the most pain if the trade war escalates, and global equity markets have suffered a rout as a result of the trade war woes.

site_title: 4 principles for better decision-making
summary: Nobel laureate Daniel Kahneman emphasized that studying only success stories leads to the wrong lesson, as failure is common. He identified four principles for better decision-making: using algorithms to make predictions, training individuals to simulate algorithmic thinking, framing decisions in a broad context, and assessing clients' risk aversion to minimize regret. Kahneman also highlighted the importance of recognizing noise, bias, and overconfidence in decision-making, and the need for experts to develop rules and feedback in testable domains.

site_title: Single parking space in land-starved Hong Kong sells for HK$6m
summary: A single luxury parking space in Hong Kong's Ho Man Tin district sold for a record HK$6 million, more than sixfold the average price of HK$2.25 million since 2006. The city's housing market remains the world's least affordable, with home prices increasing 3.4 times over the same period. The shortage of parking spaces is attributed to developers prioritizing apartment construction, with the number of parking spots growing only 9.5% between 2006 and 2016, despite a 49% surge in the private car population.

site_title: InnVest Hotels eyes US assets after buying the Trump Toronto
