summary: Japan Display Inc., the world's largest car display panel supplier, is optimistic about boosting sales due to the shift to electric vehicles, which will drive demand for fully digital dashboard screens. The company forecasts a 40% sales growth by March 2020, driven by increasing adoption in high-end cars and expansion into the US, Japan, and China markets. This shift is expected to provide higher margins for display suppliers, making them an attractive business opportunity.

site_title: Latest property cooling measures: en bloc sales will bear the brunt
summary: Singapore's latest property cooling measures aim to dampen the collective sales market, where en bloc sales have been a lucrative option for condominium owners. The measures follow a surge in en bloc sales last year, which depleted developers' land banks and led to higher selling prices for new projects. Critics argue that en bloc sales widen the wealth gap and could exacerbate social inequality, while proponents say they recycle land and spur urban rejuvenation. The government may consider prescribing minimum sinking fund contributions for condo management corporations to maintain economic longevity.

site_title: Falken Azenis FK510: Leaning on Liverpool FC
summary: Falken Tire, a Japanese brand, partners with Stamford Tyres to launch the Azenis FK510 in Singapore, a new flagship product designed to compete with high-performance tyres. The product is named after Liverpool FC captain Jordan Henderson, and Falken hopes his endorsement will help the brand gain recognition in the market. The Azenis FK510 is positioned to rival tyres from brands like Pirelli and Goodyear, catering to driving enthusiasts.

site_title: Mahathir in talks to visit China after putting projects on ice
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad is in talks to visit China in mid-August after Kuala Lumpur suspended China-backed projects worth over $20 billion. Mahathir is reviewing major projects signed by the former government, citing financial unsoundness. The East Coast Railway Link and two pipeline projects were halted, with China's success in these projects critical to maintaining relations. Mahathir aims to renegotiate terms and avoid debt to China, despite being friendly towards the country.

site_title: SingPost, US-based bike company in logistics and warehousing tie-up
summary: SingPost has partnered with US-based bike company Specialized Bicycle Components for a three-year logistics and warehousing contract. Specialized will shift its regional warehousing operations from Hong Kong to Tampines Logistics Park in Singapore, with SingPost handling warehousing, sea freight, and last-mile deliveries. The partnership aims to improve access to Specialized bicycles and products in the region, utilizing SingPost's inventory management system and good warehousing practices.

site_title: BMW X4 review: From runway to highway
summary: The article reviews the new BMW X4, highlighting that its strongest feature goes beyond its appearance. The car is marketed as a trendsetter, but its performance and features are also noteworthy. The review emphasizes that while the X4's looks may be the primary reason for some buyers, its capabilities and features are also worth considering. The article does not provide further details on the car's specifications or test results.

site_title: Mukesh Ambani, India's richest man goes on a 289b rupee shopping spree
summary: Mukesh Ambani, India's richest man, has embarked on a 289 billion rupee shopping spree with Reliance Industries Ltd, the company he helms. Over the past 12 months, the company has struck at least 12 deals, focusing on expanding its consumer offerings. Ten of these deals are related to his consumer business, with estimated costs of around $5.7 billion.

images.alt_text: Mukesh Ambani, chairman and MD of Reliance Industries, posing with his wife Nita Ambani before addressing the company's annual general meeting in Mumbai on Thursday.

site_title: Sodexo shares rise as Q3 sales beat expectations
summary: Sodexo, a French catering company, reported beating Q3 sales expectations with a 7% share price increase, despite a slowdown in sales growth to 1.4% from 1.7% in the first half. CEO Denis Machuel reaffirmed the company's full-year guidance, citing progress in cost-cutting measures and improving productivity in North America. The company's shares rose 6.9% to lead the CAC-40 index.

site_title: At The Heart Of Chinatown
summary: A site-specific theatre performance, Chinatown Crossings, takes audiences on a 2.5-hour journey through Singapore's Chinatown, exploring its history and cultural richness. The show delves into the lives of three characters, from a girl determined to succeed despite social disadvantages to a ma jie from Guangdong who helps raise two orphaned children. With authentic sights, evocative performances, and a narrative that weaves together folkloric romances and mythologies, the show offers a unique perspective on the multiracial district, running until August 18.

site_title: Xiaomi call warrants to list on SGX on July 9
summary: Xiaomi has announced that its call warrants will list on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) on July 9. The warrants will be traded in Singapore dollars and track the movement of Xiaomi shares in Hong Kong. They will follow the trading hours of the Hong Kong Stock Exchange, with a break between 12pm and 1pm. This move is part of Xiaomi's initial public offering (IPO) on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange.

site_title: Jaguar I-Pace review: Better than a Tesla?
summary: The Jaguar I-Pace, an electric SUV, has been praised for its sporty, spacious, and shapely design, as well as its impressive performance. It accelerates to 100km/h in 4.8 seconds and features a quiet, smooth ride with excellent body control. The I-Pace's electric drivetrain provides a 50/50 front/rear weight distribution, allowing for effortless handling. With a range of up to 480km, it's suitable for daily driving, and its low maintenance costs make it an attractive option. The I-Pace's unique features, such as its spacious cabin and ample boot space, make it a standout in its class, potentially appealing to both SUV and sports car buyers.

site_title: Sassy Girl
summary: Rebekah Sangeetha Dorai stars in the one-woman performance "Building A Character" at the Singapore Theatre Festival, exploring her struggles as a dark-skinned actress in a predominantly fair-skinned industry. Written by Ruth Tang and directed by Mei Ann Teo, the play delves into the challenges faced by Dorai in finding roles and staying strong in the face of discrimination. The performance runs until July 8.

images.alt_text: Rebekah Sangeetha Dorai in "Building A Character".

site_title: Funds, brokers still have faith in China's A-shares
summary: China's A-shares remain a popular investment choice for funds and brokers despite the looming US tariffs. Investment professionals cite economic reforms, quality tech companies, and the Belt and Road Initiative as reasons for their optimism. Despite a sell-off in June, A-shares have seen a higher trading volume than Hong Kong-listed H-shares. Many firms, including Fidelity, Principal, and Hermes, expect long-term growth and are diversifying their portfolios to include A-shares. Professional investors believe the inclusion of A-shares into MSCI indices will lead to increased liquidity and better corporate governance.

site_title: Paradise found
summary: Mauritius is a tropical island nation known for its stunning beaches, coral reefs, and diverse marine life. Visitors can enjoy luxury beach resorts, private island day trips, and snorkelling or scuba diving excursions. The island also offers beyond-beach attractions, including the Black River Gorges National Park, Seven Coloured Earths, and a rum distillery. In the capital city of Port Louis, visitors can explore the city's diverse culture, historical buildings, and markets, such as the Central Market and museums like the Blue Penny Museum. With its unique blend of luxury and natural beauty, Mauritius is an ideal destination for beach lovers and adventure seekers.

site_title: Face-Lift
summary: Montblanc has introduced two new complication watches, the Heritage Chronometrie Perpetual Calendar Sapphire and the Heritage Chronometrie Exo Tourbillon Slim, with modern and refined designs. The watches feature new 40mm cases with sleek horns, sapphire crystal dials, and dark-blue straps. The Perpetual Calendar Sapphire showcases a smoked sapphire dial with a realistic moon phase, while the Exo Tourbillon Slim features a skeletonised design with a dazzle-camouflage pattern. Both watches are certified by the Montblanc Laboratory Test 500 for accuracy and reliability.

site_title: India shows how to make villains of its heroes
summary: India's stock-market regulator has asked custodians to list "high-risk" countries, including China, Indonesia, and the Philippines, for know-your-customer checks on investments with Indian beneficial owners. The move is intended to curb money laundering, but it has raised concerns among fund managers, who fear it will limit their ability to invest in India. The measures have already led to a $6.1 billion pullback in bond markets and $740 million out of equity markets, potentially exacerbating the rupee's decline.

site_title: A museum with nothing - and everything
summary: The MORI Building Digital Art Museum in Tokyo is the world's first all-digital museum, featuring immersive installations that react to movement and touch. The exhibit space, 100,000 square feet, is filled with 50 kaleidoscopic installations triggered by motion sensors and projected onto every surface. Artworks include a "Forest of Lamps" that spreads light and a "Tea House" where tea is poured into a cup, and a flower blooms. Visitors can interact with the art, such as drawing marine animals and catching them, and can enjoy the experience in their own way, blurring the boundaries between visitors.

site_title: Challenger Technologies secures 2 new leases in Singapore
summary: Challenger Technologies secured two new leases in Singapore, one at a pre-owned IT store in JCube and the other at Musica Boutique in Ion Orchard. The leases will commence operations in the third and fourth quarters of 2018, respectively, as part of the company's plans to focus on retail operations.

site_title: Euro near 3-week highs on strong German data
summary: The euro reached near three-week highs on Thursday due to strong German industrial orders and hopes of a softening US trade stance towards European carmakers. German industrial orders jumped in May, and a reported US threat to suspend tariffs on EU cars if duties on US cars are lifted boosted euro sentiment. The euro was trading around US$1.16905, up 0.3% on the day, but still below its three-year highs. Markets await the European Central Bank's interest rate decision and US payrolls data for further direction.

site_title: How to get ahead in your job when you don't know anyone
summary: A study by NUS Business School and the University of Minnesota's Carlson School of Management found that new recruits with limited or no managerial connections, but strong ties with co-workers and favourable self-evaluations, are equally successful in adjusting to their new roles as those with connections to senior managers. This challenges the traditional thinking that senior-level connections are essential for success in a new job, and suggests that a flexible and engaging environment that encourages networking with co-workers and self-evaluation can help newcomers succeed.

images.alt_text: Nervous new recruits should think about how they can channel their energy into relationships with co-workers who can help them through their learning curve.

site_title: America's glory days are over
summary: US President Donald Trump's actions have sparked criticism, with some comparing him to the impulsive and deranged monarch Henry VIII. Trump's statements on Harley-Davidson's decision to move operations to EU-free zones have been deemed nonsensical and contemptuous of the rule of law. The article concludes that Trump is incapable of executing his duties in good faith, and that the US House and Senate have failed to take action to impeach him. The article also notes that the US is facing significant challenges, including low voter turnout and gerrymandering, which could impact the midterm elections and the country's democratic future.

site_title: Ryanair cabin crew in four European countries plan to strike
summary: Ryanair cabin crew in four European countries - Spain, Portugal, Italy, and Belgium - plan to hold coordinated strikes, escalating industrial action against the low-cost carrier. The strikes, which will be announced once Italian authorities approve, come after cabin crew published a list of 34 demands, including a fair living wage and improved sick pay. Ryanair has already recognized trade unions in some countries, but has struggled to reach agreement on terms. The cabin crew, representing 80% of Ryanair's 86 bases, are seeking better working conditions and compensation.

site_title: Slew of leadership changes at China Bearing (Singapore)
summary: China Bearing (Singapore) announced leadership changes following its acquisition of FE Resources. Hong Kah Ing, a 64.3% shareholder, was named executive director and CEO of China Bearing (Singapore). He previously held director positions at FE Resources and Far East Mining, where he also owns a 75.4% stake. The changes come after the completion of the acquisition, which was finalized in 2016.

site_title: Year-long effort to replace Libor in bonds may reward banks
summary: A year after its launch, a bond tied to the UK's replacement for Libor, the Sonia benchmark, has shown promising results, with the European Investment Bank's sale of Sonia-linked notes raising £1 billion. The deal's success has encouraged banks to explore the use of Sonia-linked notes for a broader client base, potentially boosting revenue in fixed income markets. Regulators, including the Bank of England, are championing the Sonia benchmark as a more reliable alternative to Libor, which is set to be phased out in 2021.

site_title: China Sun Bio-Chem to delist
summary: China Sun Bio-Chem Technology Group Company, a Singapore-listed manufacturer of corn starch, has applied to be delisted from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) due to its "hopelessly insolvent" financial situation. The company, which has been listed since 2004, has been incurring substantial losses since 2011 and lacks viable assets or funds to continue operations. The director, Cosimo Borrelli, stated that there is no prospect of a corporate rescue or restructuring, and the company's board has submitted a delisting application to the SGX, awaiting approval.

site_title: Lessons in parenting - from the World Cup
summary: A mother who doesn't understand soccer found a new appreciation for the World Cup by allowing her kids to watch matches with her while her husband covers the tournament. She believes the World Cup promotes unity and positivity, encouraging kids to identify with multiple countries and adopt a cosmopolitan mindset. The tournament also provides a safe escape from nationalism and xenophobia, fostering a sense of community and togetherness.

images.alt_text: French fans watching a match in Paris. One of the great joys of the World Cup is the feeling that you're falling into sync with other people. That's even true in France, where keeping your distance is a national sport.

site_title: Singapore shares close up 0.4% ahead of July 6 tariff deadline
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.4% ahead of a July 6 tariff deadline, where the US is set to impose tariffs on $34 billion in Chinese imports. China is expected to retaliate with its own tariffs, while US countermeasures are a possibility. The Straits Times Index closed at 3,256.71, with losers edging out gainers 200 to 175. The rally comes despite uncertainty surrounding US trade policies and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: India's Reliance unveils fibre broadband service in 1,100 cities
summary: Reliance Industries, led by chairman Mukesh Ambani, has unveiled a fibre broadband system to connect 1,100 cities in India, targeting 50 million homes. The service, JioGigaFiber, will be launched on August 15, Independence Day. Smart home solutions, such as real-time surveillance and security, will ride on the fibre network. Reliance also announced a new low-cost phone, JioPhone2, priced at 2,999 Indian rupees, and has 215 million subscribers for its telecoms venture Jio, which covers 99% of the country.

site_title: Dinner In Wonderland
summary: That CD Shop, a homegrown music store, has opened its second restaurant, Wonderland Savour, at Wisma Atria. The restaurant features a whimsical Alice in Wonderland theme and offers a menu with pasta dishes, hearty mains, and signature pastries. Next door, music fans can pick up a CD and vinyl at The CD Shop. This marks the first time a music store has ventured into the restaurant scene.

site_title: US 'opening fire' on world with tariff threats, China says
summary: The US is set to impose tariffs on $34 billion of Chinese imports, sparking a warning from China that it will retaliate immediately. China's Commerce Ministry spokesman Gao Feng described the US move as "opening fire" on the world, threatening global supply chains and international trade. China will impose tariffs on US goods, targeting top US exports such as soybeans, sorghum, and cotton. The move has sparked concerns of a full-blown trade war, with China's GDP growth expected to slow.

images.alt_text: The United States is "opening fire" on the world with its threatened tariffs, China warned on Thursday, saying no one wants a trade war, but that it would respond the instant US measures go into effect.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher on hopes of trade concessions
summary: Wall Street opened higher on Thursday, driven by hopes of trade concessions from Washington. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.46%, the S&P 500 gained 0.40%, and the Nasdaq Composite increased 0.64%. The gains were attributed to easing tensions with Europe, offsetting concerns about US-China trade.

site_title: Aligoté wines: Once dissed, now trendy
summary: A French white wine, aligoté, has been unfairly dismissed for decades due to its conventional perception as minor and inconsequential. However, recent explorations have revealed that aligoté can produce excellent, great, and even great everyday wines. Producers like Sylvain Pataille and Domaine Ponsot have successfully made single-vineyard aligotés from excellent sites, showcasing its potential. The article concludes that aligoté, like any other wine, can be good or bad, and it's essential to keep an open mind and try different examples to discover its true value.

images.alt_text: Not surprisingly, the best growers and producers in Burgundy seem to make the best aligotés.

site_title: Musical Adventure
summary: Fauxe, a Malaysian electronic music producer, has released his new album "Ikhlas" which blends traditional Malaysian music with modern hip hop elements. The 16-track album, inspired by his experiences living in Kuala Lumpur, samples Tamil and Hawaiian-Malay music. With its unique sound and globalized musical style, the album is a blast from start to end, making it a must-listen for fans of electronic music. Available for streaming on SoundCloud and purchase on Bandcamp.

site_title: US: Stocks rise, bonds fall as tariffs, jobs data loom
summary: US stocks rose on the first trading day after a holiday break, driven by technology shares and European automakers. The dollar fell, and bonds remained stable despite concerns over tariffs and the upcoming jobs report. Investors are preparing for the implementation of fresh tariffs between the US and China, as well as the release of Federal Reserve minutes. The Nasdaq index climbed over 1%, while Asian shares sank to a nine-month low due to trade fears.

site_title: Property curbs: Ahead of the curve but too much?
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore has introduced tightened cooling measures to curb the rapid rise in private home prices. Starting July 6, the additional buyer's stamp duty (ABSD) will be raised by 5 percentage points for second and subsequent properties, and 10 percentage points for any residential property. Loan-to-value (LTV) limits will also be tightened by 5 percentage points for housing loans. The measures aim to slow down the market, but critics argue that they may be too extreme, raising concerns about the impact on the market's equilibrium.

site_title: No small change in BT Weekend
summary: A recent article in The Business Times Weekend explores innovative financing and impact investing for development in remote Asia. Private capital funds, humanitarian organizations, and banks are finding new ways to address critical needs in these areas. Meanwhile, a Singaporean scientist is working towards sending a person to space, sharing his vision in an interview. The article highlights various initiatives and projects that aim to drive positive change and financial literacy, particularly for women, in the region.

site_title: Making returns on knowledge
summary: The International Monetary Fund's World Economic Outlook highlights how globalisation has facilitated the spread of technology and knowledge across borders, contributing to rising productivity levels in advanced and emerging economies. Foreign knowledge accounted for 0.7 percentage point of labour productivity growth in emerging market economies from 2004 to 2014. Despite a slowdown in frontier economies, international sources of technological innovation are changing, with countries like China and South Korea joining traditional leaders in sectors like electrical equipment and machinery. The report suggests that globalisation reinforces incentives to innovate and adopt technologies from abroad, but solutions must be found to market failures that generate disincentives to the accumulation of knowledge.

site_title: Trump's scandal-hit environment chief resigns
summary: US President Donald Trump announced the resignation of his environment chief, Scott Pruitt, amid growing scandals over his spending and conduct in office. Pruitt, who had been tasked with dismantling Barack Obama's green legacy, faced multiple investigations and accusations of enriching his family's lifestyle at the expense of federal law. The president accepted Pruitt's resignation and appointed Andrew Wheeler, his deputy, as acting head of the Environmental Protection Agency.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 2.20 points to 1,690.65 on Thursday, driven by a volume of 2.17 billion lots worth RM1.45 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 452 to 405.

site_title: JPMorgan triggers EU talent transfer as 'dozens' prepare for Brexit move
summary: JPMorgan has asked around 50 UK employees to relocate to continental Europe by early 2019, as part of plans to protect its business post-Brexit. The move comes as the bank prepares for Britain's EU exit and amid concerns of a "hard Brexit" that could cause major disruption to global banks. JPMorgan expects to migrate or add around 300 EU-based roles by March 2019, with a focus on Paris, Madrid, and Milan. The bank aims to minimize disruption for its clients and employees, but the exact number of EU staff needed remains uncertain due to ongoing negotiations with Brussels.

site_title: A Brand New Bottega Veneta
summary: Bottega Veneta's creative director Tomas Maier has stepped down after 17 years, handing the baton to 32-year-old designer Daniel Lee. Lee, who previously worked at Céline, Balenciaga, and Donna Karan, takes over the luxury brand's creative direction, marking a new chapter for Kering's strategy of promoting young designers. Maier's departure comes amid a shift in luxury consumers' preferences, with CEO François-Henri Pinault stating that the brand needs a fresh vision to appeal to millennials. Lee is tasked with retaining the brand's existing clientele while attracting a younger audience.

site_title: Mapletree Logistics in S$778m warehouse deal with HNA subsidiary
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust has acquired five modern warehouses in Singapore from CWT International, a subsidiary of debt-strapped Chinese conglomerate HNA Group, for approximately S$778.3 million. The acquisition strengthens Mapletree's presence in Singapore and increases its total gross floor area to over 20 million square feet. The deal is expected to generate an initial net property income yield of approximately 6.2% and is subject to approvals from JTC and CWT International shareholders.

images.alt_text: Two of the properties are at Tanjong Penjuru, one is at Toh Guan Road East and the other two are at Fishery Port Road and Pandan Avenue respectively.

site_title: Famous Treasure serves up familiar gems
summary: Famous Treasure, a new zi char restaurant in Singapore, has opened its doors in Capitol Piazza, serving familiar yet delicious Chinese dishes. The restaurant, which originated from Sembawang's Famous Kitchen, offers a mix of seafood-centric menu and various Chinese cooking styles. Despite some initial service hiccups, the restaurant's dishes, such as salted egg yolk fish skin crisps, soy-braised duck meat, and squid stir-fry, showcase the chef's skills. The restaurant's target is home-style cooking with no ambitions to be upscale, making it a good option for those seeking decent prices and good quality zi char cooking. Rating: 7/10.

site_title: Newcomers Set To Impress
summary: Two landscape designers, Tom Massey and Myles Baldwin, will showcase their work at the Singapore Garden Festival. Tom Massey, a 32-year-old British designer, has gained recognition for his modern designs and won a Silver-Gilt Medal at the RHS Chelsea Flower Show. His show garden will feature a Fantasy Garden with diverse tropical vegetation. Myles Baldwin, 39, has created significant gardens in Australia and is participating in the Landscape Garden category with a Victorian-inspired and contemporary landscape. Salad Dressing, a firm led by Chang Huai-Yan, will also participate with a unique design approach focused on rainforest biodiversity.

site_title: Malaysia investigates China-backed project links with 1MDB - official
summary: Malaysia is investigating whether a Chinese state-owned bank's $2.3 billion loan for pipeline projects was used to help repay debts of the scandal-ridden 1MDB state fund. The projects, signed by former Malaysian premier Najib Razak's administration, were meant to build two pipelines, but work has been suspended pending high-level talks with China to renegotiate terms. The new Malaysian government, led by Mahathir Mohamad, is reviewing major projects agreed by the Najib administration and seeking Chinese government cooperation with the investigation.

images.alt_text: Malaysia is investigating whether part of a loan from a Chinese state-owned bank for projects worth US$2.3 billion was used to help repay dues of a scandal-ridden state fund, a finance ministry official told Reuters.

site_title: Fresh property cooling measures spark last-minute buying frenzy
summary: The Singapore government has introduced fresh property cooling measures, raising the Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD) rates for second properties and beyond. For Singaporeans and PRs, the rate increases by 5 percentage points to 5%, while foreigners and entities face a 20% and 25% ABSD, respectively. Loan-to-Value (LTV) limits will also be tightened by 5 percentage points for all housing loans. The changes, effective July 6, aim to maintain a stable and sustainable property market, but analysts predict a 30-40% fall in sales and potential price drops to levels seen in the fourth quarter last year.

site_title: US private payrolls miss expectations; weekly jobless claims up
summary: US private payrolls rose 177,000 in June, below market expectations, while initial jobless claims increased 3,000 to 231,000, exceeding forecasts. The jobless rate remains low at 3.8%, and economists expect 195,000 jobs to be added in June, according to a Reuters survey. The slowdown in hiring may reflect difficulties in finding qualified workers, with a record 6.7 million unfilled jobs.

site_title: China Sun Bio-Chem applies for delisting from SGX
summary: China Sun Bio-Chem Technology Group Company, a Singapore-listed firm, has applied for delisting from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) due to its "hopelessly insolvent" financial state. The company, which manufactures corn starch and related products, has incurred substantial losses since its former provisional liquidators were discharged in 2011. Director Cosimo Borrelli stated that the company has no viable assets, limited funds, and no prospect of a corporate rescue or restructuring. The board has led the company to apply for delisting, awaiting SGX's approval.

site_title: China's top EV maker starts battery-swap service to lure users
summary: China's top electric vehicle maker, ELECTRIC Vehicle Co, has launched a battery-swap service for its EV300 compact car, aiming to reduce range anxiety and compete with rivals. The service will allow customers to change batteries as often as they want for a monthly fee of 432 yuan (S$16,368). This move is seen as a strategic move to increase customer loyalty and retention, ahead of the company's planned stock market listing. The battery-swap service will be available in the outskirts of Beijing and may expand to other locations in the future.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end lower ahead of US-China tariffs
summary: Hong Kong shares fell Thursday as investors awaited US-China tariffs, which are expected to be announced soon. The Hang Seng Index dropped 0.21% to 28,182.09, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined. The decline was attributed to uncertainty surrounding the tariffs, which could impact global trade and markets.

site_title: EU Parliament rejects copyright law in win for US tech giants
summary: The European Parliament rejected a highly controversial EU copyright law proposal, allowing US tech giants such as Google and Facebook to avoid paying royalties. The draft law aimed to ensure creators of creative content are paid fairly, but opponents argued it would stifle internet freedom and censor memes. The vote, with 318 in favor and 278 against, will be revisited in September. Key lawmakers, including Paul McCartney and Greens MEP Pascal Durand, expressed disappointment and called for a more balanced text.

site_title: Carney warns about trade war fallout on global growth
summary: Bank of England governor Mark Carney warns that a global trade war may be slowing world economic growth, citing tentative signs of reduced global export orders and manufacturing output. A 10-percentage point rise in US tariffs could erase 2.5% from US output and 1% from global economic output. Carney argues that protectionism affects the real economy through reduced trade flows, disrupted supply chains, and lower business and consumer confidence. The US is set to begin enforcing tariffs on $34 billion in Chinese imports, raising concerns about the potential for further escalation.

images.alt_text: A global trade war at risk of escalating may already be slowing world economic growth, Bank of England governor Mark Carney warned in a speech on Thursday.

site_title: Mahathir to visit China after putting US$20b of projects on ice - sources
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad is set to visit China in mid-August after suspending China-backed projects worth over $20 billion. Mahathir has reviewed major projects signed by the previous government, citing financial concerns. The trip comes amid a corruption investigation into former Prime Minister Najib Razak, who courted billions of dollars in Chinese investment through the Belt and Road Initiative. Mahathir has vowed to renegotiate terms for Chinese projects, signaling a shift in Malaysia's foreign investment strategy.

site_title: Govt raises ABSD, tightens LTV limits to cool Singapore property market
summary: The Singapore government has raised the additional buyer's stamp duty (ABSD) and tightened loan-to-value (LTV) limits on residential property purchases to cool the market. ABSD rates for non-citizens and non-permanent residents will increase by 5-10 percentage points, while rates for first-time buyers remain unchanged. The move aims to prevent prices from running ahead of economic fundamentals and stabilize the market. The changes will take effect immediately, with the aim of moderating price growth and encouraging sustainable property development.

site_title: Magnus Energy to place 2.53b new shares to raise S$2.28m
summary: MAGNUS Energy is issuing 2.53 billion new shares at 0.09 Singapore cents apiece to four private investors, Lee Thiam Seng, Ong Boon Tiong Daniel, Low Chin Yen, and Liu Bin, to raise S$2.28 million in cash. The issue price represents a 10% discount to the volume-weighted average price of S$0.001.

site_title: China warns US "opening fire" on world with tariff threats
summary: China warned the US that imposing tariffs would "open fire" on the world, with Chinese customs immediately implementing retaliatory tariffs on US goods. The US has threatened tariffs on $450 billion in Chinese goods, prompting China to vow it will not "fire the first shot." China's Commerce Ministry said US tariffs would harm international supply chains and companies worldwide, including Chinese and US firms. China's economy is expected to continue growing stably, but investors fear a full-blown trade dispute could hurt exports and the economy.

images.alt_text: The United States is "opening fire" on the world with its threatened tariffs, the Chinese government warned on Thursday, saying Beijing will respond the instant US measures go into effect as the two locked horns in a bitter trade war.

site_title: Johor menteri besar hopes to raise price of water the state sells to Singapore
summary: Johor's Menteri Besar Osman Sapian hopes to raise the price of raw water sold to Singapore from 3 Malaysian sen per 1,000 gallons to 50 sen, similar to the price sold to neighboring Melaka. The move comes after discussions with Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, who has criticized the 1962 water deal as "too costly" and "ridiculous". The agreement, set to expire in 2061, allows Singapore to draw up to 250 million gallons of raw water per day, while Johor receives treated water in return. A review of the agreement is underway.

site_title: Razer Pay launches in Malaysia
summary: Razer Pay, an e-wallet service, has launched in Malaysia as part of a partnership between Razer Inc and Berjaya Corporation Berhad. The service allows users to transfer funds via peer-to-peer cash transfers and online transactions. Over 6,000 major retail and F&B outlets, including 7-Eleven and Starbucks, will accept Razer Pay. The app is available for download and aims to expand its merchant network to include healthcare and lifestyle services in Malaysia, with plans to roll out in other South-east Asian countries.

site_title: Tesla drivers getting disgruntled in key European market
summary: Tesla drivers in Norway are becoming increasingly disgruntled due to issues with customer service and late deliveries. The Consumer Council in Norway has seen a significant increase in complaints, with Tesla ranking 4th on the list of companies with the most complaints in the first half of the year. A Tesla representative has confirmed they are working to increase their service capacity to address the issue, but the problems persist, highlighting the challenges of maintaining high standards in a large and growing market.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower as US tariff deadline looms
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on July 5, 2018, due to investor jitters ahead of a US deadline to impose tariffs on Chinese imports. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.78% and the Topix index declined 1.01%. The move follows recent US threats to extend tariffs, which has sparked uncertainty in the markets.

site_title: FSL Trust inks 3 loan agreements to refinance outstanding loan
summary: FSL Trust Management has signed three loan agreements to refinance its outstanding syndicated loan of approximately US$109.94 million. The new loan agreements, totaling US$108 million, were secured with Hellenic Bank, Chailease International, and Amsterdam Trade Bank. The trust will pay any unfunded balance from its internal resources. This move follows the trust's recent issuance of convertible bonds, which helped reduce the outstanding loan amount.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: ST Engineering divested 25% of Airbus Helicopters SE Asia Pte Ltd to Airbus Helicopters SAS for S$14 million. The group also streamlined entities in its electronics arm as part of its business review. Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust proposed the sale of 80 Hartley Street in New South Wales for A$90.5 million. Analysts tweak their estimates for ST Engineering, maintaining a buy rating, and for Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust, targeting a price of S$1.20. Both companies have strong order books and diversified operations.

site_title: Rescuers ponder how to extract boys from flooded Thai cave as more rain due
summary: Rescuers in Thailand are struggling to decide on an extraction plan for 12 boys and their soccer coach trapped in a flooded cave complex. Found on Monday, the group is in good health but must be extracted through flooded tunnels. Multiple kilometers of water pose a significant challenge, and no clear solution has been determined. The rescue operation, which began on June 23, has been ongoing for nine days. The boys are being kept in a safe area while divers assess the best route for their exit. A decision on the extraction plan is expected soon.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes on Thursday afternoon at 3,247.25, up 0.1% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading at 3,247.25, up 0.1% on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index gaining 2.36 points. About 933 million shares changed hands, with losers outnumbering gainers 146 to 126. DBS was down 0.8%, while Singtel rose 1.3%. The market benchmark was up 0.45 point from its mid-day close.

site_title: Jefferies Asia CEO Michael Alexander leaves after eight years
summary: Jefferies Asia CEO Michael Alexander has left the company after eight years to pursue other opportunities. He will remain as an adviser to Jefferies in the region. Alexander's responsibilities will be assumed by Jeff Hutchins, head of Asia sales and trading, and Nilesh Jasani, head of Asia research, who also co-head the firm's equities business in Asia.

site_title: Financials lead Australian shares higher as investors hunt for bargains; NZ up
summary: Australian shares rose 0.5% on Thursday, led by financials, as investors sought bargains in the US market's absence. The S&P/ASX 200 index gained 32.1 points to close at 6,215.5, its highest close in two weeks. Financials accounted for over half the gains, with the main financial index climbing 1%. The benchmark fell 0.4% on Wednesday.

site_title: Gold holds steady amid softer dollar ahead of Fed minutes
summary: Gold prices held steady at US$1,255.59 an ounce, unaffected by a weaker dollar, ahead of the US Federal Reserve's June policy meeting minutes. The metal traded in a narrow range, influenced by anticipation of further rate hikes and escalating trade tensions. Investors await the Fed minutes and Friday's non-farm payrolls data for cues on monetary policy.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won tumble before tariff deadline in US-China trade row
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index and won plummeted ahead of a US deadline for tariffs on Chinese imports, with the Kospi down 7.91 points or 0.35% at 2,257.55. The won fell 0.37% weaker than its previous close, and bond yields slid. This marks the Kospi's lowest close since May 2017, with the won also weakening against the US dollar. The decline is attributed to concerns over the US-China trade row, with the US dollar rising 4.87% against the won this year.

site_title: Asia: Markets slip ahead of US-China tariff deadline
summary: Asian stocks declined ahead of a US-China tariff deadline, with Hong Kong shares down 0.2% and Shanghai losing 0.1%. The US is set to impose tariffs on over $34 billion in Chinese imports, while China vows to retaliate with its own tariffs. Fears over a trade war between the world's top two economies are growing, with investors warning of a global mess and huge hit to global growth.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rise as autos bounce on report of tariff talks
summary: European shares rose 0.2% as the auto sector surged on reports of US-Europe tariff talks. The Stoxx Europe 600 Index gained ground ahead of Federal Reserve minutes and US employment numbers. Glencore Plc rose 2.5% after announcing a share buyback, while a gauge for automakers gained 2.4% after the US Ambassador to Germany reportedly discussed car tariffs with German automakers. The US is set to impose tariffs on $34 billion of Chinese goods on Friday.

site_title: Najib's stepson Riza Aziz grilled for third day in 1MDB corruption probe
summary: Malaysian Anti-Corruption Commission (MACC) grilled Najib's stepson Riza Aziz for the third consecutive day over alleged misuse of funds from state fund 1Malaysia Development Bhd to finance Hollywood films. Riza, co-founder of Red Granite Pictures, is accused of using over $100 million from 1MDB to finance movies "The Wolf of Wall Street", "Dumb and Dumber To", and "Daddy's Home". He claims to have never knowingly used stolen funds, but faces US government's civil asset forfeiture action seeking to seize assets, including luxury real estate.

images.alt_text: Mr Riza Aziz, the stepson of former premier Najib Razak, is back at the Malaysian Anti-Corruption Commission (MACC) to be questioned for the third consecutive day.

site_title: South Korea may force sale of 15 trillion won in Samsung shares
summary: South Korea's lawmakers are pushing a bill that would restrict chaebol families' control over business empires, including Samsung Electronics. The bill aims to ban insurance firms from holding a stake of over 3% in an affiliate, potentially forcing Samsung Life Insurance Co. to sell its 23 trillion won stake in Samsung Electronics. The move could weaken Lee Kun-hee's family's influence over the company, which has seen a 9% decline in its share price this year due to sluggish smartphone sales and a China investigation.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks flat at open on Thursday
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened flat on Thursday, July 5, 2018, due to Wall Street's closure for a public holiday. The Hang Seng Index lost 0.1% to 28,214.26, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also edged down. The move comes ahead of US President Donald Trump's new tariffs on Chinese imports.

site_title: Trump trade war to become reality as China tariffs hit
summary: US tariffs on $50 billion in Chinese goods are set to take effect on Friday, with China announcing retaliatory measures. The tariffs, part of a trade war, target a broad spectrum of goods, including passenger vehicles, aircraft parts, and computer hard drives. China will hit back with tariffs on $30 billion in US goods, including vehicles and agricultural products. The move is expected to raise prices, disrupt global supply chains, and threaten US jobs, with economists warning of potential economic damage.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article content:

Singapore's watchdog has ruled that a Grab-Uber deal is anti-competitive, leading to a substantial lessening of competition in point-to-point transport services. Mapletree Logistics Trust is set to acquire HNA's Singapore warehouses for S$778.3 million. Meanwhile, HDB resale prices dipped 0.3% in June, falling 1.9% from the same month last year. Global markets are reacting to various news: Vietnam is surprised by a US tariff announcement, while the Asian garment industry braces for higher US tariffs. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, and Citigroup sets a mid-2026 target for the MSCI global equity index.

site_title: Some ECB members see end-2019 rate hike as too late
summary: Some European Central Bank (ECB) policy makers believe the interest-rate hike in December 2019 may be too late, according to people familiar with the matter. The ECB is considering a move in September or October, with investors now pricing in a 10 basis points hike to the deposit rate in December. This timing matters as it sets the tone for the ECB's exit from monetary stimulus. The September meeting is also President Mario Draghi's last opportunity to cap his tenure with a rate hike before his term ends on October 31.

site_title: Britain's May proposes new customs plan to divided government
summary: Britain's Prime Minister Theresa May proposes a new customs plan, known as the "facilitated customs arrangement," to ease trade and offer more freedom to set tariffs after Brexit. The plan mirrors EU rules, uses technology to determine tariffs, and allows Britain to set its own tariffs. However, Brexit minister David Davis calls the plan "unworkable," and EU officials have expressed skepticism, leaving the government facing a divided response. The plan aims to secure an agreement to push on with Brexit talks, which are stalled and could cost the country tens of thousands of jobs if no deal is reached.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Theresa May will propose on Friday a new plan to ease trade and offer Britain more freedom to set tariffs after Brexit, a last-ditch attempt to unite her divided government on plans to leave the European Union.

site_title: Xiaomi call warrants to start trading on SGX on July 9
summary: Xiaomi has issued three new call warrants to start trading on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) on July 9, alongside its Hong Kong IPO. The warrants, issued by Macquarie Bank, track Xiaomi shares and have strike prices of HK$20, $24, and $30 with an expiry date of February 4, 2019. Trading hours will follow Hong Kong's from 9:30am to 4pm with a break from 12-1pm.

site_title: Oil falls as Trump urges Opec to cut prices; potential China duty on US crude looms
summary: US President Donald Trump urged Opec to cut oil prices, leading to a 0.7% drop in Brent crude futures to $77.68 per barrel. The move comes as a potential China duty on US crude looms, with China warning it could introduce duties on US crude imports at an unspecified date. Recent price rises have been fueled by Opec-Russia output cuts and US sanctions on Iran. Goldman Sachs warns that supply threats could lead to a sharp rise in prices and global economic growth.

site_title: Singapore 2018 growth holding steady despite rising trade friction: MAS chief
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to expand at 2.5-3.5% in 2018, unchanged from the previous forecast, despite rising protectionism risks. MAS chief Ravi Menon noted that global trade conflicts, particularly between the US and China, could pose spillover effects on Singapore's economy. However, Menon emphasized that Asian economies are relatively stronger to absorb financial shocks, with larger foreign reserves and more robust financial regulatory frameworks. The MAS chief warned that inflation and protectionism pose "tail risks" to global growth, but overall, the global economy is still in good shape.

site_title: Serial System CEO 'appears to be a person under investigation' in Taiwan
summary: Serial System CEO Derek Goh Bak Heng appears to be under investigation by Taiwanese authorities, following a call for assistance in June. The investigation concerns Bull Will Co Ltd, a Taiwanese company in which Serial System owns a 19.02% stake. The company made this announcement in a filing with the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Thursday; STI down 0.07% to 3,242.64
summary: Singapore shares opened nearly flat on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) easing 2.25 points to 3,242.64. The STI saw 35.6 million shares worth S$49.3 million change hands, with UOL Group, ComfortDelGro, and Singapore Press Holdings being among the gainers.

site_title: Provisional liquidators appointed for bike-sharing firm oBike
summary: Provisional liquidators from FTI Consulting have been appointed to handle the winding up of bike-sharing firm oBike. The liquidators, Joshua James Taylor and Yit Chee Wah, will work to collect and dispose of oBike's 70,000 bicycles. Users who made deposits of up to S$49 may receive refunds, with the liquidators liaising with oBike's director and stakeholders to determine the possibility of refunds. The deposits, totaling S$6.3 million, were initially used to fund oBike's operations, prompting criticism from the Consumers Association of Singapore.

site_title: Malaysia puts major Belt and Road rail project construction on hold
summary: Malaysia has suspended construction of the US$20 billion East Coast Railway Link project, a major part of China's Belt and Road initiative. The project's owner, Malaysia Rail Link Sdn Bhd, has instructed its main Chinese contractor to halt work, citing "national interest" reasons. Finance Minister Lim Guan Eng plans to visit China to renegotiate the project's terms, aiming for a drastic cost reduction. The suspension raises uncertainty about the project's future and comes amid Malaysia's efforts to review major projects and cut national debt.

site_title: Goldman Sachs says maintains bullish view on commodities
summary: Goldman Sachs maintains a bullish view on commodities due to strong demand growth, supply disruptions, and depleting inventory levels in energy and metals markets. The bank expects a 10% return on the S&P/Goldman Sachs Commodity Index (GSCI) in the next 12 months. It believes concerns over weak demand in emerging markets, a trade war, and Opec's exit from supply cuts have been "oversold." The bank expects the US dollar to weaken and stable demand in China to support metals demand in the second half of the year, despite potential supply shocks in oil markets.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Mapletree Logistics Trust, Alliance Mineral Assets, GP Industries, Koyo International
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust plans to acquire five modern logistics properties in Singapore for S$778.3 million. Alliance Mineral Assets' substantial shareholder Burwill Commodity cut its planned investment in the Lithium miner, taking only 13 million new shares. GP Industries sold land and buildings in China for S$54.8 million, while Koyo International won a S$5.2 million contract from the Housing & Development Board for 36 months.

site_title: Airbus CEO says expects results from CSeries deal in time for Farnborough
summary: Airbus CEO Tom Enders expects to see results from the company's new majority stake in Bombardier's CSeries jetliner program within weeks, around the time of the Farnborough Air Show. He stated he is "convinced" to see first results in the next couple of weeks, potentially including CSeries orders, which could be announced at the Farnborough event starting July 16.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open flat on investor jitters over US-China trade row
summary: Tokyo stocks opened flat on investor jitters ahead of a US deadline to impose tariffs on Chinese imports, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index edging up 0.01% to 21,718.81. The broader Topix index was down 0.16%. The uncertainty over US-China trade tensions weighed on investor sentiment, causing a flat start to trading.

site_title: Ezion ties up with TSC unit to own and operate liftboats
summary: Ezion Holdings has entered into a joint venture with TSC Group Holdings to jointly own and operate liftboats through Renergy Offshore. The joint venture will see TSC and Ezion owning 51% and 49% of Renergy, respectively. TSC will provide capital for new liftboats, while Ezion will assist in marketing and operations. Ezion's shares rose 1.2% following the announcement, and Renergy's issued and paid-up capital is expected to reach US$4 million.

site_title: Heat wave kills 19 in Canada
summary: A heatwave in Quebec, Canada, has killed at least 19 people in the past week. Twelve of the deceased were reported in Montreal, while five died in the Eastern Townships. The high summer temperatures have scorched eastern Canada, prompting health officials to issue warnings. The cause of death was not specified, but the extreme heat is believed to be a contributing factor.

site_title: Renault and Nissan set two-year target to boost alliance
summary: Renault and Nissan have set a two-year target to decide on a possible merger between the two automakers or find an alternative mechanism to enhance their partnership. The decision must be made before Carlos Ghosn steps down as Renault CEO in 2022. The companies are exploring options such as setting up a holding company to pool resources, citing the need for a solution before the current CEO tenure ends.

site_title: Australian shares rise as investors hunt for bargains; NZ flat
summary: Australian shares rose 0.5% to 6,215.0, driven by financials and telecom stocks, while New Zealand shares remained flat. The "Big Four" banks led gains, with Australia and New Zealand Bank up 1.5%. Telstra and Caltex Australia also rose, driven by a 15-year deal with Woolworths Group. Miners, however, fell due to weakening commodity prices. The telecom sector index rose 1.7%, while miners like Rio Tinto and BHP fell 2.3% and 1.1%, respectively.

site_title: Digital debt collector AsiaCollect raises US$4.5m; investors include SIG Asia, Dymon Asia
summary: AsiaCollect, an AI-driven digital debt collection startup, has raised US$4.5 million in funding led by SIG Asia Investments and Dymon Asia Ventures. The investment will support growth initiatives, including client acquisition and expansion of its collections' infrastructure. AsiaCollect, which was founded in 2016, has managed over US$40 million in assets for financial institutions and digital lenders in Vietnam, Indonesia, and the Philippines. The startup aims to deliver integrated credit management services through its AI-driven platform. Proceeds will also be used to enhance its software-as-a-service solution.

site_title: Europe: Stocks mixed in light trading; euro erases losses
summary: European stocks ended fractionally higher, erasing losses, after a report suggested the European Central Bank might raise interest rates earlier than expected, potentially boosting the euro. Asian shares slipped, with the yuan rebounding but then paring gains, while the pound rose on a UK services sector growth report. The US holiday overshadowed trading, with West Texas crude oil and industrial metals declining. The focus shifts to this week's minutes from the Federal Reserve meeting and jobs numbers.

site_title: Philippine June inflation rate quickens to 5.2%, hits 5-year high
summary: The Philippine inflation rate accelerated to 5.2% in June, the highest in over five years, exceeding economists' forecasts. This marks the fourth consecutive month of faster-than-expected price increases, raising the likelihood of a third interest rate hike this year. The country's average inflation rate for the first half of the year stands at 4.3%.

images.alt_text: Philippine annual inflation rate picked up faster than expected in June to the highest in more than five years due to costlier food and non-alcoholic beverages, according to data released on Thursday, raising chances of a third interest rate hike this year.

site_title: Mapletree Logistics Trust to acquire HNA's Singapore warehouses for S$778.3m
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust is acquiring five modern warehouses in Singapore from CWT International, a subsidiary of debt-laden HNA Group, for S$778.3 million. The acquisition, on a sale-and-leaseback arrangement, will increase Mapletree's total gross floor area by 20% to over 20 million square feet, strengthening its position as a major logistics provider in Singapore. The deal is expected to generate an initial net property income yield of approximately 6.2% and is slated for completion by September, with the manager reviewing various financing options.

site_title: Japan's emperor resumes duties after illness
summary: Japan's 84-year-old Emperor Akihito resumed his official duties after three days of treatment for cerebral anemia, which caused dizziness and nausea. The emperor had previously signalled his desire to step down in 2016 due to age and health concerns, and will be succeeded by his eldest son upon his retirement on April 30, 2019. Akihito's health is closely monitored in Japan, where the status of the emperor is sensitive due to the country's complex history.

site_title: Alliance Mineral shareholder Burwill cuts planned investment, deal underwriter has to mop up
summary: Alliance Mineral Assets' shareholder Burwill Commodity cut its planned investment in the lithium miner by 10.9 million shares, taking only 13 million shares of a proposed 23.9-million-share placement at S$0.33 per share. The company's underwriter, Canaccord Genuity, had to mop up 7.6 million unsubscribed shares. The S$0.34 per share placement price represents an 8.7% discount to Alliance Mineral's volume-weighted average price. Net proceeds will be allocated 43% to capital expenditure and 43% to working capital for the Bald Hill Lithium and Tantalum Project.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 1.90 points to 1,690.35. The index saw a gain of 93 to 33 gainer-to-loser ratio, and 50.91 million lots were traded worth RM18.0 million.

site_title: SingPost inks logistics and warehousing master contract with Specialized Bicycle
summary: SingPost has secured a three-year logistics and warehousing contract with Specialized Bicycle Components, shifting its regional operations from Hong Kong to Tampines Logistics Park in Singapore. SingPost will handle warehousing, sea freight, and last-mile deliveries for bicycles and equipment in Singapore and Malaysia, enhancing access to Specialized products for cyclists in the region.

images.alt_text: SingPost has inked a three-year logistics and warehousing contract with premium global bicycle brand, Specialized Bicycle Components.

site_title: HDB resale prices dip 0.3% in June from May: SRX
summary: RESALE prices of Housing Board flats in Singapore fell 0.3% in June from May, according to SRX Property. This marks a 1.9% decline from the same month last year and a 13.3% decrease since the peak in April 2013. The decline was relatively similar for mature and non-mature flats, at 0.2% and 0.4% respectively.

site_title: China draws up new measures to boost job creation: China Daily
summary: China is introducing new measures to boost job creation, aiming to address "uncertainties" in employment. Premier Li Keqiang stated that job creation is crucial for wealth creation and social stability. The country will focus on finding work for college graduates, veterans, and laid-off workers, as well as providing vocational training. The new measures will reduce labor costs, ease corporate burdens, and support flexible employment types. China has already created a record 6.13 million new jobs in the first five months of the year, up 140,000 from the previous year.

site_title: Major currencies in suspense before Sino-US tariff deadline, yuan steady
summary: Major currencies, including the US dollar, euro, and yen, are on high alert ahead of a July 6 deadline for the US to impose tariffs on Chinese imports. The yuan has held steady despite a recent tumble, with the People's Bank of China intervening to stem its decline. Investors are bracing for a full-scale Sino-US trade war, which could lead to increased volatility in the markets. Implied volatility in dollar/yuan options has reached a five-month high, while the yuan remains firm despite concerns about China's economic slowdown and massive capital outflows in 2016.

site_title: Brazil plane-maker Embraer sees shares soar amid talk of deal with Boeing
summary: Brazilian aircraft manufacturer Embraer's shares rose 4.77% on Wednesday after speculation of a deal with Boeing. The proposed tie-up would create a new company, with Boeing holding an 80% stake and Embraer 20%, allowing Boeing to compete in the medium-range aircraft market. The agreement would leave Embraer in control of its military activities. The deal is expected to be announced in the coming days, with negotiations confirmed to be in "advanced stages" between the two companies.

site_title: NZ Court of Appeal rules Megaupload founder Kim Dotcom can be extradited to US
summary: The New Zealand Court of Appeal ruled that internet entrepreneur Kim Dotcom can be extradited to the US to face racketeering and copyright charges. US authorities claim Dotcom and co-accused Megaupload executives generated $175 million by sharing copyrighted material, costing film studios and record companies over $500 million. Dotcom's lawyer plans to appeal the decision to the Supreme Court.

site_title: Canada's Enbridge sells US$3.1b of gas assets
summary: Canada's Enbridge sells US$3.1 billion of gas assets to investment fund Brookfield Infrastructure for C$4.1 billion. The sale includes 19 sites in British Columbia and Alberta with a capacity of 3.3 billion cubic feet of gas per day and 3,550km of pipeline. The deal must be approved by provincial authorities and the federal government, expected to happen in about a year. Brookfield Infrastructure sees the infrastructure as strategically positioned to connect high-demand markets in the US and western Canada.

site_title: China's Jiangsu launches 'green loans' to fund pollution fight
summary: China's Jiangsu province has launched an 8 billion yuan 'green loans' fund to promote environmentally friendly projects and fight pollution. The fund, which includes 400 million yuan in initial financing, will help finance projects that reduce pollution and promote green development. The loans must be paid back within five years, with interest rates determined by the "environmental credit rating" of the enterprise involved. This move follows China's State Council's promise to establish a state "green development fund" and encourage the development of green financing.

site_title: Facebook not the only one that needs examination, regulation
summary: Facebook's data collection and sharing practices are not unique, and the company's scrutiny is warranted. The tech industry's widespread partnerships with data brokers and third-party applications also raise concerns about individual privacy. Google, Apple, and other tech giants must be held accountable for their data-sharing practices, particularly with foreign companies with national security implications. The industry must prioritize humanity over profits and undergo holistic examination and regulation to protect users' sensitive personal data.

site_title: Equity bulls abandoning HK as China turmoil mounts
summary: Hong Kong's stock market has plummeted, with the Hang Seng Index falling 1.1% on its second day of losses, as China's economy slows and the yuan weakens. Valuations have cratered, and earnings estimates have been slashed, with forecasters predicting a decline in the second half of 2018. International investors have withdrawn nearly $4 billion from Hong Kong funds, and a glut of initial public offerings threatens to undermine existing shares. Despite some strategists predicting a rebound in the second half, many have tempered their projections, citing a combination of factors including yuan weakness, trade uncertainty, and tightening liquidity in China.

site_title: IMF urges NZ govt to reconsider ban on foreign home buyers
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has urged the New Zealand government to reconsider its plan to ban foreign buyers of residential property, warning it could discourage foreign direct investment needed to build new homes. The IMF believes other policies, such as tax incentives and the "Kiwibuild" programme, are sufficient to address the housing shortage. The government's ban aims to curb soaring housing prices and reduce homelessness, but the IMF says it may not improve affordability and could harm the economy.

site_title: Woolworths Group enters 15-year fuel supply deal with Caltex Australia
summary: Woolworths Group Ltd, Australia's largest supermarket operator, has entered a 15-year fuel supply deal with Caltex Australia Ltd. The deal also includes a wholesale food supply to over 700 existing Caltex convenience sites. This comes after Woolworths cancelled a A$1.8 billion sale of its petrol stations to BP Plc due to antitrust regulator blockage.

site_title: All of a flutter: Chinese bet big on World Cup
summary: Chinese gamblers have placed massive bets on the World Cup, with 28.6 billion yuan wagered in the first three weeks, exceeding the total from the 2014 tournament. Despite China not qualifying for the World Cup, betting shops have seen a surge in enthusiasm, with many gamblers viewing the tournament as a chance to make money. Officially sanctioned shops have reported significant revenue, while underground betting networks are also believed to be involved. The government remains vigilant, closing down unauthorized betting apps, but the World Cup has brought out a new wave of betting enthusiasm among Chinese fans.

site_title: Novichok nerve agent identified in more UK poisonings
summary: Two Britons in their 40s, exposed to the same nerve agent as former Russian spy Sergei Skripal, are in critical condition in southern England. The nerve agent, identified as Novichok, was found at the scene of the March 4 attack on Skripal and his daughter Yulia in Salisbury. The investigation team is working to determine how the two individuals came into contact with the agent, with police prioritizing the case.

images.alt_text: The pair, a man and woman in their 40s, are in critical condition after coming into contact with the substance just miles from the site of the March 4 attack on Mr Sergei Skripal and his daughter Yulia in Salisbury.

site_title: Trump ups pressure on Opec to boost supply as oil holds gains
summary: US President Donald Trump tweeted that Opec is "doing little to help" reduce gasoline costs, calling for a "two-way street" to lower prices. Despite Saudi pledges to boost oil output, oil prices held near three-year highs. Futures gained 0.3% after Trump's tweet, extending a 15% rally since early June. Opec had agreed to increase output by 1 million barrels a day, but Trump's comments raised concerns about the effectiveness of these efforts.

site_title: Loh Lik Peng sells Wanderlust Hotel
summary: Wanderlust Hotel in Singapore's Little India Conservation Area is being sold to 8M Real Estate for S$37 million. The freehold property, with a built-up area of 15,000-16,000 sq ft, is changing hands after being linked to Loh Lik Peng, founder of Unlisted Collection. The buyer is a Singapore-based privately-held property investment company.

site_title: Horizon Towers back on collective sale market with S$1.1b reserve price
summary: Horizon Towers, a 211-unit development in Singapore's prime district 9, is back on the collective sale market with a reserve price of S$1.1 billion. The sale comes 10 years after a previous attempt fell apart due to a dispute among owners. Owners could receive between S$4.7 million and $5.2 million for apartments and between S$9.2 million and $10 million for penthouses. The sale could be Singapore's first billion-dollar collective sale if successful, and it follows other large-scale developments in the area.

site_title: Saudi plans first change in Asia crude oil price formula in decades, to use DME Oman
summary: Saudi Aramco plans to change its long-term crude oil sales price formula to Asia starting from October, marking the first change in decades. The new formula will use the average monthly prices of Oman crude futures traded on the Dubai Mercantile Exchange (DME) and the average cash price for Dubai, instead of the current average of Oman and Dubai prices. The change aims to improve liquidity for Oman futures trading and will affect over 12 million barrels per day of crude bound for Asia.

site_title: Brent crude firm on drop in US oil inventories, Iran threat
summary: Brent crude oil rose 5 cents to $77.81 a barrel after an Iranian Revolutionary Guards commander threatened to prevent regional crude exports if US sanctions on Iranian oil sales were implemented. This came as US crude inventories dropped for the second week due to a Canadian facility outage. US crude futures fell 24 cents to $73.90 a barrel, despite earlier gains of 1.2%. The price increase was driven by concerns over potential US-Iran tensions and the impact on global oil supplies.

site_title: Scandal-hit US environment chief could face axe
summary: US President Donald Trump appears close to firing Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) chief Scott Pruitt amid growing scandals over his spending and behavior. Pruitt has been the subject of multiple investigations and has been accused of using his position to enrich himself and punish subordinates who opposed him. The accusations include excessive air travel, private security, and personal expenses, as well as allegations of favoritism towards the fossil fuel industry. Trump has expressed "not happiness" with Pruitt's actions, but has yet to take decisive action, sparking speculation about the EPA chief's future.

images.alt_text: Facing ever-growing scandals over the spending and behavior of his environment agency chief, Scott Pruitt, President Donald Trump appears close to firing the man he appointed to dismantle Barack Obama's green legacy.

site_title: Japan online fashion store unveils e-bodysuit to give the perfect fit
summary: Japan's largest e-commerce company, Start Today Co, has launched a new e-bodysuit called Zozosuit, which measures users' body proportions with a smartphone camera. The company plans to offer made-to-fit clothing, including T-shirts, jeans, and business suits, through its private label and app. The goal is to provide a perfect fit, solving the online clothing sizing challenge, and expand overseas. The company's billionaire founder, Yusaku Maezawa, aims to quintuple its market capitalization in the next decade.

site_title: Main car COE falls to eight-year-low of $25,000
summary: Singapore's Certificate of Entitlement (COE) prices for mainstream cars plummeted to an eight-year-low of $25,000 in the latest tender, with a premium of $9,110 for cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp. This marks the lowest since March 2010. COE prices for larger vehicles also decreased, with premiums ranging from $8,900 to $8,000. The decrease in COE prices is attributed to a surge in supply and a decline in demand.

site_title: Wage growth 'missing in action', workers dissatisfied: OECD
summary: The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) reports that global wage growth has been "missing in action" since the financial crisis, disproportionately affecting poorer workers and exacerbating income inequality. Real labour incomes of the top one percent of earners have risen faster than those of median full-time workers, leaving many workers dissatisfied with stagnant wages despite rising employment.

site_title: Williams sisters happy as women given centre stage at Wimbledon
summary: Venus Williams expressed her joy over women being given the spotlight at Wimbledon, with five of seven matches on Centre Court and Court One being women's singles. Williams herself beat Romanian qualifier Alexandra Dulgheru to move into the third round, becoming the fifth-five champion at the tournament. The increased focus on women's tennis was seen as a positive step, with Williams stating she was "overjoyed" about the change. The event marked a shift towards more women's tennis on the main showcourts.

site_title: For some Democrats, being anti-Trump may not be enough
summary: US Democrats are divided on how to retake ground lost in 2016 and defeat President Trump in 2020. Some Democrats advocate for a centrist approach, while others are pushing for a radical, progressive agenda. This divide is reminiscent of the 2008 election, when Republican leaders refused to cooperate with President Obama, leading to the rise of the Tea Party movement. The differing strategies may impact the party's chances in the 2020 election.

site_title: Official reserves grew S$8.5b in FY2017/18
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore reported a gain of S$8.5 billion in official foreign reserves for FY2017/18, driven by investment gains of S$22.3 billion and losses from currency translation effects of S$13.8 billion. The total official reserves stood at S$376.5 billion as of March 31. The portfolio is diversified, with investment-grade bonds in advanced economies, primarily denominated in USD, EUR, JPY, and GBP.

site_title: Russian oil faces next challenge after Opec deal
summary: Russian lawmakers will discuss legislation to move the tax burden for oil producers to the point of production, ending years of wrangling. The changes aim to boost economic growth and increase revenue, with tax incentives for petrol output and measures to raise export duties or cap pump prices considered. The tax manoeuvre, part of a wider fiscal overhaul, is expected to take six years to implement and will alter the system of charges relating to crude provision to refineries in Belarus and Kazakhstan.

site_title: Hungary to drop lower VAT rate on new homes
summary: Hungary plans to end a reduced 5% value-added tax rate on new homes at the end of 2019, as previously announced. The measure, which has fueled a housing boom and boosted economic growth, was intended to help families purchase new homes. Finance Minister Mihaly Varga stated that a bubble has emerged in the market and that extending the reduced rate would be counterproductive. The reduced tax rate will remain in place until December 31, 2019, and the government aims to prevent further fueling of the market.

site_title: Najib pleads not guilty to CBT charges
summary: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak pleaded not guilty to charges of abuse of power and criminal breach of trust related to billions of dollars missing from a state fund. Najib, who lost the election just eight weeks prior, was released on bail after a court appearance. The charges stem from an investigation into 1MDB, a state fund that was diverted to his personal accounts. Najib's trial is tentatively set for February 8-18, March 4-8, and March 11-15, totaling 19 days of hearing.

site_title: Power and energy sectors top M&As in H1 in clean energy drive
summary: Global mergers and acquisitions (M&As) in the first half of 2018 reached a historic peak, driven by the clean energy sector. The energy and power sector accounted for 16% of total M&A value, with deals increasing by 62% to $365.7 billion. Utility companies are consolidating to adapt to the shift towards renewable energy and changing business models. Deals include RWE and E.ON's 5.2 billion euro (S$8.3 billion) agreement and China Three Gorges' $10.8 billion bid for EDP.

site_title: Aviva Investors appoints new head of institutional sales for Asia from rival AXA IM
summary: Aviva Investors has appointed Tom Clapham as its new head of institutional sales for Asia, effective immediately. Clapham, who previously held senior roles at AXA Investment Managers, will focus on driving growth in the institutional segment across Asia. He brings over 20 years of industry experience and will report to Scott Callander, head of client solutions in the Asia-Pacific and Middle East. Clapham's appointment is seen as a strategic move to strengthen Aviva Investors' team and expand its outcome-oriented investment solutions for Asian investors.

site_title: ANA cancelling 113 flights to inspect engines
summary: ANA Holdings Inc will cancel 113 domestic flights from July 6-12 to inspect Rolls-Royce Trent 1000 engines for compressor issues that have caused service interruptions globally. The affected engines are used on ANA's Boeing 787 Dreamliner jets. The airline is expanding inspections to include package B engines following Japan's transport ministry instructions. The issue has already led to plane groundings by airlines such as British Airways and Virgin Atlantic.

site_title: Exercise 'creative intelligence' to reap ROI on Big Data
summary: Big Data has become a valuable resource, surpassing oil in worth, with worldwide revenues expected to reach $203 billion by 2020. However, despite its potential, few businesses report tangible ROI or success in making Big Data profitable. The key to unlocking its value lies in "Creative Intelligence," the intersection of human and machine intelligence, which enables the use of data to create valuable insights and facilitate intelligent decision-making. This approach involves combining analytical thinking with instinct and empathy, and is crucial for businesses to reap the benefits of Big Data.

site_title: Teaching kids to be savvy with money
summary: Prudential Singapore's Prudence Foundation has partnered with Cartoon Network and Junior Achievement to develop a curriculum-based financial literacy programme for children aged 7-12, called Cha-Ching. The programme aims to teach children essential money management skills, such as earning, spending, saving, and donating. Since its launch in 2011, the programme has reached over 3,000 students in Singapore, with plans to expand further. The initiative is part of Prudential's corporate social responsibility efforts, driven by employee interest in giving back to society.

site_title: Seletar's new passenger terminal to open in Dec
summary: A new S$80 million passenger terminal at Seletar Airport in Singapore is set to open in December, designed to handle up to 700,000 passengers a year. The terminal will free up capacity at Changi Airport for larger planes and accommodate private and business jet traffic. Scheduled turboprop flights will be moved to Seletar, reducing airport fees for passengers. The opening is expected to attract more airlines and increase air travel to destinations in Peninsular Malaysia and Sumatra.

site_title: Top guns primed for quarter showdowns
summary: England secured its spot in the World Cup quarter-finals with a dramatic penalty shootout victory over Colombia, becoming the eighth team to qualify. England will face Sweden in the quarter-finals, while Brazil and France will face Belgium and Uruguay, respectively. England's Gareth Southgate expressed his desire to continue his team's run, despite a poor record against Sweden. The top half of the draw, featuring Brazil and France, is considered the more likely source of the tournament winner.

site_title: Australia flags debt trap, tightens credit rules
summary: Australia's Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) plans to tighten credit rules to prevent consumers from getting trapped in credit card debt. The review found 18.5% of consumers struggle with credit card debt, with credit cards presenting a debt trap for over one in six consumers. ASIC aims to set credit limits at no higher than what customers can afford to repay in three years. This move is intended to protect consumers from debt and promote financial stability.

site_title: STI closes 0.3% up, bucking Asian trend
